One of the least studied molluscan classes, with most details remaining unknown.

title: Phylum: Nemertea (Nemerteans, or ribbon worms)
text:
Phylum: Nemertea (Nemerteans, or ribbon worms)
Ribbon worms are mostly benthic animals, they inhabit sand, mud, gravel, crevices beneath stones, and seaweeds in intertidal and shallow subtidal zones. Some species are planktonic, symbiotic with other marine invertebrates, or found in deep waters.
Collection methodology
Hand-picking, snorkel, SCUBA, submersible, remotely operated vehicle (ROV), dredges, benthic (beam, otter) trawls and sledges.
Sample processing
Animals should be anesthetised by adding chloral hydrate or magnesium sulfate crystals to their water. The anesthetisation process typically takes 6–12 hours. Once insensitive, all nemerteans can be killed and fixed in 30–50% alcohol, then stored in 3–5% formalin or 70–90% alcohol. Formalin should not be used for fixing or preserving, as it dissolves the stylets on their proboscis.
Remarks
For detailed histological investigations, more advanced fixation techniques are required. Bouin’s solution and saturated mercuric chloride solution have proven effective. After a 12-hour fixation period, specimens should be transferred to 70% iodised alcohol for a few hours before being stored in 70% alcohol.

title: Phylum: Annelida
text:
Phylum: Annelida
Annelids represent a highly diverse and ecologically significant phylum within marine ecosystems, with two primary classes found in marine environments: Polychaeta and Clitellata (which includes Oligochaeta and Hirudinea). Polychaetes are particularly abundant across a wide range of marine habitats, from intertidal zones to the deep sea. These segmented worms possess parapodia, paired lateral appendages used for locomotion and respiration, and display a remarkable variety of lifestyles. Some species are errant, actively moving across the seabed, while others are sedentary, constructing protective tubes from sand, mucus, or calcium carbonate. Polychaetes encompass both predatory and suspension-feeding forms, playing a crucial role in benthic ecosystems. Notable groups include nereids (ragworms), spionids, and terebellids (spaghetti worms). Certain deep-sea species, such as those found near hydrothermal vents, rely on chemosynthetic bacteria for energy production. Clitellates in marine environments include marine oligochaetes and leeches (Hirudinea), though they are more prevalent in freshwater and terrestrial systems. Marine oligochaetes are small, inconspicuous annelids inhabiting sediments, where they contribute to nutrient cycling and organic matter breakdown. Leeches, in contrast, are often ectoparasitic or predatory, attaching to hosts such as fish, molluscs, and marine mammals. Unlike polychaetes, clitellates lack parapodia and typically bear fewer chaetae.
The class Sipuncula, commonly known as peanut worms, are a group of unsegmented marine worms characterised by their soft, cylindrical bodies and retractable anterior portion called the introvert. These worms typically range in length from a few centimetres to over 50 centimetres. They are found in a variety of marine environments, including sandy or muddy substrates, coral crevices, and empty shells. The introvert, which can be extended and withdrawn, bears a mouth and often a crown of tentacles used for feeding on detritus and organic particles. Despite their simple appearance, sipunculans possess a coelomic body cavity and a U-shaped gut, with the anus located near the front of the body. Although once considered a separate phylum, recent molecular studies often place them within Annelida, indicating a closer evolutionary relationship to segmented worms.
Collection Methodology
Polychaetes and other marine annelids vary depending on habitat and species behaviour. Planktonic polychaetes using plankton nets and multiple plankton samplers (MPS). Benthic species hand-picking, sediment excavation using scoops, SCUBA diving, snorkelling, remotely operated vehicles (ROVs) and submersibles, dredges, benthic trawls (beam or otter), epibenthic sledges, and sediment coring, grab samplers or box corer.
Sample Processing and Preservation
Live polychaetes require delicate handling to maintain morphological and anatomical features. Relaxation is typically achieved using magnesium chloride (MgCl₂) solutions, which prevent muscular contractions that could obscure key taxonomic features. Fixation protocols depend on the intended analysis: formalin (5–10%) is used for anatomical studies, while ethanol (95%) is the preferred preservative for genetic analyses. Delicate species may undergo initial fixation in Bouin’s solution before transfer to ethanol for long-term preservation. Soft tissues are best preserved in ethanol, whereas protective tubes should be kept dry.
For marine oligochaetes, live specimens should be kept in sediment with seawater for behavioural observations before preservation. Leeches should be maintained in aerated seawater before fixation. Relaxation methods include the use of MgCl₂ or cold anaesthesia to prevent contraction. As with polychaetes, formalin fixation is used for anatomical studies, while ethanol (95%) is the standard for molecular research. Larger specimens should be dissected before preservation to ensure thorough penetration of fixative solutions.
Remarks
Photography is essential for documenting live polychaetes, as many diagnostic features, including colouration and subtle morphological structures, fade after preservation. Key taxonomic characteristics include parapodia structure, chaetal morphology, and prostomial features (such as antennae, palps, and cirri). Tube-dwelling species often possess intricate feeding structures (e.g., radials) that should be photographed before fixation. Polychaetes play a vital role in marine ecosystems by bioturbating sediments, influencing nutrient cycling, and serving as prey for fish and invertebrates.
Similarly, marine oligochaetes and leeches require careful photographic documentation. In oligochaetes, features such as chaetal arrangement are often challenging to assess post-fixation. For leeches, distinguishing characteristics include oral and caudal suckers, eye arrangements, and external colouration patterns. Parasitic species should be documented with details of their host associations, and molecular sequencing can assist in identifying cryptic species. Although relatively understudied in marine systems, marine oligochaetes and leeches make significant contributions to benthic community structure, trophic interactions, and sediment biogeochemistry.

title: Phylum: Phoronida
text:
Phylum: Phoronida
Phoronida, commonly known as phoronids or horseshoe worms,are tube-dwelling, worm-like animals characterised by their lophophore, a crown of ciliated tentacles used for filter feeding. Phoronids secrete chitinous tubes, which they use for protection and attachment to substrates such as rocks, shells, or buried sediments. They are found in shallow waters worldwide, often in sandy or muddy environments.
Collection methodology
Hand picking, SCUBA diving, snorkelling, remotely operated vehicles (ROVs) and submersibles, dredges, benthic trawls (beam or otter), epibenthic sledges, and sediment coring, grab samplers or box corer,
Sample processing
Live phoronids are require delicate handling to maintain morphological and anatomical features. Relaxation is typically achieved using magnesium chloride (MgCl₂) solutions, which prevent muscular contractions that could obscure key taxonomic features. Fixation protocols depend on the intended analysis: formalin (5–10%) is used for anatomical studies, while ethanol (95%) is the preferred preservative for genetic analyses. Delicate species may undergo initial fixation in Bouin’s solution before transfer to ethanol for long-term preservation. Soft tissues are best preserved in ethanol, whereas protective tubes should be kept dry.
Remarks
Photography is essential for documenting live phoronids, as many diagnostic features, including colouration and subtle morphological structures, fade after preservation; so live animals should be photographed before fixation.

title: Phylum: Bryozoa (moss animals)
text:
Phylum: Bryozoa (moss animals)
Bryozoans are sessile, colonial invertebrates that inhabit a range of habitats, from intertidal zones to deep-sea environments. Commonly colonise hard substrates such as shells, coral reefs, seaweed, and even artificial structures like docks and ship hulls. They can also form encrusting or branching colonies in sediment-rich areas. Bryozoans exhibit highly variable morphology, often leading to misidentification as hydroids, corals, colonial ascidians, or turfing seaweeds.
Collection methodology
Hand-picking, snorkel, SCUBA, submersible, remotely operated vehicle (ROV), dredges, benthic (beam, otter) trawls and sledges.
Sample processing
Living animal colonies are anesthetised by adding a 1% solution of stovaine or eucaine to the water, drop by drop, with intervals of 10–15 minutes between the first two doses and 5 minutes between subsequent doses. Alternatively, anesthetisation can be achieved through the slow addition of menthol crystals or Epsom salts. Once the tentacle crowns no longer respond to touch, the colonies can be killed by rapidly adding commercial formalin or Bouin’s fluid. The specimens should then be fixed in Bouin’s fluid, thoroughly washed, and preserved in 70–90% alcohol.
Remarks
Bryozoan larvae should be transferred to a dish with a pipette, then anesthetised and killed using corrosive sublimate or Bouin’s fluid. The solution should be pipetted off, the larvae rinsed with water and preserved in 70–90% alcohol. Several natural compounds isolated from bryozoans have shown potential for pharmacological applications, with bryostatins being among the earliest and most studied. Known for their potent biological activities, bryostatins are particularly notable in cancer research. They modulate protein kinase C (PKC), a key player in cell signal transduction, influencing processes such as cell growth, differentiation, and survival.

title: Phylum: Brachiopoda (lamp shells)
text:
Phylum: Brachiopoda (lamp shells)
Brachiopods resemble bivalve molluscs due to their calcareous shell made of two valves, but this resemblance is superficial. In brachiopods, the two valves are positioned dorsally and ventrally relative to the enclosed body, whereas in bivalve molluscs, the valves are lateral. In most brachiopod species, the ventral valve is larger than the dorsal, and in some species, the apex is elongated into a curved, perforated beak. Brachiopods have a worldwide distribution intertidal to abyssal depths, the majority inhabit continental shelves at depths of 200-300 meters.
Collection methodology
Hand-picking, snorkel, SCUBA, submersible, remotely operated vehicle (ROV), dredges, benthic (beam, otter) trawls and sledges.
Sample processing
The animals should be anesthetised by gradually adding small amounts of alcohol to the seawater, ensuring that the total alcohol volume does not exceed 10% of the seawater volume containing the animals. Alternatively, anaesthetics like MS 222 and propylene phenoxetol may also be effective. After anesthetisation, the animals can be fixed and preserved in 70-90% alcohol. However, a small chip of wood should first be placed between the valves of the shell to allow the alcohol to penetrate the soft tissues.
Remark
For histological preparations, the animals should first be anesthetised and then euthanised by gradually replacing the seawater with a 5% formal saline solution, as alcohol can damage the fine structure of the cells.
Phylum: Gastrotricha
They are mostly benthic, living in periphyton or sediment but they have also been found amongst seaweeds.
Collection methodology
Hand-picking, snorkelling, SCUBA.
Sample processing
The living specimens are placed in a drop of water on a microscope slide, which is then inverted for 5-10 seconds over a bottle of osmic acid. Some species contract strongly when fixed and may require prior anaesthesia using MS 222 or propylene phenoxetol, and are then preserved in 70% alcohol or 5% formalin.
Remarks
Gastrotrichs are typically collected using simple washing and sieving techniques. Vegetation can be rinsed with a substantial amount of water, and the washings are then strained through a fine sieve or bolting silk.

title: Phylum: Platyhelminthes (flatworms or tapeworms)
text:
Phylum: Platyhelminthes (flatworms or tapeworms)
Platyhelminthes are found in a wide range of habitats. This diverse group includes free-living species, as well as mostly endoparasitic and ectoparasitic flukes, including monogenetic flukes. Free-living flatworms are the most commonly encountered species in the intertidal zone.
Collection methodology
Isaacs-Kidd Midwater Trawl (IKMT), a dredging and trawling method. Benthic: hand picking, snorkel, SCUBA
Sample processing
Flatworm specimens should then be gently placed into frozen formalin for fixation before being preserved in 70- 90% ethanol. Other worms should generally be relaxed using MgCl2 before fixation. Once relaxed, fix the specimen in formalin and preserve it in 70- 90% ethanol for long-term storage.
Remarks
Photographs are essential, especially for colourful species, as they capture important characteristics that might be lost after sample processing. For DNA work, take a small snippet, such as the posterior end, and fix it in ethanol.
Phylum: Kinorhyncha
The animals are all less than 1 mm in length. They are benthic and are typically found in muddy substrates or among algae. They have been found in the intertidal zone to depths of several thousand meters.
Collection methodology
Hand-picking, snorkel, SCUBA, dredges, and grabs (Kinorhyncha are typically collected using simple washing, sieving, and flotation techniques. Species living on algae can be collected by rinsing the plant material with a substantial amount of seawater and filtering the washings through a fine-mesh sieve or bolting silk. Similarly, those inhabiting mud and slime can be collected by washing the upper layers of the substrate through a fine sieve. When large amounts of organic and/or inorganic debris accumulate on the sieve, further separation can be achieved using flotation methods.
Sample processing
Kinorhyncha can be fixed and stored in formalin solutions 10% formalin for fixation and 2-5% formalin for storage. It is beneficial to kill the animals with their head region fully extended. This can typically be achieved by fixing the animals on a microscope slide while applying slight pressure to the cover glass, or by briefly placing them in distilled water before transferring them to the fixative.
Remarks
While often confused with copepod crustaceans, they differ primarily in the absence of paired appendages.

title: Phylum: Priapulida (Penis worms)
text:
Phylum: Priapulida (Penis worms)
These animals are typically found in muddy or sandy substrates in the shallow marine environment, but can also be found at greater depths.
Collection methodology
Hand-picking, snorkeling, SCUBA, dredges and grabs (Priapulids are often extracted from sediment using sieving or washing techniques, with the washings passed through a fine-mesh sieve or bolting silk).
Sample processing
Animals should be anaesthetized with a 7% solution of magnesium chloride, which is generally effective; however, larger specimens may take longer to anaesthetize. Once anaesthetised, the animals can be fixed and stored in a 5% formalin solution. Alternatively, the anesthetised specimens can be fixed for about 24 hours in Bouin’s fluid, then placed in 50% alcohol for 1 hour before being transferred to 70% alcohol for long-term storage.
Remarks
Priapulids have a large body cavity and are filled with a variety of cells, including amebocytes and erythrocytes. Formalin preservation will damage these cells.

title: Phylum: Loricifera (jewel animals)
text:
Phylum: Loricifera (jewel animals)
They are tiny animals, measuring about 250 µm in length, that inhabit the interstitial spaces of shelly marine gravel, ranging from intertidal zones to deeper waters.
Collection methodology
Hand-picking, snorkeling, SCUBA, dredges and grabs (extracted from gravel sediment using sieving or washing techniques, with the washings passed through a fine-mesh sieve or bolting silk).
Sample processing
Animals should be anaesthetised with a 7% solution of magnesium chloride, which is generally effective; however, larger specimens may take longer to anaesthetise. Once anaesthetised, the animals can be fixed and stored in a 5% formalin solution. Alternatively, the anesthetised specimens can be fixed for about 24 hours in Bouin’s fluid, then placed in 50% alcohol for 1 hour before being transferred to 70% alcohol for long-term storage.
Remarks
Members of the phylum have been collected from various locations worldwide, yet it remains an understudied group.

title: Phylum: Nematoda (roundworms or eelworms)
text:
Phylum: Nematoda (roundworms or eelworms)
Nematodes vary in size, ranging from as small as 82 μm in free-living marine species to over 8 meters in parasitic nematodes found in the placenta of sperm whales. They inhabit a diverse range of environments, including meiobenthos, soil, and both inside and on host animals and plants.
Collection methodology
Isaacs-Kidd Midwater Trawl (IKMT), Bongo net, Benthic: hand picking, snorkel, SCUBA (However, collection of parasitic nematodes captures the host organism (e.g., fish, mammals, plants) carefully dissected in a sterile environment to isolate the organs or tissues where the nematodes are residing. Free-living species are collected using nets, mud and sand-associated animals are typically obtained through washing and sieving techniques).
Sample processing
Larger free-living nematodes can be killed and fixed by immersing them in either a hot or cold 3-5% formalin solution, or hot 70-90% alcohol. Smaller free-living species can be placed in a drop of water on a microscope slide (or any suitable glass slip) and killed by gently heating the glass over a flame. Once killed, the specimens can then be transferred to a 3-5% formalin solution or 70-90% alcohol for preservation.
Remarks
Different free-living nematode species feed on a wide range of materials, including bacteria, algae, fungi, small animals, faecal matter, dead organisms, and even living tissues. Marine nematodes are crucial and abundant members of the meiobenthic. They play a significant role in decomposition, contribute to nutrient recycling in marine environments, and are sensitive to environmental changes, particularly those caused by pollution.

title: Phylum: Tardigrada
text:
Phylum: Tardigrada
Tardigrades live on interstitial spaces of coarse sediments or as epibenthic organisms on rocks in intertidal and subtidal zones, extending down to deeper depths. They are also associated with algae (e.g., holdfasts) and other invertebrates, such as barnacles and sea cucumbers.
Collection methodology
Corers, dredges and grabs
Sample processing
Narcotisation is not required. Animals can be killed, fixed, and preserved in a 5% formalin solution or 70-80% alcohol.
Remarks
Tardigrades are tiny, eight-legged creatures known for their remarkable ability to survive extreme conditions, enduring periods of up to 30 years without food or water. These arthropod-like animals have four pairs of stumpy legs, each equipped with either four separate claws or two pairs of double claws. Adults typically range in length from about 0.05 to 1.2 mm, with most measuring less than 0.5 mm in length.

title: Phylum: Acanthocephala
text:
Phylum: Acanthocephala
Adult acanthocephalans are parasitic worms that inhabit the digestive tracts of vertebrates, primarily fish, birds, and mammals. Generally, smaller species are found in fish, while larger ones infect avian and mammalian hosts. The immature stages develop in intermediate arthropod hosts, mainly crustaceans, which are consumed by the definitive vertebrate hosts, completing the parasite's life cycle.
Collection methodology
Depending on the host animal.
Sample processing
Freshly collected specimens should be carefully cleaned using a moistened paintbrush, as prolonged soaking in water or salt solutions may cause the worms to swell. For preservation, the material can be fixed in hot 3-5% formalin or hot 70-90% alcohol.
Remarks
Acanthocephalans are a fascinating group of parasites that exhibit complex life cycles and remarkable adaptations for survival within their hosts. Some species of acanthocephalans can cause intestinal damage, malnutrition, and inflammation in their hosts, leading to serious health issues.

title: Phylum: Orthonectida
text:
Phylum: Orthonectida
Orthonectida is a parasitic organism, that infects the internal organs and tissues of various marine invertebrates, including turbellarians, nemerteans, annelids, ophiuroids (brittle stars), as well as gastropods and bivalve molluscs.
Collection methodology
Depending on the host animal.
Sample processing
One of the least studied phyla. Most of the process is unknown.
Remarks
Microscopic examination of histological and cytological details, which is best conducted using living specimens or properly fixed samples. For optimal results, specimens should be preserved either as cover-glass smear preparations from the tissues of freshly killed hosts or as tissue samples intended for sectioning.

title: Phylum: Dicyemida
text:
Phylum: Dicyemida
Dicyemida are microscopic parasites that inhabit the nephridia of cephalopods, such as squids and octopuses.
Collection methodology
Depending on the host animal.
Sample processing
One of the least studied phyla. Most of the process is unknown.
Remarks
Microscopic examination of histological and cytological details, which is best conducted using living specimens or properly fixed samples. For optimal results, specimens should be preserved either as cover-glass smear preparations from the tissues of freshly killed hosts or as tissue samples intended for sectioning.

title: Phylum: Arthropoda
text:
Phylum: Arthropoda
Marine arthropods inhabit a wide range of environments, including mobile, planktonic, and benthic habitats, across all depths. They possess a chitinous, jointed exoskeleton and exhibit specialised body segmentation. Additionally, they have compound eyes and one or two pairs of antennae, which aid in sensory perception and navigation. Horseshoe crabs are ancient marine arthropods that have existed for over 450 million years, predating even the dinosaurs. They primarily inhabit shallow coastal waters and estuaries.
The order Decapoda is a diverse group of crustaceans that includes crabs, lobsters, shrimp, and crayfish. Decapods exhibit a wide range of adaptations that enable them to thrive in diverse habitats.
The order Stomatopoda consists of marine crustaceans commonly known as mantis shrimps. Stomatopods are found in benthic environments, often living in burrows or crevices on the seafloor.
The order Euphausiacea consists of small, shrimp-like crustaceans commonly known as krill. These marine organisms play a crucial role in the oceanic food chain, serving as a primary food source for many large marine animals, including whales, seals, penguins, and fish. Krill are planktonic crustaceans, meaning they drift in ocean currents, though they are also strong swimmers.
The order Copepoda are predominantly planktonic and live in the water column of marine environments. They inhabit a variety of water depths, with most species living in the upper 50 meters of the ocean. However, some copepod species are adapted to deep-sea environments and can live at much greater depths.
Some copepods and isopods are ectoparasites, attaching themselves to the gill filaments, fins, or skin of fish; other copepods are commensals or endoparasites, living within polychaete worms, the intestines of echinoderms, tunicates, and bivalves. Cnidarians, particularly anthozoans, host many species of copepods. Additionally, small commensal crabs, called pea crabs (family Pinnotheridae), inhabit the tubes and burrows of polychaetes, and some species also reside in the mantle cavities of bivalves, snails, sand dollars, and tunicates.
The class Cirripedia (Barnacles) are sessile and attaches to a wide range of solid surfaces in marine environments. They can be found on rocks, shells, coral, floating wood, and even on other aquatic organisms, including sponges, hydrozoans, octocorals, scleractinian corals, crabs, sea snakes, sea turtles, manatees, porpoises, whales, large fish, and ship hulls. The attachment site varies by species, with some, such as acorn barnacles, attaching directly to surfaces, while others, like goose barnacles, attach via a long stalk.
The order Amphipoda is found in a wide range of habitats. Many species are burrowers, living in sediment, sand, or mud, while others construct tubes using materials such as shell fragments and algae. Some species, such as Talitrus, are beach-dwelling and can be found in moist sand beneath driftwood or in damp forest leaf litter, away from the shoreline. Some amphipods, like those inhabiting deeper waters, are found at greater ocean depths, where they may burrow or live among other benthic organisms.
The order Pycnogonida, commonly known as sea spiders, inhabit a wide range of marine environments, from shallow intertidal zones to the deep sea, reaching depths over 6,000 meters. These benthic organisms are typically found crawling on the ocean floor, often associating with marine invertebrates such as sponges, corals, and sea anemones, from which they derive their food. Their slender bodies and long legs enable them to move efficiently across soft sediments and rocky substrates, allowing them to adapt to various underwater habitats worldwide.
Ostracoda (seed shrimp) are small crustaceans with a bivalve-like shell that encloses their entire body. Cumacea (hooded shrimp) are primarily marine crustaceans that live in soft sediments on the ocean floor, from shallow coastal waters to deep-sea habitats. They are often found burrowing in sand and mud, where they feed on organic detritus and microorganisms. They have a distinct body shape, characterised by an enlarged head and a slender abdomen, and are an essential part of the diet of many fish species. Mysida (opossum shrimp) are shrimp-like crustaceans often found in coastal waters, estuaries and deep-sea habitats. Many species form large swarms and are commonly found near the seabed or in open water, where they serve as an essential food source for fish and other marine animals.
Collection methodology
Planktonic crustaceans: Isaacs-Kidd Midwater Trawl (IKMT), bongo net, multiple plankton sampler (MPS), Benthic: hand picking, snorkeling, SCUBA, submersible, remotely operated vehicle (ROV), corer (different type of corers), grab (other type of grabs), dredges, benthic (beam, otter) trawls, sledges, baited traps and pots.
Sample processing
Large arthropods, due to their size and complexity, can be effectively preserved by freezing, followed by fixation and sample processing in ethanol. Freezing helps immobilise and quickly maintain the specimen's integrity by halting decomposition. Once frozen, the arthropod can be fixed using ethanol, which serves to preserve its physical structure, particularly the delicate tissues. However, it is essential to handle these larger specimens with care during the fixation process, as any mishandling or inadequate fixation can result in damage or distortion of the body parts. For smaller arthropods, narcotization methods such as clove oil or tricaine (MS-222), propylene phenoxetol, or similar anaesthetics are commonly used to relax the specimens gently. These substances allow researchers to slow down the organism’s movement and reduce stress, which is crucial for ensuring that delicate features (such as appendages) remain intact during handling. Clove oil and tricaine are popular because they are relatively easy to use and offer a controlled means of relaxing the specimens without causing significant harm.
After narcotisation, it is crucial to fix the arthropods in 70-80% alcohol. This concentration of ethanol is ideal because it preserves the specimens without causing brittleness in the legs, antennae, or other fragile body parts. Ethanol in this range is strong enough to prevent bacterial growth and degradation while maintaining the specimen’s flexibility and overall anatomical structure. Higher concentrations of ethanol may lead to excessive dehydration, causing the specimen to become brittle, which is particularly problematic for the more delicate features of smaller crustaceans. On the other hand, lower concentrations may be insufficient to preserve the specimen properly over time. Animals that are fixed can be maintained in 90% alcohol or a 5-10% formalin solution. For long-term preservation, calcium carbonate (CaCO₃) or borax is commonly used as a buffer to stabilise formalin.
Remarks
For molecular analysis, a tissue sample collected from a leg, pleopod (in shrimp), or abdomen and preserved in concentrated ethanol provides a valuable additional genetic sample. Photographs should be taken of both the dorsal and ventral surfaces of each fresh specimen, ensuring the animal is laid out in a "natural" position in a tray. For crustaceans, capturing freshly killed specimens is ideal, especially when their legs are spread out, as this allows for a clear view of the full body and appendages, highlighting important characteristics such as the shape of the carapace, leg structure, and claw size. The spread legs also help highlight the size and structure of the limbs, which are often used in distinguishing different species.

title: Phylum: Echinodermata
text:
Phylum: Echinodermata
Echinoderms are exclusively marine animals, with most species being benthic, living on the ocean floor, except for a few pelagic holothurians. They inhabit oceans worldwide, from intertidal zones to the deepest parts of the sea. Their distribution is often aggregated, and these aggregations can be extremely dense. For example, brittle stars and feather stars can form vast clusters on the ocean floor. While a few echinoderms are found above the low-water mark, in habitats such as rock pools, seaweeds, or coral formations, the majority live in sublittoral zones. All classes, except Crinoidea, include species that live partly or wholly buried in sandy or muddy bottoms, with some sea urchins even boring holes in rocks. Deep-water echinoderms are found in all groups, with stalked crinoids primarily living at great depths.
Class: Asteroidea (Starfishes)
Starfishes have a central disc with multiple arms radiating from it. While most starfishes have five arms, some species, like the sun stars (e.g., Solaster and Heliaster), can have up to 50 arms.
Collection methodology
Hand-picking, snorkeling, SCUBA, submersible, remotely operated vehicle (ROV), grab (different types of grabs), dredges, benthic (beam, otter) trawls, sledges, baited traps and pots.
Sample processing
To relax these species, use MgCl2 or chloretone in a flat pan, allowing the animal to spread out before fixation. Once relaxed, fix the specimen in a concentrated formalin solution in seawater, and then transfer it to ethanol for Sample processing.
Remarks
For genetic analysis, tube feet, hepatic caeca, or gonads can be snipped before fixation. Live and field photos are also important for documenting the specimen’s natural appearance. Any commensals associated with the starfish should also be preserved along with the specimen.
Class: Ophiuroidea (Brittle-Stars and Basket-Stars)
Brittle stars and Basket Stars are known for their small, rounded central discs and long, slender arms. Brittle stars can easily lose their arms when handled. These arms may be branched in species like the basket stars, creating a tangle of curling tendrils.
Collection methodology
Hand-picking, snorkeling, SCUBA, submersible, remotely operated vehicle (ROV), grab (different types of grabs), dredges, benthic (beam, otter) trawls, sledges, baited traps and pots.
Sample processing
To relax these species, use MgCl2 or chloretone in a flat pan, allowing the animal to spread out before fixation. Once relaxed, fix the specimen in a concentrated formalin solution in seawater, and then transfer it to ethanol for Sample processing. Brittle stars, which tend to fragment easily, also benefit from prior treatment such as immersion in fresh water for a few hours or refrigeration, if available, to stun them.
Remarks
For genetic analysis, tube feet or arms can be snipped before fixation. Field photos are also important for documenting the specimen’s natural appearance. Any commensals associated with the basket stars should also be preserved along with the specimen.
Class: Echinoidea (heart urchins, sand-dollars and sea urchins)
Echinoids do not have arms. Their body wall is interlocked to form a rigid shell, known as a test. Sea urchins typically maintain radial symmetry, while irregular echinoids (like heart urchins and sand dollars) develop secondary bilateral symmetry.
Collection methodology
Hand picking, snorkeling, SCUBA, submersible, remotely operated vehicle (ROV), grab (different types of grabs), dredges, benthic (beam, otter) trawls, sledges, baited traps and pots.
Sample processing
Echinoids can be relaxed using a refrigerator or chemicals or fixed immediately. After relaxation, they should be fixed in ethanol or formalin and preserved in ethanol. For larger specimens, fixation in formalin followed by washing and drying is recommended. These animals can also be preserved by drying. However, it is generally beneficial to fix the material first, as unfixed specimens tend to shrink and distort. For echinoids, specimens can be fixed in formalin, as described earlier, or better results can be achieved using a corrosive sublimate solution (3-4%). The material should be soaked in this solution for about 12 hours in a non-metallic container. After soaking, specimens should be washed thoroughly and then dried, preferably on a grid or mesh to allow air circulation. In the case of large sea urchins, small holes should be made in the test or the skin around the mouth to allow the fixative to penetrate. Echinoderm specimens are usually stored in 70-90% alcohol.
Remarks
For genetic analysis, tube feet, gonads, or gut samples can be taken with forceps through a small incision in the peristomial membrane. Field photos provide valuable context and documentation of the specimen’s natural state. Any commensals associated with the sea urchin should also be preserved along with the specimen.
Class: Holothurioidea (Sea Cucumbers)
Sea cucumbers do not have arms either, and their body wall's skeletal elements are reduced, making the surface leathery and flexible. The body is elongated, with radial symmetry modified by secondary specialisations. Tube feet around the mouth are modified into tentacles, a defining feature of sea cucumbers.
Collection methodology
Hand-picking, snorkeling, SCUBA, submersible, remotely operated vehicle (ROV), grab (different types of grabs), dredges, benthic (beam, otter) trawls, sledges, baited traps and pots.
Sample processing
Holothurians can be placed in a container of seawater to expand and extend their tentacles before adding a few drops of a 1-2% aqueous solution of propylene phenoxetol, or a few crystals of magnesium sulfate or menthol. The animals should be left in the anaesthetic solution until they cease responding to probing, but they must not be allowed to die, as tissue breakdown through autolysis can occur quickly. Once adequately anaesthetised, the solution should be replaced with a fixative. Another method for obtaining expanded holothurian specimens involves allowing the animal to expand in a polythene tube filled with seawater and then immersing it in hot water to kill it quickly. Animals should be relaxed using MgCl2 and menthol until they no longer contract when touched. Once relaxed, place the specimen in ethanol until it dies, then inject it with 80-95% ethanol, depending on its size.
Remarks
Tentacles, tube feet, or internal organs can be sampled for DNA. Live photos are extremely useful, capturing details that may change after Sample processing. Any commensals associated with the cucumbers should also be preserved along with the specimen.
Class: Crinoidea (Feather-Stars and Sea Lilies)
Crinoids include both sessile sea lilies and free-moving feather stars. Sea lilies have a stalk that attaches to the seabed and can be quite long, with some species' stalks reaching up to 600 mm. The stalk may carry whorls of appendages called cirri for attachment. Feather stars, in contrast, shed their stalks and rely on cirri for temporary attachment. Both types have five arms that can divide, creating up to 200 arms in some species. These arms have jointed appearances and bear lateral rows of appendages called pinnules, giving the crinoids a feathery look.
Collection methodology
Hand-picking, snorkeling, SCUBA, submersible, remotely operated vehicle (ROV), grab (different types of grabs), dredges, benthic (beam, otter) trawls, sledges, baited traps and pots.
Sample processing
Crinoids should be rapidly pushed face-first into 95% ethanol, spreading the arms out as the animal is submerged. This process ensures the crinoid dies in a spread-out position, preserving its structure.
Remarks
Live or Field photos are useful for documenting the crinoid in its natural habitat. Any commensals associated with the crinoid should also be preserved along with the specimen.
Phylum: Hemichordata (acorn worms)
Hemichordates are free-living and typically reside in burrows or under stones in mudflats or sandy areas of the littoral zones, occupying an extensive range of ocean depths and habitats.
Collection methodology
Hand-picking, snorkeling, SCUBA, submersible, remotely operated vehicle (ROV), grab (different types of grabs), dredges, benthic (beam, otter) trawls, sledges, baited traps and pots.
Sample processing
Generally, hemichordates need to be anaesthetised before fixing them. This can be achieved by gradually adding 95% alcohol to the seawater containing the specimens until a concentration of 1 part 95% alcohol to 9 parts seawater is reached. Alternatively, the specimens can also be anaesthetised by immersing them in a 7% aqueous solution of magnesium chloride. Hemichordates can be fixed in a 5% seawater/formalin solution. However, for material intended for histological study, seawater/Bouin's fluid is preferred. After about 24 hours of fixation, formalin-fixed specimens should be transferred to fresh 5% seawater/formalin for storage or 70% alcohol. Bouin-fixed specimens should be stored in 70% alcohol.
Remarks
For DNA work, take a small snippet, such as the posterior end, and fix it in ethanol.

title: Phylum: Chordata
text:
Phylum: Chordata
The phylum Chordata is classified into three major subphyla: Urochordata, Cephalochordata, and Vertebrata. Each subphylum exhibits distinct characteristics, though they all share the fundamental chordate features at some stage of their life cycle.
The subphylum Urochordata consists of marine invertebrates commonly known as tunicates or sea squirts. These organisms are primarily filter feeders, drawing in water through an incurrent siphon to extract food particles, and then expelling the filtered water through an excurrent siphon. While adult tunicates are sessile, meaning they are permanently attached to a surface, their larval stage is free-swimming. It exhibits all key chordate characteristics, including a notochord, dorsal nerve cord, pharyngeal slits, and a post-anal tail. However, during metamorphosis, tunicates undergo a significant transformation, losing their notochord and dorsal nerve cord as they settle onto a substrate. Their body is encased in a protective outer covering called the tunic, composed of cellulose-like material. Tunicates are cosmopolitan in distribution, found in both shallow coastal waters and deep-sea environments, and can exist as either solitary individuals or colonial forms.
Cephalochordates, also known as lancelets or amphioxus, are small, fish-like marine organisms that are remarkable for retaining all chordate characteristics throughout their life cycle. Unlike tunicates, which lose their notochord and nerve cord as adults, lancelets maintain these structures, making them one of the most primitive living chordates. The notochord extends the entire length of the body and functions as a supportive structure, enabling a simple, fish-like swimming motion. Cephalochordates have a dorsal hollow nerve cord, numerous pharyngeal slits used for filter feeding, and a distinct post-anal tail. These animals burrow partially in sandy ocean floors, with their anterior end exposed to filter feed on suspended particles. Though they lack a true brain and vertebral column, their body plan provides important insights into vertebrate evolution. Cephalochordates are primarily found in shallow, warm marine waters and serve as a crucial link in understanding the transition from invertebrate to vertebrate chordates.
The subphylum Vertebrata includes the most evolutionarily advanced and diverse group of chordates, distinguished by the presence of a vertebral column (backbone), which replaces the notochord during development. Vertebrates possess a well-developed brain enclosed in a skull (cranium), a complex nervous system, and an endoskeleton made of cartilage or bone. This subphylum includes fishes, amphibians, reptiles, birds, and mammals, all of which exhibit specialised adaptations for various environments.

title: Subphylum: Urochordata
text:
Subphylum: Urochordata
Ascidians are found worldwide. While many species inhabit intertidal zones, the majority are subtidal and can even be found at great depths. The Ascidiacea, commonly known as sea squirts, are sessile tunicates that can exist as solitary individuals or colonial forms attached to rocks, stones, or seaweeds. Solitary sea squirts are sac-like animals with two prominent siphons, while colonial forms may either encrust surfaces or share a common outer covering. Thaliacea and Larvacea are planktonic tunicates that are largely transparent. Thaliaceans, such as salps, doliolids, and pyrosomes, are typically found in shoals, primarily in tropical and subtropical waters. Some species form colonies, and many exhibit brilliant bioluminescence. Larvaceans, which resemble small tadpoles, are distributed throughout plankton communities worldwide.
Collection methodology
Hand-picking, snorkeling, SCUBA, submersible, remotely operated vehicle (ROV), dredges, benthic (beam, otter) trawls, sledges, baited traps and pots.
Sample processing
Ascidians should be anaesthetised before fixation to ensure optimal preservation. Animals are placed in a bowl of seawater with a few drops of a 1-2% solution of propylene phenoxetol or a few crystals of magnesium sulphate or menthol. Once anaesthetised, they can be killed and fixed by adding a buffered commercial formalin solution to the water. Alternatively, ascidians can be left in a bowl of seawater for several hours until they become fully expanded and partially asphyxiated, after which buffered formalin can be added to fix them. Sessile tunicates are best preserved in 70-90% alcohol, though buffered 5% formalin is also suitable. Pelagic tunicates can be killed, fixed, and preserved by immersion in 5% formalin, but superior results are achieved if they are first anaesthetised and then fixed in Schaudinn’s or Bouin’s fluid. Specimens fixed in Schaudinn’s fluid should be thoroughly washed before being transferred to 5% formalin or 70-90% alcohol for long-term storage.
Remarks
A snippet from the inner siphons of larger solitary species or a chopped-up piece of a colony can be preserved in ethanol for DNA analysis. In situ and live photos are also highly valuable for the taxonomy work.

title: Subphylum: Cephalochordata
text:
Subphylum: Cephalochordata
Cephalochordates are small, eel-like marine organisms that play a crucial role in understanding the evolution of vertebrates. They are benthic organisms, meaning they live close to or within the seabed. They spend most of their time partially buried in the sand, with only their anterior end protruding above the surface. This positioning enables them to engage effectively in filter feeding, a process in which they extract microscopic food particles from the surrounding water. Using cilia on their pharyngeal slits, they generate a water current that brings plankton and organic debris into their mouths while expelling filtered water.
Collection methodology
SCUBA, submersible, remotely operated vehicle (ROV), dredges, benthic (beam, otter) trawls, sledges, baited traps and pots.
Sample processing
Animals are placed in a bowl of seawater with a few drops of a 1-2% solution of propylene phenoxetol or a few crystals of magnesium sulphate, menthol or clove oil. Specimens are killed, fixed, and preserved by immersion in 5% formalin or 70-90% alcohol for long-term storage.
Remarks
A snippet from the gill, fins or tissue can be preserved in ethanol for DNA analysis. Live photos are also highly valuable for taxonomy work.

title: Subphylum: Vertebrata
text:
Subphylum: Vertebrata
Marine vertebrates inhabit a wide range of marine habitats, from shallow coastal areas to the vast, uncharted depths of the open ocean. Subphylum Vertebrata encompasses some of the most structurally complex organisms on Earth, characterised by a vertebral column, a well-developed nervous system, and a highly organised body plan. Vertebrates are classified into several groups, with marine species being among the most diverse and ecologically significant. The major marine superclasses and classes within Vertebrata include jawless fishes (Agnatha), jawed fishes (Gnathostomata, also known as Pisces), and tetrapods (Tetrapoda), which encompass marine reptiles, birds, and mammals. These classifications reflect the evolutionary adaptations that have enabled vertebrates to thrive in diverse aquatic environments, ranging from the deep ocean to coastal habitats. Each group exhibits unique physiological and morphological traits that will allow it to survive in its respective niche, contributing to the complexity and functionality of marine ecosystems.
Agnatha, the jawless fishes, includes two primary classes: Cephalaspidomorphi, which consists of lampreys, and Myxini, which includes hagfishes. These primitive vertebrates lack actual jaws and paired fins, relying instead on suction-like mouth structures to feed. In contrast, the Gnathostomata Pisces, or jawed fishes, exhibit significant evolutionary advancements. Within this group, bony fishes (Class Actinopterygii and Class Sarcopterygii) represent the largest and most diverse vertebrate class, ranging from small reef fish to massive pelagic species. Cartilaginous fishes, which include sharks, rays, skates (Class Elasmobranchii), and chimaeras (Class Holocephali), have skeletons composed of cartilage rather than bone, an adaptation that enhances flexibility and buoyancy. These species play vital roles in marine ecosystems, often as apex predators that regulate prey populations and maintain ecological balance.
Beyond fish, marine vertebrates also include members of Tetrapoda, which evolved from lobe-finned fishes (Class Sarcopterygii) and adapted to terrestrial and aquatic environments. This group contains marine reptiles (Class Reptilia), such as sea turtles and marine iguanas, which are well-adapted to oceanic life with specialised physiological traits. Marine birds (Class Aves), including penguins, pelicans, and albatrosses, rely on the ocean for food and nesting sites, playing a key role in nutrient cycling. Finally, marine mammals (Class Mammalia), such as whales, dolphins, and seals, exhibit complex social behaviours, advanced intelligence, and adaptations for deep diving and thermoregulation. These tetrapods exemplify the remarkable evolutionary transitions that have enabled vertebrates to colonise marine environments, making them integral to the structure and sustainability of ocean ecosystems.
Collection methodology
Isaacs-Kidd Midwater Trawl (IKMT), pelagic and demersal trawl, longline, gill net, purse seine, bongo net, Multiple plankton sampler (MPS), SCUBA, plankton pumps, hooks, long-lines, Dredges, benthic (beam, otter) trawls, sledges, baited traps and pots, submersible and Remotely Operated Vehicle (ROV).
Note
Marine reptiles and marine mammals are often rare and endangered, making their monitoring a critical component of conservation efforts. Due to their low population numbers and elusive behaviour, manual observation techniques remain the most effective method for detecting and studying these species. High-powered "big eye" binoculars and advanced mirrorless cameras are commonly used tools that allow trained observers to scan vast ocean areas, identify species with accuracy, and document behaviour and physical condition. These manual methods offer real-time flexibility, enabling observers to adapt to changing field conditions, record contextual information, and capture high-resolution photographic evidence for analysis. Because many of these animals are of high conservation concern, manual observation ensures that sightings are reliable and informative, supporting efforts to protect and manage vulnerable marine species.
Sample processing
Common anaesthetics include MS 222 (Tricaine Methanesulfonate), Eugenol (Clove Oil), which is prepared as a solution mixed with ethanol; Quinaldine, which works similarly to MS 222 but is less common; and CO2, which can induce anaesthesia by increasing carbon dioxide levels in the water. Freezing is a more effective method for preserving fish samples than keeping them in ice-cold water, especially when the samples cannot be treated immediately or must be transported over long distances. For proper fixation, specimens should be fully immersed in 10% formalin. For medium-sized specimens, make an incision on the right side of the abdomen to enhance formalin absorption. When preserving a specimen in formalin, add borax powder, sodium bicarbonate (baking soda), or hexamethylenetetramine to neutralise formic acid, thereby preventing the degradation of bony tissue. For general taxonomic purposes, the entire animal can be effectively fixed and preserved in 5% neutral formalin, while 70% alcohol is commonly used as a preservative.
Remarks
Visual documentation is an essential tool for studying and conserving marine mammals, birds, and turtles, providing valuable insights into their behaviours, migration patterns, and interactions with the environment. Through high-resolution photography, drone surveillance, underwater videography, and satellite imagery, researchers can monitor these species in their natural habitats with minimal disturbance. These visual records help identify population trends, breeding sites, and potential threats such as habitat loss, pollution, and climate change. Underwater photography and thermal imaging are beneficial for monitoring elusive species, such as deep-diving cetaceans, or detecting seal populations in icy regions. Seabirds, such as albatrosses and puffins, are monitored through remote camera systems placed on their nesting sites, which helps researchers track breeding success and food availability. Satellite tagging and aerial photography provide essential data on the movements of sea turtles, revealing nesting beaches, feeding grounds, and migratory corridors. These visual records not only contribute to scientific understanding but also serve as powerful tools for storytelling, inspiring public awareness and conservation efforts worldwide. Through ongoing advancements in imaging technology, the documentation of marine life continues to play a vital role in ensuring the protection of these species and their habitats.

title: Seaweeds
text:
Seaweeds
Seaweeds are marine algae that play a vital role in ocean ecosystems by providing food, habitat, and oxygen. They are classified into three major groups based on pigmentation: green algae (Chlorophyta), brown algae (Phaeophyceae), and red algae (Rhodophyta). Found in coastal and intertidal zones, seaweeds attach to rocks, coral reefs, or other surfaces, thriving in nutrient-rich waters. They contribute to marine biodiversity, support fisheries, and hold economic importance in industries such as food, pharmaceuticals, and biofuel production. Most seaweeds require a stable attachment point, which is why they predominantly inhabit the littoral zone (nearshore waters), particularly on rocky shores rather than sandy or gravelly substrates. Seaweed also plays a crucial role in marine food webs. Macroalgae shed old fronds, which serve as an essential food source for benthic organisms in the intertidal zone. Additionally, some seaweeds contain pneumatocysts (gas-filled structures) that allow them to float.
Collection methodology
Hand-picking, snorkel, SCUBA, dredges, and bottom trawl.
Sample processing
Seaweed preservation can be achieved using either dry or wet methods, depending on the species and the intended storage purpose. In the dry process, seaweeds are carefully arranged and pressed onto herbarium sheets, ensuring their natural shape is maintained. They are then dried using blotting paper or air-drying techniques, making them suitable for long-term storage in botanical collections and research institutions. This method is ideal for taxonomic studies and the preparation of herbaria. In contrast, the wet method involves storing seaweed specimens in 4% formalin or 70% ethanol to retain their original colour and structure. This technique helps study delicate or gelatinous species that may lose their form when dried. Both methods are commonly used for reference collections.
Remarks
DNA sub-sampling of seaweeds is essential for accurate species identification, genetic diversity studies, and conservation efforts. Traditional classification based on morphology can be challenging due to environmental variations, making molecular techniques a more reliable approach. The process begins with the collection of fresh seaweed samples, which are carefully cleaned to remove contaminants and then preserved in silica gel, ethanol, or frozen for long-term storage. Seaweed photography is a vital tool for scientific research, conservation, and artistic documentation, enabling the capture of the diversity and beauty of marine algae.

title: Seagrass
text:
Seagrass
Seagrasses are flowering marine plants found in shallow coastal waters, typically in sandy or muddy substrates where light can penetrate. These habitats occur in intertidal to subtidal zones. They are commonly found in bays, lagoons, estuaries, and around coral reefs, thriving in calm, clear waters with low to moderate wave energy.
Collection methodology
Hand-picking, snorkel, SCUBA (specimens are gathered carefully to include all parts of leaves, rhizomes, roots, and reproductive structures using hand tools or by gently uprooting the plant).
Sample processing
Sample processing similar to that of seaweed and seagrasses can be preserved using both dry and wet preparation methods, depending on the intended purpose. Dry preparation is commonly used for herbarium collections and involves carefully collecting whole plants, including leaves, rhizomes, and roots, followed by rinsing them in seawater to remove sand and debris. The cleaned specimens are then arranged neatly on acid-free herbarium paper to display their key features. They are pressed between blotting paper or cardboard using a plant press and dried over several days in a well-ventilated area. Once dried, the specimens are labelled with essential details such as species name, location, habitat, and collection date. Wet preparation is used for anatomical studies, DNA analysis, or preserving delicate structures. This involves storing specimens in liquid preservatives, such as 4–10% formalin in seawater or 70–95% ethanol, depending on the analysis requirements.
Remarks
For molecular work, small seagrass fragments can be rapidly dried in silica gel and stored in sealed containers.

title: A general account of Polychaete worms
text:
A general account of Polychaete worms
Polychaetes are soft-bodied marine Annelids with bristle-like parapodia, living in tubes and burrows in the sand floating freely on the surface or crawling on the surface of the sediment (Fauchald & Rouse, 1997; Hutchings, 2000). Polychaetes can be found in intertidal regions to deep hydrothermal vents and are present in all marine habitats (Hutchings, 2000; Hutchings & Kupriyanova, 2015). Polychaetes are the most diverse group among softbottom macrobenthos with a total of 11,456 species belonging to 1,417 genera recorded to date (Pamungkas et al., 2019). The interaction between polychaetes and sediment is crucial for the functioning of ecosystems in general (Donadi et al., 2015; Kristensen et al., 2012). Polychaete associated with other macrobenthos forms a complex food web in the benthic habitat (Snelgrove, 1998). Meiobenthos such as copepods, other small crustaceans, nematodes, and other groups are known to have fed on juveniles of macrobenthos, and macrobenthos are known to have fed on meiobenthos (Warwick et al., 1990). The wide range of adaptation of polychaetes to environmental changes makes them suitable for assessing benthic community health (Díaz-Castañeda & Reish, 2009; Giménez et al., 2010). Polychaetes play a fundamental role in the functioning of the marine ecosystem by providing several ecological services, such as bioturbation, remineralisation, oxygenation, bioengineering, and food for other organisms, as well as serving as an ecological indicator. The diversity and distribution of macrobenthos depend on several factors, including environmental variables, seasonal changes, hydrodynamic pressure, and anthropogenic activities.

title: General Characteristics of the family Glyceridae (Grube, 1850)
text:
General Characteristics of the family Glyceridae (Grube, 1850)
The Glyceridae family, commonly referred to as beak-thrower worms or bloodworms, comprises elongated, tubular polychaetes that can reach up to one meter in length. These benthic organisms are present in a vast array of environments, ranging from intertidal to abyssal depths. Their body is tapered at both ends and consists of numerous bi- or triannulate segments. Distinguishing Glycerids from other species is made possible by their long, muscular, and eversible proboscis and their pointed, annulated prostomium. The anterior annulus of the prostomium has four appendages, while the posterior annulus has one pair of nuchal organs. Glycerids do not possess eyes. They are easily recognisable by their distinct reddish colouration and their four dark jaws, each with ailerons at the end of their proboscis. These characteristics set them apart from goniadids, which are closely related but differ in morphological characteristics, such as possessing iridescent integuments and a ring of macro- and micrognaths. The family has four genera, namely Glycera (Lamarck), Glycerella (Arwidsson), Hemipodia (Kinberg), and Proboscidea (Lesueur in Blainville). The original description can be found in the following citation “Grube, Adolf Eduard. (1850). Die Familien der Anneliden. Archiv für Naturgeschichte, Berlin. 16(1): 249-364., available online at https://biodiversitylibrary.org/page/6958350 page(s): 307; note: As heading "VII. Familie Glycerea Gr."”. As of 2023, the only genus of Glyceridae family recorded in India is Glycera (Lakra et al., 2018).

title: General Characteristics of the Genus Glycera (Savigny, 1818)
text:
General Characteristics of the Genus Glycera (Savigny, 1818)
The following are the identifying features of the genus Glycera. The body of the genus Glycera is characterised by numerous elongated segments that taper at both ends. These segments are bi- or triannulate. The prostomium is conical in shape, mostly pointed, and distinctly annulated. The anterior-most annulus has four appendages, with the anterior pair situated termino-aterally and the posterior pair more dorsolateral. The posterior-most annulus has one pair of nuchal organs, but no eyes are present. The proboscis is long, cylindrical, club-shaped, muscular, and densely covered with numerous papillae. These papillae bear specialised structures on their posterior sides. The tip of the everted proboscis has four dark, hook-like, curved jaws, each with a rod-like, more or less triangular or deeply incised supportive aileron. The first two sets of parapodia are typically uniramous, consisting of exclusively neuropodia, ventral cirri, and compound chaetae. Subsequent parapodia may be uni- or biramous and feature both dorsal and ventral cirri. The largest parapodia are generally found in the mid-body region. In biramous parapodia, notopodia and neuropodia are not clearly separated from one another. Each parapodium has two prechaetal and one or two postchaetal lobes. Branchiae, which may range in shape from blister-like to simple digitiform or branched, may be present or absent and are retractable in some species. They are situated on different parts of the parapodia. Noto- and neuropodia each have a single acicula, with notopodia featuring simple capillaries and neuropodia mostly having spinigerous compound chaetae. The pygidium has a pair of slender anal cirri. A total of 76 valid species are present worldwide, of which 21 species have been recorded in India. Of these, 19 have been verified by WoRMS and literature. The list of Glycera species recorded in India are as follows Glycera alba, Glycera americana, Glycera Africana, Glycera embranchiata, Glycera benguellana, Glycera brevicirris, Glycera cinnamomea, Glycera fallax, Glycera lancadivae, Glycera lapidum, Glycera longipinnis, Glycera natalensis, Glycera nicobarica, Glycera oxycephala, Glycera papillosa, Glycera posterobranchia, Glycera subaenea, Glycera sphyrabrancha, Glycera tesselata, Glycera tridactyla and Glycera unicornis. From the above species list, Glycera embranchiata is listed as a nomen nudum in WoRMS, and the species Glycera sphyrabrancha is recorded from India but lacks a distribution record in WoRMS.

title: The detailed definitions of each characteristic of Genus Glycera
text:
The detailed definitions of each characteristic of Genus Glycera
Body rings: All annelids have a segmented body, where the ring refers to the segments of the worm; all are round, ring-like throughout the body. In Glyceridae, the body rings are sometimes bi-annulated, tri-annulated, or numerous; indistinct rings are also present.
Proboscidal papillae: The proboscis is a lengthy, extensible, and often muscular feeding apparatus that is utilised to seize and immobilise prey. The surface of the proboscis is adorned with a specialised structure known as "Proboscidal Papillae". These papillae are essentially small, raised projections that can serve various purposes, such as tactile sensing or aiding in prey capture. There are primarily five types of Proboscidal papillae that have been documented from various species of Glyceridae. Different species possess different types of Proboscidal papillae or different combinations of them. The Proboscidal papillae are situated at the anterior end of the body and are retractile; therefore, they can be seen outside the body frequently or can be removed by gently pressing the anterior body part. The Proboscidal papillae can be of the following types: Conical Papillae, Digitiform Papillae, Globular or Spherical Papillae, Pedunculate Papillae, and Mucous Papillae. The Conical Papillae are cone-shaped and may be distributed in various patterns along the proboscis. Sometimes, they may have transverse ridges. The Digitiform Papillae are finger-like in appearance. The Globular or Spherical Papillae are, as the name implies, round or ball-shaped papillae. The Pedunculate Papillae have a stalked appearance, resembling a small mushroom with a stalk and nail. Sometimes, the nail has ridges of different types, such as longitudinal and transverse ridges. The Mucous Papillae secrete mucus, which can aid in prey capture or manipulation. To accurately identify species belonging to the Glyceridae family, it is necessary to conduct a thorough examination and documentation of the proboscidal papillae's specific arrangement, number, size, and type. This meticulous process is crucial for ensuring the precision and validity of any conclusions drawn from the identification process. Therefore, it is imperative to approach this task with the utmost attention to detail and expertise.
Aileron: Within the Glyceridae family of polychaete annelids, ailerons are flattened lateral extensions situated on the posterior segments of these worms. They serve various functions, including assisting in feeding, capturing prey, burrowing, and locomotion. Ailerons are a crucial diagnostic feature for species identification within the Glyceridae family and can be categorised into various forms based on their morphology and placement. These forms include simple ailerons, branched or digitate ailerons, fused ailerons, reduced ailerons, and varying margins. Taxonomists use a combination of these morphological characteristics to accurately identify species within the Glyceridae family, as relying on a single characteristic can lead to misidentification.
Prechaetal lobe: Polychaete annelids have paired lateral outgrowths on each body segment called parapodia, which can bear various structures including bristles known as chaetae. The prechaetal lobe, also known as the acicular lobe, is a structure that is often present on the parapodia. It is located in front of the chaetal row and can take on different shapes and sizes, making it an important morphological feature in identifying different species within the Glyceridae family. There are five types of prechaetal lobes in Glyceridae: simple or rounded, elongated or finger-like, branched or bifurcated, serrated or fringed, and reduced. Taxonomists studying these worms often use observations of prechaetal lobes along with other morphological features to accurately identify species.
Postchaetal lobe: The postchaetal lobe is a part of the parapodia, which are the fleshy outgrowths located on each body segment of polychaete annelids. These parapodia carry various structures, including bristles known as chaetae. The postchaetal lobe is situated behind the chaetal row and can be a crucial feature in the taxonomy of the Glyceridae family and many polychaetes. The postchaetal lobe's shape, size, and other characteristics can vary among species, making it a distinguishing feature. There are six different forms of the postchaetal lobes, including simple, elongated, branched, lamellate, reduced, and serrated. The morphology of the postchaetal lobe, combined with other anatomical features such as chaetae and ailerons, provides valuable information for species identification within the Glyceridae family. A holistic approach to taxonomy, considering multiple morphological aspects, is crucial for accurate identification.
Cirrus: Polychaete annelids are characterised by the presence of appendages known as "cirri" (plural: "cirrus"). These structures, which resemble tentacles or filaments, serve a variety of functions, including sensory roles, reproduction, and respiration. Cirri are a key taxonomic feature that enables the differentiation between species or even families of polychaetes. In the Glyceridae family, cirri are often connected to the parapodia, which are the paired lateral fleshy outgrowths on each body segment. The location of the cirri can be either dorsal (on the upper side) or ventral (on the lower side) about the main body axis. The morphology, presence, and arrangement of cirri are critical features that distinguish one species from another within the Glyceridae family. The Glyceridae family exhibits various forms of cirri, including simple, branched or bifurcated, foliaceous, papillated, setose, ventral, and dorsal types. Simple cirri are unbranched and tentacle-like structures that vary in size depending on the species. Branched or bifurcated cirri split into two or more branches or filaments. Foliaceous cirri have a leaf-like, flattened appearance, while papillated cirri have a surface covered in small, raised structures called papillae. Setose cirri have small bristles or setae on their surfaces. Ventral cirri are located on the underside (or ventral side) of the parapodia. In contrast, dorsal cirri are positioned on the dorsal side of the parapodia and can sometimes be more elongated or prominent compared to the ventral cirri. The morphology, number, and arrangement of cirri can be specific to a particular species within the Glyceridae family. Taxonomists often rely on a combination of cirral features and other morphological characteristics to accurately identify species. It is essential to observe cirri within the context of other features for a comprehensive understanding of species differences, as with many taxonomic traits. In conclusion, examining cirri is a crucial component of the taxonomic classification of polychaete annelids and requires careful observation and analysis by trained professionals.
Branchia: In annelids, such as those found in the Glyceridae family, branchiae are respiratory structures that resemble gills and aid in gas exchange. These structures can vary in shape and location, even within the same family. In the Glyceridae family, known as bloodworms, branchiae are crucial for respiration. The presence, absence, shape, and position of branchiae are important characteristics used to distinguish between species. Several types of branchiae may be observed in the Glyceridae family, including simple, branched, cirriform, lamellate, bushy, or absent branchiae. The specific location, number, and size of the branchiae can provide valuable information for identifying species within the Glyceridae family. It is essential to adopt a comprehensive approach when studying or identifying these organisms, taking into account both branchial features and other anatomical structures for accurate classification.

title: A general account of Sea Stars
text:
A general account of Sea Stars
Asteroidea (starfish or sea stars) is one of the most diverse classes of the phylum Echinodermata, comprising about 1900 extant species (Mah and Blake, 2012). Starfish occur across a broad depth range from the intertidal to abyssal depths (>6000 m) (Marine Diversity in India Venkataraman K etal; 2012). sea stars exhibit a remarkable diversity in form and function. They typically have a central disc and radiating arms, usually five, although some species can have more (Blake et al., 1989). Sea stars possess a unique water vascular system that aids in locomotion, feeding, and respiration. Their tube feet, which extend from the ambulacral grooves on the underside of each arm, are operated hydraulically and are essential for movement and prey capture (Lawrence, 2013).

title: The general characteristics of the Family Luidiidae (Sladen, 1889)
text:
The general characteristics of the Family Luidiidae (Sladen, 1889)
The family Luidiidae (Sladen, 1889) comprises sea stars within the order Paxillosida, which are recognised for their unique morphological, ecological, and behavioural traits. Luidiidae sea stars typically possess a flattened, pentaradial symmetry with long, tapering arms. The central disk is relatively small compared to the length of the arms. The arms are broad and gradually narrow towards the tips, giving them a characteristic appearance (Sladen, W.P. 1889). The skeletal system is made up of reticulated ossicles, which provide both rigidity and flexibility. The aboral (upper) surface is covered with small, spine-like paxillae, although the degree of coverage can vary among species (Jangoux, M., & Lawrence, J.M., 1982). Unlike many other sea stars, members of the Luidiidae family lack suckers on their tube feet, which are adapted for burrowing and moving through soft sediment rather than for attachment (Blake, D.B. 1989). Luidiidae generally exhibit poorly developed or absent pedicellariae (small pincer-like appendages), which in other sea stars are used for cleaning and defense (Fisher, W.K. 1906). pecies within the Luidiidae family are commonly found in sandy or muddy substrates, where their burrowing behavior is well-suited to these environments. They are typically located in shallow to moderately deep marine waters (Clark, A.M. & Downey, M.E. 1992). Luidiidae species are distributed globally, with a higher concentration in tropical and subtropical marine environments. Their adaptability to different sediment types allows them to occupy a wide range of habitats (Clark, A.M. & Downey, M.E. 1992). Luidiidae are primarily detritivores or scavengers, feeding on organic particles and small invertebrates found in sediment. Their lack of suckers on the tube feet aids in sifting through sediment to locate food (Lawrence, J.M. 1987). The burrowing behaviour and tube foot adaptations of Luidiidae are crucial to their feeding strategy, enabling them to efficiently process large amounts of sediment (Jangoux, M., & Lawrence, J.M., 1982). he family exhibits a range of reproductive strategies, with many species engaging in broadcast spawning, where eggs and sperm are released into the water column for external fertilization. Some species may also show signs of asexual reproduction (Byrne, M. 1991). By burrowing and feeding within the sediment, Luidiidae species play a crucial role in sediment turnover and nutrient cycling, thereby influencing the structure and function of the benthic ecosystem (Lawrence, J.M., 1987).

title: The general characteristics of the genus Luidia (Forbes, 1839)
text:
The general characteristics of the genus Luidia (Forbes, 1839)
The genus Luidia (Forbes, 1839) belongs to the family Luidiidae within the order Paxillosida. Luidia is known for its distinctive morphological features and ecological roles in marine environments. Luidia species typically have a flat, star-shaped body with a small central disk and long, slender arms that can range from five to nine in number. These arms are relatively flexible and taper gradually to a point, which distinguishes them from other sea stars with more robust or truncated arms (Forbes, E. 1839). The skeletal structure is composed of reticulated ossicles that provide support while allowing for the flexibility needed for their burrowing lifestyle. The aboral surface is covered with paxillae, which are small, spine-like structures that can vary in density and size among different species  (Jangoux, M. & Lawrence, J.M. (1982). Luidia species lack suckers on their tube feet, which are instead pointed and adapted for digging into and moving through soft substrates, such as sand or mud. This characteristic is typical of the order Paxillosida. Blake, D.B. (1989). Like other members of the Luidiidae family, Luidia species generally have poorly developed or absent pedicellariae, which are small, pincer-like structures found in other sea star groups Fisher, W.K. (1906). Luidia species are often found in sandy or muddy substrates in shallow to moderately deep waters. They are adapted to life in these environments, where their burrowing behaviour enables them to evade predators and access food sources (Clark, A.M., & Downey, M.E., 1992). The lack of suckers on the tube feet is an adaptation to their feeding strategy, which involves sifting through the substrate to locate prey. They can also engulf prey using their flexible arms and extend their stomach outside the body to digest food externally Jangoux, M. & Lawrence, J.M. 1982). Luidia species typically engage in sexual reproduction, with many species practicing broadcast spawning, where eggs and sperm are released into the water column for external fertilization. Some species have been observed to reproduce asexually through arm regeneration and fission (Byrne, M. 1991). Luidia species play a crucial role as predators in their ecosystems, helping to control the populations of benthic invertebrates. Their burrowing behaviour also contributes to the turnover and aeration of sediments, which is crucial for the health of benthic communities (Lawrence, J.M., 1987). According to the Zoological Survey of India (ZSI) Checklist 2023, the genus Luidia includes the following six species in Indian waters

Prechaetal lobe: The notopodial and neuropodial prechaetal lobes are of similar length. The lobes transform from broad base to digitiform from anterior to the posterior segments
Postchaetal lobe: short and rounded throughout the body
Dorsal cirrus: conical to oval shape present from 3rd segments onwards, inserted near to the parapodia basis
Ventral cirrus: broadly triangular in the anterior and mid-body regions, but in the posterior end, it transforms to digitiform shape
Branchia: absent
Position of Branchia: absent
Chaetae: Simple capillaries in notopodia and compound spinigers in neuropodia
Geographical Geographical Distribution: Atlantic, North Sea, Red Sea, Australia, Madagascar, East Pacific, and in India Andaman and Nicobar Islands

Species Name: Glycera papillosa Grube, 1857
Type Locality: Chilean part of the South Pacific Ocean
Body rings: mid-body segments are bi-annulated
Prostomium: conical with 8 rings
Proboscidal papillae: Two types of papillae 1) a few ovoid forms and 2) numerous long, slender forms without rings
Aileron: deeply forked and slender, the shorter limb being half the length of the longer one and united to it
Parapodia: First two parapodia uniramous following parapodia biramous
Prechaetal lobe: The superior prechaetal lobe is small, the inferior one large and pointed
Postchaetal lobe: Single rounded postchaetal lobe present
Dorsal cirrus: small arises from the body wall above the parapodium
Ventral cirrus: Ventral cirrus has a length of postchaetal lobe
Branchia: absent
Position of Branchia: absent
Chaetae: Simple capillaries in notopodia and compound spinigers in neuropodia
Geographical Distribution: Western Atlantic, North Carolina to the Gulf of Mexico, Chile, Western Africa, in India South Arabian Sea, Andaman and Nicobar Islands

Species Name: Glycera posterobranchia Hoagland, 1920
Type Locality: Philippines EEZ
Body rings: mid-body segments are bi-annulated
Prostomium: Elongated conical prostomium which is longer than width consisting of 10-11 rings
Proboscidal papillae: Three types of papillae 1) most abundant papillae are papillae with terminal fingernail structure with medium stalk with longitudinal ridges on the stalk, 2) rest of the papillae are short conical shaped papillae with longitudinal ridges, 3) oval shaped papillae without any ridges
Aileron: pointed triangular base
Parapodia: First two parapodia uniramous following parapodia biramous
Prechaetal lobe: two prechaetal lobes observed to be with a triangular form with abroad base in the anterior and mid-body region to digitiform in the posterior segments
Postchaetal lobe: short, notopodial lobes are triangular in shape whereas neuropodial lobes are rounded
Dorsal cirrus: starts from 3rd segment conical to oval shape placed close to parapodial base
Ventral cirrus: broadly triangular in the anterior and mid-body regions, but in the posterior end it transforms to digitiform shape
Branchia: Non-retractile branchia present
Position of Branchia: present between 16-24thsegment medio-dorsally on the parapodia to the posterior end
Chaetae: Simple capillaries in notopodia and compound spinigers in neuropodia
