Geographical Distribution: Philippine Island, South China Sea, Vietnam and in India Indian Ocean, Bay of Bengal and Andaman and Nicobar Islands

Species Name: Glycera subaenea Grube, 1878
Type Locality: Philippines EEZ
Body rings: anterior segments are bi-annulated, mid-body segments are more or less tri-annulated
Prostomium: conical with 8-10 rings
Proboscidal papillae: Two types of papillae 1) numerous bluntly conical papillae with 1-2 rings, 2) subspherical papillae without rings
Aileron: one well-developed prong and the other prong short and completely united to the first by an oblique shelf
Parapodia: First two parapodia uniramous following parapodia biramous
Prechaetal lobe: 2 long, equally pointed prechaetal lobes
Postchaetal lobe: The superior postchaetal lobe is pointed, the inferior one is shorter and blunt
Dorsal cirrus: NA
Ventral cirrus: NA
Branchia: Present
Position of Branchia: from chaetiger 12 situated on the anterior end of parapodium, with 2 to 5 branched digitiform lobes
Chaetae: Simple capillaries in notopodia and compound spinigers in neuropodia
Geographical Distribution: Philippines, Australia, South China Sea, Madagascar, Red Sea, South Africa and in India South Arabian Sea and Andaman and Nicobar Islands

Species Name: Glycera sphyrabrancha Schmarda, 1861
Type Locality: Jamaican EEZ
Body rings: Segments biannulate with the same size of annuli from chaetiger 10, anterior ones uni-annulate
Prostomium: conical with 10-12 rings
Proboscidal papillae: two types of papillae: 1. numerous digitiform papillae without ridges; 2. some isolated, oval to globular papillae, without ridges
Aileron: with deeply incised base
Parapodia: First two parapodia uniramous following parapodia biramous
Prechaetal lobe: Two slender triangular to digitiform prechaetal lobes, on anterior parapodia, noto- and neuropodial prechaetal lobes subequal, middle and posterior parapodia with neuropodial prechaetal lobes slightly longer than notopodial ones.
Postchaetal lobe: Rounded postchaetal lobe
Dorsal cirrus: digitiform with a slightly swollen dorso-basally, longer on anterior and parapodia, diminishing in size from middle to posterior parapodia
ventral cirrus: triangular on anterior parapodia, digitiform on middle body region and slender on posterior parapodia
Branchia: non-retractile, simple slightly triangular anteriorly becoming digitiform from middle of the anterior region, and best developed in the middle body region
Position of Branchia: appears from chaetiger 15 near upper chaetal lobe
Chaetae: Simple capillaries in notopodia and compound spinigers in neuropodia
Geographical Distribution: Arabian Gulf, Andaman Sea, Aruba, Belize, Caribbean Sea, Cuba, Curaçao, Honduras, Jamaica, Panama, Philippines, Red Sea, South Africa, South China Sea, Tobago, Trinidad, Venezuela, in India Andhra Pradesh, Gujarat, Goa, Kerala, Lakshadweep Island, Maharashtra, Odisha, West Bengal, Tamil Nadu

Species Name: Glycera tesselata Grube, 1863
Type Locality: Mediterranean Sea
Body rings: anterior segments are bi-annulated, mid-body segments are more or less tri-annulated
Prostomium: Conical with 8-9 rings
Proboscidal papillae: Two types of papillae 1) Most abundant papillae digitiform shape 
with the straight longitudinal median ridge, 2) the rest are conical shape papillae without any distinct ridges
Aileron: deeply incised base
Parapodia: First two parapodia uniramous following parapodia biramous
Prechaetal lobe: The prechaetal lobe observed to be a triangular form with an abroad base in the anterior and mid-body region to digitiform in the posterior segments
Postchaetal lobe: short and rounded throughout the body segments
Dorsal cirrus: Conical to oval dorsal cirrus started from the 3rd segment and placed far away from the parapodial basis
Ventral cirrus: broadly triangular in the anterior and mid-body regions, but in the posterior end it transforms to digitiform shape
Branchia: absent
Position of Branchia: absent
Chaetae: Simple capillaries in notopodia and compound spinigers in neuropodia
Geographical Distribution: Northwestern and Northeastern Atlantic, Gulf of Mexico, Caribbean Sea, Mediterranean Sea, Red Sea, South coasts of Africa, Indo-Pacific, Northwestern Pacific and in India Bay of Bangla, Arabian Sea, North Indian Ocean and Andaman and Nicobar Islands

Species Name: Glycera tridactyla Schmarda, 1861
Type Locality: Atlantic Ocean
Body rings: mid-body segments are bi-annulated
Prostomium: Conical with 11-14 rings
Proboscidal papillae: Three types of papillae 1) the most abundant papillae terminal fingernail structure with short length stalk and longitudinal ridges on the nail, 2) the rest of the papillae are digitiform shape with longitudinal ridges, 3) oval shape without any ridges
Aileron: pointed triangular base
Parapodia: First two parapodia uniramous following parapodia biramous
Prechaetal lobe: The two prechaetal lobes observed to be with a triangular form with abroad base in the anterior and mid-body region to digitiform in the posterior segments
Postchaetal lobe: short, notopodial lobes are triangular in shape and longer than the rounded neuropodial lobes
Dorsal cirrus: from 3rd segment conical to oval shape placed close to the parapodial base
Ventral cirrus: broadly triangular in the anterior and mid-body regions, but in the posterior end it transforms to digitiform shape
Branchia: Non-retractile digitiform branchia present
Position of Branchia: between 17-22rd segment, termino-dorsally on the parapodia to the posterior end
Chaetae: Simple capillaries in notopodia and compound spinigers in neuropodia
Geographical Distribution: West coasts of Europe, Mediterranean Sea, Black Sea, Coasts of South Africa, Red Sea, Coasts of Japan, East and South China Sea, Coasts of New Guinea, East coast of Australia, Andaman Sea and in India Arabian Sea, Bay of Bengal, Andaman coast.

Species Name: Glycera unicornis Lamarck, 1818
Type Locality: Unknown
Body rings: Mid-body segments biannulate; anterior annulus about as long as posterior one or slightly longer
Prostomium: Conical with 10-13 rings
Proboscidal papillae: two types of papillae: 1. numerous conical papillae with 3 U-shaped ridges; 2. isolated, broader, oval to globular papillae without ridges
Aileron: with triangular base
Parapodia: First two parapodia uniramous following parapodia biramous
Prechaetal lobe: Two slender triangular to digitiform prechaetal lobes of about same length; both lobes becoming slightly slimmer in posterior parapodia; in last parapodia notopodial lobe shorter than neuropodial one.
Postchaetal lobe: Two shorter postchaetal lobes; anteriorly both lobes are rounded; in following parapodia both lobes elongated and slender triangular, of about same length
Dorsal cirrus: from 2nd parapodium, conical to oval
Ventral cirrus: slender triangular to digitiform, about as long as postchaetal lobes
Branchia: Branchia retractile, 1-2 digitiform branchial rami present
Position of Branchia: starting from about 16th to 30th parapodium to near posterior end
Chaetae: Simple capillaries in notopodia and compound spinigers in neuropodia
Geographical Distribution: The Andaman Sea, Black Sea, North Sea, Mediterranean Sea, Madagascar, South China Sea, Java Sea, and in India, Andhra Pradesh, Gujarat, Goa, Karnataka, Kerala, Maharashtra, Odisha, West Bengal, Tamil Nadu, and the Andaman coast.

Species name: Hermonia hystrix Savigny, 1820
Body: oval and depressed, about 30-40 mm long with 32-34 setigers
Prostomium: small and rounded with a slender median antenna arising from a stout ceratophore
Eyes: A pair of swollen ommatophores, each bearing two eye spots
Elytra:  Fifteen pairs of smooth elytra
Setae:  Notosetae of clytrigerous feet include very, long harpoon-setae, sabre-setae and few small capillaries
Notosetae: Notosetae of cirrigerous feet smaller and lack harpoon-setae
Neurosetae: bifurcate, the longer prong having one to four accessory teeth but no fringe of hair
Geographical distribution: Northern Atlantic from Scotland to Senegal, Mediterranean, Red Sea, Indian Ocean, and Japan.

Species name: Laetmonice wyvillei McIntosh, 1885
Body: almost oblong, up to 35 mm. long for 42 segments
Ventrum:  smooth with only a few papillae between the parapodia
Eyes: Ocular peduncles not pigmented
Lobes: No lobes on the tentacular segment at the sides of the prostomium
Elytra:  Eighteen pairs of smooth elytra
Notosetae:  Notosetae of elytrigerous segments stouter than those of cirrigerous ones and include long harpoon-setae,  Notopodia with mere vestiges of felt
Cirri: Ventral cirri small and weak and never reach the bases of the inferior neurosetae
Geographical distribution:  Subantarctic (abyssal)

Species name: Laetmonice benthaliana McIntosh, 1885
Body: flattened oval, up to 30 mm long with 32–36 segments
Ventrum: Smooth, with only a few papillae between the parapodia
Eyes: Ocular peduncles not pigmented
Lobes: No lateral lobes on the tentacular segment beside the prostomium
Elytra: Fifteen pairs; each elytron covered with a very delicate felt
Notosetae: Notosetae of elytrigerous segments: stouter, with long harpoon-setae; notosetae of cirrigerous segments: more slender, without harpoon-setae
Neurosetae: With a spur at the base of the feathered apex
Cirri: Ventral cirri small and weak, never reaching the bases of the inferior neurosetae
Geographical distribution:  Subantarctic

Species name: Aphrodita alta Kinberg, 1855
Body: Oval, about 30 mm long, ventrally flattened with 37–40 segments; posterior segments taper but do not form a distinct tail
Antenna: Median antenna small and slender, with a slight subapical swelling
Prostomium: Rounded, bearing large ocular swellings with light pigmentation
Felt: Well developed; nearly obscures the short acicular notosetae
Parapodia: Short, stout, and papillose
Notosetae: Tips hooked; shafts finely hairy proximally and minutely nodular distally
Neuropodial setae: Brown spines, each with a bent, pilose tip
Ventrum: Papillose
Geographical distribution: Brazil, Senegal, Antarctica

Species name: Pontogenia chrysocoma Baird, 1865
Body: Oblong, up to 40 mm long with 34 segments; dorsum arched and dark brown
Ventrum: Ventrum and parapodia papillose
Prostomium: Small, bearing four eyes on a pair of divergent peduncles; median antenna composed of four unequal joints
Facial tubercle: Papillose
Elytra: Fifteen pairs, each with a few small chitinous tubercles
Notosetae: Large erect sabre-like paleae, dentate along the convex margin, few short capillaries, bundle of very long, fine capillaries forming the felt
Neurosetae: Few, stout, with a very small spur just below the apex
Geographical distribution: Mediterranean; Zanzibar; Madagascar; Morocco

Species name: Iphione muricata Savigny, 1818
Body: Oval, dorsally arched, up to 20 mm long with 29 segments; dorsum fully covered by 13 pairs of tough, imbricating elytra
Prostomium: Square, deeply bilobed; lateral antennae terminal with large ceratophores fused to the facial tubercle; median antenna reduced to a small papilla in a postero-dorsal position, usually hidden beneath the nuchal fold
Eyes: Small; both pairs positioned posteriorly
Elytra: Thirteen pairs; large, reniform, tough; surface divided into punctate polygonal areas bearing one or two rows of stout chitinous projections and long adhesive papillae near the posterior margin
Cirri: Dorsal and ventral cirri papillose
Notosetae: Numerous very fine biserrate capillaries
Neurosetae: Neuropodium large and truncate, with numerous stout unidentate setae ornamented by transverse striations
Geographical distribution: Red Sea; Indo-Pacific region, including Madagascar, Zanzibar, the Philippines, and Japan

Species name: Alentia australis Monro, 1936
Body: Elongate, flattened, exceeding 95 mm in length with more than 59 segments
Prostomium: Lateral antennae terminal; median antenna more dorsally placed; two pairs of large lateral eyes; antennae smooth and about three times the prostomial length; palps long; facial tubercle prominent; occipital flap large
Cirri: Dorsal cirri long and smooth
Elytra: Large, smooth, with scattered small three-pronged tubercles
Notopodium: Small, bearing a few long, smooth capillaries
Neuropodium: Large and pointed; superior neurosetae slender, lanceolate, with denticulate tips; inferior neurosetae numerous, bidentate, with smooth slanting pockets along the blade
Geographical distribution: South Georgia and the Falkland Islands region

Species name: Macellicephala mirabilis McIntosh, 1885
Body: Purple, up to 30 mm long with 18 segments
Prostomium: Bears a pair of large, forward-projecting lobes, each with minute lateral antennae (often broken); median antenna very large, smooth, arising dorsally; no eyes
Elytra: Nine to ten pairs; cover the dorsum; deciduous and structurally unknown
Cirri: Dorsal cirri long, smooth, slightly expanded distally
Notosetae: Few, stout, lacking serrations; tentacular segment without setae
Neurosetae: Long, with slightly expanded spear-shaped tips and weak serrations; no secondary tooth
nephridial papillae: Large nephridial papillae present on segments 10–12
Geographical distribution: South Georgia; New Zealand; North Atlantic; North Pacific

Species name: Pareulepis geayi Fauvel, 1918
Body: Oblong, up to 35 mm long with 36–38 setigers; white
Prostomium: Broader than long, recessed between the anterior segments and medially attached to an overlying fold of setiger 2; median antenna ovoid and dorsally inserted; lateral antennae conical and terminal
Eyes: Absent or reduced to faint dark pigment
Elytra: Twelve pairs, tough and glabrous, increasing in length posteriorly; the 12th elytron is 2–3× longer than broad; the first pair bears 3–4 soft papillae near the anterior margin; subsequent elytra have 10–12 non-jointed digitiform processes along the external margin, with the 12th elytron carrying 15–18 processes
Cirri: Dorsal cirrophores large with ventral ridges; dorsal cirri small, conical, smooth; ventral cirri small and ovoid with a terminal filament; anal cirri extremely long and slender
Notopodium: Short; setiger 1 with all long silky notosetae; subsequent notosetae include long silky capillaries (some spinulose) and stout brown setae with a flattened spathulate tip bent at right angles to the shaft
Neuropodium: Truncate, with the aciculum expanded distally; neurosetae include one superior pectinate seta and numerous large recurved setae tapering to fine unidentate tips
Geographical distribution: Indo–West Pacific; Red Sea; Madagascar; New Caledonia

Species name: Paralepidonotus ampulliferus Grube, 1878
Body: Oblong, up to 17 mm long with 38 segments, mostly covered by 15 pairs of elytra
Prostomium: Lacks lateral peaks; lateral antennae inserted subterminally below the level of the median antenna; anterior eyes lateral and positioned well back; median antenna slender and about 1.5× the prostomial length; lateral antennae about three-quarters the prostomial length
Cirri: Dorsal cirri long, reaching the tips of the neurosetae; antennae and cirri papillose
Elytra: Oval with a small marginal fringe; surface bearing numerous small tubercles, some with two or three blunt projections; posterior margin with a series of large pear-shaped vesicles
Ventral structures: Ventral lamellae conspicuous
Notosetae: Numerous and coarsely serrated, ending in blunt tips
Neurosetae: Slender and mainly bidentate, with the fine secondary tooth nearly as long as the terminal tooth
Geographical distribution: Red Sea; tropical Indo-Pacific from Mombasa to the Philippine Islands

Species name: Paralepidonotus indicus Potts, 1910
Body: Oblong, up to 16 mm long with 36 segments, completely covered by 15 pairs of elytra
Prostomium: Without lateral peaks; lateral antennae inserted subterminally; eyes large, with the anterior pair antero-lateral; median antenna about three times the prostomial length; lateral antennae about twice the prostomial length
Cirri and antennae: Antennae and dorsal cirri slender, densely papillose, each bearing a subterminal swelling; ventral lamellae present
Elytra: Each elytron with a transverse arc of dark pigment and densely covered with small dark spines; posterior margin fringed with papillae; no large vesicles present
Notosetae: Stout and spinulose to their tips
Neurosetae: Slender, with long blades bearing multiple rows of spinules; tips bidentate; secondary tooth most developed in the mid-series, where it is straight and slender
Geographical distribution: Maldives

Species name: Malmgrenia purpurea Day, 1960
Body: Oblong, up to 17 mm long with 38 segments; purple
Prostomium: Longer than broad, with rather small eyes; anterior pair lateral and positioned about halfway back; median antenna very stout and as long as the prostomium; lateral antennae about half that length; facial tubercle well developed
Tentacular cirri: Short, each bearing a single seta
Antennae and cirri: Smooth, swollen, and darkly pigmented
Elytra: Oval with smooth margins; surface smooth except for a small anterior patch of rounded tubercles
Notopodium: Small, with about 12 setae
Neuropodium: Large, each with a pointed presetal lip; ventral lamellae rudimentary
Notosetae: Stout, curved, transparent; convex margin lightly serrated; tip abruptly pointed
Neurosetae: Numerous, fairly short and slender; blades with ~25 rows of fine spinules; tips sharp and hooked, some with a minute secondary tooth
Ecology: Probably commensal with Spatangus capensis
Geographical distribution:  (South Africa)

Species name: Malmgrenia marquesensis Monro, 1928
Body: Oblong, up to 20 mm long; fresh specimens with mauve markings, preserved specimens mottled brown with a white transverse ridge across each segment
Prostomium: Hexagonal; anterior pair of eyes large and positioned halfway back on lateral prominences; median antenna longer than the prostomium; lateral antennae inserted subterminally, strongly tapered, and borne on broad ceratophores; facial tubercle well developed; palps stout; tentacular cirri slender
Cirri and antennae: Antennae and cirri smooth; dorsal cirri evenly tapered and reaching the ends of the neurosetae
Elytra: Fifteen pairs, oval to rounded, covering the dorsum; smooth except for a small anterior patch of rounded tubercles; posterior elytra may be missing and their positions sticky with adherent sand grains
Notosetae: Sabre-like, with a single row of 8–12 denticles on the distal third of the blade and an abruptly pointed tip
Neurosetae: Bidentate and slenderer than the notosetae; superior series with long, well-marked spinous rows and tips truncate with two subequal teeth; inferior series with shorter, less distinct spinous rows, a more hooked terminal tooth, and a much smaller secondary tooth
Ecology: Commensal with the asteroid Linckia multiforis
Geographical distribution: South Pacific

Species name: Gastrolepidia clavigera Schmarda, 1861
Body: Up to 30 mm long; purple when fresh, fading to dark brown in alcohol
Prostomium: Bilobed without frontal peaks; anterior eyes lateral and positioned halfway back; median antenna with a subterminal swelling about half the prostomial size; lateral antennae slightly smaller; occipital fold well developed
Antennae and cirri: Smooth, each with a pear-shaped swelling just before the filiform tip
Elytra: Twenty-one pairs, large, oval to reniform; margins smooth; surface without tubercles or papillae but bearing white blister-like swellings near the posterior margin
Ventral structures: Ventral lamella broad and rounded, as wide as the segment is long at the base of each parapodium
Notopodium / Notosetae: Notopodia well developed; notosetae serrated to their blunt tips
Neuropodium / Neurosetae: Neuropodia large; neurosetae unidentate with slightly hooked tips
Ecology: Commensal with Holothuria atra
Geographical distribution: Tropical Indo-West Pacific, from Sri Lanka and Madagascar to New Caledonia

Species name: Acholoe squamosa Delle Chiaje, 1825
Body: Very long and fragile, reaching about 50 mm with more than 100 segments
Prostomium: With frontal peaks; lateral antennae inserted subterminally; median antenna short and tapered; antennae and cirri bearing a few small papillae; occipital collar present
Elytra: Up to 45 pairs covering the dorsum; each oval with smooth margins; surface glabrous except for a small anterior patch of rounded tubercles
Cirri: Dorsal cirri short; cirrigerous segments possess T-shaped ciliated processes aligned with the elytrophores
Notosetae: Few, curved, weakly serrated, and bluntly pointed
Neurosetae: Stout and unidentate, with a few weak spinous rows and a long, curved, sharply pointed apex
Ecology: Commensal with asteroids
Geographical distribution: English Channel; Mediterranean; Angola

Species name: Polyeunoa laevis McIntosh, 1885
Body: Elongate and flattened, up to 35 mm long with about 80 segments; pale with intermittent reddish cross-bars
Prostomium: Bilobed with prominent frontal peaks; lateral antennae inserted ventrally; median antenna extremely long (about five times prostomial length); lateral antennae about twice the prostomial length; anterior eyes lateral and positioned halfway back
Antennae and cirri: Long, slender, and smooth
Elytra: About 20 pairs; deciduous; oval with entire margins and a glabrous surface
Notopodium: Notopodium small and pointed; notosetae few, stout, weakly serrated, and ending in long pointed tips
Neuropodium: Neuropodium large and pointed; neurosetae numerous, long, with rows of small spinules and long blade-shaped tips, occasionally bearing a minute secondary tooth
Geographical distribution: Antarctic and Subantarctic

Species name: Polynoe erythrotaenia Schmarda, 1861
Body: About 50 mm long with numerous segments; posterior naked segments bear lateral rows of swellings but lack a median row
Prostomium: Roughly square with poorly defined frontal peaks; anterior eyes partly hidden beneath the peaks; lateral antennae about equal to the prostomial length; median antenna about half as long
Antennae and cirri: Covered with small clavate papillae
Elytra: Half dark and half pale; a few small chitinous tubercles near the anterior margin
Notosetae: Few (4–8), stout, blunt, and weakly serrated
Neurosetae: Stout, unidentate, with a few rows of spinules

Species name: Polynoe scolopendrina Savigny, 1822
Body: About 50 mm long with numerous segments; anterior half covered with speckled elytra, posterior half naked; each posterior segment bears a median swelling and two lateral swellings, often pigmented
Prostomium: Hexagonal; large anterior eyes positioned well forward and often hidden by small prostomial peaks; median antenna about twice the prostomial length; lateral antennae slightly shorter than the prostomium
Antennae and cirri: With short papillae
Elytra: Speckled and blotched; external margin bearing a microscopic fringe; surface with conical chitinous tubercles
Notosetae: Numerous, serrated, and tapered
Neurosetae: Strongly bidentate; in posterior feet of adults, one or two superior neurosetae become enlarged and unidentate and may lose their spinules
Geographical distribution: North Atlantic from Scotland to Senegal; Mediterranean; Red Sea

Species name: Antinoe epitoca Monro, 1930
Body: About 30 mm long with 36 segments
Prostomium: Bilobed; large anterior eyes positioned immediately below the prostomial peaks and above the bases of the small lateral antennae; median antenna about twice the prostomial length; lateral antennae about three-quarters the prostomial length
Antennae and cirri: Smooth; dorsal cirri arise from large cirrophores, cirrostyles long and tapered
Elytra: Large, oval, with entire margins and smooth surfaces
Notopodium: Notosetae numerous, long, fine, and minutely serrated, though some may appear smooth
Neuropodium: Neuropodium with a pointed presetal lobe; neurosetae with numerous rows of small weak spinules and long, tapering, hair-like tips
Geographical distribution: Angola

Species name: Antinoe lactea Day, 1953
Body: Broad and flattened, up to 40 mm long with 36 segments; creamy white with crescentic brown markings on the large elytra
Prostomium: Small with poorly developed peaks; small eyes; anterior pair of eyes positioned posterior to the prostomial peaks; median antenna slender and about twice the prostomial length; lateral antennae about three-quarters the prostomial length; palps short and stout
Cirri: Dorsal cirri long and slender
Elytra: Fifteen pairs, completely covering the dorsum; large, oval, smooth except for a small anterior patch of minute tubercles
Notopodium: Notosetae of varied lengths; shorter ones fairly stout; longer ones slender and closely serrated to fine tips
Neuropodium: Neuropodium with a long, pointed presetal lip; neurosetae strongly spinulose, tapering to long fine hair-like tips

Species name: Scalisetosus longicirrus Schmarda, 1861
Body: Up to 15 mm long with 45–50 segments; anterior end narrowed; dorsum arched and often bearing two dark longitudinal stripes
Prostomium: Brown, markedly bilobed without frontal peaks; anterior eyes set well back and lateral; median antenna about twice the prostomial length; lateral antennae shorter, arising ventrally
Antennae and cirri: Smooth, slender, tapering to delicate tips; dorsal cirri extremely long, projecting to more than twice the length of the neurosetae
Elytra: About 15 pairs covering most of the dorsum, leaving ~12 posterior segments naked; individual elytra delicate with entire margins, smooth surfaces except for a few anterior small tubercles; coloration mauve with clear specks
Notopodium: short and pointed; notosetae sabre-shaped with three to four small serrations or entirely smooth, terminating in stumpy bidentate tips
Neuropodium: large, with a triangular presetal lobe and a shorter rounded postsetal lip; neurosetae of two types: a few superior slender setae with faint serrations and bidentate tips, and numerous inferior setae with falcate unidentate tips and only slight serration traces beyond the spinous pocket
Ecology: Commensal with crinoids (Tropiometra carinata and Lamprometra klunzingeri)
Geographical distribution: Japan; tropical Indian Ocean; Red Sea

Species name: Scalisetosus fragilis Claparède, 1868
Body: Short, depressed, extremely fragile, about 15 mm long
Prostomium: Bilobed with rudimentary frontal peaks; anterior eyes large and positioned well back on the sides of the prostomium; median antenna about three times the prostomial length; lateral antennae only slightly longer than the prostomium
Antennae and cirri: With short papillae and very long terminal filaments; dorsal cirri long, extending well beyond the neurosetae
Elytra: Oval, delicate, and strongly deciduous; when present, completely cover the body; surface covered with numerous minutes, weakly chitinised pedunculate tubercles and occasionally a few large spherical vesicles; margins with a very fine fringe
Notopodium: short and stout; notosetae stout with ~10 coarse serrations, the basal serrations particularly enlarged; tips pointed and minutely flanged
Neuropodium: long and pointed; neurosetae long, very transparent, with a large basal spinous pocket followed by additional pockets diminishing to coarse serrations distally; each neuroseta ends in a strong curved terminal tooth with a smaller secondary tooth
Geographical distribution: Atlantic from Scotland, North Carolina, and the English Channel south to Madeira and Morocco; Mediterranean; Indian Ocean including Maldives and Andaman Islands

Species name: Gattyana mossambica Day, 1962
Body: Pale, up to 15 mm long with 45 segments
Prostomium: First pair of eyes positioned well forward and ventro-lateral to the prostomial peaks; lateral antennae about half the prostomial length; median antenna about twice the prostomial length
Antennae and cirri: Antennae and cirri with tapered tips and minute papillae; dorsal cirri short, flattened, and not reaching the tips of the neurosetae
Elytra: Fifteen pairs covering most of the dorsum; each with a network of brown pigment markings and smooth margins, Anterior elytra densely covered with minute rounded tubercles, Posterior elytra with only a small anterior patch of rounded tubercles
Notosetae: much finer than neurosetae; appear smooth but bear very close-set minute serrations extending to the fine hairlike tips
Neurosetae: with ~15 rows of delicate spinules almost to the blade tips; two superior neurosetae unidentate with tapered tips; remaining neurosetae bidentate; blade ends short and broad, appearing split because the secondary tooth is nearly as large as the apical one
Geographical distribution: Mozambique

Species name: Eunoe hubrechti McIntosh, 1900
Body: Brown, up to 25 mm long; adults with 46 segments, planktonic juveniles with fewer than 30; posterior segments tapered, with the last 9–10 segments lacking elytra
Prostomium: With frontal peaks; first pair of eyes large and positioned about one-third of the way back; median antenna very long and slender; lateral antennae shorter, about twice the prostomial length
Antennae and cirri: All antennae and cirri smooth; dorsal cirri long and slender
Elytra: Pale, with smooth margins; surface covered with numerous minute conical tubercles; do not extend over the last 9–10 segments
Notosetae: very long, stout, and held stiffly erect; crystalline in appearance; serrations reduced to ridges that half encircle the shaft, leaving the long pointed tips naked
Neurosetae: slender, transparent, with long blades bearing numerous rows of spinules; tips long and naked, usually unidentate but sometimes with a minute secondary tooth
Pygidium: bearing a voluminous caudal appendage
Geographical distribution: Atlantic Ocean from Greenland to the Antarctic; species bathypelagic

Species name: Eunoe assimilis McIntosh, 1925
Body: Broad but tapering posteriorly; up to 30 mm long with 30–70 segments
Prostomium: With small frontal peaks; no eyes present; palps long
Antennae: Lateral antennae strongly ventral in origin, about 1.5× the prostomial length; Median antenna antero-dorsal, borne on a stout ceratophore, with a very slender ceratostyle more than three times the prostomial length
Antennae and cirri: Appearing smooth but actually bearing very short papillae
Elytra: Large, delicate, mainly pale with smooth margins; each bearing a patch of small rounded tubercles near the anterior margin
Dorsal cirri: Tapered, reaching the ends of the neurosetae
Notosetae: Few, very stout, with close-set rows of extremely weak serrations; tips long, pointed, and almost blade-like
Neurosetae: Few, unidentate; blades short and somewhat swollen, with ~20 rows of short spinules before the long, slightly hooked naked tip; no secondary tooth present

Species name: Eunoe macrophthalma McIntosh, 1925
Body: Short and slightly tapered
Prostomium / Eyes: Eyes extremely large, covering most of the prostomium; lateral antennae short
Antennae and cirri: Dorsal cirri very long and slender; antennae and cirri otherwise slender and smooth (no additional ornamentation mentioned)
Elytra: Diaphanous, smooth, entire-margined; each bearing a patch of minute tubercles
Notosetae: Stout, with rows of small serrations
Neurosetae: Unidentate, with weakly marked spinules; long, almost straight tips lacking any secondary tooth
Geographical distribution: South Atlantic west of Cape Town at ~2200 m; known from a single specimen

Species name: Harmothoe dictyophora Grube, 1878
Body: Up to 25 mm long with 36 segments; dorsum fully covered by 15 pairs of tough brown elytra
Prostomium: With well-defined frontal peaks; anterior eyes lateral; lateral antennae slightly longer than the prostomium; median antenna about twice the prostomial length
Antennae and cirri: Densely clothed with long papillae
Elytra: Large and tough, surface divided into polygonal areas; densely covered with conical chitinous tubercles of various sizes, including large multi-pointed spines (2–3 points); margins densely fringed with long papillae
Notosetae: Very numerous, strongly serrated, ending in long pointed tips
Neurosetae: Strongly bidentate, with the secondary tooth positioned well back along the blade
Geographical distribution: Tropical Indo-Pacific; Red Sea

Species name: Harmothoe antilopis McIntosh, 1876
Body: Up to 25 mm long with 35 segments; flesh pink in alcohol; elytra pale
Prostomium: Hexagonal; large anterior eyes positioned immediately below the small prostomial peaks; median antenna ~1.4× prostomial length; lateral antennae just over half the prostomial length, markedly tapered and papillose
Antennae and cirri: Dorsal cirri about as long as the neurosetae; antennae and cirri covered with slender papillae
Elytra: Large, oval; lateral margins fringed with slender papillae; surface bears a few soft papillae but primarily covered with numerous cylindrical tubercles, each with 4–5 blunt projections giving a crown-like appearance; additional tubercles near the posterior margin capstan-shaped, ornamented with three saucer-like depressions with raised rims
Notosetae: Stout, with a close-set series of strong serrations extending almost to the faintly flanged tips
Neurosetae: Blades with 15–20 rows of fine spinules; tips bidentate in the superior series, with a broad, blade-like terminal tooth and a much shorter secondary tooth; inferior neurosetae become unidentate
Geographical distribution: North Atlantic from Sweden to Senegal; Mediterranean

Species name: Harmothoe gilchristi Day, 1960
Body: Oblong, up to 16 mm long with 38 segments; elytra extend to within six segments of the pygidium
Prostomium: With large frontal peaks; first pair of eyes lateral and positioned halfway back; lateral antennae about three-quarters the prostomial length; median antenna about twice the prostomial length
Antennae and cirri: Papillose, each marked with two dark transverse bands
Elytra: Mottled brown; surface densely covered with truncate-cylindrical or capstan-shaped tubercles; margins with a small fringe
Notosetae: Numerous, strongly serrated, ending in blunt tips with a shallow longitudinal groove
Neurosetae: Bidentate; blades fairly long, with ~15 rows of well-developed spinules preceding the long naked tip; terminal tooth strong; secondary tooth long and slender
Geographical distribution:  to South Africa

Species name: Harmothoe goreensis Augener, 1918
Body: Small, about 10 mm long with 35–36 segments; body rusty brown; cirrophores conspicuously dark
Prostomium: With sharp frontal peaks; anterior eyes lateral and positioned nearly halfway back; median antenna about twice the prostomial length; lateral antennae about one-third the length of the median
Antennae and cirri: Papillose
Elytra: Fifteen to sixteen pairs covering the dorsum; oval, brown with a central dark spot or ring; margins fringed with papillae; surface bearing a few soft papillae and numerous short, bluntly conical tubercles
Notosetae: Stout and strongly serrated; tips flanged and pointed
Neurosetae: Strongly bidentate with a broad terminal tooth and a straight secondary tooth ~half its length; inferior neurosetae with a weak or absent secondary tooth
Geographical distribution: Senegal; Angola; records also from South West Africa, Cape region, Natal, and Mozambique

Species name: Harmothoe lagiscoides serrata Day, 1963
Body: Pale brown, tapering posteriorly, about 20 mm long
Prostomium: With well-defined frontal peaks; first pair of eyes lateral and positioned halfway back; lateral antennae ventral in origin, tapered, papillose, and about two-thirds the prostomial length; median antenna not observed
Antennae and cirri: Dorsal cirri long, extending beyond the neurosetal tips and covered with long papillae; ventral cirri very small
Elytra: Large, delicate, mottled brown; surface with a few long slender papillae; postero-lateral margins densely fringed with numerous papillae; elytral tubercles consist of sharp curved thorns of uniform size except for a row of larger thorns along the posterior margin
Notosetae: Strongly serrated with pointed tips
Neurosetae: With ≥20 well-developed spinules; distal ends long, naked, and blade-like; tips bidentate
Geographical distribution: South Africa

Species name: Harmothoe saldanha Day, 1953
Body: Oblong, about 25 mm long with 39 segments; colour pale with a brown arc on each elytron; after the first three pairs, elytra no longer meet across the dorsum, leaving most of the back exposed
Prostomium: With blunt frontal peaks; first pair of eyes positioned well back; median antenna large; lateral antennae short
Antennae and cirri: Dorsal cirri shorter than the neuropodia; antennae and cirri sparsely covered with a few lumpy papillae
Elytra: Oval, longer than broad; smooth surface without marginal fringe; in midbody too small to contact each other, exposing most of the dorsum
Nephridial papillae: Well developed, with conspicuously swollen bases
Notosetae: About 10–12 per fascicle; short, weakly serrated, with long blunt tips
Neurosetae: Strongly bidentate, the secondary tooth nearly as long as the terminal one; in middle and posterior segments, the superior neuroseta becomes stouter and darker, lacks spinules, and transforms into an unidentate form
Geographical distribution:  to South Africa

Species name: Harmothoe lunulata Delle Chiaje, 1841
Body: Up to 35 mm long with 39 segments; broad; dorsum completely covered by 15 pairs of large elytra
Prostomium: Brownish with small frontal peaks; eyes well separated, first pair antero-lateral; lateral antennae short and strongly tapered
Antennae and cirri: Antennae and cirri sparsely beset with small clavate papillae; dorsal cirri short and banded near the tip
Elytra: Large, oval, longer than broad; surface glabrous and entire except for a few minute anterior tubercles; pale with a central spot and an incomplete crescentic ring of brown pigment
Notosetae: Short, serrated to their blunt tips
Neurosetae: Fine, with short blades; strongly bidentate, the secondary tooth long and aligned with the shaft
Ecology: Commonly commensal with tubicolous polychaetes
Geographical distribution: Atlantic coasts of Europe (North Sea to Mediterranean); western Canada to southern California; southern Arabian region; also recorded from South West Africa, Cape region, Natal, and Mozambique

Species name: Harmothoe fraseri-thomsoni McIntosh, 1897
Body: Pale, relatively broad, up to 20 mm long with 39–40 segments; dorsum fully covered by 15 pairs of elytra
Prostomium: With well-marked frontal peaks; first pair of eyes positioned well back; palps large; median antenna slender and about twice the prostomial length; lateral antennae about equal to the prostomium
Antennae and cirri: With a few small papillae; dorsal cirri long, bearing a subterminal brown band
Elytra: Large and delicate with smooth margins; surface bearing a few small anterior tubercles and large blister-like swellings with a central nipple posterolaterally
Notosetae: Numerous, closely serrated, ending in short blunt tips
Neurosetae: Strongly bidentate; secondary tooth much smaller than the terminal one and diverging outward
Geographical distribution: Ireland; Plymouth; Cape Verde Islands; Mediterranean; also recorded from the Cape region (South Africa)

Species name: Harmothoe agulhana Day, 1960
Body: Up to 12 mm long with 36 segments; pale, with speckled elytra covering the dorsum
Prostomium: With small frontal peaks; first pair of eyes lateral; lateral antennae short and stumpy; median antenna tapered and about equal to the prostomial length; tentacular cirri slender
Antennae and cirri: Sparsely covered with clavate papillae
Elytra: Large, thin, speckled, reniform; surface with an anteromedial patch of small chitinous tubercles and scattered weakly chitinised blister-like tubercles elsewhere; margins smooth
Notosetae: Densely serrated all the way to their blunt tips
Neurosetae: With a strong terminal tooth and a slender secondary tooth about three-quarters the length of the terminal tooth
Geographical distribution:  to South Africa

Species name: Harmothoe profunda Day, 1963
Body: 15–20 mm long with 35 segments; dorsum dark, elytra and parapodia pale
Prostomium: With distinct frontal peaks; eyes large, first pair positioned well back and lateral; median antenna not observed; lateral antennae small, about half the prostomial length
Antennae and cirri: Sparsely clothed with long papillae; dorsal cirri extending to the tips of the neurosetae
Elytra: Fifteen pairs covering the dorsum; rounded to oval; surface densely tuberculate, with tubercles increasing in size posteriorly—from small blunt cones anteriorly to large almost spherical tubercles near the posterior margin; largest tubercles smooth, smaller ones rugose or with blunt projections; margins with a few small papillae
Notopodium: well developed; notosetae much stouter than neurosetae; strongly serrated with blunt flanged tips
Neuropodium: Long blades with 15–20 rows of spinules; tips bidentate with a strong terminal tooth and a straight secondary tooth about half its length
Geographical distribution: Known only from deep water west of Cape Town (∼2000 m)

Species name: Drieschia pelagica Michaelsen, 1892
Body: Translucent, 5–8 mm long with ~30 segments
Prostomium: Swollen posteriorly; first pair of eyes positioned well back; median antenna slender and more than twice the prostomial length; lateral antennae shorter
Antennae and cirri: Dorsal cirri with very long swollen cirrophores and slender cirrostyles
Elytra: Deciduous, delicate, smooth; elytrophores stout
Notopodium: Notopodium reduced to a small papilla containing the aciculum; no notosetae present
Neuropodium: Presetal and postsetal lips equal; Superior neurosetae very slender with microscopic serrations; Inferior neurosetae shorter and stouter, with tapered unidentate blades and 5–6 weak spinous rows
Geographical distribution: Indo–West Pacific; planktonic; recorded from Ceylon and Natal

Species name: Euphione elisabethae McIntosh, 1885
Body: Broad, oval, up to 46 mm long with 26 segments
Prostomium: Both pairs of eyes large, posterior, and close together; antennae long with small subterminal swellings; nuchal fold prominent
Elytra: Twelve pairs, large, tough, reniform; lateral and posterior margins with a short fringe of papillae; surface bearing large pedunculate tubercles, often expanded into daisy-like forms
Cirrigerous segments / paraelytrophores: Cirrigerous segments possess paraelytrophores
Branchiae: Segments 3–20 with ~3 small branchial papillae each
Nephridial papillae: Well developed
Notosetae: Numerous, long, fine, silky, with blades completely ringed by minute spinules
Neurosetae: Stout, unidentate, with long fine spinules giving the blades a distinctly bearded appearance
Geographical distribution:  to South Africa (Cape region; 275 m and deeper)

Species name: Hermenia acantholepis Grube, 1875
Body: Up to 30 mm long; chestnut-brown elytra; exposed dorsum warty; ventrum with minute papillae
Prostomium: Anterior eyes lateral; median antenna ~1.5× prostomial length; lateral antennae ~prostomial length; palps short; facial tubercle well developed
Antennae and cirri: Distally banded; each with a subterminal swelling and slender terminal tip
Elytra: Relatively small; only first 2–3 pairs overlap, posterior ones widely separated; individual elytra subcircular; external margin with a fringe of small papillae; surface with very large tubercles—central ones flattened, marginal ones ovoid and projecting beyond the edge
Notosetae: Few, weak, with minute serrations extending to the tapered tip
Neurosetae: Uniformly stout; spinous blade reduced to faint transverse striations; base of terminal tooth bearing a pair of stout spines; terminal tooth long; no secondary tooth
Geographical distribution: Tropical Indo–West Pacific from the Philippines and Samoa to Sri Lanka and Madagascar

Species name: Lepidonotus (Thormora) jukesii Baird, 1865
Body: Oblong, up to 25 mm long; pale dorsum with dark pigment medially between elytra
Prostomium: Anterior region grey; first pair of eyes well back; second pair small and often concealed by the nuchal fold; lateral antennae ≈ prostomial length; median antenna ~1.5× prostomial length
Antennae and cirri: Smooth; each bearing a dark-pigmented subterminal swelling
Elytra: Tough, not fringed; mainly dark grey; surface with small conical tubercles—best developed centrally and forming a marginal row; tubercles larger on anterior elytra
Notosetae: Three groups present; Outer palisade: short, curved setae with close-set serrations to blunt tips; Inner palisade: long, smooth setae with hastate (spear-shaped) tips; Central tuft: very long, fine setae resembling the inner palisade
Neurosetae: Stout; blades with 8–12 rows of spinules; tips long, naked, unidentate
Geographical distribution: Indo–West Pacific—from the Red Sea to the Philippines; also recorded from Mozambique, Madagascar, New Zealand, and Japan

Species name: Lepidonotus tenuisetosus Gravier, 1901
Body: Oblong, up to 15 mm long
Prostomium: Longer than broad; first pair of eyes lateral and positioned well back
Antennae and cirri: Smooth with a subterminal swelling and a dark band; median antenna ~2× prostomial length; lateral antennae shorter
Elytra: Margins fringed; surface densely covered with innumerable small conical tubercles—largest centrally, often with blunt projections giving a star-shaped appearance
Parapodia: Short, stout; neuropodia bilabiate
Notosetae: Numerous, slender, spinulose to tapered tips
Neurosetae: Stout; tips minutely bidentate or unidentate
Geographical distribution: Tropical West Africa; Red Sea; Indo–West Pacific to Japan; records from South Africa, Mozambique, and Madagascar

Species name: Lepidonotus cristatus Grube, 1876
Body: Large and stout, up to ~40 mm long
Prostomium: Longer than broad; partly covered by a square occipital fold; anterior eyes large and well back; posterior eyes smaller, closer together, often hidden by the fold
Antennae and cirri: Median and lateral antennae subequal, ~2× prostomial length, on long ceratophores; smooth with subterminal swellings; dorsal cirri similar in form and reaching the tips of the neurosetae
Elytra: Without marginal fringes; elytra palette-shaped with a dark mark over the elytrophore and two large soft cushions; surface covered with numerous conical tubercles; cirrigerous segments bear swellings corresponding to elytrophores
Notosetae: Finely and closely serrated, ending in short tips
Neurosetae: Stout, with ~24 rows of spinules minute proximally, enlarging distally; tips long and hooked; mostly unidentate, but some with a minute secondary tooth
Geographical distribution: Red Sea and tropical Indo–West Pacific; records from Mozambique and Madagascar

Species name: Lepidonotus glaucus Peters, 1854
Body: Up to ~20 mm long; blue-grey
Prostomium: Longer than broad; anterior eyes lateral and well back; median antenna smooth and ~2.5× prostomial length; lateral antennae slightly shorter
Antennae and cirri: Dorsal cirri often flattened, evenly tapered, lacking subterminal swellings; antennae smooth
Elytra: Brown or blue; margins smooth; surface with scattered squat ridged tubercles appearing as pale spots; often two posteriorly directed ridges from the elytrophore bearing larger keeled tubercles
Notosetae: Few (~10), small; longer ones denticulate to their tapering tips
Neurosetae: Stout and bidentate; strongly denticulate in anterior segments, weakly so posteriorly
Geographical distribution: Red Sea and tropical Indian Ocean; type locality Mozambique

Species name: Lepidonotus purpureus Potts, 1910
Body: Up to ~20 mm long; mauve, each elytron with a central white spot
Prostomium: Hexagonal with long cirrophores; anterior eyes lateral and well separated from the posterior pair; median antenna ~2.5× prostomial length; lateral antennae ~2× prostomial length; occipital fold well developed with lateral ridges
Antennae and cirri: Smooth with slight subterminal swellings
Elytra: Not fringed; smooth except for scattered minute ovoid tubercles that appear as refringent dots among pale and dark pigment cells
Notosetae: Small, closely serrated to their fine tips
Neurosetae: Stout, with short spinulose blades; tips clearly bidentate
Geographical distribution: Tropical Indian Ocean; also recorded from Australia and New Zealand; type locality Zanzibar

Species name: Lepidonotus semitectus Stimpson, 1856
Body: Tough, rusty brown; up to ~40 mm long; head and first elytra often paler than the rest; mid-dorsum not fully covered by elytra
Prostomium: Longer than broad; first pair of eyes well back; second pair often hidden beneath the occipital fold; median antenna slightly longer than prostomium; lateral antennae slightly shorter
Antennae and cirri: Smooth with a subterminal swelling and dark band before the filiform tip
Elytra: Tough, oval, entire; surface with cylindro-conical tubercles longest and minutely granulose on the first 2–3 elytra, becoming ovoid posteriorly
Notosetae: Fairly numerous; short; blades with close-set small serrations leading to long sharply pointed tips
Neurosetae: With ~7 rows of spinules and strong curved unidentate tips; no true secondary tooth, though the last spinule may mimic one
Geographical distribution:  to southern Africa South West Africa, Cape region, and Natal; common under stones and in rocky dredgings

Species name: Lepidonotus durbanensis Day, 1934
Body: Tough, grey, up to ~30 mm long; elytra reddish brown
Prostomium: Longer than broad; first pair of eyes positioned halfway back; median antenna ~2× prostomial length; lateral antennae ~1.5× prostomial length
Antennae and cirri: Smooth with a dark band at the subterminal swelling
Elytra: Oval with smooth margins; surface densely covered with large spherical tubercles of varying size largest sculptured like “golf balls,” smaller tubercles with minutely scaly surfaces
Notosetae: Small, closely serrated to their fine filiform tips
Neurosetae: Very stout, with short spinulose blades and curved unidentate tips; last spinule strong and may mimic a secondary tooth
Geographical distribution:  to South Africa; recorded from Durban, Cape region, Natal, and Mozambique; common on rocky shores of Natal

Species name: Parahalosydna capensis McIntosh, 1885
Body: Oblong, ~25 mm long; 15 pairs of elytra covering all but the last 4–6 segments
Prostomium: All three antennae terminal in origin (as in Lepidonotus); lateral antennae smooth, ~⅔ prostomial length; median antenna unknown; anterior eyes lateral and positioned about halfway back
Antennae and cirri: Dorsal cirri smooth, slightly swollen distally, shorter than the neurosetae
Notopodium: Notopodium well developed; notosetae long, stout, finely serrated, with abruptly pointed tips
Neuropodium: Neuropodium long with a pointed presetal lip; neurosetae long, with weakly spinulose blades and bidentate tips, the secondary tooth very small
Geographical distribution: Cape of Good Hope region (single record)

Species name: Pseudopolynoe inhaca Day, 1951
Body: Elongate, tapered, up to ~45 mm long with ~78 segments; 16 pairs of elytra covering only the anterior half; posterior segments cirrigerous with three longitudinal rows of fleshy dorsal tubercles
Prostomium: Longer than broad; lateral ceratophores with basal constrictions; median antenna smooth with a slight subterminal swelling, ~2× prostomial length; lateral antennae shorter; palps short and stout
Antennae and cirri: Antennae smooth with faint subterminal swellings
Elytra: Oval, mottled grey, margins smooth; not large enough to cover the dorsal midline; surfaces glabrous except for a few small marginal tubercles
Notosetae: Few, weak, spinulose to their fine tapered tips
Neurosetae: Stout, with short blades and strongly bidentate tips
Geographical distribution: Only known from Mozambique (Inhaca Island region)

Species name: Halosydna (Hyperhalosydna) alleni Day, 1934
Body: Up to ~35 mm long with ~55 segments; 20–24 pairs of pale mottled grey elytra extending nearly to the posterior end
Prostomium: Rectangular; both eye pairs posterior and close together; all three antennae terminal; median antenna slightly longer than prostomium, lateral antennae ~⅔ prostomial length
Antennae and cirri: Smooth, slightly distally swollen, banded before the terminal filament
Elytra: Smooth margins; surfaces smooth and mottled
Notopodium: very small; notosetae 2–4 in number, minute, serrated to slender tapered tips
Neurosetae: large, mainly bidentate with short spinulose blades; in posterior parapodia of large individuals, a single giant superior neuroseta may be present unidentate and nearly without spinules
Geographical distribution:  to South Africa (Cape, Natal)

Species name: Lepidasthenia mossambica Day, 1962
Body: Very long, up to ~100 mm with ~150 segments; dorsum marked by regular brown cross-bars
Prostomium: Rectangular, partly overlapped by a large occipital fold with a papillose margin; first eyes well back and lateral; antennae slender with faint subterminal swellings — median ~2× prostomial length, laterals slightly shorter; palps very long
Cirri: Dorsal cirri tapered, just reaching the tips of the neurosetae
Elytra: Fifty-six pairs; rounded, smooth, not large enough to cover the dorsal midline; extend nearly to the posterior end; anteriorly alternate with cirri regularly, becoming irregular posteriorly; each elytron with a dark transverse bar from the elytrophore (reduced to a spot-on posterior elytra)
Parapodia: Bases of anterior parapodia papillose dorsally and ventrally
Notopodium: Notopodia very small; notosetae usually absent except occasionally on anterior feet; when present, few in number with ~15 rows of spinules and blunt, nearly truncate tips
Neurosetae: Neurosetae with ~10 rows of spinules and blunt unidentate tips; no superior slender neurosetae in anterior parapodia; no giant neurosetae in posterior parapodia
Geographical distribution: Known only from Mozambique (Inhaca Island region)

Species name: Lepidasthenia microlepis Potts, 1910
Body: ~25 mm long with ~65 segments; body irregularly banded brown
Prostomium: Large; anterior eyes lateral; median antenna ~1.5× prostomial length; lateral antennae slightly shorter
Cirri: Dorsal cirri pale, tapered, and longer than the neurosetae
Elytra: Nineteen pairs; first pair large and brown; subsequent pairs decrease rapidly in size, becoming very small and colourless posteriorly, reduced to caps on the elytrophores; margins smooth
Parapodia: Lacking papillae
Notopodium: Notopodia very small; notosetae absent
Neurosetae: Neurosetae with short spinulose blades; bidentate tips with a secondary tooth nearly equal to, and barely diverging from, the terminal tooth
Geographical distribution: Indo–West Pacific; recorded from Maldives, Mozambique, and South Africa (Natal)

Species name: Lepidasthenia elegans Grube, 1840
Body: Elongate, flattened; up to ~70 mm with ~100 segments; purple transverse bars; elytra speckled with a white spot over the elytrophore
Prostomium: Bilobed; eyes set well back; long antennae with banded subterminal swellings; small smooth nuchal fold
Cirri: Anterior dorsal cirri long with swellings; posterior cirri short
Elytra: Small, rounded, smooth, speckled; do not cover the dorsum
Parapodia: Lacking papillae
Notosetae: Usually absent; occasional weakly serrated seta anteriorly
Neurosetae: Superior slender setae in anterior feet (variable); numerous bidentate setae with a smaller secondary tooth; posterior feet with a giant brown unidentate superior seta
Ecology: Sometimes commensal in terebellid tubes
Geographical distribution: Mediterranean; Indo–West Pacific; South Africa, Mozambique, Madagascar

Species name: Lepidasthenia maculata Potts, 1910
Body: Elongate, flattened, up to ~70 mm with ~100 segments; purple transverse bars on most segments except alternate cirrigerous ones; elytra each with a central dark spot
Prostomium: Bilobed; eyes large; antennae long and slender without subterminal swellings; nuchal fold prominent, sometimes papillose
Cirri: Dorsal cirri long, extending beyond neurosetal tips
Elytra: ~30 pairs; extend along the whole body but do not cover the dorsal midline; smooth, oval, with a central dark spot
Parapodia: No papillae
Notopodium: reduced to a small conical papilla; notosetae rarely present
Neuropodium: large, bilabiate, obliquely truncate; neurosetae mainly bidentate, secondary tooth nearly as long as the terminal (giving a bifid appearance); anterior parapodia also bear 2–4 long fine superior setae with blunt tips; no enlarged superior neuroseta posteriorly
Ecology: Recorded as commensal in burrows of Dasybranchus caducus
Geographical distribution: North Atlantic (Scotland, Azores, Morocco, possibly North Carolina); Indian Ocean (Zanzibar, Mozambique)

Species name: Eupanthalis kinbergi McIntosh, 1876
Body: Elongate, up to ~130 mm with >100 segments
Prostomium: Bilobed; four sessile eyes in a rectangular arrangement; median antenna postero-dorsal; lateral antennae terminal and longer than prostomium; palps very long
Feeding structures: Jaws with 4–5 basal denticles; proboscis papillae simple/bifid dorsally and trilobed ventrally
Cirri: Dorsal cirri short, conical
Elytra: Smooth, oval; anterior pairs meet over dorsum; posterior pairs lateral
Gland: Spinning gland from segment 8–9 onward; no branchial vesicles
Notosetae: Few serrated capillary setae
Neurosetae: Three groups of superior spinulose setae; middle stout aristate setae with tapered hairy ends; inferior serrulate setae with curved, spirally serrated blades
Geographical distribution: North Atlantic; Mediterranean; recorded from Angola

Species name: Polyodontes melanonotus Grube, 1876
Body: Large tubicolous species; up to ~300 mm; stout anteriorly, flattened posteriorly
Prostomium: Elongate, strongly bilobed with raised median ridge; anterior eyes large, stalked, pear-shaped; posterior eyes minute, sessile at ommatophore bases
Cirri / First segments: First segment forms a small occipital fold; first parapodium elongated, forward-directed, with tentacular cirri and fine setae
Antennae / Palps: Median antenna tapered, ~prostomial length; laterals slightly shorter and often hidden; palps long and banded
Elytra: Oval, smooth, brownish; margins curl upward forming a shallow pocket; do not meet across the dorsum
Parapodia: Notopodia as anterodorsal folds; neuropodia very stout
Notosetae: Few, very fine, minutely spinulose
Neurosetae: Mixture of short fine capillaries, long pseudopenicillate “paint-brush” setae, very stout aristate setae with blunt or hairy subterminal features, and slender recurved, spirally serrated inferior setae
Glands: Internal coiled spinning gland opening between noto- and neuropodium from setiger ~8 onward
Ecology: Tubicolous, burrowing in sandy mud
Geographical distribution: Indo–Pacific; tropical West Africa (Senegal–Congo); recorded from Mozambique

Species name: Panthalis oerstedi capensis McIntosh, 1925
Body: Up to ~120 mm long
Prostomium: Small; median antenna long and projecting forward beyond the eye-stalks; lateral antennae thicker than the median, each with a brown spot
Elytra: Smooth; first pairs cover the head but do not cover most of the posterior dorsum
Notosetae: Slender, minutely spinulose
Neurosetae: Three groups Superior Unknown, Middle (aristate setae) Stout acicular setae with flattened spear-like tips bearing a cluster of spinules, Inferior Serrated setae with hairy tips, the hairs arising from a basal group of long spinules
Geographical distribution: South Africa; recorded from Eastern Cape (single specimen)

Species name: Eunice siciliensis Grube, 1840
Body: Very large, up to ~300 mm long; anterior region tough and cylindrical, posterior region softer and flattened
Prostomium: Anterior margin notched between rounded palps; antennae short, scarcely extending beyond palps and often wrinkled in preservation; tentacular cirri smooth
Jaws: Mandibles large, gouge-shaped, often heavily calcified; maxillae with few large teeth; maxillary formula: I 1+1, II (2–3)+(2–3), III 1+0, IV 1+1, V 1+1
Cirri: Dorsal cirri smooth
Branchiae: Absent in juveniles (~25 mm); appear late, from about setiger 60 or beyond 100 in adults; one or two filaments only
Acicula: Slightly bent with blunt tips
Notosetae: Absent (no acicular or comb setae)
Neurosetae: Superior simple, narrow-winged capillaries with pilose blades; inferior compound bidentate falcigers with short blades
Geographical distribution: Mediterranean; tropical Atlantic (Gulf of Mexico, western Africa); tropical Indo–West Pacific; recorded from South Africa, Mozambique, Madagascar

Species name: Eunice cincta Kinberg, 1865
Body: Elongate, rounded anteriorly; up to ~120 mm long
Prostomium: Anterior margin deeply bilobed; antennae subequal, about 1–5× prostomial length
Peristomium: Long; bears a pair of very small tentacular cirri
Branchiae: Absent in small specimens (~25 mm); in adults appear far posteriorly (after ~50th setiger) as 1–2 filaments
Acicula: Stout, pale brown, bluntly pointed
Setae: Acicular setae yellow, with two small blunt teeth and small guards; compound setae falcigerous with small bidentate blades; comb setae present
Geographical distribution: South Pacific; Indian Ocean; West Africa (Senegal); recorded from South Africa (Cape, Natal)

Species name: Eunice schemacephala Schmarda, 1861
Body: 70–90 mm long; red when alive, dark brown in alcohol
Prostomium: Anterior margin deeply notched between the palps
Antennae: About twice the peristomial length; weakly articulated distally
Tentacular cirri: As long as the peristomium; with three weak joints
Jaws: Mandibles with calcified cutting edges and straight dark shafts; maxillae weakly chitinised and brown; maxillary formula: Mx I = 1+1, Mx II = 6+6, Mx III = 10+0, Mx IV = 9+12, Mx V = 1+1
Cirri: First 3–4 dorsal cirri pairs twice as long as the parapodial lobe; posterior dorsal cirri much shorter; ventral cirri short on branchiferous segments
Branchiae: Begin on setiger 5 with four filaments; increase to a maximum of eight; persist posteriorly in reduced numbers
Acicula: Black, blunt-ended; usually two per parapodium in mid-body
Setae: Acicular setae from ~setiger 40, black, simple, very blunt, without guards; compound falcigers with short triangular blades, weakly bidentate, without visible guards
Geographical distribution: Tropical West Indies; tropical East Africa (Mombasa); not recorded from southern Africa

Species name: Eunice antennata Savigny, 1820
Body: Rounded anteriorly, somewhat flattened posteriorly; fresh specimens with a median row of pale spots
Prostomium: Anterior margin notched between the palps
Antennae and tentacular cirri: Deeply annulated
Jaws: Typical eunicid jaws; maxilla II with 4–5 teeth
Branchiae: Begin on setigers 4–7; rapidly increase to 10–18 filaments, decrease mid-body, and may increase again posteriorly
Acicula: Two yellow acicula per parapodium, with bent truncate to bilobed tips
Setae: Compound falcigers with bidentate blades; two yellow acicular setae with tridentate tips and guards (apical tooth small and may break, giving a bidentate appearance)
Geographical distribution: Red Sea; tropical Indo–Pacific; Gulf of Suez; southern California; Senegal; North Carolina; recorded from South Africa (Cape, Natal), Mozambique, and Madagascar

Species name: Eunice australis Quatrefages, 1865
Body: 50–70 mm long; reddish brown; pale bars on the tentacular segment and fifth setiger; posterior segments with white median spots
Prostomium: Anterior margin deeply notched between the palps
Antennae and tentacular cirri: Deeply annulated; median antenna long (about twice the peristomial breadth); tentacular cirri annulated and brown-barred
Cirri: Anterior dorsal cirri stout, weakly annulated, and brown-barred
Branchiae: Begin between setigers 3–8 (usually 6–7); increase rapidly to a maximum of ~18 slender filaments; decrease and end around mid-body or slightly posterior
Acicula: Yellow, with curved tips
Setae: Acicular setae yellow, tridentate, with small guards; two to four per parapodium from about setiger 30 onward
Geographical distribution: Red Sea; tropical Indian Ocean; Australia and New Zealand; recorded from South Africa (Cape, Natal), Mozambique, and Madagascar

Species name: Eunice vittata Delle Chiaje, 1825
Body: About 50 mm long; anterior segments with red-brown transverse bars that fade in alcohol
Prostomium: Anterior margin shallowly notched between broad palps, giving a rounded outline
Antennae and tentacular cirri: Antennae long (≈1.5× prostomial breadth), weakly annulated distally; tentacular cirri and first 5–6 dorsal cirri very long and tapered
Jaws: Maxillary formula: Mx I = 1+1; Mx II = 9+10; Mx III = 9+0; Mx IV = 10+13; Mx V = 1+1
Branchiae: Begin on setiger 3; increase to 10–20 filaments by about setiger 20; end around setiger 45
Acicula: Yellow, with faintly curved, blunt tips
Setae: Acicular setae yellow, tridentate with a small apical tooth; posterior feet with one or two acicular setae; compound falcigers with bidentate blades and long pointed guards
Geographical distribution: Atlantic (English Channel to tropical West Africa); Mediterranean; southern California; eastern Japan; recorded from South Africa (Cape, Natal) and Madagascar

Species name: Eunice indica Kinberg, 1865
Body: About 50 mm long
Prostomium: Small; palps largely fused, anterior margin only faintly notched
Antennae and tentacular cirri: Antennae smooth and long, reaching back to about setiger 7; tentacular cirri long and slender
Jaws: Pale with numerous teeth; maxillary formula: Mx I = 1+1; Mx II = 9–11 + 8–11; Mx III = 8–11 + 0; Mx IV = 7–10 + 13
Cirri: Anterior dorsal cirri not elongated, at most ~1.5× parapodial length
Branchiae: Begin on setiger 3 or 4; increase rapidly to 10–15 filaments; restricted to the anterior region
Acicula: Yellow, blunt, almost straight
Setae: Compound falcigers bidentate with long pointed, striated guards; acicular setae yellow, strongly tridentate with distinct guards, up to four per parapodium in posterior feet
Geographical distribution: Red Sea; tropical Indo–West Pacific; recorded from Mozambique and Madagascar; uncertain record from South Africa Tropical

Species name: Eunice tubifex Crossland, 1904
Body: Very large, elongate; up to ~400 mm long; anterior region rounded, posterior region flattened; lives permanently in a tough, branching, parchment-like tube with multiple openings
Prostomium: Anterior margin deeply notched between the palps
Antennae and tentacular cirri: Five antennae, smooth to slightly wrinkled, reaching back to setiger 2; tentacular cirri short and smooth
Jaws: Mandibles strong and calcified; maxillae well developed; maxillary formula: Mx I = 1+1, Mx II = 6+6, Mx III = 6+0, Mx IV = 3+8, Mx V = 1+1
Cirri / glands: Anterior parapodia bear a brown glandular ridge below the setigerous lobe
Branchiae: Begin between setigers 20–35 (size dependent); up to five filaments, usually three; slightly reduced posteriorly
Acicula: Brown, with simple blunt tips
Setae: Acicular setae brown, bidentate, with small guards; compound setae knife-shaped anteriorly, falcigerous and bidentate posteriorly, with both types present in mid-body
Geographical distribution: Tropical Indo–West Pacific; recorded from South Africa (Natal), Mozambique, and Madagascar

Species name: Eunice norvegica Linnaeus, 1767
Body: Large, 100–200 mm long; inhabits a parchment-like tube with older tube openings visible as closed scars along the sides
Prostomium: Anterior margin deeply notched between the palps
Antennae and tentacular cirri: Antennae very long, tapered, indistinctly jointed distally, about twice the peristomial width; tentacular cirri long and smooth, reaching the anterior margin of the palps
Cirri: Anterior dorsal cirri very long and smooth; posterior dorsal cirri shorter
Jaws: Maxillary formula: Mx I = 1+1; Mx II = 5+5; Mx III = 7–10+0; Mx IV = 3–5+7–10; Mx V = 1+1
Branchiae: Begin on setigers 7–10; with 4–8 filaments; persist without reduction to the posterior end
Acicula: Black, with blunt tips
Setae: Acicular setae black, bidentate, with small guards; compound setae all falcigerous and bidentate, with rounded guards
Geographical distribution: North Atlantic (including Norway, Iceland, Azores, Senegal); recorded from South Africa Tropical

Species name: Eunice pennata Müller, 1776
Body: Up to ~150 mm long (South African specimens usually ≤50 mm)
Prostomium: Anterior margin notched between the palps
Antennae and tentacular cirri: Antennae long, weakly annulated; tentacular cirri smooth and as long as the peristomium
Jaws: Numerous teeth; maxillary formula: Mx I = 1+1; Mx II = 6–8 + 7–10; Mx III = 8–12 + 0; Mx IV = 5–9 + 8–12; Mx V = 1+1 (small chitinised areas)
Branchiae: Begin on setigers 3–5; increase to ≥12 filaments; end around setiger 40
Cirri: Ventral cirri well developed
Acicula: Yellow
Setae: Acicular setae yellow, bidentate, with guards; compound setae with bluntly pointed guards
Geographical distribution: Arctic and Atlantic (Sweden to Morocco; Newfoundland to Florida); Tristan da Cunha; subantarctic and Antarctic; recorded from South Africa Tropical

Species name: Eunice coccinea Grube, 1878
Body: Copper-red; about 120 mm long
Prostomium: Anterior margin shallowly notched between the palps
Antennae and tentacular cirri: Antennae smooth; median antenna longest, about equal to the peristomial width; tentacular cirri extend forward beyond the prostomial–peristomial junction
Branchiae: Restricted to the anterior third of the body; first filament appears on setigers 5–9; increase to as many as ~10 slender filaments between setigers 12–21
Acicula: Black, blunt
Setae: Acicular setae black, bidentate; compound falcigers with short, almost triangular blades bearing weak teeth
Geographical distribution: Red Sea; tropical Indo–West Pacific; Gulf of Guinea; recorded from Mozambique and Madagascar

Species name: Eunice aphroditois Pallas, 1788
Body: Very large; up to ~560 mm long and ~20 mm wide; brownish-purple; head and peristome white with a distinct white band on setiger 4
Prostomium: Deeply notched between large palps
Antennae and tentacular cirri: Antennae slightly tapered; median antenna about twice prostomial length, not annulated (often wrinkled in preservation); tentacular cirri smooth, shorter than peristome
Cirri: Dorsal cirri stout, thicker than branchial filaments
Branchiae: Begin on setigers 6–10; increase to a maximum of ~20 filaments; gradually decrease toward posterior end
Acicula: Black, pointed
Setae: Acicular setae black, bidentate with small guards (sometimes absent); compound setae falcigerous with two well-developed teeth and rounded guards
Geographical distribution: Warm North Atlantic (France, West Indies to Morocco); Mediterranean; tropical Indo–West Pacific to Japan; southern California; recorded from South West Africa, Cape region, and Natal

Species name: Eunice torquata Quatrefages, 1865
Body: Large; ~100–250 mm long; reddish brown, often with a distinct white bar on setiger 4
Prostomium: Anterior margin deeply notched between the palps
Antennae: Long and distinctly jointed
Tentacular cirri: Jointed; as long as the peristome
Maxillae: Robust; maxillary formula: Mx I = 1+1; Mx II = (5–6)+(5–6); Mx III = (6–7)+0; Mx IV = (3–5)+(8–10); Mx V = 1+1
Cirri: Dorsal cirri jointed
Branchiae: Begin on setiger 3; increase to >10 filaments (shorter than dorsal cirri); decrease posteriorly
Acicula: Black
Setae: Acicular setae black, bidentate with small guards; compound setae falcigerous, bidentate with two well-developed teeth and rounded guards
Geographical distribution: Eastern Atlantic (English Channel to Cape Verde Islands and Angola); Mediterranean; recorded from Madagascar

Species name: Eunice tentaculata Quatrefages, 1865
Body: Large; up to ~350 mm long and ~15 mm wide; reddish brown, often with a white collar on setiger 4
Prostomium: Anterior margin deeply notched between the palps
Antennae & tentacular cirri: Long and deeply annulated
Maxillae: Strong; maxillary formula: Mx I = 1+1; Mx II = 6+5; Mx III = 6+0; Mx IV = 6+7; Mx V = 1+1
Cirri: First three dorsal cirri pairs very long (about twice parapodial length); posterior dorsal cirri shorter
Branchiae: Begin on setiger 3–4; increase to 6 filaments by setiger 6; reach 6–20 filaments; decrease gradually toward posterior end
Acicula: Black, blunt-ended
Setae: Acicular setae bidentate with small guards; compound setae falcigerous, bidentate with two strong teeth and rounded guards
Geographical distribution: Tropical Indian Ocean (Laccadive Islands, India, Sri Lanka); western Australia; New Zealand; possibly Tasmania

Species name: Eunice grubei Gravier, 1900
Body: Large; ~150–230 mm long
Prostomium: Anterior margin notched between the palps
Antennae & tentacular cirri: Antennae long, weakly ringed; peristomial segment elongate with smooth, slender tentacular cirri
Maxillae: Maxillary formula: Mx I = 1+1; Mx II = 5+5; Mx III = 7+0; Mx IV = 6+9
Cirri: Anterior dorsal cirri longer than the branchiae
Branchiae: Begin on setiger 3; rapidly increase to a maximum of ~8 filaments; gradually decrease posteriorly
Acicula & setae: Acicula and acicular setae brown; acicular setae bidentate with small guards
Geographical distribution: Red Sea; tropical Indo–West Pacific; records from Mozambique and Madagascar; doubtful record from South Africa Tropical

Species name: Eunice filamentosa Grube, 1856
Body: About ~120 mm long
Prostomium: Anterior margin deeply notched between the palps
Antennae & tentacular cirri: Antennae short, slender, smooth to wrinkled; peristome elongate; tentacular cirri about half the peristomial length
Maxillae: Maxillary formula: Mx I = 1+1; Mx II = (4–5)+(3–4); Mx III = (5–4)+(6–8); Mx IV = (3–7)+0
Branchiae: Begin on setiger ~26; up to three filaments; extend to posterior end
Acicula & setae: Acicula brownish with distinctive fist-shaped terminal knobs; acicular setae brown, bidentate with recurved teeth and large guards; compound setae bidentate with well-developed teeth and rounded guards
Geographical distribution: Tropical Atlantic from North Carolina and Florida to Ghana and Angola; recorded from Natal (South Africa)

Species name: Marphysa mossambica Peters, 1854
Body: Large, elongate; up to ~350 mm; flattened posterior to the anterior segments
Prostomium: Anterior margin deeply bilobed
Antennae: Smooth; about 1.5× prostomial length
Branchiae: Appear on setiger ~25–33 (size-dependent); increase to 6–8 filaments; persist to posterior end
Setae: All setae simple capillaries with very narrow, striated blades; comb-setae absent
Acicula: Yellow to black, straight with blunt tips
Acicular setae: Pale, bidentate, about half the thickness of acicula; absent from some parapodia
Geographical distribution: Red Sea; tropical Indo–West Pacific; recorded from Mozambique Island

Species name: Marphysa depressa Schmarda, 1861
Body: Slender, cylindrical in section; up to ~100 mm long
Prostomium: Anterior margin bilobed
Antennae: Smooth; longer than the prostomium
Branchiae: Begin on setiger ~10–25 (size-dependent); with 2–4 filaments at maximum; gradually decrease posteriorly
Setae: Superior setae include capillaries and asymmetrical comb-setae with numerous teeth; inferior setae compound, including spinigers and long-bladed bidentate falcigers (falcigers more common anteriorly)
Acicula: Three per parapodium anteriorly, reduced to two posteriorly; shafts dark brown to black with pale tips
Acicular setae: Pale distally, bluntly bidentate, with small guards
Geographical distribution: New Zealand; recorded from South Africa (Cape, Natal)

Species name: Marphysa sanguinea Montagu, 1815
Body: Stout, oval in section; up to ~250 mm long
Prostomium: Anterior margin bilobed
Antennae: Smooth; nearly twice the prostomial length
Cirri: Dorsal cirri about as long as the setigerous lobes
Branchiae: Begin on setiger ~16–30; up to 4–7 filaments; decreasing posteriorly
Setae: Superior setae include winged capillaries and numerous comb-setae with coarse teeth; inferior setae compound, spinigerous
Acicula: Two to three, black, blunt-tipped
Acicular setae: Pale, bidentate with small guards in adults; guards larger in juveniles
Habitat/Ecology: Common in muddy sandbanks and Zostera beds
Geographical distribution: North Atlantic (Scotland to Senegal; North Carolina to Gulf of Mexico); Mediterranean; New Zealand; southern California; Japan

Species name: Marphysa macintoshi Crossland, 1903
Body: Slender, rounded to slightly flattened; over ~200 mm long
Prostomium: Palps partially fused; anterior margin not distinctly bilobed; eyes indistinct
Antennae: Smooth; about equal to prostomial length
Jaws: Mandibles normal; maxillary formula: Mx I 1+1, Mx II 7+7, Mx III 7+0, Mx IV 3+8, Mx V reduced to chitinised areas without teeth
Branchiae: Appear on setiger ~20–50 (size-dependent); up to 6 filaments; decreasing posteriorly
Acicula: Brown with pale tips; blunt; three anteriorly, reducing to one mid-body
Acicular setae: Single brown seta with a simple blunt tip
Setae: Superior setae winged capillaries and comb-setae; inferior setae compound with knife-shaped blades, often deeply retracted and appearing simple
Geographical distribution: Red Sea and tropical Indian Ocean; recorded from South Africa (Cape to Natal), Mozambique, and Madagascar

Species name: Marphysa bifurcata Kott, 1951
Body: About ~80 mm long
Prostomium: Palps completely fused; anterior margin rounded
Antennae: Short, smooth; about half the prostomial length
Branchiae: From setiger ~22 to posterior end; up to 4–5 filaments; filaments arise directly from dorsum (no axial stem)
Cirri: Dorsal cirri short and conical anteriorly; bifurcate in branchial region (diagnostic character)
Acicula: Three brown acicula with pale blunt tips anteriorly, reduced to one posteriorly
Acicular setae: Brown, yellowish distally; minutely bidentate; lacking guards
Setae: Superior setae winged capillaries and comb-setae; inferior setae falcigerous, bidentate with divergent teeth and rounded guards
Geographical distribution: Southwest Australia; recorded from Mozambique

Species name: Marphysa purcellana Willey, 1904
Body: ~60 mm long; oval in cross-section; prostomium with a brown bar; anterior body with reddish-brown pattern
Prostomium: Bilobed anterior margin
Antennae: Short, smooth; about equal to prostomial length
Jaws: Maxillary formula: Mx I = 1+1; Mx II = 5+5; Mx III = 5+0; Mx IV = 3+8
Branchiae: Begin on setiger 8 with four filaments; increase to ~18 filaments by setiger 18; decrease and end around setiger 28
Cirri: Dorsal cirri equal to setigerous lobe prebranchially; equal to branchial filaments in branchial region; much longer than setigerous lobe post-branchially
Acicula: Yellow, blunt
Acicular setae: Yellow, strongly bidentate with small guards
Setae: Ventral setae compound, falcigerous, with two large teeth
Geographical distribution:  to South Africa (South-West Africa and Cape)

Species name: Marphysa adenensis Gravier, 1900
Body: Slender, rounded in cross-section; up to ~70 mm long with ~200 segments; no colour markings
Prostomium: Anterior margin smoothly rounded
Antennae: Tapered, not annulated; median antenna slightly longer than prostomium
Jaws: Weakly chitinised; maxillary formula: Mx I = 1+1; Mx II = 7+8; Mx III = 7+0; Mx IV = 7+11; Mx V = chitinous plates without teeth
Branchiae: Appear abruptly around setigers 15–19; end ~20 segments later; each branchia large, pectinate, with 8–10 long filaments arising from a short dorsal cirrus
Acicula: Pale, blunt; three anteriorly, reduced to one over most of body
Acicular setae: Single pale seta from setigers ~35–40 onwards; bidentate with small terminal tooth and guards
Setae: Superior setae narrow-winged capillaries and comb-setae with 5–10 teeth; inferior setae compound falcigers with long, narrow bidentate blades
Geographical distribution: Red Sea; recorded from Madagascar

Species name: Marphysa posterobranchia Day, 1962
Body: Slender, rounded in cross-section; ~30 mm long
