Prostomium: Anterior margin bilobed
Antennae: Smooth to weakly wrinkled; slightly longer than prostomium
Jaws: Pale; maxillary formula: Mx I = 1+1; Mx II = 4+4; Mx III = 6+0; Mx IV = 5+10
Branchiae: Simple filaments restricted to posterior segments; appear after setiger ~55 (juveniles) and best developed on last few segments (adults)
Cirri: Dorsal cirri well developed anteriorly, smaller than branchiae posteriorly
Acicula: Blunt; pale in juveniles, black in adults; appear from ~setiger 30
Acicular setae: Bidentate with guards; pale in juveniles, black in adults
Setae: Superior setae winged capillaries and comb-setae with 8–15 teeth; inferior setae compound falcigers with two strong teeth
Geographical distribution: South Africa (Cape to Natal)

Species name: Marphysa capensis Schmarda, 1861
Body: Up to ~150 mm long, ~10 mm wide; roughly oval in cross-section; brown with slightly darker peristome
Prostomium: Anterior margin bilobed
Antennae: Smooth; extend back to the first setiger
Jaws: Maxillary formula: Mx I = 1+1; Mx II = 3+4; Mx III = 4+0; Mx IV = 3+6; Mx V = 1+1
Branchiae: Begin on setiger 12–30 (size-dependent); extend almost to posterior end; up to four filaments
Setae: Superior setae winged capillaries and comb-setae; inferior setae falcigerous with rounded guards
Acicula: Black, bluntly pointed
Acicular setae: Black, unidentate, without guards
Geographical distribution: South West Africa to Western Cape; also New Zealand, Chatham Islands, subantarctic regions, Antarctica

Species name: Marphysa corallina Kinberg, 1865
Body: Very long, up to ~300 mm; anterior region rounded, posterior region flattened
Prostomium: Anterior margin bilobed
Antennae: Smooth; about 1.5× prostomial length
Branchiae: Begin on setiger 20–50 (size-dependent); up to six filaments at maximum; continue to posterior end with reduced filaments
Setae: Superior comb-setae with 20–25 teeth; inferior setae compound and falcigerous
Acicula: Dark with pale, blunt tips
Acicular setae: Pale, bidentate, with small guards
Geographical distribution: Tropical Indo–West Pacific; recorded from Eastern Cape to Natal, Mozambique, and Madagascar

Species name: Lysidice natalensis Kinberg, 1865
Body: Up to ~100 mm long and ~5 mm wide; brown with minute white spots
Prostomium: Anterior margin white and bilobed; pair of reniform black eyes just external to lateral antennae
Antennae: White, slightly tapered, about equal to prostomial length
Jaws: Mandibles heavy, gouge-shaped, strongly calcified; maxillary formula: Mx I = 1+1, Mx II = 3+3 (teeth very robust), Mx III = (2–3)+0, Mx IV = 2+(4–8), Mx V = 1+1
Parapodia: Dorsal cirrus conical; setigerous lobe truncate; ventral cirrus rounded anteriorly, posteriorly merging with glandular ventral pad
Setae: Superior limbate capillaries and comb-setae; inferior setae compound with short falcigerous blades
Acicula: Black with blunt tips
Acicular setae: Appear from ~setiger 20; brown, bidentate, with small guards
Geographical distribution:  to southern Africa; recorded from South West Africa, Cape region, and Natal

Species name: Lysidice collaris Grube, 1870
Body: Up to ~75 mm long
Prostomium: Anterior margin bilobed; eyes reniform
Antennae: Tapered, slightly longer than the prostomium
Jaws: Mandibles gouge-shaped, partly calcified; maxillary formula: Mx I = 1+1, Mx II = (4–5)+4, Mx III = (3–5)+0, Mx IV = 2+5, Mx V reduced to chitinised areas
Parapodia: Short conical dorsal cirrus set high above the broad setigerous lobe; ventral cirrus papilliform, becoming indistinct from the glandular ventral pad after ~setiger 30
Setae: Superior limbate capillaries and comb-setae; inferior setae bidentate falcigers
Acicula: Brown shafts with blunt ends
Acicular setae: Appear from ~setiger 20; brown, with blunt, minutely bilobed tips
Geographical distribution: Red Sea and tropical Indo–West Pacific to Japan; recorded from Cape, Natal, Mozambique, and Madagascar

Species name: Lysidice ninetta Audouin & Milne Edwards, 1833
Body: Up to ~150 mm long; reddish with white punctuations and white transverse bars on setigers 2 and 5
Prostomium: Anterior margin bilobed; eyes large, black, and oval
Antennae: Subequal, shorter than the prostomium
Jaws: Mandibles heavy and gouge-shaped; maxillary formula: Mx I = 1+1, Mx II = 4+4, Mx III = 4+0, Mx IV = 4+4, Mx V reduced to chitinised patches
Parapodia: Dorsal cirri digitiform, as long as the compressed, truncate setigerous lobes; ventral cirri papilliform with swollen bases
Setae: Superior limbate capillaries and comb-setae; inferior compound falcigers with bidentate blades
Acicula: Dark
Acicular setae: Appear from ~setiger 20; bidentate with guards
Geographical distribution: North Atlantic (English Channel, North Carolina), Mediterranean, Angola; possibly Indian Ocean

Species name: Epidiopatra gilchristi Day, 1960
Body: Slender, up to ~60 mm long; enclosed in an erect, tough, translucent tube that may be annulated or spirally twisted but is always attached
Prostomium: With subulate frontal antennae and five smooth occipital antennae of normal length; antennae borne on ceratophores with 5–7 rings; inner lateral ceratophores sometimes bearing short stumpy projections
Jaws: Pale and weakly chitinised; maxillary formula: Mx I = 1 + 1; Mx II = 8 + 7; Mx III = 7 + 0; Mx IV = 6 + 10
Parapodia: Setigers 1–3 with subulate dorsal cirri, low presetal lips, postsetal lobes with an inferior papilla, and subulate ventral cirri; in posterior segments ventral cirri become glandular pads and postsetal lobes are reduced to papillae
Branchiae: Poorly developed; 2–5 pairs present on setigers 4–9
Setae: Pseudocompound setae on setigers 1–4 strongly bidentate with well-developed hoods; comb setae with ~12 teeth from setiger 6; two bidentate acicular setae appear a few segments later
Geographical distribution:  to South Africa (southern and eastern Cape; Natal)

Species name: Epidiopatra hupferiana hupferiana Augener, 1918
Body: Slender, up to ~30 mm long; anterior region brownish with a dark spot behind each parapodium, paired spots connected by a dorsal cross-bar; tube encrusted with debris, coarse sand, or mud
Prostomium: With distinct eyes; frontal antennae subulate; occipital antennae fairly long, borne on ceratophores with 6–7 rings, sometimes with short lateral projections
Parapodia: First three setigers each with cirriform dorsal and ventral cirri and a tapered postsetal lobe; later parapodia simpler
Branchiae: Begin on setiger 5 and extend to setiger 20–30; anterior branchiae well developed with spirally arranged filaments, posterior ones progressively reduced to 1–2 filaments
Setae: Anterior setigers (1–3/4) with capillaries and pseudocompound hooks that are bidentate and hooded; posterior setigers lack hooks, with capillaries developing broader wings, and comb-setae plus bidentate acicular setae appearing
Geographical distribution: West Africa (Senegal; South West Africa records)

Species name: Diopatra dubia Day, 1960
Body: Small, ~35 mm long; tube fragile, of mud with large projecting shell fragments; pigmentation variable, anterior segments often brown, ventral cirri white with a mid-ventral pale streak
Prostomium: Frontal antennae reduced to flattened expansions of the prostomium; occipital antennae on short, ringed ceratophores with lateral lobes on five rings
Jaws: Poorly developed; mandibles with straight, tapered shafts
Branchiae: Begin on setiger 5; weakly developed with 2–3 whorls of filaments; disappear by about setiger 30
Setae: Anterior pseudocompound setae hooded and strongly bidentate; winged capillaries with serrated blades present; bidentate acicular setae from setiger 10; comb-setae with 18–20 teeth from setiger 15
Ontogeny: Juveniles lack tentacular cirri until relatively late development
Geographical distribution: South Africa (Cape region);

Species name: Diopatra monroi Day, 1960
Body: Large, 100–150 mm long; tube sausage-like, of hardened mud without shell fragments; anterior region brown with a darker spot behind the median occipital antenna and dark transverse bars on anterior branchiferous segments
Prostomium: Frontal antennae subulate; median occipital antenna borne on a ceratophore with 6–8 rings
Jaws: Mandibles dark, thickened, often sausage-shaped in adults
Branchiae: Begin on setiger 5; filaments fairly long and well developed
Setae: Anterior pseudocompound setae hooded and strongly bidentate; comb-setae appear on setigers 6–8 with 15–25 teeth; bidentate acicular setae appear around setiger 16
Ecology: Tubicolous, inhabiting firm mud tubes
Geographical distribution: South-west Africa and western Cape, South Africa;

Species name: Diopatra musseraensis Augener, 1918
Body: Medium-sized, up to ~50 mm long; anterior region brown, without distinct colour pattern; tube with projecting shell fragments
Prostomium: Frontal antennae subulate; median occipital antenna borne on a ceratophore with ~10 smooth rings
Jaws: Mandibles with straight, tapered shafts
Branchiae: Well developed, with fairly long filaments
Setae: Anterior pseudocompound setae hooded and strongly bidentate; comb-setae with 15–25 teeth, blades broad and rolled into a funnel-like form giving the appearance of a single broad central tooth
Geographical distribution: Tropical western Africa (Ghana to Angola); not recorded

species_name: Paradiopatra quadricuspis M. Sars in G.O. Sars, 1872
text:
Species name: Paradiopatra quadricuspis M. Sars in G.O. Sars, 1872
Body: Medium-sized, ~40–60 mm long; anterior segments rounded, posterior segments dorsally flattened; anterior region with brown transverse bars; tube reinforced with mud
Prostomium: With a pair of minute anterior eyes; occipital antennae long, borne on short ceratophores with ~6 rings
Antennae / Cirri: Tentacular cirri inserted behind inner lateral antennae, shorter than the peristomial segment; ventral cirri subulate on setigers 1–3
Jaws: Maxillary formula: Mx I = 1 + 1; Mx II = 7 + 8; Mx III = 8 + 0; Mx IV = (4–6) + (7–8)
Branchiae: Begin on setiger 6–9; increase to a maximum of four filaments; reduced to a single filament after setiger ~40
Setae: Anterior pseudocompound hooks hooded and tridentate; posterior feet with winged capillaries, comb-setae, and bidentate acicular setae with guards
Acicula: Yellow
Ecology: Tubicolous, living in mud-reinforced tubes
Geographical distribution: North Atlantic—Norway and Sweden to the English Channel and Senegal; western Atlantic from Canada to Massachusetts; South African record Tropical considered doubtful

Species name: Nothria conchylega Sars, 1835
Body: 40–150 mm long; body elongate; lives in a characteristically free, flattened tube densely covered with large shell fragments
Prostomium: Cordate with a central brown spot; one anterior pair of minute eye spots and a large pair of eyes external to the inner lateral antennae
Antennae / Ceratophores: Ceratophores short with 3–4 rings; ceratostyles long, tapered, reaching to about setiger 6
Jaws: Mandibles with a weak tooth on the calcareous cutting edge and straight diverging shafts; maxillary formula: Mx I = 1 + 1; Mx II = 6 + (6–7); Mx III = 8 + 0; Mx IV = (6–8) + (8–10); Mx V = 0 + 0 (dark, toothless plates)
Cirri / Parapodia: Tentacular segment short but tentacular cirri long, reaching the anterior margin of the prostomium; setigers 1–3 greatly enlarged and projecting forward; presetal lamella dorsal and heart-shaped on anterior feet; postsetal lobe elongate and cirriform on setigers 2–15, reduced posteriorly; ventral cirri tapered on first 2–3 feet, then swollen and cushion-like; dorsal cirri elongate anteriorly, reduced posteriorly
Branchiae: Single branchial filament present from setiger 9–13, depending on size
Setae: Anterior setigers (1–3 or 1–4) with stout pseudocompound or simple hooks, bidentate and usually guarded; from setiger 4 onward smooth-winged capillaries and fine comb-setae with ~10–12 teeth; long stout bidentate acicular setae appear around setigers 10–15
Ecology: Free-living tubicolous species, common in dredged sediments
Geographical distribution: Cosmopolitan; recorded from the Arctic to the subantarctic, including South Africa Tropical, Natal, and Mozambique

Species name: Oenone fulgida Savigny, 1818
Body: Large, elongate; ~100–350 mm long
Prostomium: Rounded; two pairs of eyes, outer pair larger
Antennae: Three stout antennae, much shorter than the prostomium and often hidden by a biannulate peristomial fold
Jaws: Mandibles well chitinised; maxillae with long slender supports and a faint dagger-shaped median piece; jaws often asymmetrical with the first tooth much larger than the rest; maxillary formula: Mx I = 12 (or 7+5) + 7; Mx II = 9 + 15; Mx III = 6 + 5; Mx IV = 6 + 6; Mx V = 1 + 1
Parapodia: Uniform throughout; dorsal cirrus flattened and strap-like, constricted at base; presetal lobe short and rounded; postsetal lobe longer
Setae: Fine tapered capillaries present throughout; posterior feet with two yellow acicular setae, bidentate
Ecology: Free-living carnivorous polychaete
Geographical distribution: Red Sea and Suez; tropical Indo–West Pacific; recorded from Natal, Mozambique, and Madagascar

Species name: Augneria tentaculata Monro, 1930
Body: Slender, cylindrical; up to ~135 mm long and ~3 mm wide with ~110 segments; lumbrinerid-like in appearance
Prostomium: Ovoid to rounded; eyes absent; three small antennae recessed in a peristomial pocket
Peristomium: Peristomium and following segment apodous and achaetous; paired buccal cushions present anterior to mouth
Jaws: Mandibles well developed with short divergent shafts; maxillae of four symmetrical toothed plates with small supports; maxillary formula: Mx I = 1 + 1; Mx II = 3 + 3; Mx III = 2 + 2; Mx IV = 1 + 1 (rectangular, toothless plates)
Parapodia: Anterior feet with low presetal lobe and large ear-shaped postsetal lobe; posterior feet with subequal lobes, postsetal lobe bearing a superior point
Setae: Winged capillaries and compound hooks anteriorly; capillaries with very narrow blades and hooks becoming simple in middle and posterior feet; acicula absent
Ecology: Deep-water benthic species
Geographical distribution: Subantarctic and Antarctic; not recorded from southern Africa

Species name: Lumbrineris magalhaensis Kinberg, 1865
Body: Slender; up to ~100 mm long
Prostomium: Conical
Jaws: Maxillary formula Mx I = 1+1; Mx II = 4+4; Mx III = curved cutting plate without a distinct tooth; Mx IV = 1+1; maxillary supports short and broad
Parapodia: Presetal lobe low and rounded throughout; postsetal lobe conical and compressed anteriorly, becoming shorter posteriorly and nearly equal to the presetal lobe
Setae: Anterior feet with long winged capillaries and short-bladed compound hooks (from setigers 1–4 to ~12–15); posterior feet with simple hooks only
Acicula: Yellow
Geographical distribution: Southern South America (Chile); subantarctic islands; Antarctica; recorded from South African waters (Cape, rare)

Species name: Lumbrineris meteorana Augener, 1931
Body: Slender; ~20 mm long with ~120 segments; pale yellow
Prostomium: Bluntly conical
Jaws / Maxillae: Maxillary formula Mx I = 1+1; Mx II = 3+3 (teeth stout, almost bilobed); Mx III = cutting plates without distinct teeth; Mx IV = 1+1 (large, rounded); mandibles poorly calcified with united shafts; maxillary supports broad and triangular
Parapodia: Anterior feet bilobed with presetal lobe initially smaller but soon equal to postsetal lobe; this condition persists over most of body; mid-body feet reduced; posterior feet with both lobes long and filamentous, presetal lobe slightly longer
Setae: Anterior feet with ~2 long-bladed compound hooks and 3–4 winged capillaries; capillaries disappear before mid-body; hooks become simple after ~10–15 segments and persist as 2–3 simple hooks to posterior end
Acicula: Yellow
Ecology: Common in dredgings on muddy sand
Geographical distribution:  to southern Africa; recorded from South West Africa, Cape, and Natal

Species name: Lumbrineris albidentata Ehlers, 1908
Body: Elongate; up to ~100 mm; anterior segments swollen in juveniles to accommodate large jaws
Prostomium: Conical with a conspicuous nuchal slit at the prostomial–peristomial junction
Jaws / Maxillae: Mandibles heavily calcified with widely divergent shafts; maxillae robust with characteristic large white plates on Mx IV bordered in black; maxillary formula Mx I = 1+1; Mx II = (2–3)+(2–3); Mx III = 2+2; Mx IV = indistinct paired plates; maxillary supports long and triangular
Parapodia: Anterior feet with low presetal and rounded postsetal lobes; middle feet with subequal lobes directed obliquely upward; posterior feet elongate and bilabiate with stout lobes
Setae: Winged capillaries from setiger 1–50; long compound hooks from setiger 1–30; simple hooks plus capillaries from setiger 31–50; only simple hooks posteriorly
Acicula: Yellow; four per parapodium
Ecology: Common in deep dredgings on muddy sand
Geographical distribution: South West Africa, South Africa (Cape, Natal), Mozambique; also recorded from North Carolina

Species name: Lumbrineris brevicirra Schmarda, 1861
Body: Slender; ~50–70 mm long
Prostomium: Conical
Jaws / Maxillae: Maxillary formula Mx I = 1+1; Mx II = 5+5; Mx III = indistinct paired cutting plates; Mx IV = 1+1
Parapodia: Anterior feet small with rudimentary presetal lobe and deep, compressed postsetal lobe; presetal lobe enlarges posteriorly while postsetal lobe reduces; posterior feet with elongated base and subequal lobes
Setae: Slender capillaries present to mid-body; long-bladed simple hooks appear within first ~10 setigers and persist posteriorly, with blades shortening toward the rear
Acicula: Pale throughout (black reported in some Chatham Island material)
Geographical distribution: South Africa (Cape, Natal); New South Wales; Chatham Island; Chile; Japan

Species name: Lumbrineris inflata Moore, 1911
Body: Small; ~20 mm long; body short and orange
Prostomium: Spherical, conspicuously white
Jaws / Maxillae: Maxillary formula Mx I = 1+1; Mx II = 4–5 + 4–5; Mx III = 3–4 + 3–4; Mx IV = 2+2; maxillary supports long
Parapodia: Anterior feet with low rounded presetal lobe and a longer but similar postsetal lobe; setae always exceed postsetal lobe length
Setae: Winged capillaries present in first ~30–40 feet; hooded compound (or incompletely compound) hooks appear in first 3–4 feet, becoming simple posteriorly and persisting to the end
Acicula: Yellow
Ecology: Occurs on rocky shores; uncommon
Geographical distribution: Circumtropical (Atlantic, Indian, and Pacific oceans); recorded from Natal and Mozambique

Species name: Lumbrineris coccinea Renieri, 1804
Body: Small; ~40 mm long; orange when alive, pale in alcohol
Prostomium: Globular
Jaws / Maxillae: Maxillary formula Mx I = 1+1; Mx II = 4–5 + 4–5; Mx III = 2+2; Mx IV = 1+1
Parapodia: Anterior feet with low rounded presetal lobe and longer conical postsetal lobe; posterior feet slightly longer but similar; setae always exceed postsetal lobe
Setae: Winged capillaries present on first ~30–40 feet; compound hooks from first to ~20th foot, becoming simple posteriorly with opaque white heads
Acicula: Yellow
Ecology: Common in algal tufts
Geographical distribution: North Atlantic (USA, English Channel to Morocco and Senegal); Mediterranean; recorded from South West Africa, Cape coast, and Mozambique

Species name: Lumbrineris oculata Ehlers, 1908
Body: Small; ~20 mm long with ~87 segments
Prostomium: Ovoid with dark lateral pigmentation
Jaws / Maxillae: Maxillary formula Mx I = 1+1; Mx II = 3+4; Mx III = 1+1 (very small plate); Mx IV = 2+2; maxillary supports long and kite-shaped
Parapodia: Anterior feet with low presetal lobes and long ear-shaped postsetal lobes with an inferior expansion; posterior feet unknown
Setae: Winged capillaries from first to ~34th foot; long-shafted compound hooks from anterior feet to ~16th foot, replaced posteriorly by simple short-headed hooks
Acicula: Unknown
Geographical distribution:  to South Africa; known only from the type

Species name: Lumbrineris latreilli Audouin & Milne Edwards, 1834
Body: Elongate; up to ~150 mm long
Prostomium: Conical
Jaws / Maxillae: Maxillary formula Mx I = 1+1; Mx II = (4–5)+(4–5); Mx III = 2+2; Mx IV = 1+1; maxillary supports fairly long
Parapodia: Anterior feet with a low rounded presetal lobe and a larger bluntly triangular postsetal lobe; posterior feet with long conical postsetal lobes, always shorter than the setae
Setae: Winged capillaries from first to ~40–50th foot; long-bladed compound hooks from ~3rd to ~25th foot, replaced posteriorly by simple hooks with progressively shorter heads
Acicula: Yellow
Geographical distribution: Cosmopolitan in temperate and tropical seas; recorded from South Africa (Cape, Natal), Mozambique

Species name: Lumbrineris aberrans Day, 1963
Body: Very small; ~10 mm long with ~60 segments
Prostomium: Conical, extremely elongated; as long as the peristome plus first four setigers
Jaws / Maxillae: Mandible shafts completely fused; maxillary supports very large; maxillary formula Mx I = 1+1; Mx II = 3+3; Mx III = 1+1 (short plates with indistinct teeth); Mx IV = 0+0 (toothless oval plates)
Parapodia: First six setigers with minute lobes; later parapodia larger, conical, with rudimentary presetal lobe and a conical postsetal lobe shorter than the setae; posterior parapodia unknown
Setae: Winged capillaries present from first setiger, with very short broad blades; simple hooks from setiger 4, bidentate with divergent teeth and a short broad hood
Acicula: Pale
Geographical distribution: Known only from the Agulhas Bank, South Africa (single specimen)

Species name: Lumbrineris tetraura Schmarda, 1861
Body: Large; up to ~250 mm long
Prostomium: Conical
Jaws / Maxillae: Maxillary formula Mx I = 1+1; Mx II = (4–5)+(4–5); Mx III = 2+2; Mx IV = 1+1; major plates with 4–5 teeth; maxillary supports long and kite-shaped
Parapodia: Anterior feet with low rounded presetal lobe and longer bluntly conical postsetal lobe; posterior feet longer but similar in shape
Setae: Winged capillaries from setiger 1 to ~60; long-headed simple hooks from setiger ~4 to posterior end, hook heads shortening and becoming whitish after ~setiger 30
Acicula: Yellow
Geographical distribution: Cosmopolitan in temperate and tropical waters; recorded from South-west Africa, South Africa (Cape, Natal), and Chile

Species name: Lumbrineris hartmani Day, 1953
Body: Elongate; up to ~100 mm or more
Prostomium: Conical
Jaws / Maxillae: Maxillary formula Mx I = 1+1; Mx II = (4–5)+(4–5); Mx III = 2+2; Mx IV = 1+1; maxillary supports long and triangular
Parapodia: Anterior feet with low rounded presetal lobe and longer conical postsetal lobe; posterior feet with lengthened postsetal lobe, never exceeding setal length
Setae: Winged capillaries from anterior segments to setiger ~60–70; long-bladed simple hooks appear around setiger ~25–45 and persist posteriorly, blades shortening after mid-body
Acicula: Yellow
Geographical distribution:  to South Africa (False Bay, Cape); closely related to Lumbrineris fragilis

Species name: Lumbrineris heteropoda difficilis Day, 1963
Body: Elongate, often exceeding ~120 mm
Prostomium: Conical, with dark pigmentation at the base
Jaws / Maxillae: Maxillary formula Mx I = 1+1; Mx II = (4–5)+(4–5); Mx III = 2+2; Mx IV = 1+1; maxillary supports heart-shaped
Parapodia: Anterior feet with low rounded presetal lobe and compressed postsetal lobe produced dorsally; posterior feet with postsetal lobe very long, digitiform, and greatly exceeding setal length (diagnostic character)
Setae: Anterior setae all winged capillaries (superior long and tapering, inferior short and blunt); long-bladed simple hooks appear around setiger ~40, becoming shorter posteriorly; posterior feet dominated by short-bladed hooks with occasional capillaries
Acicula: Black
Geographical distribution: South West Africa and South Africa Tropical; also recorded from Tristan da Cunha and Congo (Brazzaville)

Species name: Lumbrineris papillifera Fauvel, 1919
Body: Elongate, often exceeding ~100 mm
Prostomium: Conical
Jaws / Maxillae: Maxillary formula Mx I = 1+1; Mx II = (4–5)+(4–5); Mx III = 2+2; Mx IV = 1+1; maxillary supports long and triangular
Parapodia: Anterior feet with low rounded presetal lobe and longer conical postsetal lobe; posterior feet with short presetal lobe and very long postsetal lobe that may exceed setal length; adults may develop a ventral papilla between parapodia from mid-body onwards (new diagnostic character)
Setae: Anterior setae all winged capillaries; short-headed simple hooks appear around setiger ~40 and fully replace capillaries before mid-body
Acicula: Yellow
Geographical distribution: Tropical East Africa; recorded from Natal, Mozambique, and Madagascar

Species name: Arabella mutans Chamberlin, 1919
Body: Elongate; up to ~190 mm with >300 segments
Prostomium: Conical; four eyes present
Jaws / Maxillae: Mandibles black, roughly M-shaped; maxillae well developed with enlarged falcate hooks; maxillary formula Mx I = (1+4)+(1+4); Mx II = (0+12)+(0+12); Mx III = (1+4)+(1+4); Mx IV = (1+3)+(1+3); Mx V = 1+1 (presence of enlarged falcate hook is a diagnostic character)
Parapodia: Dorsal cirrus reduced to a slight swelling at parapodial base; presetal lobe low and rounded; postsetal lobe a longer blunt cone
Acicula: Two to three; yellow, pointed, tips just piercing the body wall between parapodial lobes
Setae: Winged capillaries with smooth or basally serrated blades; one inferior asymmetrically hooded acicular seta (distinctive character)
Geographical distribution: Easter Island; Zanzibar; Cape Verde Islands; North Carolina; recorded from Cape coast and Mozambique

Species name: Arabella iricolor iricolor Montagu, 1804
Body: Tough, wiry, strongly iridescent; up to ~100 mm; segments short and crowded
Prostomium: Bluntly conical; four eyes in a transverse row along posterior margin
Jaws / Maxillae: Mandibles strong, black, roughly H-shaped; maxillae with enlarged first tooth in series; maxillary formula Mx I = (1+9)+(1+8); Mx II = 8+14; Mx III = 7+5; Mx IV = (7+4)+(7+3); Mx V = 1+1
Parapodia: Presetal lobe low and rounded; postsetal lobe longer, conical
Cirri: Dorsal cirrus well developed anteriorly as a curved papilla arising from dorsal base of parapodium
Acicula: About three; yellow, pointed, tips just piercing parapodial skin
Setae: Four to five winged capillaries, often basally serrated
Geographical distribution: Cosmopolitan in temperate and tropical seas; recorded from Madagascar

Species name: Drilonereis falcata Moore, 1911
Body: Slender, rounded in cross-section; about 100 mm long
Prostomium: Depressed, bluntly conical; internal eyes may be present
Jaws / Maxillae: Mandibles stout, black, triangular; maxillae with basal teeth on Mx I and enlarged anterior tooth on all plates; median unpaired support dagger-shaped and entirely black; maxillary formula Mx I = 8+6; Mx II = 8+8; Mx III = 4+3; Mx IV = 1+1; Mx V = 1+1
Parapodia: First two segments achaetous; parapodia well developed thereafter with very small presetal lobe and conical postsetal lobe
Acicula: Stout, projecting aciculum present from about setiger 10–20; sometimes two per foot
Setae: Not differentiated in original description beyond association with parapodia
Posterior end: Unknown
Geographical distribution: California (deep water); recorded sparsely from South West Africa and the Cape

Species name: Drilonereis monroi Day, 1960
Body: Long, tough, wiry; exceeding 200 mm in length
Prostomium: Blunt, depressed, eyeless; almost fused to the first segment
Jaws / Maxillae: Mandibles absent; maxillae well developed; Mx I without basal teeth and Mx V absent; maxillary formula Mx I = 1+1; Mx II = (6–8)+(6–8); Mx III = 4+4; Mx IV = 4+4; maxillary supports very slender; unpaired median piece pale with a black, heart-shaped basal area
Parapodia: Small but well formed; presetal lobe low and rounded, postsetal lobe bluntly conical; posterior parapodia elongate with presetal lobe increasing to about half the length of the postsetal lobe
Setae: Four to five smooth-winged capillaries between parapodial lobes
Acicula: One stout, blunt, projecting aciculum per foot plus three to four internal acicula with long tapering tips that may resemble emerging capillaries
Geographical distribution: South West Africa; Cape coast; Tristan da Cunha

Species name: Ophryotrocha puerilis Claparede & Metschnikov, 1869
Body: Small, vermiform, colourless; ~5 mm long with 20–30 segments; all segments with rings of cilia
Prostomium: Rounded; two ciliary rings; papilliform antennae dorsolaterally and similar palps anteroventrally; one pair of eyes
Jaws / Maxillae: Jaws brown and well chitinised; mandibles with divergent shafts and bilobed, crenulate cutting edges; maxillae composed of stout forceps (not dentate at base) plus seven pairs of dentate elements—basal three with ~5 teeth of decreasing size, distal four with ~12 minute subequal teeth
Parapodia: Small; setigerous lobe bearing both dorsal and ventral cirri
Setae: Dorsal one to three stout simple setae; median two to four unidentate falcigerous compound setae; ventral single simple pointed seta
Ecology: Intertidal; often appears in aquaria, feeding on algal films
Geographical distribution: Cosmopolitan in temperate and tropical seas

Species name: Protodorvillea egena Ehlers, 1913
Body: Small; 4–8 mm long with ~60 segments
Prostomium: Broadly conical; two pairs of eyes (anterior pair minute); antennae very small with a single club-shaped joint; palps long, wrinkled, each with a distinct terminal palpostyle
Cirri: Dorsal cirri short, ovoid, lacking cirrophores and internal acicula; present on all feet except the first and arising distally; ventral cirri ovoid
Parapodia: Setigerous lobes elongate with a triangular presetal lobe
Maxillae: Four rows of minute dentate elements
Setae: Superior setae include one serrated capillary and one to two forked setae with smooth shafts and short, equal prongs flanged internally; inferior setae four, compound, with short falcigerous blades bearing minutely bidentate tips
Geographical distribution: South India; Red Sea; South Africa (False Bay)

Species name: Dorvillea gardineri Crossland, 1924
Body: Large for the genus; up to ~50 mm long with ~100 segments
Prostomium: Small, rounded; four large eyes; separated from peristomium by a deep dorsal incision containing a prominent nuchal papilla
Antennae/palps: Antennae with ~10 indistinct annulations; palps slightly longer than antennae; terminal palpostyle weakly defined
Parapodia: With tapering dorsal cirri; cirrus composed of a long cirrophore incompletely fused to a much shorter cirrostyle (~¼ its length); dorsal cirrus present on setiger 1
Cirri: Dorsal cirri well developed; ventral cirri not emphasized
Maxillae: Four rows of toothed plates
Mandibles: Well developed; anterior margins denticulate
Setae: Superior setae capillaries with flattened blades and blunt tapering tips (broken setae may appear forked); inferior setae compound, falcigerous, with short tridentate blades
Ecology: Benthic; tropical marine habitats
Geographical distribution: Tropical Indian Ocean; recorded from Madagascar

Species name: Dorvillea neglecta Fauvel, 1923
Body: Small; ~15 mm long with ~80 segments
Prostomium: Broadly conical and depressed; two pairs of eyes
Antennae/palps: Palps long with a well-developed terminal palpostyle; antennae slightly shorter, with 8–11 joints
Mandibles: Dentate cutting edges; outer 3–4 teeth easily detached
Maxillae: Four rows of small toothed plates
Parapodia: Setigerous lobe elongate with a conical presetal lip and a shorter postsetal lobe
Cirri: No dorsal cirrus on setiger 1; subsequent dorsal cirri with a long cirrophore containing an internal aciculum and a cirrostyle about half its length
Setae: Superior setae include 3–4 fine, weakly serrated capillaries and 1–2 forked setae with subequal prongs and smooth shafts; inferior setae numerous, compound, with faintly serrated shafts and falcigerous blades of variable length bearing tridentate tips
Geographical distribution: English Channel; recorded from the Cape and Natal

Species name: Dorvillea rudolphi Delle Chiaje, 1825
Body: Small; ~15 mm long with ~80 segments
Prostomium: Broadly conical and depressed; two pairs of eyes
Antennae/palps: Palps long with a distinct terminal palpostyle; antennae slightly shorter, with 6–11 joints
Mandibles: Dentate cutting edges; outer 3–4 teeth easily detached
Maxillae: Four rows of small toothed plates
Parapodia: Setigerous lobe elongate with a conical presetal lip and a shorter postsetal lobe
Cirri: No dorsal cirrus on setiger 1; subsequent dorsal cirri with a long cirrophore containing an internal aciculum and a cirrostyle about half its length
Setae: Superior setae include 3–4 fine, weakly serrated capillaries and 1–2 forked setae with unequal prongs and serrated shafts; inferior setae numerous, compound, with faintly serrated shafts and falcigerous blades of variable length, bidentate and guarded by minute hoods
Ecology: Benthic marine species
Geographical distribution: English Channel; Mediterranean; Madeira; North Carolina; recorded from the Cape

Species name: Amphinome rostrata Pallas, 1766
Body: Large, up to ~250 mm; dark grey; pentagonal in cross-section
Prostomium: Rounded dorsally, ventrally grooved; lateral palps present; three dorsal antennae; two pairs of eyes
Caruncle: Small, smooth, cordate; extends to setiger 2
Branchiae: Tufts of branched filaments from setiger 2–3 onwards
Cirri: Single dorsal cirrus posterior to notosetae; ventral cirrus short
Notopodium / Notosetae: Notosetae include simple capillaries and characteristic harpoon-setae with pointed tips and recurved serrations
Neuropodium / Neurosetae: Neuropodium very short, stout, and widely separated from notopodium; neurosetae few, stout, curved, acicular
Acicula: With knobbed distal end
Ecology: Planktonic on driftwood; commonly associated with floating objects bearing Lepas
Geographical distribution: All warm and tropical seas; recorded from Agulhas Current (South Africa) on drifting substrates

Species name: Chloeia flava Pallas, 1766
Body: Oval in outline; up to ~70 mm long; dorsum with a median row of rounded purple spots
Prostomium: Median antenna slightly longer than lateral antennae
Caruncle: Well developed, extending to setiger 4; with >30 lateral pleats
Branchiae: Present from setiger 4 onwards
Notopodium / Notosetae: Notosetae serrated; anterior notosetae with a slight basal step but not distinctly forked
Neuropodium / Neurosetae: Neurosetae long, silky, spurred, not serrated
Ecology: Free-living amphinomid
Geographical distribution: Tropical Indo-Pacific; recorded from Natal (South Africa)

Species name: Chloeia fusca McIntosh, 1885
Body: Small, brownish; ~20 mm long; dorsum with a pair of narrow purple longitudinal stripes
Prostomium: Median antenna longer than lateral antennae
Caruncle: Extends to setiger 4; with ~16 lateral lamellae
Branchiae: Begin from setiger 5
Notosetae: Anterior notosetae smooth and distinctly forked, with the longer limb ~4× the shorter; posterior notosetae include serrated forms
Neurosetae: All neurosetae smooth and forked
Ecology: Free-living amphinomid
Geographical distribution: Tropical Indian Ocean; recorded from Natal (South Africa)

Species name: Pseudeurythoe microcephala Fauvel, 1932
Body: Slender; ~30 mm long with ~120 segments
Prostomium: Small; anterior part ventrally grooved with a pair of cirriform dorsal antennae and lateral palps; posterior part roughly square, often hidden by a skin fold, bearing two pairs of eyes and a median antenna similar to the lateral ones
Caruncle: Very small, oblong, usually concealed
Cirri: No hooks on setiger 1
Branchiae: Tufted branchiae from setiger 3 to mid-body
Notopodium / Notosetae: Few harpoon setae; numerous slender notosetae, smooth or with very faint serrations
Neuropodium / Neurosetae: Spurred setae of two types—most very long with a minute basal spur and lightly serrated blade; a few shorter with a strong spur and coarser serrations
Geographical distribution: Tropical Indian Ocean; recorded from Natal and Mozambique

Species name: Euphrosine myrtosa Savigny, 1818
Body: Ovoid; ~15 mm long with 36–43 setigers; colour red to purple
Prostomium: With four eyes; one stout, tapered median antenna; smaller antero-ventral antennae
Caruncle: Extends posteriorly to setiger 5
Branchiae: Six to eight branchial tufts per notopodium; branchial filaments long, evenly tapered with blunt tips
Cirri: Dorsal cirri longer than branchiae; first dorsal cirrus medial to first branchial trunk, second medial to third branchial trunk
Notosetae: All forked; two types present—(a) straight, smooth prongs and (b) curved prongs serrated on inner margins (ringent setae)
Neurosetae: Forked with smooth, straight prongs
Ecology: Occurs under stones and on old coral; rare
Geographical distribution: Mediterranean; Red Sea; Indian Ocean; tropical West Africa (Cameroons); recorded from South Africa (Cape to Natal) and Mozambique

Species name: Etiphrosine capensis Kinberg, 1857
Body: Ovoid; up to ~25 mm long; red in colour
Prostomium: Antennae and palps very short, almost papilliform
Caruncle: Extends to setiger 5 and overlaps setiger 6
Branchiae: Present from first setiger; notopodia with 9–11 branchial trunks even in juveniles; terminal branchial filaments end in ovoid, acorn-like tips
Cirri: Dorsal cirri shorter than branchiae; first dorsal cirrus medial to first branchial trunk, second medial to third branchial trunk
Notosetae: Two types—smooth forked setae with very unequal prongs, and forked ringent setae with prongs serrated on inner margins
Neurosetae: Forked, smooth, with unequal prongs
Ecology: Common under stones in the intertidal
Geographical distribution:  to southern Africa; recorded from South West Africa around the Cape to Natal

Species name: Eurythoe parvecarunculata Horst, 1912
Body: Elongate; up to ~220 mm long with ~120 segments
Prostomium: Median antenna much longer than laterals; posterior part with a very small oval caruncle, often concealed beneath a fold of setiger 2
Branchiae: From setiger 3; with long filaments anteriorly, progressively reduced posteriorly
Notosetae: Include short harpoon-setae and spurred setae with the longer prong tapering and serrated
Neurosetae: Predominantly forked setae; anterior segments also with finer setae bearing a basal step and faint serrations
Ecology: Free-living amphinomid polychaete
Geographical distribution: Tropical Indian Ocean and tropical West Africa; recorded from Natal, Mozambique, and possibly Madagascar

Species name: Eurythoe complanata Pallas, 1766
Body: Large, elongate and dorsoventrally flattened; up to ~140 mm long; colour greyish-green
Prostomium / Caruncle: Caruncle elongated with a flat keel; attached to setiger 3 and overlapping setiger 4
Branchiae: Present from setiger 2 onward
Notosetae: Of three types: smooth pointed capillaries; harpoon-setae with recurved serrations on one side; fine setae with a small spur/step and long slender blades with very faint serrations
Neurosetae: Of two main types, including forked forms and finer spurred setae (less diverse than notosetae)
Ecology: Common free-living amphinomid; often associated with coral rubble and hard substrates
Geographical distribution: All tropical seas; recorded from Eastern Cape, Natal, Mozambique, and Madagascar

Species name: Eurythoe chilensis Kinberg, 1857
Body: Small; usually ≤ 25 mm long with ~50 segments
Prostomium / Caruncle: Caruncle sinuous and elongate; attached to setiger 2 and overlapping setiger 3–4
Cirri: Dorsal cirri long and tapered
Branchiae: From setiger 2; each branchia with 4–7 finger-like filaments
Notosetae: Three main types: harpoon-setae; spurred setae with 2–4 widely spaced serrations on the longer prong; a few long spurred setae with minute serrations or steps on the blade
Neurosetae: Mostly stout spurred setae with more developed spurs and serrations than notosetae; a few long fine spurred setae with minute serrations
Ecology: On rocks and old shells
Geographical distribution: Southern Chile and Tristan da Cunha; recorded from the Cape region of South Africa

Species name: Pisionidens indica Aiyar & Alikunhi, 1940
Body: Elongate, slender, depressed; ~25 mm long with ~70 segments; segments weakly defined; dorsolateral muscular ridges and lateral grooves
Prostomium: Depressed conical; one pair of frontal antennae; lateral palps with basal sheaths; four closely grouped subdermal eyes
Peristome / Mouth: Peristome fused to prostomium; two pairs of long tentacular cirri; mouth a ventral slit at level of tentacular cirri
Pharynx / Jaws: Pharynx with marginal papillae; two pairs of small, lightly chitinised jaws
Parapodia: First 5–6 parapodia without setigerous lobes; subsequent parapodia with elongate setigerous lobe supported by an aciculum; adult parapodia lack setae
Cirri: Dorsal and ventral cirri small and biarticulate
Reproduction: Sexes separate; males with sperm-filled segments and a club-shaped vesicula seminalis opening on a large genital papilla (copulatory organ); females with a receptaculum seminis opening below the parapodium; series of median ventral genital suckers
Pygidium: With a pair of long cirri
Ecology: Surf beaches; locally common
Geographical distribution: India; recorded from Natal, South Africa

Species name: Mysta siphodonta Delle Chiaje, 1830
Body: Elongate and dorsoventrally flattened; up to ~200 mm long with ~350 segments; dorsum uniformly mauve-brown, ventrum pale
Prostomium: Depressed, truncate-conical; antennae equal and slender; eyes distinct
Tentacular cirri: Subequal; approximately as long as the width of the tentacular segment
Anterior segments: Segment following the tentacular segment lacks a dorsal cirrus but bears a setigerous lobe with several setae and a ventral cirrus
Proboscis: Wide dorsal band of minute, flattened, denticulate papillae; paired ventrolateral rows of large triangular papillae; narrow ventral streak—globular papillae absent in South African material
Cirri: Dorsal cirri ovate, 1.5–2× as long as broad, borne on fairly long cirrophores; ventral cirri bluntly pointed
Parapodia: Setigerous lobe blunt and shallowly notched
Setae: 15–20 per parapodium; blades fairly long; shaft-heads asymmetrical with one large blunt tooth and three to five smaller teeth
Geographical distribution: Mediterranean Sea; Atlantic coast of Africa (Morocco to Senegal); South Africa from False Bay to Natal

Species name: Phyllodoce quadraticeps Grube, 1878
Body: Slender, elongate; exceeding 100 mm in length; yellowish with a distinct dark transverse bar on each segment
Prostomium: Oval to subquadrate; posterior notch bearing an occipital papilla; antennae ovoid; a papilliform (possibly nuchal) organ present anterior to the first tentacular cirrus
Tentacular segments: First tentacular segment not visible dorsally; second and third tentacular segments distinct and separate; tentacular segments without setae (chaetal formula: 1 + 0 + 0)
Tentacular cirri: Unusual in form; D2 cylindrical and tapered; remaining cirri with long cirrophores and short, swollen cirrostyles
Proboscis: Very long; covered with irregularly arranged papillae
Cirri: Dorsal cirri reddish, oval, broader than long; ventral cirri oval
Parapodia: Setigerous lobes elongate and faintly bilobed
Setae: Five to six short setae per parapodium; shaft-heads swollen and striated; blades short and dagger-like
Geographical distribution: Tropical Indo–west Pacific; recorded from Mozambique Island

Species name: Phyllodoce fristedti Bergström, 1914
Body: Very long and slender; up to ~100 mm long and ~2 mm wide; colour uniformly bluish green
Prostomium: Cordate with large posterolateral lobes; posterior notch bearing a minute occipital papilla
Tentacular segments: First tentacular segment not visible dorsally; second and third tentacular segments distinct and separate; tentacular segments without setigerous lobes or setae (chaetal formula: 1 + 0 + 0)
Tentacular cirri: All tentacular cirri long and cylindrical
Proboscis: Proximally covered with small irregular papillae; distally with six rugose longitudinal ridges
Cirri: Dorsal cirri hastate in anterior segments, becoming rhomboidal with obliquely truncate distal margins posteriorly; ventral cirri oval and longer than the setigerous lobes
Parapodia: Setigerous lobes bluntly rounded
Setae: Fairly numerous; shaft-heads oval, distally striated; blades tapering
Geographical distribution: Western Indian Ocean; recorded from Madagascar and Mombasa (Kenya); type locality Ceylon (Sri Lanka)

Species name: Phyllodoce malmgreni Gravier, 1900
Body: Slender; about ~70 mm long; colour green, often with a dark median dorsal stripe
Prostomium: Cordate; occipital papilla absent
Tentacular segments: First tentacular segment not visible dorsally; second and third tentacular segments distinct and separate; third tentacular segment bearing a small setigerous lobe with setae (chaetal formula: 1 + 0 + S)
Tentacular cirri: Very long and cylindrical
Proboscis: Proximal region covered with irregularly arranged papillae; distal region with six rugose longitudinal ridges
Cirri: Dorsal cirri broadly rhomboidal or asymmetrically truncate; ventral cirri pointed and longer than the setigerous lobes
Parapodia: Setigerous lobes bluntly rounded
Setae: Numerous; shaft-heads oval and striated; blades strongly tapered
Geographical distribution: Red Sea and Indian Ocean; recorded from Mozambique; type locality Red Sea

Species name: Phyllodoce tubicola Day, 1963
Body: Very slender; about ~30 mm long; sometimes enclosed in a delicate, transparent, closely annulated tube
Prostomium: Longer than broad; with marked posterolateral lobes; posterior margin with a small notch containing a minute occipital papilla
Tentacular segments: First tentacular segment not visible dorsally; second and third distinct and separate; third tentacular segment bearing a few setae (chaetal formula: 1 + 0 + S)
Tentacular cirri: All extremely long and cylindrical; dorsal tentacular cirrus of segment 2 (D2) longest, reaching back to setiger 8
Proboscis: Proximal region covered with irregularly arranged papillae; distal half with rugose longitudinal ridges
Cirri: Dorsal cirri bluntly cordate in anterior segments, becoming longer and almost hastate posteriorly; ventral cirri tapered, pointed, and much longer than the setigerous lobes
Parapodia: Setigerous lobe with a bluntly rounded apex
Setae: Shaft-heads oval and distinctly striated; blades long and tapering
Ecology: Free-living or facultatively tubicolous; tube delicate and transparent
Geographical distribution:  to South Africa; Agulhas Bank and Cape region

Species name: Phyllodoce schmardai Day, 1963
Body: Moderately broad; green; up to ~30 mm long
Prostomium: Cordate; large eyes conspicuous; small occipital papilla present
Tentacular segments: First tentacular segment not visible dorsally; second and third distinct and separate; setae present on tentacular segments 2 and 3 (chaetal formula: 1 + S + S)
Tentacular cirri: All cylindrical and fairly long
Proboscis: Proximal half lightly papillose; distal half with six rugose longitudinal ridges
Cirri: Dorsal cirri cordate and as broad as long anteriorly, becoming longer and almost hastate posteriorly; ventral cirri broad at base, distally pointed, but not exceeding the length of the setigerous lobes
Parapodia: Setigerous lobes bluntly rounded
Setae: Shaft-heads oval and distally striated; blades relatively short
Geographical distribution: South Africa (Cape region: False Bay); distribution doubtful due to confused synonymy

Species name: Tomopteris nationalis Apstein, 1900
Body: Elongate, pelagic; up to ~20 mm long; body with 17 segments and a long posterior tail bearing 3–4 rudimentary parapodia
Prostomium: Shallowly notched between the antennae
Antennae and cirri: Antennae moderately long; first cirrus almost as long as the antennae; second cirrus exceptionally long, equalling body length plus tail
Parapodia: Biramous; pinnules restricted to the parapodial rami
Pinnules: Present only on rami, not on trunks
Glands: Chromophil glands large, swollen, present from the 2nd or 3rd parapodium onward; Spur glands present; Rosette glands present in the trunks of the first two parapodia and at the apices of both rami in subsequent parapodia
Gonads: Present in both rami from the 2nd parapodium (possibly from the 1st)
Ecology: Holopelagic planktonic species
Geographical distribution: Mediterranean Sea; recorded in warm currents off southern Africa

Species name: Tomopteris apsteini Rosa, 1908
Body: Pelagic, elongate; about ~20 mm long; body with 18–24 pairs of parapodia followed by a tapering tail formed by four additional segments
Prostomium: Notched between the antennae
Antennae and cirri: Antennae moderate; first cirrus small; second cirrus elongate, about three-quarters the length of the trunk
Parapodia: Biramous; pinnules restricted to the parapodial rami
Pinnules: Present only on rami
Glands: Chromophil glands present from the 3rd parapodium onward, rapidly becoming large and swollen; Spur glands present from the 2nd parapodium; Rosette glands absent; Hyaline glands absent, but a distinct clear glandular area present
Gonads: Present in both rami from the 1st parapodium
Ecology: Holopelagic planktonic species
Geographical distribution: Mediterranean Sea; subtropical and tropical Atlantic; tropical Pacific

Species name: Tomopteris helgolandica Greeff, 1879
Body: Pelagic, elongate; about ~12 mm long; trunk narrow with a distinct neck; 14–16 pairs of parapodia followed by a long tail bearing three to four rudimentary parapodia
Prostomium: Notched between the antennae
Antennae and cirri: Antennae moderate; first cirrus present in juveniles but lost in adults; second cirrus elongate, about two-thirds of body length
Parapodia: Biramous; pinnules restricted to the parapodial rami
Pinnules: Present only on rami; relatively narrow
Glands: Chromophil glands present from the 1st parapodium, always small and faint; situated in the middle of the inferior half of the pinnule; Rosette glands well developed from the 1st parapodium, located on the inner side of the pinnules near the apex of each ramus; Spur glands not reported
Gonads: Present in both rami from the 1st parapodium
Ecology: Holopelagic planktonic species
Geographical distribution: North Atlantic

Species name: Tomopteris dunckeri Rosa, 1908
Body: Pelagic, elongate; up to ~15 mm long; body with 16–17 pairs of parapodia followed by a tail bearing 9–10 additional parapodia; tail not sharply demarcated from trunk
Prostomium: Notched between the antennae; antennae large, often with a frilled margin; nuchal epaulettes very large
Antennae and cirri: First cirrus retained until late juvenile stage, with stumps still visible in adults; second cirrus slightly exceeding total body length
Parapodia: Biramous; pinnules restricted to the parapodial rami
Pinnules: Confined to rami; pinnules of middle parapodia appear reticulate when fresh
Glands: Chromophil glands large, beginning on the 3rd parapodium; Spur glands present from the 2nd or 3rd parapodium; Rosette glands present in the trunks of the first two parapodia and at the apices of both rami in later parapodia
Gonads: Present in the dorsal rami from the 1st or 2nd parapodium
Ecology: Holopelagic planktonic species
Geographical distribution: Indian Ocean (confirmed from Ceylon)

Species name: Tomopteris duccii Rosa, 1907
Body: Pelagic, elongate; trunk up to ~15 mm long with 19 pairs of parapodia, followed by a tail about 5 mm long
Prostomium: Not specified; consistent with genus Tomopteris
Antennae and cirri: First cirrus well developed; second cirrus about two-thirds of body length
Parapodia: Biramous; pinnules restricted to the parapodial rami
Pinnules: Confined to rami; ventral pinnule bearing major glandular structures
Glands: Chromophil glands large, beginning on the 5th parapodium and located in the inferior part of the ventral pinnule; spur glands well developed from the 3rd parapodium and indistinct on the 1st–2nd; rosette glands present in the trunks of the 1st and 2nd parapodia and near the apices of both rami in subsequent parapodia
Gonads: Present in the dorsal rami from the 2nd parapodium
Ecology: Holopelagic planktonic species
Geographical distribution: Eastern Pacific near Mexico (type locality); not recorded from southern Africa

Species name: Tomopteris euchaeta Chun, 1888
Body: Holopelagic, very large; reaching up to ~150 mm long; trunk with up to 39 body segments plus several distinct tail segments; juveniles much shorter with ~15 segments
Prostomium: Notched between long antennae; eyes small; pharynx short, not reaching the first parapodium
Antennae and cirri: Antennae very long, extending laterally to the width of the parapodia; first cirrus lost after larval stage and absent in juveniles and adults; second cirrus extremely long in juveniles (up to ~4× body length) but shorter than body length in adults
Parapodia: Biramous; rami expanded with very broad pinnules
Pinnules: Broad and divided into two regions—an outer frilly glandular zone and an inner clear zone resembling a flattened extension of the ramus; glandular margin not continuous between rami in juveniles
Glands: Chromophil glands present from the 4th parapodium, apico-inferior in position and becoming swollen in adults; spur glands absent; hyaline glands always present from the 3rd parapodium onwards on the distal inferior part of the ventral pinnule, indistinct but consistent; hyaline glands absent in dorsal pinnules of juveniles and variable in adults
Gonads: Present in the dorsal rami from the 2nd parapodium
Ecology: Deep-water holopelagic planktonic species, commonly recorded below 100 m and frequently below 500 m
Geographical distribution: Mediterranean Sea; temperate and tropical Atlantic; North Pacific (often recorded under Tomopteris nisseni)

Species name: Tomopteris krampi Wesenberg-Lund, 1936
Body: Holopelagic, elongate; up to ~26 mm long; trunk with 21 pairs of parapodia and a very short tail
Prostomium: Not notched between the antennae; antennae long and slender
Antennae and cirri: First cirrus retained in the adult but slender; second cirrus slightly longer than total body length
Parapodia: Biramous; parapodial trunks extended distally, with pinnules reaching onto the ends of the trunks
Pinnules: Pinnules extend onto distal ends of parapodial trunks; ventral pinnule larger and gland-bearing
Glands: Chromophil glands voluminous from the 4th parapodium onwards, located in the inferior half of the ventral pinnule; spur glands absent; hyaline glands very faint but present at the apices of both pinnules from the 3rd or 4th parapodium
Gonads: Present in the dorsal rami from the 3rd parapodium
Ecology: Holopelagic planktonic species, typically taken in deep-water hauls
Geographical distribution: Atlantic Ocean from south-west Iceland to the warm South Atlantic; also recorded from deep hauls off California

Species name: Tomopteris carpenteri Quatrefages, 1865
Body: Holopelagic, very large; reaching up to ~90 mm in length; trunk with ~35 pairs of parapodia; tail absent
Prostomium: Not notched between the antennae; neck short and broad
Antennae and cirri: Antennae long; first cirrus absent in adults; second cirrus about half the total body length
Parapodia: Biramous; parapodial trunks broad, with pinnules extending onto their distal ends
Pinnules: Oval and frilly; extend onto distal ends of parapodial trunks; ventral pinnule dominant and gland-bearing
Glands: Chromophil glands large and voluminous from the 4th parapodium onwards, situated in the inferior half of the ventral pinnule; spur glands absent; hyaline glands pigmented, appearing from the 3rd parapodium in the superior half of the ventral pinnule and present on all subsequent parapodia
Gonads: Present in both dorsal and ventral rami from the 1st or 2nd parapodium onwards
Ecology: Holopelagic planktonic species, characteristic of cold southern waters
Geographical distribution: Subantarctic and Antarctic Oceans

Species name: Tomopteris elegans Chun, 1888
Body: Holopelagic, slender and delicate; < 10 mm long; trunk with ~14 body segments; tail absent
Prostomium: Notched between long, broad antennae; neck narrow
Antennae and cirri: Antennae long and broad; first cirrus retained in adults but often small; second cirrus with a globular base, reaching about ⅔ of total body length
Parapodia: Biramous; parapodial trunks long and slender
Pinnules: Oval; restricted to the parapodial rami
Glands: Chromophil glands well developed from the 4th parapodium onwards, located below the tip of the ventral ramus; spur glands absent; hyaline glands restricted to the dorsal pinnules of the 3rd and 4th parapodia, positioned at the pinnule apex and usually evident only in sexually mature adults
Gonads: Present in the dorsal rami from the 3rd to about the 8th parapodium
Ecology: Holopelagic planktonic species, typically small and delicate
Geographical distribution: Atlantic Ocean (from temperate North Atlantic south to the subtropical convergence); warm North Pacific

Species name: Tomopteris planktonis Apstein, 1900
Body: Holopelagic, small and delicate; ~7 mm long; trunk with 13–18 pairs of parapodia; tail absent
Prostomium: Not notched between the antennae; neck broad and short
Antennae and cirri: Antennae long; first cirrus absent in adults; second cirrus reaching up to ~¾ of total body length
Parapodia: Biramous; parapodia relatively short; pinnules confined to the parapodial rami
Pinnules: Restricted to rami; ventral pinnules swollen proximally due to gland development
Glands: Chromophil glands large and conspicuous from the 4th parapodium onwards, situated proximally in the inferior half of the ventral pinnule and causing a distinct swelling; spur glands absent; hyaline glands indistinct but present at the apices of ventral pinnules from the 1st parapodium onwards
Gonads: Present in the dorsal rami from the 2nd or 3rd parapodium onwards
Ecology: Holopelagic planktonic species, common in open ocean waters
Geographical distribution: North Atlantic to Antarctic; subarctic North Pacific; widespread around southern Africa

Species name: Tomopteris cavallii Rosa, 1907
Body: Holopelagic, very small and delicate; ~5 mm long; trunk with 17 pairs of parapodia; tail absent
Prostomium: Shallowly notched between the antennae; neck broad and short
Antennae and cirri: Antennae short; first cirrus absent in adults; second cirrus reaching about ⅔ of total body length
Parapodia: Biramous; parapodial trunks short; pinnules confined to the parapodial rami
Pinnules: Restricted to rami; dorsal pinnules of the first 2–3 parapodia contain diffuse tubular glands
Glands: Chromophil glands large, beginning on the 4th parapodium, situated centrally in the inferior half of the ventral pinnule; tubular glands present in dorsal pinnules of the first 2–3 parapodia; spur glands absent; hyaline glands absent; rosette glands absent
Gonads: Present in the dorsal rami from the 1st or 2nd parapodium
Ecology: Holopelagic planktonic species
Geographical distribution: North-western Atlantic; Indian Ocean; western Pacific; southern African records doubtful and possibly referable to Tomopteris planktonis

Species name: Travisiopsis lanceolata Southern, 1910
Body: Fusiform; up to ~30 mm long; head region of three segments followed by ~19 trunk segments; head segments each bearing a single pair of lamellar cirri; trunk segments with both dorsal and ventral cirri
Prostomium: Conical; bearing a stout palpode
Caruncle: Broad and T-shaped; base transversely oval, produced posteriorly as a freely projecting tongue-shaped lobe
Nuchal organs: Present as paired ridges embracing the caruncle and extending posteriorly as free digitiform lobes, about twice the length of the caruncle
Cirri: Dorsal and ventral cirri reniform to quadrangular or cordate in the mid-body; becoming progressively elongated posteriorly; posterior cirri lanceolate
Anal cirri: Ovate-lanceolate; broader at the base, tapering distally; reinforced by a median rib
Ecology: Holopelagic, recorded from deep plankton tows
Geographical distribution: North Atlantic; temperate South Atlantic (deep waters); North Pacific

Species name: Travisiopsis lobifera Levinsen, 1885
Body: Fusiform; up to ~25 mm long; composed of three anterior head segments followed by ~18 trunk segments; head segments each bearing a pair of lamellar cirri; trunk segments with both dorsal and ventral cirri
Prostomium: Conical; with a large, well-developed anterior palpode
Caruncle: Present as a swollen, oval structure formed by the dorsal surface of the head; freely projecting posterior lobe absent
Nuchal organs: Paired semicircular ridges embracing the caruncle; posteriorly continuous with a pair of digitiform lobes
Cirri: Dorsal and ventral cirri cordate in the mid-body; becoming progressively pointed towards the posterior end
Anal cirri: Subtriangular; distally expanded; approximately as broad as long
Parapodia: Setigerous lobes and setae weakly developed anteriorly but well marked on posterior segments
Ecology: Holopelagic; recorded from plankton tows
Geographical distribution: Temperate and tropical North and South Atlantic; temperate to subtropical Pacific

Species name: Travisiopsis levinseni Southern, 1910
Body: Fusiform; up to ~24 mm long; composed of three anterior head segments followed by ~22 trunk segments; head segments each bearing a single pair of lamellar cirri; trunk segments with both dorsal and ventral cirri
Prostomium: Conical; with a small, distinct palpode
Caruncle: Flattened, almost rectangular; without any freely projecting posterior lobe
Nuchal organs: A pair of short, semicircular, freely projecting lobes; bases extend anteriorly as narrow ridges alongside the caruncle and join a pair of small wart-like lobes
Head cirri: Three pairs of lamellar cirri enveloping the head region
Cirri (trunk): Dorsal and ventral cirri cordate with a broad area of attachment in mid-body; posterior cirri elongate and tapered
Anal cirri: Ovate–triangular; narrower proximally and broader distally
Ecology: Holopelagic, deep-water species collected in plankton tows
Geographical distribution: Temperate North Atlantic; South Atlantic; subantarctic and Antarctic waters; North Pacific off California

Species name: Ancistrosyllis rigida Fauvel, 1919
Body: Slender, rigid, wiry; up to ~35 mm long; segments uniform, muscular, and similar throughout
Prostomium: Small, sometimes partially retracted; three short, subequal, fusiform antennae; palps large with minute terminal palpostyles
Tentacular segment: Distinct and comparable in size to setigerous segments; bears two pairs of short tentacular cirri similar to antennae
Parapodia: Small, lateral, weakly developed; biramous condition highly modified
Notopodium: Represented solely by a fusiform dorsal cirrus containing an internal aciculum; from approximately setigers 12–20 onward, a stout, heavy, projecting notopodial spine develops; spine blunt-tipped, only slightly curved, never hooked
Neuropodium: Small, truncate setigerous lobe; bears neurosetae and a fusiform ventral cirrus slightly smaller than the dorsal cirrus
Cirri: Dorsal cirri Fusiform, present on all segments including setiger 2; Ventral cirri Fusiform, slightly shorter than dorsal cirri
Setae: Neurosetae include one to two short forked setae and several capillaries with minutely spinulose margins; true notosetae absent
Geographical distribution: Circumtropical; recorded from the Red Sea and Natal, South Africa

Species name: Ancistrosyllis cf. constricta Southern, 1921
Body: Juvenile specimens; small, 3–4 mm long with ~36 setigers; body slender; no distinct constricted neck region
Prostomium: With three cirriform antennae; two pairs of eyes present; palps massive, bent ventrally, each bearing a slender palpostyle
Pharynx: Muscular; jaws absent
Peristomium (Tentacular segment): Distinct from prostomium; bears two pairs of tentacular cirri
Parapodia: Present on all setigers; setigerous lobe blunt; parapodia otherwise simple and weakly developed
Notopodium: Typical, well defined; bears an internal aciculum, one to two fine capillary setae, and a stout recurved hook; notopodial hook first appears on setiger 8
Neuropodium: Reduced; bears only serrated capillary neurosetae; hooks absent
Cirri: Dorsal cirri tapered; ventral cirri tapered but absent on setiger 2
Setae: Notosetae include fine capillaries and a stout recurved hook; neurosetae consist of serrated capillaries only
Ontogenetic note: Description based on juveniles; adult morphology unknown; identification tentative
Geographical distribution: India (type locality of A. constricta); South Africa (Natal)

Species name: Ancistrosyllis robusta Ehlers, 1908
Body: Elongate, colourless; up to ~54 mm long with ~182 segments; segments uniform
Prostomium: Broader than long, rounded anteriorly; three slender antennae present, median antenna extending posteriorly to about setiger 5; palps stout with knob-shaped palpostyles
Pharynx: Short and stout; mouth opening surrounded by 16 ovoid papillae
Peristomium (Tentacular segment): Distinct from prostomium; bears two pairs of tentacular cirri similar to antennae but shorter
Parapodia: Present from setiger 1; parapodial lobes well developed; anterior parapodia with setae and cirri already present
Notopodium: Represented by a tapered dorsal cirrus containing a fine internal aciculum in anterior segments; from approximately setiger 70 onward, the aciculum is replaced by a stout, projecting notopodial hook
Neuropodium: Forms an ovoid setigerous lobe; bears only capillary neurosetae
Cirri: Dorsal cirri Tapered; dorsal cirrus of setiger 1 conspicuously elongate, about twice the length of the tentacular cirri; Ventral cirri Short; presence on setiger 2 uncertain
Setae: Neuropodial setae capillary only; shorter capillaries finely serrated, longer capillaries smooth; true notosetae absent
Ontogenetic note: Development of stout notopodial hook in posterior segments is a key diagnostic character distinguishing this species from other Ancistrosyllis
Geographical distribution: Known only from type locality, Great Fish Bay, Angola

Species name: Ophiodromus agilis Ehlers, 1864
Body: Small; ~4–5 mm; 16–22 setigers
Prostomium: Square; four eyes; anterior pair slightly larger and more widely spaced; median antenna fusiform, about prostomial length; lateral antennae similar, longer; palps elongate with short palpophores
Proboscis: Without papillae or jaws
Peristomium (Tentacular segments): Six pairs of tentacular cirri; cirri fusiform; borne on ringed ceratophores
Parapodia: Biramous, weakly developed
Notopodium: Reduced; aciculum, single capillary seta, vaguely ringed dorsal cirrus
Neuropodium: Triangular presetal lobe; rounded postsetal lip
Cirri: Dorsal cirri fusiform, weakly ringed; ventral cirri slender
Setae: Notosetae single capillary; neurosetae falcigerous with long, finely bidentate blades
Diagnostic character: Reduced notopodium with single capillary and aciculum; falcigerous neurosetae with long bidentate blades
Geographical distribution: Mediterranean; doubtful record from Natal, South Africa

Species name: Syllidia armata Quatrefages, 1865
Body: Small, <10 mm; rather broad; 26–35 setigers; greenish-yellow with transverse stripes, fading in alcohol
Prostomium: Almost square; four eyes; two long antennae; palps biarticulate
Proboscis: Armed; median ventral stylet; paired lateral jaws with serrated cutting edges; margin with 10–15 papillae
Peristomium (Tentacular segments): Six pairs of tentacular cirri; cirri annulated
Parapodia: Uniramous
Notopodium: Reduced to dorsal cirrus; aciculum present in cirrophore
Neuropodium: Triangular presetal lip; low, rounded postsetal lamella
Cirri: Dorsal cirri long, faintly annulated
Setae: Falcigerous; blades variable in length; terminal hook with very fine secondary tooth below
Geographical distribution: Eastern Atlantic (Scotland to Angola); Mediterranean; recorded from South West Africa and Cape, South Africa

Species name: Syllidia capensis McIntosh, 1925
Body: Greyish; ~12 mm long
Prostomium: Antennae unknown; four eyes; palps slightly tapered with articulation at distal third
Parapodia: Uniramous
Notopodium: Represented by long dorsal cirrus; cirrophore with at least four internal spines
Neuropodium: Three pointed lobes; median lobe markedly larger than lateral lobes
Cirri: Dorsal cirrus long; ventral cirrus present
Setae: Neurosetae variable in length; median setae longest with hair-like tips; inferior setae with minutely bidentate blades
Geographical distribution: South Africa (Cape; single doubtful deep-water record)

Species name: Hesione splendida Savigny, 1818
Body: Cylindrical, slightly posteriorly tapered; 40–70 mm long; 4–6 mm broad
Prostomium: Deeply posteriorly notched; four eyes, anterior pair larger and more widely spaced; two minute anterolateral antennae
Pharynx: Wide, smooth; ovoid dorsal tubercle anterior to prostomium; jaws and marginal papillae absent
Tentacular cirri: Jointed, subequal; arranged in oblique rows 3,3,2
Parapodia: Well developed; setigerous lobe stout
Notopodium: Dorsal cirri long, closely jointed; borne on long cirrophores with fine internal acicula
Neuropodium: With presetal and postsetal lips; superior conical papilla present
Cirri: Dorsal cirri long, articulated; ventral cirri short, indistinctly jointed; two long anal cirri
Setae: Falcigerous; blades of variable length; tips bidentate with two strong teeth and a fine straight accessory tooth
Geographical distribution: Eastern Atlantic (France to Senegal); Mediterranean; Red Sea; tropical Indo–west Pacific

Species name: Leocrates claparedii Costa, 1868
Body: Stout; 40–60 mm long; 16–17 rounded setigers
Prostomium: Bilobed; antennae slender; palps stout; large ovoid facial tubercle anterior to prostomium
Pharynx (Proboscis): With one stout styliform dorsal tooth and one finer ventral tooth
Tentacular cirri: Long, closely annulated; tentaculophores strengthened by black acicula
Parapodia: Well developed
Notopodium: Notopodial capillaries from setiger 4–5; capillaries distally finely serrated
Neuropodium: Bearing falcigerous neurosetae
Cirri: Dorsal and tentacular cirri elongate, annulated
Setae: Notosetae capillary, distally serrated; neurosetae falcigerous, blades bidentate with an additional fine accessory tooth
Geographical distribution: Senegal; Mediterranean; Red Sea; tropical Indo–west Pacific; South Africa (Transkei to Natal)

Species name: Pharyngeovalvata natalensis Day, 1951
Body: Soft, dorsally swollen; ~12 mm long
Prostomium: Broader than long; large eyes (possibly two pairs fused); palps bent ventrally; occipital flap present
Pharynx: Valvate; longitudinal dorsal ridge meeting transverse ventro-lateral ridges at ~setiger 5; chitinous teeth absent
Proventriculus: From setiger 10–18; ~70 rows of points
Antennae: Long, indistinctly jointed
Tentacular cirri: Long, indistinctly jointed
Parapodia: Weakly developed
Notopodium: Without distinct notosetae
Neuropodium: Bearing compound setae
Cirri: Dorsal cirri long, indistinctly jointed
Setae: Compound; shaft-heads expanded; blades short, hooked; unidentate or with minute secondary tooth
Geographical distribution: South Africa (Natal; Cape);

Species name: Haplosyllis trifalcata Day, 1960
Body: ~9 mm long; ~88 segments; pale in alcohol
Prostomium: Four eyes; antennae short, subequal; palps broad, not fused
Pharynx: Elongate; proventriculus with ~40 rows of points
Parapodia: Small; each parapodium with 3–6 simple setae
Notopodium: Reduced; no distinct notosetae
Neuropodium: Bearing simple setae only
Cirri: Dorsal cirri very short, tapered, often coiled; 9–12 articulations; ventral cirri small
Setae: Simple; shaft-head expanded; terminally trifalcate with three subequal claw-like teeth
Geographical distribution: South Africa (False Bay, Cape)

Species name: Syllis gracilis Grube, 1840
Body: Slender; ~35 mm long; two dark transverse cross-bars on anterior segments
Prostomium: Four eyes; antennae stout, 8–12 articulations
Pharynx: Long; single anterior tooth
Proventriculus: From setiger 10 to 14
Parapodia: Typical syllid form
Notopodium: Reduced
Neuropodium: Bearing compound and simple setae
Cirri: Dorsal cirri stout; anterior cirri cylindrical with ~16 joints; median cirri shorter, fusiform with 8–12 joints
Setae: Anterior parapodia with compound bidentate setae; mid-body parapodia with 2–3 stout Y-shaped simple setae (derived from loss of blade of compound setae); compound setae reappearing posteriorly
Geographical distribution: Cosmopolitan in temperate and tropical seas; South West Africa to Mozambique

Species name: Syllis amica Quatrefages, 1866
Body: Slender; 20–60 mm long
Prostomium: Four eyes
Pharynx: Long; single anterior tooth
Proventriculus: Extending over five segments
Parapodia: Typical syllid form
Notopodium: Reduced
Neuropodium: Bearing compound and simple setae
Cirri: Dorsal cirri stout but tapered; 15–25 articulations; length approximately equal to body width
Setae: Compound setae numerous with short unidentate or minutely bidentate blades; one to three stout simple setae formed by loss of blade, shaft-head obliquely truncate; aciculum with small apical knob
Geographical distribution: Northeastern Atlantic and Mediterranean; recorded from Natal, South Africa

Species name: Syllis anops Ehlers, 1897
Body: Slender; 15–25 mm; ~120 segments
Prostomium: Broader than long; eyes absent
Antennae: Short, subequal; 25–30 joints
Palps: Fused basally
Pharynx: With anterior tooth
Proventriculus: Extending over ~11 segments
Parapodia: Typical syllid parapodia
Notopodium: Reduced
Neuropodium: Bearing compound and modified setae
Cirri: Dorsal cirri about equal to body width; ~30 joints; ventral cirri short, arising near distal end of setigerous lobes
Setae: Anterior compound setae with blades of unequal length, tips minutely bidentate; middle parapodia with superior Langerhansia-type setae with very long slender blades and inferior setae with normal unidentate blades; acicula very stout with blunt tip
Geographical distribution: Magellan region; Chatham Islands; recorded from the Cape, South Africa

Species name: Paraehlersia ferrugina Langerhans, 1881
Body: Thread-like; ~10 mm; slender
Prostomium: With four eyes and two ocular specks
Palps: Large
Pharynx: Long; anterior tooth present
Proventriculus: With ~25 rows of points
Parapodia: Typical syllid parapodia
Notopodium: Reduced
Neuropodium: Bearing compound and modified setae
Cirri: Dorsal cirri long, slender; 15–25 joints, joints distinct anteriorly, poorly marked posteriorly; ventral cirri slightly longer than setigerous lobes
Setae: Anterior compound setae with blades of variable length, terminal tooth stronger than secondary; middle parapodia with 1–2 superior Langerhansia-type setae with greatly elongated blades, remaining setae with short blades and secondary tooth stronger than terminal; acicula stout with knobbed tips in middle parapodia
Geographical distribution: Eastern and western Atlantic, from North Carolina and Ireland to Angola; common around the Cape, South Africa

Species name: Syllis cornuta Rathke, 1843
Body: Thread-like; 10–15 mm
Prostomium: With four eyes and two ocular specks
Palps: Large
Pharynx: Long; anterior tooth present
Proventriculus: With ~30–35 rows of points
Parapodia: Typical syllid parapodia
Notopodium: Reduced
Neuropodium: Bearing compound setae
Cirri: Dorsal cirri short; 10–18 joints; joints always clearly marked
Setae: One to three superior compound setae with very long blades; ~six compound setae with normal bidentate blades, secondary tooth slender
Geographical distribution: Atlantic from Greenland to Georgia (USA) and Scotland to Antarctic; tropical Indian Ocean; common along South African coast

Species name: Syllis prolifera Krohn, 1852
Body: 10–20 mm; anterior segments with two dark transverse lines
Prostomium: With four eyes; palps fairly long, separate
Antennae: Median antenna with ~27 joints; lateral antennae with ~16 joints
Pharynx: Extending to setiger 9
Proventriculus: Extending to setiger 15; ~25–30 rows of points
Parapodia: Typical syllid parapodia
Notopodium: Reduced
Neuropodium: Bearing compound setae
Cirri: Dorsal cirri alternately long and short; with ~22 and ~27 joints respectively
Setae: ~10 compound setae; blades strongly bidentate; of normal length
Geographical distribution: Eastern Atlantic from South West Africa to the Cape; Mozambique; British Channel; Mediterranean; Indo–West Pacific

Species name: Syllis variegata Grube, 1860
Body: Up to ~40 mm; tough; anterior segments with broken brown transverse bars
Prostomium: With four eyes
Pharynx: Long; reaching setiger 12; anterior dorsal tooth present
Proventriculus: Long; extending over ~8–10 segments
Parapodia: Typical syllid parapodia
Notopodium: Reduced
Neuropodium: Bearing compound setae
Cirri: Dorsal cirri longer than body width; with ~20–40 distinct joints
Setae: All compound; blades strongly bidentate; of normal length
Geographical distribution: South West Africa; Cape coast; Natal; Mozambique; cosmopolitan in temperate and tropical seas

Species name: Opisthosyllis ankylochaeta Fauvel, 1921
Body: Smooth, colourless; ~15 mm long
Prostomium: With four large eyes; palps long, separated at base; occipital flap absent
Pharynx: With dorsal tooth positioned far posteriorly at ~setiger 10
Proventriculus: Long; extending over ~6 segments
Peristomium (Tentacular segment): Tentacular cirri with ~30 joints
Parapodia: Typical syllid parapodia
Notopodium: Reduced
Neuropodium: Bearing compound and simple setae depending on segment
Cirri: Dorsal cirri alternating in length; longer cirri ~30-jointed and about equal to body width, shorter cirri with fewer joints; ventral cirri sausage-shaped
Setae: Anterior and posterior feet with compound unidentate setae; middle feet with two simple setae formed by fusion of short hooked blade to shaft
Geographical distribution: Madagascar (Tamatave); New Caledonia

Species name: Opisthosyllis brunnea Langerhans, 1879
Body: Smooth, soft, rather broad; up to ~10 mm; ~75 segments
Prostomium: With occipital flap covering posterior eye pair and part of prostomium
Palps: Tapered; about twice prostomial length
Pharynx: Long, broad; small dorsal tooth at ~setiger 8
Proventriculus: Extending over ~8 segments; ~70 rows of points
Parapodia: Typical syllid parapodia
Notopodium: Reduced
Neuropodium: Bearing compound setae
Cirri: Dorsal cirri slender; ~20 joints
Setae: Compound; blades short, unidentate
Geographical distribution: Madeira; tropical West Africa; South Africa (False Bay to Natal); Mozambique

Species name: Trypanosyllis prampramensis Augener, 1918
Body: Elongate, ribbon-like; ~25 mm long, ~2 mm broad; two dark transverse lines on anterior segments
Prostomium: Broader than long, faintly bilobed; four anterior eyes; palps short; antennae short with 10–12 joints
Pharynx: Short; trepan with ~10 triangular teeth
Proventriculus: With ~25–30 rows of points
Peristomium (Tentacular segment): Tentacular cirri with 15–20 joints
Parapodia: Typical for genus
Notopodium: Reduced
Neuropodium: Bearing compound setae
Cirri: Dorsal cirri short, stout, often spindle-shaped; 8–12 joints; purplish when fresh
Setae: ~10 compound setae per parapodium; blades short, unidentate, hooked
Reproduction: Possibly single sexual stolon
Geographical distribution: Tropical western Africa; South Africa Tropical

Species name: Trypanosyllis ankyloseta Day, 1960
Body: Very short, flattened, oval; ~8 mm long, ~1.8 mm broad; ~120 segments; segments extremely short, ~20× broader than long
Prostomium: Inserted between anterior segments; four eyes in rectangular arrangement; palps ovoid; antennae three, short, with 6–8 joints
Pharynx: Long, S-shaped; trepan with ~10 teeth
Proventriculus: With ~40–50 rows of points
