Peristomium (Tentacular segment): Not distinctly differentiated
Parapodia: Reduced
Notopodium: Reduced
Neuropodium: Bearing simple setae
Cirri: Dorsal cirri short with 6–8 joints; ventral cirri inconspicuous
Setae: Simple; falcate blade fused to shaft-head
Geographical distribution: South Africa, False Bay (; single record)

Species name: Trypanosyllis zebra Grube, 1860
Body: Elongate, flattened, ribbon-like; ~30–60 mm long; two purple transverse bars per segment; dorsal cirri often purple
Prostomium: Broader than long; four eyes
Pharynx: With trepan of ~10 triangular teeth; additional dorsal tooth present
Proventriculus: Long; ~30 rows of points
Parapodia: Biramous, well developed
Notopodium: With dorsal cirrus
Neuropodium: Bearing compound setae
Cirri: Dorsal cirri alternating long and short; ~20–50 short joints; ventral cirri pointed
Setae: Compound, bidentate; secondary tooth close behind terminal tooth; blade without basal spur; cutting edge spinulose
Reproduction: Single stolon; clusters of buds absent
Geographical distribution: North Atlantic; Mediterranean; tropical Indian Ocean; Japan; southern Africa from False Bay to Natal and Mozambique

Species name: Amblyosyllis formosa Claparede, 1863
Body: Short; ~10–15 mm; 13 setigers; segments nearly as long as broad; dorsal pattern of broken purple bars
Prostomium: Roughly square; four large eyes; palps bent ventrally, fused basally; prominent nuchal epaulettes reaching setiger 2
Pharynx: Long, coiled; crown of 6–7 teeth
Proventriculus: Ovoid
Antennae: Very long, coiled, pseudo-articulate
Tentacular cirri: Very long, coiled, pseudo-articulate
Parapodia: Well developed
Notopodium: With long, coiled dorsal cirrus
Neuropodium: With ventral cirrus and compound setae
Cirri: Dorsal cirri very long, coiled, pseudo-articulate; ventral cirri pinniform, postero-ventral, longer than setigerous lobes
Setae: Compound; blades finely bidentate; blade length variable
Geographical distribution: North Atlantic (Plymouth to Senegal); Mediterranean; Japan; South Africa Tropical; Madagascar

Species name: Syllides longocirrata Oersted, 1845
Body: Small; ~5 mm; 37–46 segments; parapodia and cirri elongate
Prostomium: Broader than long; palps large, fused basally, bent ventrally
Antennae: Distally swollen, wrinkled
Tentacular cirri: Distally swollen, wrinkled
Pharynx: Unarmed
Proventriculus: 40–45 rows of points
Parapodia: Long
Notopodium: With compound setae and a simple superior seta
Neuropodium: With compound setae
Cirri: Anterior dorsal cirri slightly swollen distally; posterior dorsal cirri long with 10–15 distinct joints; ventral cirri slender
Setae: Compound setae with long, minutely bidentate blades; one superior simple sabre-like seta per parapodium with minutely serrated blade
Geographical distribution: North-east Atlantic; Mediterranean; Chile; New Zealand; South Africa Tropical

Species name: Odontosyllis polycera Schmarda, 1861
Body: Soft, dorsally swollen, fragile; up to ~50 mm long by ~2 mm wide
Prostomium: With four large eyes arranged rectangularly; median antenna inserted between and posterior to lateral antennae; large occipital flap covering most of prostomium
Pharynx: Long, vertically S-shaped; anterior half thin-walled with soft dorsal ridge; posterior half thick-walled; minute dorsal tooth at junction; ventral semicircle of 6–9 triangular teeth with lateral cutting plates
Proventriculus: Long; 60–80 rows of points
Antennae: Tapered, smooth to faintly wrinkled
Parapodia: With numerous compound setae
Notopodium: Reduced; dorsal cirrus only
Neuropodium: Setigerous lobe with compound setae
Cirri: Dorsal cirri tapered, smooth or faintly wrinkled; anterior dorsal cirri relatively long, middle-body dorsal cirri less than half body width; ventral cirri swollen, cushion-like, ventro-lateral to setigerous lobe
Setae: ~25 compound setae per parapodium; blades short, triangular, bidentate; secondary tooth median on blade
Geographical distribution: Southern Africa (South West Africa, Cape region, Mozambique); Madagascar; Chatham Islands (New Zealand)

Species name: Pionosyllis magnidens Day, 1953
Body: Small; ~4 mm long; ~45 segments
Prostomium: Broader than long; two pairs of eyes; palps united basally, bent ventrally
Antennae: Tapered, wrinkled, non-annulated
Pharynx: With very large dorsal tooth; extending to setiger 4
Proventriculus: Extending to setiger 11
Parapodia: Setigerous lobes truncate
Notopodium: Reduced; dorsal cirrus only
Neuropodium: Bearing compound setae
Cirri: Dorsal cirri similar to antennae, equal to body width; ventral cirri conical
Setae: Compound only; blades short, unidentate, strongly hooked; simple setae absent
Geographical distribution: South Africa, Cape coast (Lamberts Bay, Cape Province)

Species name: Pionosyllis longocirrata Saint-Joseph, 1887
Body: Small; ~8 mm; soft, very fragile
Prostomium: Not specified
Antennae: Smooth, extremely long
Pharynx: Short; anterior tooth present
Proventriculus: ~30 rows of points
Parapodia: Setigerous lobes long
Notopodium: With very long dorsal cirri only
Neuropodium: Bearing compound setae only
Cirri: Anterior dorsal cirri exceedingly long; posterior dorsal cirri shorter but still >2× body width; ventral cirri large, triangular
Setae: Compound only; very long, fine; blades slender, bidentate; terminal tooth strong and hooked; secondary tooth weak, directed toward terminal tooth; simple setae absent
Geographical distribution: English Channel; Mediterranean; South Africa Tropical

Species name: Spermosyllis capensis Day, 1953
Body: ~12 mm; ~60 segments
Prostomium: Broader than long; single median antenna arising near anterior margin; palps large, tapered, transversely striated, fused throughout
Pharynx: Extending to setiger 6
Proventriculus: To setiger 9; ~25 rows of points
Peristomium (Tentacular segment): Separate from prostomium; partially fused to setiger 1
Parapodia: Setigerous lobes obliquely truncate
Notopodium: With dorsal cirrus only
Neuropodium: Bearing compound and simple setae
Cirri: Dorsal cirri ovoid, present on all setigers; ventral cirri present throughout
Setae: Superior simple seta from ~setiger 12 onward; 1–3 compound setae with long, knife-like blades; 5–8 compound falcigers with short blades, secondary tooth large, terminal tooth minute
Geographical distribution: South Africa (Langebaan Lagoon; Cape)

Species name: Anguillosyllis capensis Day, 1963
Body: Minute, thread-like; ~5 mm; ~30 segments; tapered at both ends; segments ~4× broader than long
Prostomium: Broader than long; eyes absent; three minute papilliform antennae; palps very large, tapered, fused for half their length, projecting anteriorly as a rostrum
Pharynx: Short, broad, straight; to setiger 3; unarmed; dorsal tooth absent
Proventriculus: Barrel-shaped; setigers 3–6; ~30 rows of points
Peristomium (Tentacular segment): Distinct; one pair of papilliform tentacular cirri
Parapodia: Large; setigerous lobe with tapered, retractile dorsal projection
Notopodium: Represented by long, often coiled dorsal cirrus
Neuropodium: With setigerous lobe and ventral cirrus
Cirri: Dorsal cirri long, often coiled; ventral cirri slender, distinct
Setae: All compound; long and fine; blades uniformly slender with blunt apical tooth
Geographical distribution: South Africa (Agulhas Bank; Cape);

Species name: Exogone clavator Ehlers, 1913
Body: Slender; ~4.5 mm; 40–50 segments
Prostomium: Broader than long; four eyes; lateral antennae short; median antenna long, club-shaped, arising between eyes; palps large, fused almost to tips
Pharynx: ~3 segments long; anterior dorsal tooth present
Proventriculus: ~2.5 segments; ~25 rows of points
Peristomium (Tentacular segment): Tentacular cirri minute, ovoid
Parapodia: Setigerous lobes truncate; parapodia with single aciculum bearing knobbed tip
Notopodium: Reduced; no true notosetae
Neuropodium: Setigerous lobe bearing compound and simple setae
Cirri: Dorsal cirri ovoid, present on all segments including setiger 2; ventral cirri slightly smaller, present on all feet
Setae: Superior simple seta with obliquely truncate tip from ~setiger 10, increasing in stoutness posteriorly; inferior simple seta appearing in posterior segments; anterior feet with two superior compound setae with long sword-shaped blades, reduced to one then absent posteriorly; ~3 compound setae with short bidentate chopper-shaped blades, terminal tooth minute, secondary tooth larger
Geographical distribution: Southern Africa (South West Africa to Cape);

Species name: Exogone normalis Day, 1963
Body: Slender, smooth, pale; ~5 mm long; segment number not fixed
Prostomium: Short; 2–3 pairs of eyes; median antenna longer than prostomium, reaching palpal base; lateral antennae short, ~⅓ median length
Palps: Large, completely fused; longer than broad
Pharynx: To setiger 5; dorsal tooth present
Proventriculus: To setiger 10; ~23 rows of points
Peristomium (Tentacular segment): Indistinct; tentacular cirri minute, papilliform, half size of first dorsal cirri
Parapodia: Small; setigerous lobes low
Notopodium: Absent as a distinct lobe
Neuropodium: Bears compound and simple setae
Cirri: Dorsal cirri small, ovoid, absent from setiger 2; ventral cirri longer than setigerous lobes, projecting distally
Setae: Compound setae uniform with straight unidentate blades and pointed shaft-heads; superior simple seta blunt, needle-like from ~setiger 10, stouter posteriorly; inferior simple seta present on last few segments
Geographical distribution: South Africa, Agulhas Bank ()

Species name: Exogone heterosetosa McIntosh, 1885
Body: Minute, smooth; ~2 mm long; segments numerous
Prostomium: Broader than long; two pairs of eyes; anterior eye-specks sometimes present; median antenna equal to prostomial length; lateral antennae shorter
Palps: Large, fused almost to tips
Peristomium (Tentacular segment): Distinct
Parapodia: Small; setigerous lobes low
Notopodium: Absent as distinct lobe
Neuropodium: Bears simple and compound setae
Cirri: Dorsal cirri ovoid, absent from setiger 2; ventral cirri present
Setae: Three types first superior simple seta with obliquely truncate tip; then superior compound seta with swollen shaft-head and short triangular blade; third  ~3 compound setae with short bidentate blades, secondary tooth larger than apical
Geographical distribution: Subantarctic, Antarctica, Chile, Tristan da Cunha; not recorded from southern Africa

Species name: Sphaerosyllis capensis Day, 1953
Body: Short, ~3 mm; ~29 setigers; surface lightly papillose
Prostomium: Broader than long; two pairs of coalescent eyes; three long piriform antennae on anterior margin
Palps: Fused; bent ventrally
Peristomium (Tentacular segment): Partially fused to prostomium; single pair of tentacular cirri at eye level
Pharynx: With anterior tooth; extending to setiger 2; surrounded by brownish glands
Proventriculus: Short; ~2 segments; 10–14 rows of points
Parapodia: Setigerous lobe conical; two apical papillae
Notopodium: Reduced
Neuropodium: Setigerous lobe bearing simple and compound setae
Cirri: Dorsal cirri piriform; absent from setiger 2; ventral cirri digitiform
Setae: Superior simple setae with curved tips; compound setae with unidentate blades; inferior simple seta present in posterior segments
Special feature: Spherical dorsal vesicle with fibrillar contents from ~setiger 4 onward
Geographical distribution: South Africa (Cape Agulhas region);

Species name: Syllis anops Ehlers, 1897
Body: Slender; 15–25 mm; ~120 segments
Prostomium: Broader than long; eyes absent
Antennae: Short, subequal; 25–30 joints
Palps: Fused basally
Pharynx: With anterior tooth
Proventriculus: Extending over ~11 segments
Parapodia: Typical syllid parapodia
Notopodium: Reduced
Neuropodium: Bearing compound and modified setae
Cirri: Dorsal cirri about equal to body width; ~30 joints; ventral cirri short, arising near distal end of setigerous lobes
Setae: Anterior compound setae with blades of unequal length, tips minutely bidentate; middle parapodia with superior Langerhansia-type setae with very long slender blades and inferior setae with normal unidentate blades; acicula very stout with blunt tip
Geographical distribution: Magellan region; Chatham Islands; recorded from the Cape, South Africa

Species name: Sphaerosyllis erinaceus Claparede, 1863
Body: Short, ~3 mm; ~30 segments; flattened; surface densely covered with adhesive papillae extending onto palps and parapodia
Prostomium: Broader than long; three pairs of eyes; three equal flask-shaped antennae, median antenna inserted posterior to laterals
Palps: Papillose
Peristomium (Tentacular segment): Very short; embracing prostomium; tentacular cirri arising at eye level
Pharynx: With anterior dorsal tooth; extending to setiger 3
Proventriculus: Extending to setiger 6; 15–18 rows of points
Parapodia: Small; without dorsal glands
Notopodium: Reduced
Neuropodium: Setigerous lobe bearing compound and simple setae
Cirri: Tentacular and dorsal cirri flask-shaped, slightly larger than antennae; dorsal cirri absent from setiger 2; ventral cirri small, cylindrical
Setae: About five compound setae per foot with unidentate blades; superior simple seta with oblique tip from setiger 6–8 onward
Geographical distribution: Eastern Atlantic (Ireland to France), South West Africa to western Cape; Arctic, NW Japan, Kerguelen

Species name: Sphaerosyllis suhlaevis Ehlers, 1913
Body: Relatively large; up to ~10 mm; ~36 setigers; dorsum smooth; adhesive papillae absent
Prostomium: Arched anteriorly; two pairs of eyes; anterior eye-specks present; antennae flask-shaped, about prostomial length
Palps: Stout; united dorsally for most of length
Peristomium (Tentacular segment): Short; embracing prostomium; tentacular cirri lateral, smaller than antennae
Parapodia: Small; setigerous lobes present
Notopodium: Reduced
Neuropodium: Setigerous lobe bearing compound and simple setae
Cirri: Dorsal cirri flask-shaped anteriorly, more elongate posteriorly; dorsal cirri absent from setiger 2; ventral cirri small, conical
Setae: Compound setae with unidentate blades of variable length; superior simple seta present
Geographical distribution: South Africa (False Bay); Chile (42°S)

Species name: Exogonoides antennata Day, 1963
Body: Very long, smooth, slender; ~35 mm × 0.5 mm; >200 segments; anterior segments short and crowded, posterior segments elongate
Prostomium: Bluntly conical; four eyes; three ovoid frontal antennae, median antenna superior to laterals
Palps: Small, ventral; partially fused
Pharynx: Slender; reaching setiger 6; unarmed; trepan absent
Proventriculus: Short, dark, weakly muscular; ~15 rows of large, poorly defined points
Peristomium (Tentacular segment): Short, distinct; one pair of small ovoid tentacular cirri
Parapodia: Conical setigerous lobes; ventral cirri absent, fused to posterior margin of setigerous lobe
Notopodium: Reduced
Neuropodium: Setigerous lobe bearing compound or simple setae
Cirri: Dorsal cirri ovoid, compressed, subequal to setigerous lobe; present on all setigers including setiger 2; ventral cirri absent
Setae: Anterior parapodia with compound setae bearing short triangular bidentate blades; posterior parapodia with simple setae, shafts short, tips bluntly triangular
Geographical distribution: South Africa, Agulhas Bank Tropical

Species name: Autolytus pictus Ehlers, 1864
Body: 10–25 mm; paired dorsal red pigment rectangles (fading in alcohol)
Prostomium: Small; three long antennae; median antenna longer than laterals; palps not visible dorsally
Pharynx: S-shaped; trepan with ~20 teeth, alternating large and small
Proventriculus: With 50–60 rows of points
Nuchal epaulettes: Indistinct; not reaching setiger 2
Peristomium (Tentacular segment): Tentacular cirri very long
Parapodia: Normal autolytine type
Cirri: Tentacular cirri and dorsal cirri of setiger 1 very long; subsequent dorsal cirri shorter than body width
Setae: Compound; bidentate blades; shaft-heads denticulate
Geographical distribution: North Atlantic (English Channel to Madeira and Morocco); Mediterranean; Angola; SW Australia

Species name: Autolytus maclearnus McIntosh, 1885
Body: 6–12 mm; dusky anteriorly, otherwise pale
Prostomium: Rounded; four eyes; three long, wrinkled antennae; palps slightly visible dorsally
Pharynx: Long, twisted; margin weakly chitinised; enclosed in sheath with ~10 papillae; numerous minute indistinct teeth
Proventriculus: At setiger 4; 25–30 rows of points
Nuchal epaulettes: Indistinct
Peristomium (Tentacular segment): Dorsal tentacular cirri long, antenna-like; ventral tentacular cirri much shorter
Parapodia: Typical autolytine type
Cirri: Dorsal cirri of setiger 1 long; subsequent dorsal cirri very short, ~¼ body width
Setae: Four to five compound bidentate setae; posterior feet with single superior simple seta, pointed
Geographical distribution: Subantarctic; Chile; Kerguelen; Chatham Islands

Species name: Micronereides capensis Day, 1963
Body: Small; ~6 mm; 30–40 segments; colourless
Prostomium: Broad, subquadrate; eyes indistinct or absent; antennae paired, widely separated; palpophores stout, fully fused to prostomium; palpostyles slender, longer than antennae
Proboscis: Without paragnaths; jaws paired, large, with seven teeth each
Peristomium (Tentacular segments): Two pairs of short tentacular cirri arranged 2+2; derived from two fused segments; no anterior apodous segment
Parapodia: First two setigers uniramous; notopodial lobes and notosetae absent, dorsal cirrus retained; subsequent parapodia biramous, uniform throughout
Notopodium: Superior lobe absent; inferior lobe elongated, exceeding dorsal cirrus; intermediate setigerous lobe absent
Neuropodium: Stout conical setigerous lobe; very small inferior lobe; ventral cirrus small
Cirri: Dorsal cirri short; ventral cirri small
Setae: All homogomph spinigers; inferior neuropodial setae with shorter blades, shaft-heads tending to hemigomph condition
Geographical distribution: ; Agulhas Bank, South Africa

Species name: Unanereis macgregori Day, 1962
Body: Elongate; ~60 mm; ~120 segments
Prostomium: Oval; single slender median antenna; palps paired, long
Proboscis: Paragnath formula I=0, II=12, III=5, IV=12, V=0, VI broad fleshy lobe, VII–VIII=0
Peristomium (Tentacular segment): Tentacular cirri very long, slender
Parapodia: Anterior and posterior parapodia dissimilar
Notopodium: Anterior parapodia with two notopodial lobes and very long dorsal cirrus; posterior parapodia with superior notopodial lobe forming cirrophore of dorsal cirrus
Neuropodium: Anterior neuropodium with setigerous lobe bearing long presetal lip; posterior neuropodium with inferior lobe reduced to ventral papilla on setigerous lobe
Cirri: Dorsal cirri very long anteriorly; ventral cirri reduced posteriorly
Setae: Anterior setae heterogomph and homogomph spinigers, heterogomph falcigers with long blades; posterior notosetae homogomph spinigers and hemigomph falcigers with bidentate apices; posterior neurosetae homogomph and heterogomph spinigers and heterogomph falcigers
Geographical distribution: Madagascar (Diego Suarez)

Species name: Dendronereis arborifera Peters, 1854
Body: Slender; up to ~85 mm; colour pale, gills red in life
Prostomium: Deeply cleft between antennae; palps short, fused to divided prostomium
Peristomium (Tentacular segment): Tentacular cirri distally indistinctly jointed
Proboscis: Without paragnaths; papillae absent
Parapodia: Anterior, branchiferous, and posterior parapodia differentiated
Notopodium: Anterior feet with three lobes; branchiferous feet with three-lobed notopodium; posterior feet simplified, bilabiate
Neuropodium: Anterior feet with four postsetal lobes, later with one to two presetal lobes; branchiferous feet with setigerous lobe subdivided into six, later four lobes; posterior neuropodium conical, bilabiate
Cirri: Dorsal cirri tapered anteriorly; ventral cirri short
Branchiae: Bipinnate branchial filaments on dorsal cirri from ~setiger 12 to 24
Setae: Homogomph spinigers only; neuropodial blades shorter than notopodial
Geographical distribution: Mozambique and Madagascar; eastern South Africa mangrove habitats

Species name: Laeonereis ankyloseta Day, 1957
Body: Up to ~50 mm; anterior segments with brown spotting
Prostomium: As broad as long; median longitudinal groove
Peristomium (Tentacular segment): Tentacular cirri short
Proboscis: Maxillary ring smooth; area VI with large soft transverse lobe; areas VII–VIII with row of six soft papillae
Parapodia: Anterior and posterior parapodia differentiated
Notopodium: Three lobes throughout; intermediate lobe well developed anteriorly, reduced posteriorly; dorsal cirrus slightly longer anteriorly, long posteriorly
Neuropodium: Setigerous lobe with long postsetal lip; posterior neuropodia with modified simple setae
Cirri: Dorsal cirri elongated posteriorly; ventral cirri present
Setae: Notosetae homogomph spinigers throughout; neuropodial falcigers with long straight blades anteriorly, shorter posteriorly with terminal tendon; posterior neuropodia with 1–3 enlarged simple hammer-shaped setae formed by blade fusion
Geographical distribution: South Africa (False Bay to Natal) and Mozambique;

Species name: Platynereis australis Schmarda, 1861
Body: Up to ~105 mm in subantarctic material; ~30 mm in South African specimens
Prostomium: As in Platynereis dumerilii
Parapodia: Similar to P. dumerilii with posterior regional differentiation
Notopodium: Notopodial falcigers absent in adults; posterior notopodial lobes elongated
Neuropodium: As in P. dumerilii
Cirri: Dorsal cirri markedly elongated on posterior parapodia
Setae: As in P. dumerilii except absence of adult notopodial falcigers
Geographical distribution: South West Africa and Cape coast; subantarctic regions

Species name: Platynereis calodonta Kinberg, 1866
Body: ~30 mm; greenish
Prostomium: Longer than broad; palps swollen
Proboscis: Paragnaths comb-like, strongly developed, distribution typical of genus
Tentacular cirri: Long
Parapodia: Regionally differentiated
Notopodium: Anterior feet with two rounded lobes and long dorsal cirrus; posterior feet with enlarged superior lobe bearing long dorsal cirrus and smaller inferior lobe
Neuropodium: Typical of genus
Cirri: Dorsal cirri long, especially on posterior parapodia
Setae: Notopodial spinigers few in all feet; numerous notopodial falcigers from ~setiger 5 onward with short, brown, strongly hooked blades attached by a tendon; neurosetae spinigers and falcigers, falcigers with tendon at blade tip
Geographical distribution: ; South Africa from False Bay to Natal

Species name: Platynereis dumerilii Audouin & Milne-Edwards, 1833
Body: Up to ~45 mm; greenish; often pale dorsal stripe
Prostomium: Longer than broad; palps large, swollen
Proboscis: Paragnaths comb-like, typical generic arrangement
Tentacular cirri: Long
Parapodia: Regionally differentiated
Notopodium: Anterior feet with two large rounded lobes, minute intermediate lobe, long dorsal cirrus; posterior feet with two conical lobes and longer dorsal cirrus
Neuropodium: Typical of genus
Cirri: Dorsal cirri long, increasing posteriorly
Setae: Notosetae spinigers numerous; homogomph falcigers from mid-body onward, blades elongate with sharply recurved tip bearing terminal knob; neurosetae spinigers and falcigers, falciger blades recurved with short tendons
Reproductive note: Heteronereid modification begins at setiger 15 in males, 18 in females
Geographical distribution: Cosmopolitan; South West Africa to Natal, very common along South African coast

Species name: Nereis granulata Day, 1957
Body: Small; ~26 mm; ~50 segments; brown bands on setigers 2–3; scattered brown spots on remaining segments
Prostomium: Typical of genus
Proboscis: Paragnaths minute, pale, granular; Group I small patch (~6); II wedge-shaped; III small oval patch; IV wedge-shaped; V absent; VI rosette of ~6; VII–VIII broad ventral band
Tentacular cirri: Typical
Parapodia: Regionally differentiated
Notopodium: Anterior feet with two lobes and a long dorsal cirrus; posterior feet similar with relatively longer dorsal cirrus; posterior notopodia with 1–2 falcigers
Neuropodium: Typical; falcigers present
Cirri: Dorsal cirri elongate, longer posteriorly
Setae: Notopodial falcigers with straight conical blades, lightly serrated basally; neuropodial falcigers with relatively straight blades
Geographical distribution: Mozambique; Inhaca Island (single record)

Species name: Nereis jacksoni Kinberg, 1865
Body: Small; ~15–25 mm; slender
Prostomium: Anterior margin not notched
Proboscis: Paragnaths pale, minute; Group I absent; II double row; III oval patch of 4–6 (sometimes absent); IV wedge-shaped; V absent; VI small compact group of 3–6; VII–VIII single row of 7–8
Tentacular cirri: Short
Parapodia: Regionally differentiated
Notopodium: Anterior feet with two lobes and longer dorsal cirrus; superior lobe small, further reduced posteriorly; anterior notosetae homogomph spinigers; posterior notopodia with 1–2 stout falcigers
Neuropodium: With heterogomph falcigers
Cirri: Dorsal cirri elongate, relatively longer posteriorly
Setae: Posterior notopodial falcigers with dark blades bearing 2–3 large teeth; neuropodial falcigers with slightly curved blades
Geographical distribution: Indo-west Pacific; Red Sea; South Africa (Cape, Natal); Mozambique; Madagascar

Species name: Neanthes trifasciata Grube, 1878
Body: 15–30 mm; slender
Prostomium: Rather long
Proboscis: Paragnaths: Group I 0–1; II double row; III oval patch of 6–12; IV long triangular group; V absent; VI compact group of 3–9; VII–VIII single row of ~8 (juveniles sometimes with double row)
Tentacular cirri: Long
Parapodia: Regionally differentiated
Notopodium: Anterior feet with two lobes and slightly longer dorsal cirrus; posterior feet similar with superior lobe slightly expanded; notosetae spinigers throughout, with 1–2 homogomph falcigers appearing from mid-body onward
Neuropodium: Typical nereid condition
Cirri: Dorsal cirri elongate, slightly longer posteriorly
Setae: Homogomph falcigers with straight, elongate blades, lightly serrated near base
Geographical distribution: Tropical Indo-west Pacific; Red Sea; Mozambique; Madagascar; Juan Fernandez Islands

Species name: Nereis persica Fauvel, 1911
Body: 15–30 mm
Prostomium: Broadly triangular
Proboscis: Paragnaths: Group I 0–1; II double row; III few scattered points; IV 2–3 rows; V absent; VI cluster of 6–10; VII–VIII broad band with anterior row of large points and 2–3 posterior rows of fine points
Parapodia: Anterior and posterior differentiated
Notopodium: Anterior feet with two lobes and long dorsal cirrus; posterior feet with both lobes smaller and more slender; posterior notosetae with 1–2 dark homogomph falcigers bearing blades with 2–3 blunt teeth
Neuropodium: Neuropodial falcigers with curved blades and slight apical tendon
Cirri: Dorsal cirri long anteriorly, shorter posteriorly
Setae: Notosetae spinigers anteriorly, falcigers posteriorly; neuropodial falcigers curved
Geographical distribution: Red Sea; tropical Indo-west Pacific; South Africa (Cape, Natal); Mozambique; Madagascar

Species name: Nereis pelagica Linnaeus, 1758
Body: 60–120 mm; 80–120 segments
Prostomium: Broad inverted T-shape; palps large; tentacular cirri short
Proboscis: Paragnaths: Group I 2–3; II oblique double row; III oval patch; IV wedge-shaped group; V absent; VI 4–5 large points in cross; VII–VIII 1–2 irregular rows of large points followed by several rows of smaller points
Parapodia: Anterior and posterior feet similar in structure
Notopodium: Two subequal lobes; dorsal cirrus longer than lobes; posterior notosetae with homogomph spinigers and single falciger with short smooth blade
Neuropodium: Typical nereid neuropodium; neurosetae spinigers and falcigers
Cirri: Dorsal cirri longer than notopodial lobes; ventral cirri present
Setae: Notosetae spinigers and single posterior falciger; neurosetae spinigers and falcigers
Geographical distribution: Arctic; Atlantic coasts of Europe; Mediterranean; Senegal; Okhotsk Sea; South Pacific; South Africa Tropical; Mozambique

Species name: Neanthes unifasciata Willey, 1905
Body: 20–30 mm; brown transverse bar on setiger 2
Prostomium: Rather long; often brown-tinged
Proboscis: Paragnaths: Group I 1–6 in line; II double row; III small patch of 7–15; IV wedge-shaped group; V 0–1; VI rounded or rectangular group of 3–8; VII–VIII single row of ~7
Tentacular cirri: Long
Parapodia: Anterior and posterior parapodia differentiated
Notopodium: Anterior feet with two lobes and shorter dorsal cirrus; posterior feet with more pointed lobes and elongate superior lobe; notopodial falcigers absent
Neuropodium: Neuropodial falcigers present
Cirri: Dorsal cirri shorter than notopodial lobes anteriorly, relatively longer posteriorly; ventral cirri present
Setae: Neuropodial falcigers with short hooked blades, blade tips attached by a distinct tendon
Geographical distribution: Tropical Indo–West Pacific; rare record from Mozambique

Species name: Neanthes agulhana Day, 1963
Body: ~20 mm; brown transverse bar on setiger 2
Prostomium: Not specified
Proboscis: Paragnaths: Group I 0; II 8–9 in double row; III 5–6 in crescentic patch; IV wedge of ~10; V 0; VI 2–4 in line; VII–VIII single row of 3–5
Tentacular cirri: Not specified
Parapodia: Anterior and posterior parapodia differentiated
Notopodium: Anterior feet with three lobes, intermediate lobe smaller; posterior feet with two lobes; dorsal cirrus slightly longer than superior lobe; notopodial falcigers absent
Neuropodium: Neuropodial falcigers present
Cirri: Dorsal cirrus slightly exceeding superior notopodial lobe; ventral cirri present
Setae: Neuropodial falcigers with rather straight blades; blade tips attached by indistinct tendon
Geographical distribution: ; Agulhas Bank and Cape region, South Africa

Species name: Neanthes agnesiae Augener, 1918
Body: ~80 mm; ~90 segments
Prostomium: Broad, inverted T-shaped; palps broad; tentacular cirri short
Proboscis: Paragnaths: Group I 2 in line; II 12–15 in double row; III triangular group of ~16; IV wedge of 18–24; V group of 5; VI rosette of ~10; VII–VIII 2–3 rows of mixed large and small points
Parapodia: Anterior, middle, and posterior parapodia differentiated
Notopodium: Anterior feet with three lobes and short dorsal cirrus; middle feet with expanded superior lobe bearing dorsal cirrus terminally; posterior feet with large lamellate superior lobe, dorsal cirrus small and set in terminal notch
Neuropodium: Typical; without falcigers
Cirri: Dorsal cirri short anteriorly, reduced posteriorly; ventral cirri present
Setae: Spinigerous setae only; falcigers absent throughout
Geographical distribution: South West Africa (Swakopmund; type locality)

Species name: Alitta succinea Leuckart, 1847
Body: Reddish brown; up to ~80 mm long
Prostomium: Typical of genus; palps well developed; tentacular cirri present
Proboscis: Paragnaths: Group I 1; II double row; III few scattered points; IV wedge-shaped group; V 3–5; VI cluster of 8–12; VII–VIII broad band of ~4 irregular rows
Parapodia: Anterior and posterior parapodia differentiated
Notopodium: Anterior feet with three notopodial lobes and setal lip; posterior feet with superior lobe greatly enlarged and lamellate, dorsal cirrus short and set in terminal notch; intermediate lobe reduced; inferior lobe pointed; notopodial falcigers absent
Neuropodium: Well developed; bears falcigers only
Cirri: Dorsal cirri short posteriorly, reduced and carried on enlarged superior notopodial lobe; ventral cirri present
Setae: Notosetae spinigers only; neurosetae falcigers with long straight blades lacking distinct terminal tendons
Geographical distribution: Widely distributed; cosmopolitan in temperate and subtropical waters

Species name: Ceratonereis mirabilis Kinberg, 1866
Body: ~30 mm long; anterior segments with vague brown transverse bars; dorsum minutely papillose, especially posteriorly
Prostomium: Deeply cleft between slender antennae; palps elongate; tentacular cirri very long
Proboscis: Paragnaths: Group I 0; II wedge-shaped group; III few scattered points; IV wedge-shaped group
Parapodia: Anterior and posterior parapodia similar in basic structure
Notopodium: Anterior feet with two lobes; superior lobe slender, sometimes appearing as ventral branch of dorsal cirrus; posterior feet with superior lobe further reduced; dorsal cirri very long
Neuropodium: Well developed; falcigers present
Cirri: Dorsal cirri extremely long; ventral cirri present
Setae: Notosetae with 1–2 homogomph falcigers in posterior feet, blades long, slightly curved, spinulose; neurosetae heterogomph falcigers with very long spinulose blades and hooked tips
Geographical distribution: Brazil; Gulf of Mexico; Red Sea; Indo–west Pacific to Japan

Species name: Ceratonereis costae Grube, 1840
Body: Up to ~80 mm long
Prostomium: As broad as long; tentacular cirri of moderate length
Proboscis: Paragnaths: Group I 0–1; II double row; III three in a triangular group; IV wedge-shaped group
Parapodia: Anterior parapodia with two notopodial lobes and slightly elongate dorsal cirrus; middle parapodia (about setigers 7–17) with a small but distinct intermediate notopodial lobe; posterior parapodia with all lobes elongate and more pointed
Notopodium: Two lobes anteriorly; transient intermediate lobe in mid-body; no notopodial falcigers
Neuropodium: Setigerous lobe with long presetal lip and stout postsetal lip; posterior neuropodia elongate
Cirri: Dorsal cirri slightly longer than notopodial lobes anteriorly, elongate posteriorly; ventral cirri present
Setae: Notosetae spinigers only; neuropodial setae few heterogomph falcigers with long blades; in posterior feet two falcigers enlarged, often losing blades
Geographical distribution: North Atlantic; Mediterranean; Red Sea; Indo–west Pacific; recorded from Mozambique and Madagascar

Species name: Ceratonereis pachychaeta Fauvel, 1918
Body: Up to ~45 mm long
Prostomium: Hexagonal; tentacular cirri of moderate length
Proboscis: Paragnaths: Group I 0–1; II one–two rows of 4–10; III 2–3 in line; IV 4–6 in triangular group
Parapodia: Anterior parapodia with three subequal notopodial lobes and elongate dorsal cirrus; posterior parapodia with notopodia and neuropodia diverging, notopodial setigerous lobe reduced or vestigial, remaining notopodial lobes long and pointed
Notopodium: Three lobes anteriorly; posteriorly reduced setigerous lobe; no notopodial falcigers
Neuropodium: Well developed; posterior neuropodia with modified falcigers
Cirri: Dorsal cirri longer than notopodial lobes anteriorly; ventral cirri present
Setae: Notosetae spinigers only; neuropodial falcigers anteriorly straight to slightly convex, posteriorly more hooked with distinct tendon; posterior feet with two to three giant falcigers with blades partly fused to shafts
Geographical distribution: Red Sea and Indo–west Pacific; recorded from Madagascar

Species name: Ceratonereis erythraeensis Fauvel, 1918
Body: Slender; up to ~160 mm long
Prostomium: Broader than long; antennae short; tentacular cirri fairly long
Proboscis: Paragnaths elongate, conical; Group I 2–6; II double row ~10; III transverse patch ~18; IV wedge-shaped group 12–15
Parapodia: Anterior parapodia with two notopodial lobes and a short dorsal cirrus of similar length; posterior parapodia similar, lobes more pointed
Notopodium: Two lobes; notopodial falcigers absent
Neuropodium: Well developed; posterior neuropodia with modified falcigers
Cirri: Dorsal cirri short, subequal to notopodial lobes; ventral cirri present
Setae: Notosetae spinigers only; neuropodial falcigers with short blades lacking tendons; posterior feet with one to two enlarged falcigers with blades fused to shafts forming simple hooks
Geographical distribution: Indian Ocean (Djibouti, Madagascar, western Australia) and Japan

Species name: Leonnates decipiens Fauvel, 1929
Body: Stout; up to ~300 mm long; ~90 segments
Prostomium: Broader than long; palps stout, as long as antennae
Proboscis: Basal ring with soft, indistinct papillae; Group V absent; VI single large square papilla; VII–VIII single row; maxillary ring with chitinous paragnaths, Group I absent, II oblique row, III transverse group, IV triangular group
Parapodia: Anterior parapodia with three notopodial lobes and dorsal cirrus of equal length; neuropodium with setigerous lobe, presetal lip shorter than postsetal lip; posterior parapodia with superior notopodial lobe longer than dorsal cirrus, neuropodial postsetal lip long, slender, equal to inferior lobe
Notopodium: Three lobes anteriorly; superior lobe elongate posteriorly; notopodial falcigers absent
Neuropodium: Setigerous lobe well developed; posterior neuropodia with elongated postsetal lip
Cirri: Dorsal cirri moderate, subequal to notopodial lobes anteriorly; ventral cirri present
Setae: Notosetae homogomph spinigers only; neurosetae homogomph spinigers and falcigers, falcigers with convex, spinous blades and expanded truncate tips
Geographical distribution: Senegal, Congo, Suez region, Gulf of Manaar; recorded from Mozambique

Species name: Pseudonereis variegata Grube, 1857
Body: Large, robust; up to ~150 mm long, ~8 mm wide; dark green; ovigerous females bluish
Prostomium: Broad inverted T; palps large, bulbous
Proboscis: Group I 0–1; II double row of 12–15; III three comb-like rows of 12–24; IV wedge of 15–20; V single paragnath; VI single large transverse bar; VII–VIII 2–3 irregular rows; paragnaths in II–IV comb-like, not basally fused
Parapodia: Anterior parapodia with two rounded notopodial lobes and longer dorsal cirrus; posterior parapodia with superior notopodial lobe enlarged, flattened, lamellate, dorsal cirrus small and terminal
Notopodium: Two lobes anteriorly; superior lobe expanded and lamellate posteriorly; falcigers absent
Neuropodium: Setigerous lobe well developed; neuropodial falcigers stout
Cirri: Dorsal cirri longer than notopodial lobes anteriorly, reduced posteriorly; ventral cirri present
Setae: Notosetae homogomph spinigers only; neuropodial falcigers with short, faintly hooked blades
Geographical distribution: Circumtropical; South West Africa to Mozambique; abundant on rocky shores under algae and barnacles

Species name: Perinereis vancaurica Ehlers, 1868
Body: Up to ~80 mm long
Prostomium: Broadly triangular; antennae tapered; tentacular cirri short
Proboscis: Group I 1–2; II two curved rows; III square group; IV triangular field of numerous points; V three large points in triangle; VI two narrow transverse bars; VII–VIII 2–3 irregular rows
Parapodia: Anterior parapodia with two notopodial lobes and short dorsal cirrus equal to lobe length; posterior parapodia similar with slightly longer lobes
Notopodium: Two lobes; notosetae homogomph spinigers with short blades; falcigers absent
Neuropodium: Inferior lobe short anteriorly; heterogomph falcigers present with very straight blades
Cirri: Dorsal cirri short, subequal to notopodial lobes; ventral cirri present
Setae: Notosetae homogomph spinigers; neuropodial falcigers heterogomph, blades straight
Geographical distribution: Red Sea and Indo–west Pacific; Mozambique (single record)

Species name: Perinereis capensis Kinberg, 1866
Body: Brown anteriorly; up to ~70 mm long
Prostomium: Broad inverted T; palpophores large, compressed, each with small terminal button; antennae tapered; tentacular cirri fairly short
Proboscis: Group I 2–3 in row; II wedge of 12–15; III oval group ~10; IV triangle ~15; V absent; VI single large transverse bar; VII–VIII two irregular rows of large and small points
Parapodia: Anterior parapodia with two to three notopodial lobes, intermediate lobe fused to inferior lobe; posterior parapodia with enlarged base of superior notopodial lobe
Notopodium: Superior lobe bearing dorsal cirrus; dorsal cirrus ~2× length of superior lobe anteriorly; notosetae homogomph spinigers only
Neuropodium: Setigerous lobe with short pointed postsetal projection throughout; neurosetae spinigers and falcigers
Cirri: Dorsal cirri long, arising from superior notopodial lobe; ventral cirri present
Setae: Notosetae homogomph spinigers; neurosetae homogomph and heterogomph spinigers plus heterogomph falcigers with nearly straight apices
Geographical distribution: Tropical Indian Ocean; Senegal; South Africa from False Bay to Natal

Species name: Perinereis cultrifera Grube, 1840
Body: Large; up to ~250 mm; ~125 segments
Prostomium: Broadly triangular; palps large; tentacular cirri long, slender
Proboscis: Group I 1–3 large points in line; II few points in triangle; III oval patch; IV wedge-shaped group; V three large points in triangle; VI transverse bar; VII–VIII two to three rows of equal-sized points
Parapodia: Anterior parapodia with two notopodial lobes; posterior parapodia similar, lobes more pointed
Notopodium: Two lobes throughout; dorsal cirrus short anteriorly, little change posteriorly; notosetae spinigers only
Neuropodium: Setigerous lobe simple; falcigers present
Cirri: Dorsal cirri short, weakly increasing posteriorly; ventral cirri present
Setae: Neuropodial falcigers with fairly straight blades; notopodial falcigers absent
Geographical distribution: NE Atlantic; Mediterranean; tropical Indo-west-Pacific; South Africa (Cape to Natal); Madagascar

Species name: Aglaophamus dibranchis Grube, 1877
Body: About 25 mm long
Prostomium: Pentagonal; anterior margin straight; antennae well developed, subequal, tapered; eyes visible through body wall
Proboscis: Fourteen rows of 4–5 papillae each; single elongated median dorsal papilla; jaws tetrahedral, chitinous
Parapodia: Biramous; rami strongly divergent; setigerous lobes pointed
Notopodium: Presetal lamella small, auricular anteriorly; postsetal lamella larger; middle feet with postsetal lamella projecting dorsally; posterior feet with postsetal lamella reduced, scarcely exceeding acicular lobe
Neuropodium: Anterior feet with three lamellae (anterior auricular, superior tongue-like, postsetal auricular); middle feet with superior lamella elongated and strap-like; posterior feet with lamellae reduced, superior lamella lost
Branchiae: Cirriform branchiae from setiger 4; straight or involute; each with slender notopodial cirrus at base
Cirri: Dorsal cirrus of first setiger well developed; branchial cirri present from setiger 4
Setae: Anterior notosetae laddered capillaries; posterior notosetae long flattened capillaries; forked setae present posteriorly
Geographical distribution: Tropical Indian Ocean; Natal, South Africa; possibly New Zealand and Campbell Islands

Species name: Aglaophamus lyrochaeta Fauvel, 1902
Body: About 30 mm long
Prostomium: Pentagonal; anterior margin straight; eyes absent
Proboscis: Fourteen rows of 4–5 papillae each; single enlarged median dorsal papilla
Parapodia: Biramous; lamellae prominent anteriorly, reduced posteriorly
Notopodium: Anterior feet with rounded presetal lamella and larger orbicular postsetal lamella, both exceeding setigerous lobe; posterior feet with lamellae reduced, shorter than setigerous lobe
Neuropodium: Anterior feet with oval presetal lamella, blade-like superior lamella, large orbicular postsetal lamella; posterior feet with lamellae reduced, superior lamella absent
Branchiae: From setiger 4 or 5; involute; each with notopodial cirrus at base, length variable among authors
Cirri: Notopodial cirrus at base of branchiae, short to very long
Setae: Anterior fan of laddered capillaries; posterior fan of long-bladed capillaries; forked setae present in both rami
Geographical distribution: Morocco; Congo (Brazzaville); Persian Gulf

Species name: Aglaophamus macroura Schmarda, 1861
Body: Large; up to ~150 mm
Prostomium: Subquadrate; eyes absent; antennae unequal, second antenna longer, ventro-lateral in origin
Proboscis: Distal region with 22 rows of large papillae; proximal region with 14 rows of smaller papillae
Parapodia: Biramous; setigerous lobes produced into small auricular processes receiving acicula
Notopodium: Presetal lamella bilobed, superior part very small, inferior part large and square anteriorly, reduced after ~20 setigers; postsetal lamella large, unequally bilobed, superior part expanded into foliaceous process; dorsal cirrus absent on first foot, blade-like on branchiferous feet
Neuropodium: Presetal lamella bilobed with two small widely separated lobes persisting posteriorly; postsetal lamella large, unequally bilobed, main lobe inferior and becoming ligulate posteriorly
Branchiae: From setigers 2–4; cirriform, involute; size increasing to maximum around setiger 20 then decreasing; each with flattened blade-like dorsal cirrus
Cirri: Ventral cirri blade-like throughout; dorsal cirri associated with branchiae
Setae: Anterior laddered capillaries; posterior fan of very long, flattened capillaries
Geographical distribution: Subantarctic; Chile; Antarctica; South Africa (Cape records)

Species name: Nephtys capensis Day, 1953
Body: About 60 mm
Prostomium: Pentagonal, slightly arched anteriorly; eyes absent; posterior antennae slightly shorter than anterior pair
Proboscis: 22 rows of papillae, each row with six papillae; one larger median dorsal papilla
Parapodia: Biramous throughout
Notopodium: Conical; presetal lamella small, entire (not notched); postsetal lamella large, rounded
Neuropodium: Conical; presetal lamella small with slightly produced upper margin; postsetal lamella large, rounded, projecting well beyond setigerous lobe
Branchiae: From setiger 4; anterior branchiae rectangular and compressed; posterior branchiae cirriform and recurved, especially in large specimens
Cirri: Ventral cirrus of first foot elongate, equal to antennae; dorsal cirrus absent on first foot
Setae: Anterior fan of laddered capillaries; posterior fan of numerous very long capillaries with spinulose margins; few shorter geniculate setae with coarse teeth
Geographical distribution:  to South Africa; Cape and Natal coasts

Species name: Nephtys paradoxa Malmgren, 1874
Body: Large; up to ~150 mm
Prostomium: Straight to slightly concave anteriorly; eyes indistinct or two; posterior antennae larger than anterior pair
Proboscis: 22 rows of papillae, each row with 4–6 papillae; enlarged median dorsal papilla
Parapodia: Biramous; rami divergent
Notopodium: Setigerous lobe broadly rounded anteriorly, becoming more pointed posteriorly; anterior lamellae rudimentary; posterior lamellae small, rounded, scarcely exceeding setigerous lobe
Neuropodium: Setigerous lobe conical anteriorly, becoming more pointed posteriorly; anterior lamellae rudimentary; posterior lamellae small, rounded
Branchiae: From setigers 8–10; anterior branchiae cirriform, recurved, with small notopodial cirrus at base; middle branchiae flattened or lamellar; branchiae decreasing and absent in posterior segments
Cirri: Ventral cirrus of first foot stout, conical; dorsal cirrus reduced to low papilla on first foot
Setae: Anterior fan of laddered capillaries; posterior fan of long, flattened capillaries with transverse rows of fine teeth on one margin
Geographical distribution: North Atlantic, Arctic, Bering Sea, north-west Japan; southern African records doubtful

Species name: Nephtys ambrizettana Augener, 1918
Body: Small; ~6.5 mm; ~42 segments
Prostomium: As broad as long; antennae slender; eye-spots doubtful
Proboscis: Not described
Parapodia: Poorly developed throughout
Notopodium: Notopodial cirri absent; branchiae absent; presetal lamellae rudimentary or absent; postsetal lamellae present but scarcely exceeding setigerous lobes
Neuropodium: Setigerous lobes conical; presetal lamellae rudimentary or absent; postsetal lamellae small
Cirri: Ventral cirrus of setiger 1 longer than setigerous lobe; dorsal cirrus of setiger 1 similar; ventral cirri small on subsequent segments
Setae: Anterior fan of laddered capillaries; posterior fan of long setae finely serrate on convex margin
Geographical distribution: Angola; not recorded from South Africa

Species name: Glycera rouxi Audouin & Milne-Edwards, 1833
Body: Elongate; 100–150 mm; cylindrical
Prostomium: Conical, tapered; 10–12 indistinct rings
Proboscis: Eversible; papillae numerous, mainly smooth conical with a few globular forms
Jaws: Jaw supports with one well-developed prong; second prong reduced to a triangular basal projection, not separated by a notch
Parapodia: Biramous; presetal lobes equal, pointed; postsetal lobes shorter than presetal lobes
Notopodium: Postsetal lobe subequal to neuropodial lobe in middle feet; superior postsetal lobe elongate and pointed posteriorly
Neuropodium: Inferior postsetal lobe rounded and shorter posteriorly
Cirri: Dorsal cirrus ovoid, basally attached; ventral cirrus long, pointed, directed ventrally
Branchiae: Retractile; single digitiform lobe per parapodium; arising from anterior face; beginning at setiger ~20
Geographical distribution: Eastern Atlantic (Norway to Senegal); Mediterranean; tropical Indian Ocean; Japan

Species name: Goniada emerita Audouin & Milne-Edwards, 1833
Body: Elongate, tapering at both ends; iridescent brown in alcohol; up to ~360 mm
Prostomium: Long conical; 8–10 annulations; four short antennae; eyes absent
Proboscis: Eversible; papillae small, rounded, each with curved flange around central pore and groove; 12–17 chevrons on each side at base
Jaws: Macrognaths with four teeth; micrognaths ~30 dorsal and ~15 ventral
Parapodia: Anterior region with 60–70 uniramous segments; posterior region biramous
Notopodium: Anterior feet lacking notosetae; posterior feet with triangular dorsal cirrus and similar inferior lobe; 2–3 simple blunt acicular setae between lobes
Neuropodium: Large; two presetal lobes united basally; single postsetal lobe with expanded base and pointed tip
Cirri: Dorsal cirri tapered, basally flattened anteriorly, triangular posteriorly; ventral cirri long, triangular
Setae: Anterior notosetae absent; posterior notopodial acicular setae blunt; neurosetae spinigerous
Geographical distribution: North Atlantic (Scotland to Morocco); Mediterranean; tropical Indian Ocean; Chatham Islands (New Zealand)

Species name: Goniada maculata Oersted, 1843
Body: Elongate; 50–100 mm; brown maculation; anterior region uniramous, posterior region biramous
Prostomium: Conical; 8–10 annulations; eyes absent
Proboscis: With 7–11 chevrons; densely covered with low cordate papillae
Jaws: Dorsal arc of four micrognaths; ventral arc of three micrognaths; paired ventro-lateral macrognaths with 4–8 teeth
Parapodia: Anterior 35–40 segments uniramous; posterior segments biramous
Notopodium: Anterior feet without notosetae; posterior feet with dorsal cirrus and inferior setigerous lobe bearing capillary notosetae
Neuropodium: Anterior feet with fused pre- and postsetal lips in early segments, later differentiated into two presetal and one postsetal lobe; posterior feet with two finger-like presetal lobes and one blunt triangular postsetal lobe
Cirri: Dorsal cirri blade-shaped anteriorly; ventral cirri blade-shaped to digitiform
Setae: Anterior notosetae absent; posterior notosetae capillary; neurosetae spinigerous compound
Geographical distribution: Arctic; North Atlantic (Norway to English Channel and North Carolina); North Pacific (Alaska to Japan); possibly Persian Gulf

Species name: Goniadella gracilis Verrill, 1873
Body: Thread-like; up to ~20 mm; anterior uniramous region and posterior biramous region
Prostomium: With eight annulations; one pair of eyes in basal ring, sometimes also in terminal ring; four slender biarticulate antennae
Proboscis: With 25–30 basal chevrons; papillae uniform, broadly conical, obliquely truncate
Jaws: Macrognaths with four teeth; micrognaths three ventrally and ~12 dorsally in a semicircle
Parapodia: Anterior region with 28–30 biannulate uniramous segments; posterior region biramous
Notopodium: Absent in anterior region; posterior region with notopodium corresponding to dorsal cirrus, bearing 1–3 straight blunt acicular notosetae
Neuropodium: Setigerous lobe elongate; presetal projection long and fused to shorter postsetal lobe anteriorly; similar structure posteriorly
Cirri: Dorsal cirri pointed; ventral cirri triangular
Setae: Anterior region with 3–5 spinigers and 2–4 falcigers; posterior region with similar neurosetae plus blunt acicular notosetae; spinigers with tapering blades, falcigers with short blades
Geographical distribution: Atlantic coast of U.S.A.; recorded from the Cape region of South Africa

Species name: Goniadopsis incerta Fauvel, 1932
Body: ~50 mm; tapered at both ends; regions differentiated into anterior, middle, posterior
Prostomium: With ~10 annulations
Proboscis: Covered with small spherical papillae
Jaws: Dorsal arc of ~14 macrognaths; one pair of macrognaths each with four teeth; ventral arc of ~20 micrognaths
Parapodia: Anterior and middle regions uniramous; posterior region biramous
Notopodium: Anterior region absent; middle region absent; posterior region with one presetal and two triangular postsetal lobes bearing acicular notosetae with faintly spoon-shaped tips
Neuropodium: Anterior region with two presetal and one postsetal lobe bearing falcigerous setae; middle region with two conical presetal and one postsetal lobe bearing spinigers; posterior region with two presetal and one triangular postsetal lobe bearing spinigers
Cirri: Dorsal cirri lamellar and flattened in anterior region, tapered in middle region; ventral cirri cirriform anteriorly, very long in middle region, triangular posteriorly
Setae: Anterior neuropodia with falcigers; middle neuropodia with spinigers; posterior notopodia with acicular notosetae, neuropodia with spinigers
Geographical distribution: Burma (deep water); recorded off the Cape, South Africa

Species name: Goniadopsis maskallensis Gravier, 1904
Body: Slender; up to ~75 mm; tapered at both ends; body divided into anterior, middle, posterior regions
Prostomium: With ~10 annulations; antennae relatively long
Proboscis: Covered with subspherical papillae
Jaws: Macrognaths with four teeth; 13 dorsal micrognaths; 9 ventral micrognaths
Parapodia: Anterior and middle regions uniramous; posterior region biramous
Notopodium: Absent in anterior and middle regions; posterior region with two blunt lobes bearing 1–3 stout acicular notosetae with elongate spoon-shaped tips
Neuropodium: Anterior region with single presetal and single postsetal lobe bearing falcigers; middle region with presetal lobe and postsetal lobe bearing spinigers; posterior region with longer presetal and shorter postsetal lobes bearing spinigerous compound setae
Cirri: Dorsal cirri flattened in anterior and middle regions; ventral cirri larger than setigerous lobe anteriorly, smaller and rounded in middle region, short posteriorly
Setae: Anterior neuropodia with falcigers; middle neuropodia with spinigers; posterior notopodia with acicular spoon-tipped setae; posterior neuropodia with spinigers
Geographical distribution: Red Sea; recorded from Natal, South Africa

Species name: Glycinde kameruniana Augener, 1918
Body: Small, pale; ~30–40 mm; body divided into anterior uniramous and posterior biramous regions
Prostomium: With eight annulations; one pair of eyes embedded in basal ring
Proboscis: With five longitudinal bands of papillae
Jaws: Ventral macrognaths with four teeth; dorsal arc of 4–5 micrognaths
Parapodia: Anterior region with 21 uniramous segments; posterior region biramous
Notopodium: Anterior region absent; dorsal cirrus strap-like, later ventrally broadened (setigers 15–20); posterior region with small dorsal cirrus, minutely bilabiate setigerous lobe, 2–3 acicular notosetae with blunt hooked apex and pointed guard
Neuropodium: Anterior region with single tapering presetal lobe and subequal postsetal lobe; posterior region similar but presetal lobe longer than postsetal
Cirri: Dorsal cirri strap-like anteriorly, reduced posteriorly; ventral cirri similar to dorsal cirri anteriorly, shorter posteriorly
Setae: Anterior and posterior neurosetae compound spinigers; posterior notosetae stout acicular
Geographical distribution: Tropical West Africa; recorded from South West Africa and the Cape

Species name: Glycinde capensis Day, 1960
Body: Yellowish-brown; up to 40 mm long; about 112 segments
Prostomium: With 8–10 annulations; two pairs of eyes (one basal, one terminal)
Proboscis: With five longitudinal bands of papillae; a pair of macrognaths each with five teeth; dorsal arc of 15–25 micrognaths
Parapodia: Body divided into anterior uniramous and posterior biramous regions; Anterior region, 28–30 uniramous segments; parapodium with a strap-like dorsal cirrus, a single tapered setigerous lobe formed by fusion of pre- and postsetal lobes, and a ventral cirrus similar to the dorsal one; base of dorsal cirrus expanded inferiorly from about setiger 20 onwards; Posterior region, Biramous parapodia; notopodium with flattened dorsal cirrus and a setigerous lobe bearing a distinct apical notch; neuropodium similar in form to the anterior setigerous lobe
Cirri: Dorsal cirri strap-like anteriorly, flattened posteriorly; ventral cirri similar to dorsal cirri in anterior region
Setae: Notosetae acicular with bluntly hooked tips and pointed guards; neurosetae compound spinigers throughout
Distribution:  to southern Africa

Species name: Boccardia ligerica Ferronnière, 1898
Body: About 25 mm long
Prostomium: Anterior margin distinctly notched; a median keel present, extending posteriorly to setiger 2; four eyes present
Parapodia: Notosetae present on setiger 1
Branchiae: Begin on setiger 2; absent on setiger 5; present again from setiger 6 and continuing to about setiger 30
Setae: Setiger 5 with enlarged, plain blunt hooks, Bidentate hooded hooks appear in the neuropodium from setiger 7 onward; No specialised notosetae present in posterior segments
Geographical distribution: France (estuarine); doubtful record from South Africa Tropical

Species name: Boccardia polybranchia Haswell, 1885
Body: Large for the genus, up to 25 mm long with about 80 segments.
Prostomium: Anterior margin distinctly notched; outlined in black; with a median keel extending posteriorly to setiger 2; eye-spots variable, ranging from none to about ten.
Antennae and tentacular cirri: Not described as differentiated in the available material.
Cirri: Notosetae absent on setiger 1.
Branchiae: Fused to the dorsal lamellae; present on setigers 2–4, absent on setiger 5, then reappear and continue to about the middle of the body.
Setae: Setiger 5 with two types of enlarged hooks: an anterior row of expanded, truncate hooks bearing a dense brush of fibrils, and a posterior row of simple hooks; bidentate hooded hooks appear in the neuropodium from setiger 7 onward; no specialised notosetae present in posterior segments.
Pygidium: Small, posterior margin concave.
Geographical distribution: Widely distributed—recorded from the English Channel, Bay of Biscay, Mediterranean, Brazil, Japan, Australia, New Zealand, Subantarctic regions (Magellan area, Kerguelen, Macquarie Islands), and southern Africa (South West Africa and the Cape).

Species name: Boccardia pseudonatrix Day, 1961
Body: Small, about 10 mm long, approximately 70 segments.
Prostomium: Bilobed; posterior keel extending to setiger 2; two eye-spots.
Antennae and tentacular cirri: Not differentiated in available material.
Cirri: First setiger with well-developed notopodium and several notosetae.
Branchiae: Present on setigers 2–4 and 6; continuing on subsequent segments to about setiger 40.
Setae: Setiger 5 without notosetae; two types of enlarged hooks, first row with three blunt conical hooks partially surrounded by a raised margin, second row with four simple curved hooks; bidentate hooded hooks in neuropodium from setiger 7 onward; no specialised posterior notosetae.
Pygidium: Very small.
Geographical distribution: ; known only from Knysna Estuary, South Africa.

Species name: Polydora capensis Day, 1955
Body: Up to 20 mm long; about 100 segments; boring habit in living gastropod shells.
Prostomium: Anterior margin not notched; posterior keel extending to setiger 3; buccal segment forming paired supporting lobes laterally.
Antennae and tentacular cirri: Not differentiated in available material.
Cirri: Notosetae present on setiger 1.
Branchiae: Present from setiger 7 to setiger 37.
Setae: Setiger 5 with enlarged plain blunt hooks; neuropodial hooks from setiger 7, three to five anteriorly, hooded and bidentate; posterior hooks without hoods, unidentate, reduced to two to three; posterior notosetae including straight spines and capillaries.
Pygidium: Small.
Geographical distribution:  to South Africa; recorded from the Cape region.

Species name: Polydora armata Langerhans, 1880
Body: Small; about 5 mm long; 24–45 segments.
Prostomium: Anterior margin bilobed; posterior dorsal ridge extending to setiger 2; eyes absent.
Antennae and tentacular cirri: Not differentiated.
Cirri: Notosetae present on setiger 1, two to three in number.
Branchiae: Present from setiger 7 to setiger 14.
Setae: Setiger 5 with two to three enlarged bluntly hooked setae with stout hoods; neuropodial bidentate hooded hooks from setiger 7 onward, three to four in number; posterior notosetae eight to twelve stout spines, forming a cone when retracted and a funnel when everted.
Geographical distribution: North Atlantic (English Channel to Morocco, Madeira); Gulf of Mexico; Mediterranean; Ceylon; North Pacific (Japan)

Species name: Polydora flava Claparede, 1870
Body: Large; up to 45 mm long; about 150 segments.
Prostomium: Anterior margin notched; posterior ridge extending to setiger 2; eyes absent.
Antennae and tentacular cirri: Not differentiated.
Cirri: Few notosetae on setiger 1.
Branchiae: From setigers 7–9; extending beyond mid-body.
Setae: Setiger 5 with enlarged hooks having curved, blunt tips flattened on concave side, accompanied by fine straight spear-shaped capillaries; neuropodial bidentate hooded hooks from setiger 7 onward, three to four per parapodium; posterior notopodia with packets of very fine needle-like setae embedded near bases of capillaries.
Geographical distribution: English Channel; Mediterranean; Ceylon; Sumatra; Japan; northern Pacific; southern Africa Tropical.

Species name: Polydora caeca Oersted, 1843
Body: Up to 40 mm long; about 130 segments.
Prostomium: Anterior margin deeply notched; dorsal ridge extending posteriorly to setiger 2; eyes four or absent.
Antennae and tentacular cirri: Not differentiated.
Cirri: Few notosetae on setiger 1.
Branchiae: From setigers 7–9; extending beyond mid-body.
Setae: Setiger 5 with two specialised series: a row of fine hastate setae and an oblique row of stout hooks excavated on the concave side; bidentate hooded neuropodial hooks from setiger 7 onward; posterior notopodia with three to four stout straight spines plus capillaries.
Pygidium: Saucer-shaped with a dorsal notch.
Geographical distribution: Arctic; North Atlantic from Greenland to North Carolina; English Channel to Morocco; Mediterranean; tropical Indian Ocean; southern Africa (Natal, Mozambique).

Species name: Polydora ciliata Johnston, 1838
Body: Up to 30 mm long; about 100 segments; anterior and posterior ends often blackened.
Prostomium: Slightly notched anteriorly; dorsal ridge extending posteriorly to setiger 2; four eyes in juveniles, eyes often absent in adults.
Antennae and tentacular cirri: Not differentiated.
Cirri: Notosetae absent on setiger 1.
Branchiae: From setiger 7; extending nearly to posterior end of body.
Setae: Setiger 5 with stout hooks bearing an accessory tooth; hooded bidentate hooks in neuropodium from setiger 7 onward; no specialised notosetae in posterior segments.
Pygidium: Saucer-shaped with a dorsal incision.
Habitat: Burrows in calcareous rock and Lithothamnion.
Geographical distribution: Baltic Sea; North Atlantic from Scotland and English Channel to Senegal; Mediterranean; Red Sea; India; Madagascar; Falkland Islands; north-western Japan; Mozambique.

Species name: Polydora antennata Claparede, 1870
Body: Up to 30 mm long; about 100 segments.
Prostomium: Anterior margin deeply notched; dorsal ridge extending posteriorly; single free occipital tentacle; two to four eyes.
Antennae and tentacular cirri: Occipital tentacle present; other structures not differentiated.
Cirri: Notosetae absent on setiger 1.
Branchiae: From setiger 7; weakly developed; ending around setiger 40.
Setae: Setiger 5 with enlarged spoon-shaped hooks arranged in a horseshoe; bidentate hooded hooks in neuropodium from setiger 8 onward; no specialised notosetae in posterior segments.
Pygidium: Saucer-shaped with dorsal and ventral notches.
Geographical distribution: Mediterranean; Arabian Sea; Ceylon; Gulf of Manaar; Japan; southern Africa Tropical.

Species name: Polydora maculata Day, 1963
Body: Up to 20 mm long; about 130 segments; tubes in old gastropod shells occupied by hermit crabs; palps with black bars, remainder unpigmented.
Prostomium: Bilobed anteriorly; median dorsal ridge extending posteriorly to setiger 2; two small prostomial tentacles arranged sequentially on the ridge between palp bases.
Antennae and tentacular cirri: Prostomial tentacles short, paired, aligned antero-posteriorly.
Cirri: Notosetae absent on setiger 1.
Branchiae: From setiger 7 to posterior end of body.
Setae: Setiger 5 with enlarged hooks, plain, curved, slightly flattened distally, alternating with normal winged capillaries; no separate tuft on setiger 5; bidentate hooded hooks in neuropodia from setiger 9, eight to ten anteriorly, reduced to four posteriorly; no specialised posterior notosetae.
Geographical distribution: ; South Africa (Cape; type locality off East London).

Species name: Polydora kempi Southern, 1921
Body: About 12 mm long.
Prostomium: Anterior margin faintly notched; single posterior occipital tentacle; four eyes.
Antennae and tentacular cirri: Occipital tentacle single, median.
Cirri: Notosetae absent on setiger 1.
Branchiae: Present from setiger 7 to setiger 14.
Setae: Setiger 5 with normal notopodial capillaries plus two specialised rows: anterior row of recurved fang-like setae with basal swelling of blade, posterior row of stout, simple, faintly curved hooks; normal neuropodial setae on setiger 5; bidentate hooded hooks in neuropodia from setiger 8 onward; no specialised posterior notosetae.
Pygidium: Small, saucer-shaped.
Geographical distribution: India (type locality: Chilka Lake); Mozambique (single record).

Species name: Spiophanes bombyx Claparède, 1870
Body: Up to 60 mm long; about 180 segments.
Prostomium: Broad, anterior margin straight; large pointed lateral peaks; single posterior occipital tentacle; four eyes; paired interrupted dorsal sensory grooves extending to setiger 4.
Antennae and tentacular cirri: Occipital tentacle single, posterior.
Cirri: Anal cirri cylindrical.
Parapodia: Notopodial lamella of setiger 1 slender, succeeding ones basally broadened; low dorsal ridges from setiger 3 onward; neuropodial lamellae of setigers 1–4 triangular, posterior ones low and rounded; fibrous glands in setigers 5–15.
Setae: Notosetae of first setiger very long; enlarged neuropodial setae of setiger 1 with recurved blades; from setiger 15 onward neuropodia with bidentate hooks bearing partial guard below rostrum, plus an inferior sabre-like seta.
Geographical distribution: Widely distributed—North Atlantic (Sweden, Scotland, English Channel to North Carolina), Mediterranean, Gulf of Mexico, Cape Verde Islands, Liberia, Angola, Falkland Islands, and North Pacific (Japan to western Canada and southern California); recorded from South Africa (Cape, Natal).

Species name: Spiophanes soederstromi Hartman, 1953
Body: Slender; up to 25 mm long; about 60 segments.
Prostomium: Transversely oval anteriorly; laterally supported by buccal segment; posteriorly narrowed; single occipital tentacle; two pairs of subdermal eyes; paired raised nuchal ridges extending to setiger 4.
Antennae and tentacular cirri: Occipital tentacle single, posterior.
Parapodia: Notopodial postsetal lobes of setigers 1–4 pointed; setigers 5–12 blunt and broadened; subsequent notopodia again slender and pointed; transverse dorsal ridges on setigers 16–35; neuropodial postsetal lamellae pointed on first four setigers, low and rounded thereafter.
Setae: Notosetae winged capillaries throughout; first setiger with very long capillaries, markedly shorter from setiger 4 onward; neuropodium of setiger 1 with stout, strongly curved seta; tridentate hooks with partial or absent guard from setiger 15 onward; sabre-like genital setae without fibrils from about setiger 15, occasionally present anteriorly.
Geographical distribution: Sweden, Greenland, Uruguay, South Georgia; possibly Okhotsk and Bering Seas; southern Africa (Cape and Natal).

Species name: Malacoceros indicus Fauvel, 1928
Body: Up to 60 mm long; 1–1.5 mm broad.
Prostomium: Broad, shield-shaped; laterally projecting frontal peaks; posterior end of cephalic keel free; numerous eye-specks.
Antennae and tentacular cirri: Not differentiated.
Branchiae: Long, cirriform; from setiger 1; united to bases of dorsal lamellae; dorsal lamellae lanceolate, long anteriorly, reduced posteriorly to about one-third branchial length.
Parapodia: Neuropodial lamellae rounded anteriorly; posterior lamellae with nipple-like projection.
Setae: Notopodial capillaries undotted; anterior neuropodia with five to six large capillaries with abruptly pointed tips; long bidentate hooded hooks from about setigers 40–70; sabre-like setae in posterior neuropodia.
Geographical distribution: India (Gulf of Manaar), New Caledonia; records from southern Africa (Natal, Mozambique; doubtful from the Cape).

Species name: Laonice cirrata Sars, 1851
Body: Large; up to 100 mm long; about 160 segments.
Prostomium: Broadly rounded anteriorly; two large eyes; occipital tentacle posteriorly.
Dorsal features: Long ciliated dorsal ridge extending over 28–40 segments; membranous transverse ridges on middle segments.
Branchiae: Long, cirriform; from setiger 2 to setiger 40.
Parapodia: Notopodial lamellae large and auricular in branchial region; lateral membranous pockets between parapodia from about setiger 25 in mature specimens.
Setae: Bidentate hooded hooks in neuropodia from about setiger 45 onward.
Geographical distribution: Cosmopolitan; Arctic to Antarctic; shallow to abyssal depths; recorded from the Cape region.

Species name: Spio filicornis Müller, 1776
Body: Small; up to 30 mm long; about 90 segments; usually smaller.
Prostomium: Anterior margin blunt; posterior end pointed.
Branchiae: Anteriorly attached to bases of notopodial lamellae; posteriorly free.
Parapodia: Notopodial lamellae auricular; neuropodial lamellae broadly oval anteriorly, narrower posteriorly.
Setae: Neuropodial bidentate hooded hooks from setiger 10–11, about 8–10 per neuropodium; two inferior sabre setae in posterior neuropodia.
Geographical distribution: Arctic; North Atlantic from Greenland and North Sea to Bay of Biscay; Pacific from Bering Sea and Japan to California; recorded from the Cape region.

Species name: Dispio magna Day, 1955
Body: Very large; up to 100 mm long; about 200 segments; width ~3 mm.
Prostomium: Smoothly conical; median ridge extending posteriorly to setiger 2; eyes absent.
Peristomium: Closely applied to lateral margins of prostomium.
Branchiae: From setiger 1 to posterior end; anterior branchiae completely fused to notopodial lamellae; mid-body notopodium with distal triangular lobe; accessory branchiae as minute lamellae posterior to neuropodia from about setiger 35.
Parapodia: Neuropodium with small oval presetal lobe; postsetal lobe dorsoventrally elongate, with free superior projection in posterior segments.
Setae: Notopodial and neuropodial capillaries, some with speckled axes; neuropodial hooded hooks from setiger ~30–44, bilobed in juveniles, bluntly unidentate in adults; one to two inferior sabre setae from setiger 14 onward.
Geographical distribution: ; South Africa (Cape, Simonstown)

Species name: Scolelepis lefebvrei Gravier, 1905
Body: Large; up to 80 mm long; ~150 segments; width ~3 mm.
Prostomium: Anteriorly pointed; posterior keel to setiger 2; four eyes in transverse row; occipital tentacle absent; peristomial lateral folds enclosing prostomium.
Branchiae: From setiger 2 to near posterior end.
Parapodia: Neuropodial lamellae oval anteriorly, deeply notched posteriorly; notopodial lamellae almost completely fused to branchiae anteriorly, progressively separate posteriorly, joined only at base by ~setiger 60; dorsal fold connecting lamellae from mid-body onward.
Setae: Anterior notosetae numerous winged capillaries with distal punctuations; posterior notosetae few, fine, elongate; notopodial hooded hooks absent; anterior neurosetae winged capillaries; unidentate hooded hooks from ~setiger 40, up to six posteriorly; posterior neurocapillaries reduced to small tuft.
Pygidium: With ventral cushion below anus.
Geographical distribution: Red Sea; Madagascar.

Species name: Scolelepis squamata Müller, 1806
Body: Up to 80 mm long; ~200 segments.
Prostomium: Anteriorly pointed; four to six eyes in a transverse row; distinct occipital ridge extending to setiger 2.
Branchiae: Fused to notopodial lamellae anteriorly.
Parapodia: Notopodial lamellae fused to branchiae in anterior segments; auricular and largely free posteriorly, inferior margin produced ventrally toward neuropodium.
Setae: Bidentate hooded hooks in neuropodia from setigers 30–35 onward (up to twelve per neuropodium); bidentate hooded hooks in notopodia from about setiger 60.
Pygidium: Small pygidial cushion, broader than long.
Geographical distribution: North Atlantic from Scotland and the English Channel to Senegal and North Carolina; Mediterranean; Pacific coast from western Canada to southern California; also recorded from South-west Africa, the Cape, Natal, Mozambique; doubtful records from India and Madagascar.

Species name: Nerinides gilchristi Day, 1961
Body: About 25 mm long; ~100 segments.
Prostomium: Sharply pointed anteriorly; erect occipital tentacle posteriorly; two pairs of subdermal eyes; short nuchal bands extending to setiger 2.
Peristomium and first setiger: First setiger small; notosetae and neurosetae present.
Branchiae: From setiger 2; anterior branchiae large, strap-like, completely fused to notopodial lamellae; from setiger ~16 onward branchiae and lamellae progressively separating; posterior branchiae narrow-stalked with flag-like distal ends.
Parapodia: Neuropodia ear-shaped throughout; notopodial lamellae triangular and laterally placed in posterior region.
Setae: Anterior notosetae and neurosetae winged capillaries; punctate setae absent; neuropodial hooded hooks from setigers 16–18 onward, replacing capillaries; hooks with three long teeth above main fang; inferior sabre setae absent; posterior notosetae unknown.
Posterior region: Often missing; posterior characters unknown.
Geographical distribution: South Africa (Saldanha Bay, Cape, Natal) and South-west Africa; .

Species name: Prionospio cirrifera Wirén, 1883
Body: About 30 mm long; ~90 segments.
Prostomium: Bluntly pointed anteriorly; posterior keel extending to setiger 2; four subdermal eyes, often indistinct.
Peristomium and anterior segments: Buccal segment partly fused with reduced setiger 1.
Branchiae: Long, smooth, tapered branchiae from setiger 2 to 10; longest on setigers 2–4; branchiae about three times the length of corresponding notopodial lamellae.
Parapodia: Anterior notopodial lamellae pointed, small on first setiger, increasing to setiger 6 then decreasing; posterior notopodial lamellae subequal; dorsal ridges absent; neuropodial lamellae small, triangular; lateral pouches between neuropodia from about setiger 5 in mature specimens.
Setae: Neuropodial hooded hooks from setigers 15–18; notopodial hooded hooks from after setiger 30; hooks with paired teeth above main fang in South African material (two paired teeth).
Geographical distribution: Arctic; North Atlantic (Greenland to Portugal); North and South America; North Sea and English Channel; North Pacific (Behring Sea to southern California); records from South Africa Tropical.

Species name: Prionospio cirrobranchiata Day, 1961
Body: Small, thread-like; about 15 mm long; ~60 segments.
Prostomium: Depressed; square anterior margin; posterior extension as an inconspicuous plate; keel absent; two pairs of small eyes, indistinct or absent in adults.
Branchiae: About 11–12 pairs; from setiger 2 onward; smooth, cirriform; uniform in length; two to three times longer than notopodial lamellae.
Parapodia: Notopodial lamellae triangular, pointed, subequal except first, which is small; neuropodial lamellae small, triangular, similar in shape to notopodial lamellae throughout, including posterior segments.
Setae: Neuropodial hooded hooks from setigers 18–19 onward; about five per neuropodium; each hook with a single tooth above the main fang.
Cirri: Four pairs; subequal; cirriform.
Geographical distribution: South Africa (Cape, including Saldanha Bay); North Carolina.

Species name: Prionospio pinnata Ehlers, 1901
Body: Large; up to 60 mm long.
Prostomium: Bluntly pointed anteriorly; posterior ridge present; enclosed by large wing-like lateral expansions of the peristomium; eyes rarely visible in adults; membranous transverse ridge dorsally behind palp bases.
Peristomium: Lateral expansions broad, wing-like.
Branchiae: Three pairs of large pinnate gills on setigers 1–3; one or more pairs often lost.
Parapodia: First setiger well developed; notopodial postsetal lamellae large and pointed on setigers 1–5, smaller and rounded posteriorly; from setiger 21 to mid-body united across dorsum as low ridges; neuropodial lamellae prominent and pointed anteriorly, low and rounded posteriorly.
Setae: Winged capillary setae in both rami anteriorly; neuropodial hooded hooks from setiger 9 onward, up to 12–15 per neuropodium; hooks with four pairs of teeth above main fang; inferior sabre seta associated with hooks.
Geographical distribution: Atlantic (North Carolina, Morocco, tropical west Africa, South Africa); tropical Indian Ocean; Pacific (western Canada, Japan to Chile); New Zealand.

Species name: Prionospio sexoculata Augener, 1918
Body: Small; 10–20 mm long.
Prostomium: Rounded anteriorly; supported laterally by small peristomial ridges; six eyes.
Peristomium: Reduced; setiger 1 very small, without branchiae or notosetae.
Branchiae: Two pairs of pinnate branchiae on setigers 2 and 3 only.
Parapodia: Notopodial lamellae triangular on setigers 3–5, becoming smaller and rounded posteriorly; no membranous dorsal crests.
Setae: Inferior sabre setae in neuropodia from setiger 12; tridentate hooded hooks in neuropodia from setigers 14–16 onward and in notopodia from setiger 30.
Geographical distribution:  to southern Africa; recorded from South West Africa, the Cape, and Natal.

Species name: Prionospio steenstrupi Malmgren, 1867
Body: Up to 45 mm long; about 100 segments.
Prostomium: Rounded anterior margin; median keel extending posteriorly to setiger 2; eyes indistinct or absent.
Peristomium: Erect lamellae fused to notopodia of setiger 1.
Branchiae: Four pairs on setigers 2–5; first pair pinnate and much larger; second and third pairs smooth, stout, subequal to notopodial lamellae; fourth pair short and pinnate.
Parapodia: Notopodial lamellae triangular and pointed anteriorly, increasing to setiger 4, then decreasing and becoming low and rounded posteriorly; neuropodial lamellae low and oval after anterior segments; no membranous dorsal ridges; no genital pouches.
Setae: Hooded hooks in neuropodia from setigers 18–19 and in notopodia from setiger 50 onward; hooks with four paired rows of teeth above main fang; inferior sabre seta in neuropodia from setiger 18.
