Geographical distribution: North Atlantic (Greenland, Iceland, Norway, North Sea, North Carolina); southern Africa records from South West Africa, Cape, and Natal.

Species name: Prionospio bocki Söderström, 1920
Body: Up to 20 mm long.
Prostomium: Blunt anteriorly; posterior keel extending to setiger 2; two pairs of eyes, anterior pair small, posterior pair large and comma-shaped.
Peristomium / Setiger 1: Setiger 1 small; broad notopodial and neuropodial lamellae present.
Branchiae: Four pairs on setigers 2–5; first pair large, papillate; second and third pairs short and smooth; fourth pair tapered with marginal papillae.
Parapodia: Notopodia largest on setigers 3–4, decreasing posteriorly; low dorsal ridges uniting notopodia from setiger 6; neuropodial lamellae low and oval throughout; membranous genital pockets between neuropodia from setiger 2, conspicuous after about ten segments.
Setae: Hooded hooks in neuropodia from setigers 16–18 onward; hooks with four to five paired teeth above the main fang.
Geographical distribution: Japan; recorded from Madagascar.

Species name: Prionospio ehlersi Fauvel, 1936
Body: Up to 20 mm long.
Prostomium: Anteriorly expanded; posteriorly narrowed into an elevated keel between peristomial folds; two to four small eyes; scattered black pigment flecks.
Peristomium / Setiger 1: First setiger with small notopodial and neuropodial lamellae.
Branchiae: Four pairs on setigers 2–5; first pair pinnate; second and third pairs short and smooth; fourth pair long, smooth, and tapered.
Parapodia: Notopodial lamellae triangular and pointed, largest on setigers 3–5, decreasing posteriorly; low membranous dorsal ridge uniting notopodial lamellae from setiger 5–6 for 20–30 segments; neuropodial lamellae rounded, initially longer than broad, later oval; genital pockets between neuropodia from setiger 2 for about 20 segments in adults.
Setae: Hooded hooks in neuropodia from setigers 19–21 and in notopodia from setiger 37; hooks with numerous teeth above the main fang; punctate sabre seta in inferior neuropodium from setigers 19–23 onward.
Geographical distribution: Morocco; recorded from Natal and Mozambique.

Species name: Prionospio saldanha Day, 1961
Body: Thread-like; up to 25 mm long; about 80 segments.
Prostomium: Rounded anteriorly; posterior keel extending to setiger 2; four eyes.
Peristomium / Setiger 1: Setiger 1 small; fused to peristomium.
Branchiae: Four pairs on setigers 2–5; first three pairs smooth; fourth pair larger and pinnate.
Parapodia: Anterior notopodial lamellae pointed and laterally directed; maximum size on setigers 6–9; posterior lamellae smaller and rounded; dorsal ridges uniting lamellae from setiger 20 onward.
Setae: Hooded hooks in neuropodia from setiger 15; up to six per neuropodium; hooded hooks in notopodia from setigers 25–35; hooks with a single tooth above the main fang; inferior sabre seta in neuropodium from setiger 12.
Geographical distribution:  to southern Africa; recorded from South West Africa, the Cape, and Natal.

Species name: Prionospio malmgreni Claparède, 1870
Body: Thread-like; about 25 mm long; ~60 segments.
Prostomium: Bluntly rounded anteriorly; posterior ridge extending to setiger 2; four eyes, second pair large and elongate.
Peristomium / Setiger 1: Small lateral peristomial folds fused to setiger 1; first setiger reduced.
Branchiae: Four pairs on setigers 2–5; first and fourth pairs long and pinnate; second and third pairs short and smooth.
Parapodia: Anterior notopodial lamellae triangular; largest on setiger 4; lamellae decreasing posteriorly and low, rounded from setiger 8 onward; membranous dorsal ridge across setiger 7 with smaller incomplete ridges on following segments; neuropodial lamellae low and rounded throughout; genital pockets absent.
Setae: Pluridentate hooded hooks in neuropodia from setigers 12–14; hooded hooks in notopodia after setiger 40; inferior sabre seta in neuropodium from setiger 12.
Geographical distribution: Atlantic (North Carolina, North Sea, Madeira); Mediterranean; South California; Japan; southern Africa (Cape, Natal).

Species name: Magelona papillicornis Müller, 1858
Body: Up to 170 mm long; ~150 segments; uniformly white.
Prostomium: Bluntly spear-shaped; anterior end smoothly rounded; median thickening present.
Parapodia (anterior region): Notopodia with low, rounded presetal lips and large tongue-shaped postsetal lamellae; small erect digitiform lobe above notosetae on setigers 1–8; neuropodia with smaller lamellae than notopodia; presetal lamella of neuropodium produced ventrally below neurosetae; postsetal lip small except on setigers 7–8.
Setiger 9: Short; presetal and postsetal lobes subequal in both rami.
Parapodia (abdominal region): From setiger 10 onward, rami with equal tongue-shaped postsetal lamellae curving medially; lateral pockets present on several segments after setiger 25.
Setae: Setigers 1–8 with narrow-winged capillaries in both rami; setiger 9 with few capillaries and numerous modified setae bearing a subterminal expansion before a fine tip; abdominal segments with rows of hooks, each hook with two teeth side by side above the main fang.
Geographical distribution: Atlantic (Scotland, English Channel, North Carolina, Brazil, tropical West Africa); Mediterranean; Madagascar; southern Africa (South West Africa, Cape).

Species name: Magelona cincta Ehlers, 1908
Body: Up to 30 mm long; distinct reddish to purple transverse band on setigers 5–8.
Prostomium: Truncate triangular; about as broad as long; paired muscular strands diverging anteriorly to antero-lateral projections.
Parapodia (anterior region): Neuropodial lamellae slightly larger than notopodial lamellae; notopodial postsetal lamellae ligulate; erect superior lobe (dorsal cirrus) absent; neuropodial lamellae mainly infrasetal; lamella of setiger 8 markedly enlarged; presetal lamellae absent.
Setiger 9: Short; parapodia reduced; setae similar to those of preceding segments.
Parapodia (abdominal region): From setiger 10 onward, rami with subequal, tongue-shaped postsetal lamellae, curved medially and pointed distally; lateral pocket-like folds present anterior to some posterior parapodia in adults.
Setae: Setigers 1–8 with simple capillary setae in both rami; abdominal segments with rows of hooks, each hook bearing two teeth side by side above the main fang.
Geographical distribution: Southern Africa (Cape, Natal, Mozambique); Morocco; tropical western Africa.

Species name: Magelona capensis Day, 1961
Body: About 35 mm long; ~40 segments; uniformly pale; red band on setigers 5–8 absent.
Prostomium: Elongate, 1–3 times as long as broad; antero-lateral corners distinct.
Parapodia (anterior region): Notopodia of setigers 1–8 with small superior lobe united to a much larger inferior lobe; neuropodia with a tapered inferior lobe.
Setiger 9: Notopodium without superior lobe; neuropodium with a small ventral projection.
Parapodia (abdominal region): Notopodial and neuropodial postsetal lamellae subequal; oval in outline with constricted bases.
Setae: Setiger 9 with broad-winged capillaries similar to those of setigers 1–8; abdominal segments with hooded hooks bearing two teeth side by side above the main fang.
Geographical distribution: Southern Africa;  (South West Africa, Cape, Natal).

Species name: Dodecaceria laddi Hartman, 1954
Body: Small; about 7 mm long.
Palps: Long; lateral in origin.
Branchiae: Two pairs; both shorter than palps; first pair dorso-lateral on posterior margin of buccal segment; second pair more dorsal on setiger 1.
Setae: Capillary setae in both rami except neuropodia of middle segments; hooks in both rami from setigers 11–15 onward; anterior hooks with slightly flattened tips; middle hooks spoon-shaped; posterior neuropodial hooks with a boss below the excavation.
Geographical distribution: Marshall Islands (Pacific); recorded from South Africa Tropical.

Species name: Dodecaceria pulchra Day, 1955
Body: Black; gregarious; up to 20 mm long; boring in encrusting calcareous algae.
Prostomium: Stout, hood-like; overhanging mouth.
Palps: Lateral in origin.
Branchiae: Four pairs; longer and more slender than palps; first pair dorsal on buccal segment above palps; second pair on setiger 1; third and fourth pairs on setigers 2 and 3; branchial bases progressively wider apart, forming an inverted V.
Setae: Saw-edged capillaries in notopodia of setigers 1–12, often absent in middle segments, reappearing posteriorly; capillaries absent from neuropodia after setiger 12; spoon-shaped hooks in neuropodia from setiger 10 and in notopodia from setiger 12; posterior hooks with a boss below the excavation.
Geographical distribution: South Africa (False Bay, Cape); South West Africa; .

Species name: Dodecaceria capensis Day, 1961
Body: Gregarious; boring in calcareous algae; up to 15 mm long; about 60 segments.
Prostomium: Stout, hood-like; overhanging elongate mouth.
Palps: Short; lateral; arising just anterior to setiger 1.
Branchiae: Four pairs; longer than palps; first pair immediately above palps; second pair immediately below palps; third pair dorso-lateral on setiger 1; fourth pair lateral on setiger 2.
Setae: Setiger 1 with neurosetae only; notosetae capillaries to setiger 12, replaced by acicular hooks for ~10 segments, later both hooks and capillaries; neurosetae capillaries on setigers 1–7, mixed capillaries and hooks on setigers 8–11, hooks only for several segments, then both types reappearing posteriorly; acicular hooks spoon-shaped.
Geographical distribution: South Africa (False Bay, Cape); South West Africa; .

Species name: Tharyx filibranchia Day, 1961
Body: Elongate; up to 20 mm long; about 180 very short segments; branchiae filamentous.
Prostomium: Pointed; one pair of subdermal eyes.
Palps: One pair; large; grooved; arising at junction of buccal segment and setiger 1.
Branchiae: Very fine filaments; from setiger 1 to near posterior end; anteriorly above notosetae, posteriorly between notosetae and neurosetae.
Setae: Capillaries in both rami throughout; posterior neuropodia with pointed setae intermediate between capillaries and acicular setae.
Geographical distribution: South Africa (False Bay, Cape, Natal); very few records.

Species name: Tharyx marioni Saint-Joseph, 1894
Body: Large; up to 100 mm long and about 1 mm wide; anterior region swollen; body tapered at both ends; anterior segments very short and broad, posterior segments longer.
Prostomium: Broadly conical; eyes absent.
Buccal segment: Triannulate; third annulus distinct.
Palps: One pair; very stout; grooved; arising at junction of buccal segment and setiger 1.
Branchiae: Long, filamentous; from setiger 1 to near posterior end; arising immediately above notosetae throughout.
Setae: All smooth capillaries in both rami; notosetae longer than neurosetae; posterior notosetae extremely long, sometimes as long as body width.
Geographical distribution: North Atlantic (Scotland to Morocco, including English Channel and North Carolina); Mediterranean; also recorded from Persian Gulf and Madras; southern Africa (South West Africa, Cape, Natal).

Species name: Tharyx dorsobranchialis Kirkegaard, 1959
Body: Thread-like; about 35 mm long; anterior segments short; posterior segments about as broad as long.
Prostomium: Sharply conical; eyes absent.
Buccal segment: Expanded; triannulate.
Palps: One pair; large; grooved; caducous; arising at junction of third buccal annulus and setiger 1.
Branchiae: Very slender filaments; present from setiger 1 to posterior end; anterior branchiae arising dorsally within a fusiform interbranchial area extending to about setiger 20; posterior branchiae arising from mid-dorsal line.
Setae: All saw-edged capillaries; acicular hooks absent.
Geographical distribution: Angola; southern Africa (South West Africa, Cape, Natal).

Species name: Tharyx annulosus Hartman, 1965
Body: Up to 18 mm long; cylindrical anteriorly; middle region with strong segmental constrictions producing a beaded appearance; posterior segments short and slightly flattened.
Prostomium: Bluntly conical; eyes absent.
Buccal segment: Elongate; without annuli.
Palps: One pair; grooved; dorso-lateral in position; arising at junction of buccal segment and setiger 1.
Branchiae: Filamentous; inserted immediately above notosetae; anterior pairs nearly as long as palps; progressively shorter posteriorly; disappearing before mid-body.
Setae: Serrated capillaries only; anterior capillaries relatively long; remaining setae short, about one-third segmental width; blades thick and expanded, abruptly tapering to filiform tips; margins strongly saw-toothed.
Geographical distribution: Western Atlantic from Massachusetts to north-eastern South America; recorded from Natal, South Africa.

Species name: Caulleriella capensis Monro, 1930
Body: Yellow; rather swollen; 20–30 mm long; segments relatively long; branchiae stout.
Prostomium: Short; conical; depressed; posterior margin with paired dark ocular bars composed of three to four eyes.
Buccal segment: Swollen; third annulus bearing a pair of stout palps.
Palps: Thick; stouter than branchial filaments.
Branchiae: Filamentous; restricted to anterior body; usually fewer than 15 pairs; arising immediately above notosetae.
Parapodia: Parapodial tori prominent anteriorly.
Setae: Capillary setae with finely spinulose margins in both rami throughout; unidentate acicular hooks from setigers 15–20 onward.
Geographical distribution: South Africa (Simonstown, Cape region); possible record from South West Africa; probably .

Species name: Caulleriella acicula Day, 1961
Body: Up to 20 mm long; about 200 segments; segments short and somewhat flattened; prominent parapodial ridges laterally.
Prostomium: Sharply conical; pair of small subdermal eyes.
Buccal segment: Swollen; palps arising at junction with setiger 1.
Palps: Slender.
Branchiae: Slender filaments; arising just above notosetae; extending at least to mid-body.
Parapodia: Rami well separated.
Setae: Notopodia with very few capillaries; neuropodia without capillaries; acicular hooks in both rami throughout; hooks bidentate with small secondary tooth and a narrow hood on convex side of shaft.
Geographical distribution: South Africa (False Bay, Cape, Natal); .

Species name: Caulleriella zetlandica McIntosh, 1911
Body: Thread-like; up to 25 mm long; pale in alcohol; rounded in section; segments short and crowded.
Prostomium: Long conical; eyes absent.
Peristome: Stout; triannulate.
Palps: One pair; stout; grooved; arising at junction of peristome and setiger 1.
Branchiae: Slender filaments; arising immediately above notosetae; progressively shorter posteriorly.
Parapodia: Notosetae and neurosetae closely approximated.
Setae: Notosetae, Capillaries only; some long with slender blades, others shorter with broader, curved blades; Neurosetae, Short, broad-bladed capillaries plus two to four stout sigmoid hooks; hooks bidentate in juveniles, teeth very blunt to almost truncate in adults; hoods absent.
Geographical distribution: Ireland; doubtful record from South Africa.

Species name: Caulleriella bioculatus Keferstein, 1862
Body: Up to 40 mm long; about 140 segments.
Prostomium: Pointed; two eye-spots present.
Palps: One pair; long; grooved; inserted at junction of buccal segment and setiger 1.
Branchiae: Slender filaments; from setiger 1 to about mid-body.
Parapodia: Notopodia, Capillaries throughout; one to three acicular hooks from about setigers 6–9 onward; Neuropodia, Capillaries on setigers 1–2 only; hooks thereafter.
Setae: Hooks bidentate with a minute secondary tooth; hoods absent.
Geographical distribution: English Channel; questionable record from Angola; not recorded from southern Africa.

Species name: Chaetozone setosa Malmgren, 1867
Body: Elongate; 20–25 mm long; 70–90 segments.
Prostomium: Conical; eyes absent.
Palps: Two stout palps; anterior margin of setiger 1.
Branchiae: Filamentous; from setiger 1 to mid-body; arising close above notosetae.
Setae: Capillary setae from setiger 1 to posterior end; notosetae up to four times segmental width; simple sigmoid acicular hooks in notopodia from setiger 3 onward and in neuropodia from setiger 1; notopodial and neuropodial bundles separate anteriorly, forming a continuous dorsoventral arc of spines in posterior segments.
Pygidium: Dorsal anus.
Geographical distribution: Arctic and subarctic regions; North Atlantic from Greenland and Sweden to Morocco; tropical West Africa to Angola; Mediterranean; Aden; subantarctic (Heard Island); North Pacific from Bering Sea and Japan to California; recorded from the Cape, South Africa.

Species name: Cirratulus filiformis Keferstein, 1862
Body: Very slender; up to 50 mm long; greenish brown in life.
Prostomium: Pointed; eyes absent.
Buccal segment: Swollen.
Tentacular filaments: About four; arising at junction of buccal segment and setiger 1.
Branchiae: Filamentous; from setiger 1 to near posterior end; arising just above notosetae throughout.
Parapodia: Parapodial ridges well marked.
Setae: Slender, flattened capillaries throughout; hooks entirely absent.
Geographical distribution: Eastern Atlantic from Scotland to Morocco; Senegal; possibly Sweden, tropical western Africa, South Georgia, and Persian Gulf; recorded from South West Africa and the Cape.

Species name: Cirratulus africanus Gravier, 1906
Body: About 50 mm long; brown in colour.
Prostomium: Long, pointed; eyes absent.
Tentacular filaments: Three to four; arising above setigers 2–3.
Branchiae: From setiger 3; extending over most of the body; arising close above notosetae.
Parapodia: Parapodial rami similar throughout.
Setae: Capillary setae in both rami throughout; from about setiger 10, setae abruptly tapering and intermediate between capillaries and hooks; changing to normal sigmoid acicular hooks about mid-body.
Geographical distribution: Gulf of Aden; recorded from Mozambique.

Species name: Cirratulus gilchristi Day, 1961
Body: Thread-like; about 12 mm long; strongly tapered.
Prostomium: Bluntly rounded; four pairs of eyes, reduced to one or two pairs in juveniles.
Tentacular filaments: Three to five pairs; stout; arising from the anterior margin of setiger 1 in a transverse row.
Branchiae: From setiger 1 to posterior end; in mid-body arising high on the parapodium, as far above the notosetae as the distance between noto- and neurosetae.
Setae: Unidentate acicular hooks in both rami from setigers 3–6 onward; capillaries present in all notopodia; neuropodial capillaries absent from setiger 6 onward.
Geographical distribution:  to South Africa; recorded from Saldanha Bay and the Cape region (three records).

Species name: Cirratulus cirratus Müller, 1776
Body: Elongate, cylindrical; up to 50 mm long and 1–2 mm in diameter; segments two to three times broader than long.
Prostomium: Bluntly conical; two to four pairs of eyes arranged in a transverse row.
Peristome: Elongate, as long as the first three to four segments.
Tentacular filaments: Numerous; forming a transverse row above setiger 1.
Branchiae: Stout; from setiger 1 to posterior end; in middle segments arising higher above the notosetae than the distance between noto- and neurosetae.
Setae: Capillary setae in both rami throughout; one to two sigmoid acicular hooks in the notopodia from about setiger 20 onward; two to four sigmoid acicular hooks in the neuropodia from about setiger 12 onward.
Geographical distribution: Arctic and North Atlantic (North Sea to English Channel); subantarctic regions from the Magellan area and Falkland Islands to Kerguelen; no confirmed southern African records.

Species name: Cirratulus concinnus Ehlers, 1908
Body: Small, thread-like; about 25 mm long with ~80 segments.
Prostomium: Elongate conical; eyes absent.
Peristome and tentacular filaments: Buccal segment elongate; one to two pairs of grooved tentacular filaments at the junction of the peristome and setiger 1.
Branchiae: From setiger 1 onward; in mid-body arising close above the notosetae.
Setae: Long capillary setae in both rami throughout; acicular hooks absent from notopodia; acicular hooks present in neuropodia from about setiger 32 onward.
Geographical distribution: Known only from the type locality, Agulhas Bank, South Africa; single record.

Species name: Cirriformia tentaculata Montagu, 1808
Body: Slender; up to 200 mm in European material, up to 80 mm in South African specimens; uniformly brown; gills red in life.
Prostomium: Pointed.
Tentacular filaments: Numerous; arranged in two clusters; arising above setigers 5–7.
Branchiae: Slender filaments from setiger 1 to posterior end; arising close above notosetae.
Segments: Narrow and closely crowded.
Setae: Capillary setae in both rami throughout; four to five unidentate acicular hooks per ramus from about the posterior third of the body (around segment 50 onward).
Geographical distribution: Eastern Atlantic from the North Sea to Morocco and tropical western Africa; Persian Gulf; tropical Indian Ocean; Pacific from Japan and New Caledonia to New Zealand and Campbell Islands; recorded from South West Africa, Cape coast, Natal, and Mozambique.

Species name: Cirriformia saxatilis Gravier, 1906
Body: About 50 mm long; yellowish brown; anterior segments darker ventrally.
Prostomium: Rounded.
Tentacular filaments: Arising above setigers 2–4.
Branchiae: From setiger 1 to posterior half of body; arising immediately above notosetae.
Setae: Saw-edged capillaries in both rami throughout; sigmoid hooks in neuropodia from setiger 8; sigmoid hooks in notopodia from setiger 42.
Geographical distribution: Gulf of Aden; recorded from Mozambique.

Species name: Cirriformia afer Ehlers, 1908
Body: Up to 20 mm long; fairly stout; parapodia forming lateral ridges.
Prostomium: Broadly rounded; eyes absent.
Tentacular filaments: Five to six on each side; arising above setiger 2.
Branchiae: From setiger 1 to posterior half of body; arising close above notosetae.
Setae: Capillaries in both rami throughout; hooks absent anteriorly; occasional single spine accompanying capillaries in some posterior segments.
Geographical distribution: Angola.

Species name: Cirriformia punctata Grube, 1859
Body: About 40 mm long; fairly broad; brown with black flecking; tentacles and branchiae barred.
Prostomium: Rounded anteriorly; eyes not evident.
Tentacular filaments: Numerous; arising around setiger 4.
Branchiae: From setiger 1 to near posterior end; arising well above notosetae in mid-body, higher than distance between noto- and neurosetae.
Setae: Capillary setae in both rami throughout; slender sigmoid hooks appearing from about setiger 12.
Geographical distribution: Circumtropical; recorded from Natal and Mozambique

Species name: Cirriformia capensis Schmarda, 1861
Body: Large; up to 150 mm long and 6 mm wide; numerous segments; uniformly brown; gills and tentacles orange.
Prostomium: Broadly rounded anteriorly; eyes absent.
Tentacular filaments: Numerous; arising above setigers 3–4.
Branchiae: From setiger 1 to posterior end; stout filaments; in mid-body arising higher above notosetae than the distance between noto- and neurosetae.
Setae: Capillary setae in both rami throughout; sigmoid hooks appearing from about setiger 12.
Geographical distribution: Southern Africa; records from South West Africa and the Cape; Angola.

Species name: Cirriformia filigera Delle Chiaje, 1825
Body: Very large; up to 250 mm long; uniformly brownish; gills reddish.
Prostomium: Bluntly conical; eyes absent in adults.
Tentacular filaments: Numerous; arising above setigers 4–6.
Branchiae: From setiger 1 to near posterior end; in mid-body arising higher above notosetae than the distance between noto- and neurosetae.
Setae: Capillary setae in both rami throughout; sigmoid hooks from about setiger 12.
Geographical distribution: Warm and tropical Atlantic (Morocco, São Tomé, North Carolina, Gulf of Mexico); Mediterranean; Persian Gulf; tropical Indian Ocean; doubtful Pacific records; southern Africa (Natal, Mozambique)

Species name: Poecilochaetus serpens Allen, 1904
Body: Slender; up to 55 mm long; segments indistinct.
Prostomium: Rounded; four eyes; dorsal lip with a digitiform process; three long nuchal processes from occipital region.
Palps: Long, grooved, caducous.
Parapodia: First setiger with vestigial notopodial postsetal lobe and long cirriform postsetal neuropodial lobe; setigers 2–6 with tapered noto- and neuropodial lobes; setigers 7–13 with club-shaped lobes with swollen bases and knobbed tips; setiger 14 onward lobes tapered again; two to four filamentous gills behind middle and posterior parapodia.
Setae: Long forward-directed capillaries on setiger 1 forming a cephalic cage; two to four curved spines in neuropodia of setigers 2–3; remaining anterior setae smooth capillaries; a few feathered setae in middle segments, persisting posteriorly; last 16–17 setigers with notosetae replaced by simple or serrate spines.
Geographical distribution: North Atlantic (Scotland, Ireland, English Channel to Morocco); Mediterranean; southern Africa (Cape, Natal)

Species name: Phyllochaetopterus herdmani Willey, 1905
Body: Large; up to 80 mm long.
Prostomium: Without eyes.
Tentacular cirri: Long, tapered; supported by fine internal setae.
Buccal segment: Large, truncate, upcurved; palps barred.
Anterior region: Nine to ten segments; segment 4 with six to eight stout setae, obliquely truncate distally.
Middle region: Two segments; notopodia elongate and bilobed; branchiae flattened; neuropodia large, wing-like, with uncini along entire outer margin.
Posterior region: Numerous segments; notopodia digitiform with knobbed tips; neuropodia inferior, square, projecting pinnules.
Uncini: With twelve to fourteen teeth.
Tube: Fragile; thickly encrusted with sand grains and shell fragments.
Geographical distribution: Ceylon; Indian Ocean records from Natal and Mozambique.

Species name: Phyllochaetopterus elioti Crossland, 1903
Body: Large; 50–100 mm long, 2–3 mm broad.
Prostomium: With one pair of eyes.
Buccal segment: Truncate.
Palps: Barred with brown.
Tentacular cirri: Well developed, digitiform; arising laterally from the prostomium.
Anterior region: Fifteen segments; segment 4 with two to three enlarged, truncate setae.
Middle region: More than twenty short segments; notopodia bilobed, each with six slender setae; lateral triangular branchiae continuous with ventro-lateral neuropodia bearing numerous minute uncini with about 30 teeth.
Posterior region: Slender, knobbed notopodia, each supported by a single spear-headed seta.
Tube: Horny, not ringed, densely encrusted with sand.
Geographical distribution: Zanzibar; Ceylon; Gulf of Manaar; recorded from Mozambique and the Cape (South Africa).

Species name: Phyllochaetopterus socialis Claparede, 1870
Body: Small; usually ≤30 mm long; posterior region dark green.
Prostomium: Ovoid; two lateral eyes, often obscured by small tentacular cirri.
Buccal segment: Truncate anteriorly; laterally curved upward along sides of prostomium.
Palps: Two; long, stout, grooved.
Anterior region: Ten to eighteen segments; setiger 4 with a single stout brown specialised seta with irregularly truncate tip.
Middle region: Seven to twenty-four segments; notopodia bilobed dorsally; lateral triangular branchiae; neuropodia ventro-lateral and uncigerous.
Uncini: About 24 teeth.
Posterior region: Numerous segments; digitiform notopodia with one to two spear-headed setae.
Tube: Horny; distally ringed; frequently aggregated into branching colonies.
Geographical distribution: Atlantic from U.S.A. and English Channel to Falkland Islands and South Africa; Mediterranean; tropical Indian Ocean; Australia; recorded from South West Africa, Cape, Natal, and Mozambique.

Species name: Spiochaetopterus vitrarius Ehlers, 1908
Body: Slender; >35 mm long; three regions—anterior with nine uniramous segments, middle with ~20 segments of decreasing length, posterior with numerous short segments.
Prostomium: Ovoid; one pair of lateral eye-spots.
Buccal segment: Broad, truncate; laterally upcurved.
Palps: Long; distally barred.
Tentacular cirri: Absent.
Anterior region: Segment 4 with a fan of hastate setae and one enlarged seta with swollen, conical tip; segment 7 with a sharp ventral black pigment arc; segments 8–9 with a white glandular patch.
Middle region: Notopodia large, flattened, bilobed; lateral branchiae present; neuropodia with undivided rows of serpuliform uncini.
Posterior region: Notopodia short, blunt; supported by one to two long hastate setae; branchiae absent; neuropodia with serpuliform uncini.
Tube: Clear, horny, closely ringed.
Geographical distribution: Tropical western Africa from Senegal to Angola; recorded

Species name: Spiochaetopterus costarum Claparède, 1870
Body: Slender, fragile; 50–60 mm long; anterior, middle, and posterior regions distinct.
Prostomium: Not described.
Palps: Long; brown-speckled.
Anterior region: Nine to ten setigers; large white glandular patch on ventrum of setiger 7; setiger 4 with one enlarged seta, swollen and truncate distally, cutting edge serrate.
Middle region: Numerous segments; bilobed notopodia; lateral triangular branchiae; neuropodia with numerous uncini bearing 25–30 small teeth; cupule present on second middle segment.
Posterior region: Short; segments crowded; digitiform notopodia; neuropodia reduced.
Tube: Horny, transparent, distinctly ringed.
Geographical distribution: Atlantic coast of France; Mediterranean; Madagascar; Japan; western Canada to southern California; recorded from the Cape, South Africa.

Species name: Chaetopterus variopedatus Renier, 1804
Body: Large, robust; about 100–150 mm long and ~10 mm broad; ~70 segments; body divided into anterior, middle, and posterior regions.
Prostomium: Very small; head truncate; buccal segment very large, forming a glandular lower lip; one pair of small eyes.
Palps: One pair; short, tapered.
Anterior region: Eight to twelve segments; triangular notopodia; notosetae with flattened, knife-like blades; setiger 4 with several stout, obliquely truncate setae plus a few capillaries.
Middle region: Five biramous segments; first short with small notopodia; second elongate with large wing-like notopodia anteriorly and a posterior cupule; third to fifth segments with large notopodia fused across the dorsum forming paddles; neuropodial uncini with six to eight teeth.
Posterior region: More than 20 segments; digitiform notopodia with knobbed ends; neuropodia bilobed.
Geographical distribution: Cosmopolitan except Arctic and Antarctic; recorded from the Cape and Natal (South Africa) and Mozambique.

Species name: Mesochaetopterus capensis McIntosh, 1885
Body: Small; about 15 mm long; more than 20 segments; solitary.
Prostomium: Ovoid; one pair of eyes at bases of palps.
Palps: Long; faintly barred distally.
Anterior region: Nine uniramous segments; fourth setiger with eight modified setae, obliquely truncate and serrated.
Middle region: Two elongate segments; first with a pair of short notopodia close to posterior anterior segment; second with longer strap-like notopodia and a posterior cupule; neuropodia as bilobed ridges with divided series of uncini.
Uncini: Individual uncini with six to nine teeth.
Posterior region: Short segments; simple conical notopodia supported by two setae with flattened, tapering blades.
Tube: Fragile; encrusted with sand or foraminiferal shells.
Geographical distribution: ; recorded from the Cape and Natal, South Africa

Species name: Scoloplella capensis Day, 1963
Body: Small, thread-like; about 6 mm long in incomplete specimen; 25 segments.
Prostomium: Bluntly conical; eyes absent.
Peristome: Achaetous; following segment also achaetous.
Thorax: Seven short setigerous segments; nearly rounded; sharply demarcated from abdomen.
Parapodia (thorax): Rami close together; each reduced to a small papilla with a bundle of crenulate capillary setae.
Abdomen: Segments longer than broad; notopodium with a short blunt postsetal lobe; neuropodium stout and bilobed; intermediate and ventral cirri absent.
Branchiae: Absent from thorax; first appearance from setiger 24.
Setae: Thoracic and abdominal neurosetae short, broad-bladed, crenulate capillaries; specialised setae absent.
Geographical distribution: Known only from the type locality west of Cape Town (183 m depth).

Species name: Proscoloplos cygnochaetus Day, 1954
Body: Very small; 3–5 mm long.
Prostomium: Rounded.
Anterior segments: First two segments achaetous.
Parapodia: Essentially uniform throughout.
Notopodia: Digitiform postsetal lobe; few crenulate capillary setae arising from base.
Neuropodia: Similar to notopodia but smaller and more lateral; neurosetae of a few crenulate capillaries; posterior segments with one to two swan-shaped hooks bearing four to five denticles above the rostrum.
Branchiae: Stout, fusiform; from setiger 8.
Geographical distribution: Tristan da Cunha; single record from the Cape.

Species name: Schroederella pauliani Laubier, 1962
Body: Minute; 3–4 mm long; about 40 segments.
Prostomium: Long, pointed, conical; divided into two annuli; one pair of eyes.
Thorax: About 8–20 segments; without branchiae; thoracic neuropodia as slight lateral swellings; no foot papillae; postsetal notopodial lobe small, appearing on setigers 7–9.
Intermediate region: Short; 4–5 segments between thorax and abdomen.
Abdomen: 16–20 segments; digitiform dorsal branchiae; small postsetal notopodial lobes; neuropodia better developed than thoracic ones; ventral cirri absent.
Setae: Notosetae crenulate capillaries throughout, with a sharp pointed aciculum in the abdomen; thoracic neurosetae of a few crenulate capillaries and several serrated acicular uncini; abdominal neurosetae of one to two crenulate capillaries and a single blunt acicular seta or projecting aciculum.
Geographical distribution: Sandwich Bay, South West Africa; no further records.

Species name: Orbinia angrapequensis Augener, 1918
Body: Length up to 30 mm; about 90 segments; thorax with 18–24 setigers.
Thorax: Branchiae from setiger 6; postsetal notopodial lobe distinct from first setiger; about 12 foot papillae per neuropodium; continuous rows of stomach papillae near thorax–abdomen junction.
Abdomen: Notopodia with few forked setae among capillaries; neuropodia bilobed with inner ramus longer than outer; ventral cirri present on all abdominal neuropodia; ciliated cushion present; interramal cirrus absent.
Setae: Thoracic neurosetae in three to four rows of flanged, bent, serrated hooks plus a row of crenulate capillaries; abdominal notosetae mainly capillaries with few forked setae.
Geographical distribution: South West Africa (Lüderitz); Cape region, South Africa; .

Species name: Orbinia cuvieri Audouin & Milne-Edwards, 1834
Body: Very large; up to 300 mm long; about 400 segments; thorax with 22–26 setigers.
Thorax: Branchiae from setiger 5; postsetal notopodial lobe distinct from first setiger; neuropodia with 10–15 foot papillae; continuous rows of stomach papillae at thorax–abdomen junction.
Abdomen: Notopodia with chopper-shaped postsetal lobes and larger tapered branchiae; well-developed interramal cirrus; neuropodia bilobed with a small conical ventral cirrus.
Setae: Thoracic neurosetae in three to five rows of flanged, bent, serrated hooks plus a few crenulate capillaries; no enlarged superior spines; abdominal notosetae mainly crenulate capillaries with a few forked setae bearing unequal prongs; abdominal neurosetae few short crenulate capillaries.
Geographical distribution: North Atlantic (Greenland, Sweden, North Sea, English Channel); Mediterranean; southern Africa recorded from Natal.

Species name: Orbinia bioreti Fauvel, 1919
Body: Large; up to 130 mm long; more than 120 segments; thorax with 31–39 setigers.
Thorax: Branchiae from setiger 5–6; postsetal notopodial lobe distinct from first setiger; neuropodia with about 12 foot papillae; continuous rows of stomach papillae at thorax–abdomen junction.
Abdomen: Notopodia without forked setae; interramal cirrus rudimentary anteriorly, well developed posteriorly; neuropodia with small unequal lobes.
Setae: Thoracic neurosetae in four to five rows of flanged, bent, smooth hooks with very few crenulate capillaries; abdominal neurosetae with two blunt, bent acicula and two to three crenulate capillaries, some abruptly tapered.
Geographical distribution: Bay of Biscay; Madagascar; southern Africa recorded from Natal.

Species name: Orbinia monroi Day, 1955
Body: Large; up to 100 mm long; about 200 segments; thorax with ~50 setigers.
Thorax: Branchiae from setiger 5; posterior thoracic neuropodia with ~11 foot papillae; stomach papillae numerous (~30) on setigers 40–45.
Abdomen: Interramal cirrus well developed; notopodial postsetal lobe chopper-shaped.
Setae: Thoracic neurosetae in four to five rows of flanged, bent, smooth hooks with a few crenulate capillaries; abdominal forked setae with weakly serrated shafts.
Geographical distribution:  to southern Africa; recorded from the Cape and Mozambique.

Species name: Haploscoloplos fragilis Verrill, 1873
Body: Small; up to 20 mm long; thorax with 15–16 setigers.
Thorax: Notopodia with a well-marked postsetal lobe from the first setiger; anterior neuropodia with a single postsetal lobe; last two thoracic neuropodia with two to three postsetal lobes.
Abdomen: Notopodia slender; neuropodia bilobed with initially two, later one ventral cirrus; interramal cirrus present at thorax–abdomen junction, decreasing posteriorly.
Branchiae: From setigers 14–15; larger than notopodia.
Setae: Crenulate capillaries in both rami throughout; no hooks.
Geographical distribution: Cape (South Africa); identity uncertain—possibly distinct from Atlantic H. fragilis populations.

Species name: Haploscoloplos kerguelensis McIntosh, 1885
Body: Small; up to 20 mm long.
Thorax: 10–14 slightly flattened segments; branchiae from setigers 9–15 onward; notopodial postsetal lobes distinct from first setiger; neuropodia with a single long median foot papilla; stomach papillae absent.
Abdomen: Notopodia small and tapered; neuropodia with unequal lobes; interramal cirrus absent; ventral cirrus absent.
Branchiae: Small anteriorly, becoming much larger than notopodia in posterior abdomen.
Setae: Crenulate capillaries in both thoracic and abdominal rami only.
Geographical distribution: Southern Ocean regions—Kerguelen Island, Magellan area, South Georgia, Antarctica; recorded from South Africa Tropical; Western Australia; doubtful record from India.

Species name: Scolaricia dubia Day, 1955
Body: Up to 35 mm long; about 100 segments
Thorax: Nineteen setigers; branchiae from setiger 13
Prostomium: Conical, pointed; eyes absent
Parapodia (thoracic): Neuropodia with a single median foot papilla, increasing to three at end of thorax
Stomach papillae: Six to twelve at thorax–abdomen junction
Interramal cirrus: Large, well developed
Parapodia (abdominal): Neuropodia with equal lobes; ventral cirrus absent; blunt glandular lamella below neuropodium, later notched and sometimes divided into two lamellae
Notopodia: Postsetal lobe present; notosetae crenulate capillaries only; forked setae absent
Setae (thoracic neuropodia): Three rows of flanged, bent, serrated hooks; posterior row of crenulate capillaries
Setae (abdominal neuropodia): Few crenulate capillaries; long flail setae with abruptly tapered tips and serrated shafts
Geographical distribution:  to South Africa; recorded from the Cape region

Species name: Scoloplos capensis Day, 1961
Body: Up to 45 mm long; about 112 segments
Thorax: Seventeen setigers; branchiae from setiger 15
Prostomium: Conical, pointed; eyes absent
Parapodia (thoracic): Neuropodia faintly bilobed with a single median foot papilla
Stomach papillae: Absent
Interramal cirrus: Absent
Parapodia (abdominal): Neuropodia bilobed with a single inferior lamellar expansion; ventral cirrus absent
Notopodia: Postsetal lobe present; abdominal notosetae without forked setae
Setae (thoracic neuropodia): Blunt hooks with a few coarse serrations; posterior row of crenulate capillaries
Setae (abdominal neuropodia): One to two crenulate capillaries; one to two flail setae
Geographical distribution:  to South Africa; recorded from the Agulhas Bank and Cape region

Species name: Scoloplos marsupialis Southern, 1921
Body: Up to 50 mm long; about 210 segments
Thorax: About 18 setigers; branchiae from setiger 9–13 onward
Prostomium: Conical, pointed; eyes absent
Parapodia (thoracic): Neuropodia with a single foot papilla from setiger 4–12
Stomach papillae: Absent
Interramal cirrus: Absent
Parapodia (abdominal): Segments with membranous pockets between adjacent neuropodia
Setae (thoracic neuropodia): Mainly crenulate capillaries; hooks few or absent, serrated, flanged, faintly recurved when present
Setae (abdominal): Forked setae very few
Geographical distribution: India (Chilka Lake, Gulf of Manaar); Mozambique

Species name: Leodamas johnstonei Day, 1934
Body: Up to 35 mm long; about 180 segments
Thorax: 21–24 setigers; branchiae from setiger 6
Prostomium: Conical, pointed; eyes absent
Parapodia (thoracic): Neuropodia without foot papillae or with one to two papillae on the last two to three thoracic segments
Parapodia (abdominal): Neuropodia bilobed, outer ramus larger than inner; inferior lamella absent
Interramal cirrus: Absent
Setae (thoracic neuropodia): Three to five rows of hooks plus a few capillaries; hooks slightly bent near tip, lightly serrated and flanged
Setae (abdominal notopodia): Crenulate capillaries plus a few forked setae with equal prongs
Setae (abdominal neuropodia): Crenulate capillaries with normally tapered tips
Acicula: Blunt-tipped
Geographical distribution: South Africa (Cape, Natal); Mozambique;

Species name: Scoloplos madagascariensis Fauvel, 1919
Body: Large; up to 120 mm long; over 250 segments
Thorax: 24–30 thoracic setigers; branchiae from about setiger 22
Parapodia (thoracic): Notopodial postsetal lobe minute anteriorly, distinct from about setiger 10; neuropodia without foot papillae, occasionally one to three on last thoracic segments
Parapodia (abdominal): Neuropodia without ventral cirri
Setae (thoracic neuropodia): Two rows of hooks with very few accompanying capillaries; hooks smooth, almost straight, without serrations or flange
Setae (abdominal notopodia): Capillaries plus forked setae with unequal rami
Geographical distribution: Madagascar; tropical West Africa (Mauritania, Gulf of Guinea, Angola); southern Africa (Cape, Natal, Mozambique)

Species name: Scoloplos armiger Müller, 1776
Body: Large; up to 120 mm long; about 200 segments
Prostomium: Pointed; subdermal eyes present
Thorax: 16–18 thoracic setigers; branchiae from setigers 12–15
Parapodia (thoracic): Neuropodia with at least one foot papilla; last three to four thoracic segments with two foot papillae
Stomach papillae: One to two at thorax–abdomen junction
Parapodia (abdominal): Neuropodia bilobed; inner lobe longer; no ventral cirrus
Interramal cirrus: Absent
Setae (notopodia): Crenulate capillaries throughout; one to two forked setae in abdomen
Setae (thoracic neuropodia): Five rows; mixture of crenulate capillaries and short blunt hook-like setae
Geographical distribution: Arctic; North and South Atlantic; North Pacific (Japan to California); possibly Indian Ocean; doubtful records from the Cape

Species name: Aricidea curviseta Day, 1963
Body: Up to 20 mm long; about 100 segments; anterior segments very short (about six times broader than long); posterior segments about as broad as long
Prostomium: Bluntly conical; slightly longer than broad
Antenna: Short; not reaching tip of prostomium
Branchiae: 34–44 pairs; from setiger 4; anterior branchiae about half segmental width; posterior branchiae progressively smaller
Parapodia (notopodia): Postsetal lobes tapered; anterior lobes about one-third branchial length; posterior lobes very slender
Parapodia (neuropodia): Postsetal lobes not visible
Setae (anterior): Notosetae and neurosetae curved capillaries; stout shafts; tapering blades
Setae (posterior notopodia): Few slender capillaries
Setae (posterior neuropodia): Capillaries only; superior setae normally tapering; inferior setae numerous, short, stout, abruptly tapered with a distinct kink between shaft and blade; no articulation
Geographical distribution: South Africa (Agulhas Bank, Cape, Natal); possibly

Species name: Aricidea (Acmira) simplex Day, 1963
Body: Slender; about 12 mm long; ~80 segments; anterior segments about six times broader than long; posterior segments slightly longer
Prostomium: Slightly longer than broad
Antenna: Short; club-shaped; not reaching tip of prostomium
Branchiae: From setiger 4 to about setiger 15; anterior branchiae overlapping medially; posterior branchiae smaller
Parapodia (notopodia): Postsetal lobe slender; anterior lobes about two-thirds branchial length; posterior lobes similar in length
Parapodia (neuropodia): No distinct postsetal lobes
Setae (anterior): Notosetae and neurosetae curved capillaries with tapered blades
Setae (posterior): Capillaries straight and much finer
Specialised setae: From setiger 24; neuropodia with 6–10 stout, blunt, sigmoid acicular setae; no terminal filament
Geographical distribution: South Africa (west of Cape Town, abyssal);

Species name: Aricidea fauveli Hartman, 1957
Body: About 20 mm long; ~0.4 mm wide; ~100 segments; anterior region strongly flattened with segments about eight times broader than long; posterior region rounded with slightly longer segments
Prostomium: Bluntly triangular; about as broad as long; indistinct eyes; small median antenna
Branchiae: From setiger 4; extending over 20–24 segments; anterior branchiae about two-thirds segmental breadth; posterior branchiae basally stouter and as long as segmental width
Parapodia (notopodia): Anterior postsetal lobes well developed, about half the length of the branchia; posterior lobes slender
Parapodia (neuropodia): Postsetal lobes not prominent
Setae (anterior): Notosetae and neurosetae curved, tapered capillaries
Setae (posterior): Reduced in number; notosetae few fine capillaries slightly longer than notopodial lobes; neurosetae a few capillaries plus about four curved unidentate hooks with a delicate pointed hood (arista) over the convex side of the apex
Geographical distribution: Eastern Atlantic—Morocco, tropical western Africa, Angola; recorded from South Africa Tropical

Species name: Aricidea longobranchiata Day, 1961
Body: Vermiform, tapering; up to 20 mm long, ~0.8 mm wide; about 120 segments; anterior segments flattened, six to eight times broader than long; posterior segments only slightly broader than long
Prostomium: Bluntly triangular; as broad as long; eyes absent; median antenna very long, reaching setiger 5
Branchiae: From setiger 4; extending over 18–22 segments; anterior branchiae uniformly tapered and slightly overlapping mid-dorsally; last three pairs with swollen bases and very long slender tips exceeding segmental width
Notopodia: Anterior postsetal lobes well developed; posterior postsetal lobes very slender
Neuropodia: Postsetal lobes inconspicuous
Setae (anterior): Notosetae and neurosetae curved capillaries with relatively broad blades
Setae (posterior): Capillaries fine and straight; neuropodia with four to five hooks, each unidentate and curved, with a fine tapered guard (arista) arising from the concave side of the shaft
Geographical distribution: Southern Africa; recorded from South West Africa and the Cape;

Species name: Aricidea capensis Day, 1961
Body: Thread-like; about 10 mm long, ~0.2 mm wide; more than 75 segments; anterior segments about three times broader than long; posterior segments scarcely broader than long
Prostomium: Conical; about 1.5 times longer than broad; eyes absent; antenna slightly longer than prostomium, obscurely annulated near tip
Branchiae: From setiger 4; extending over about 14 segments; most branchiae about two-thirds of segmental breadth; last two to three pairs smaller
Notopodia: Anterior postsetal lobes about one-third length of branchiae; posterior postsetal lobes reduced
Neuropodia: Postsetal lobes not prominent
Setae (anterior): Notosetae and neurosetae curved, broad-bladed capillaries
Setae (posterior): Capillaries fine and straight; neuropodia with about four curved hooks, each bidentate with a minute secondary tooth above the main fang and a long tapering arista arising from the concave side below the apex
Geographical distribution: South Africa; recorded from the Cape (Mossel Bay area) and Natal; known from only two records

Species name: Cirrophorus branchiatus Ehlers, 1908
Body: Slender; about 25 mm long, ~0.4 mm wide; around 120 segments; anterior segments flattened and three to four times broader than long; posterior segments slightly broader than long with marked intersegmental constrictions
Prostomium: Bluntly conical; slightly longer than broad; eyes absent; median antenna short, stout, less than half prostomial length; peristome reduced, dorsally visible only as a narrow band, ventrally fused to prostomium
Branchiae: From setiger 5; extending over 20–25 segments; cylindro-conical lobes about two-thirds segmental breadth; last two to three pairs reduced
Notopodia: Postsetal lobes well developed anteriorly, reduced in mid-body, elongate again posteriorly
Neuropodia: Postsetal lobes inconspicuous; posterior neuropodial capillaries markedly longer than notopodial ones
Setae (anterior): Fine capillaries in both rami to about setiger 12
Setae (posterior): From setiger 13, one to two heavy notopodial spines per segment, straight and blunt with a fine curved filament arising subapically; notopodial capillaries reduced; neuropodial capillaries long; specialised hooks absent
Posterior end: Four pairs of cirriform projections, possibly representing rudimentary segmental lobes
Geographical distribution: South Africa (Agulhas Bank, Cape, Natal); also recorded from North Carolina and possibly California

Species name: Aedicira belgicae Fauvel, 1936
Body: About 20 mm long, ~1 mm broad; around 100 segments; anterior region flattened with segments about six times broader than long; posterior region rounded with segments about twice as broad as long
Prostomium: Broadly rounded anteriorly; about as broad as long; pale indistinct eyes; well-marked nuchal slits; median antenna short, stout, not reaching prostomial margin; peristome reduced, ventrally fused, not visible dorsally
Branchiae: From setiger 4; extending over 13–24 segments; stout cylindro-conical gills about two-thirds segmental width; posterior gills shorter with swollen bases and short filamentous tips
Notopodia: Anterior postsetal lobes well developed, tapered, about half length of gill; posterior postsetal lobes very slender and filamentous, length retained
Neuropodia: Without postsetal lobes distinct from general ramus
Setae: Anterior rami with numerous curved, tapered capillaries; posterior setae reduced in number; no specialised setae; notopodial capillaries very fine; neuropodial capillaries much longer, many equal to segmental breadth
Geographical distribution: Subantarctic regions; North Carolina; South Africa Tropical

Species name: Paradoneis lyra Southern, 1914
Body: Thread-like; up to 20 mm long, ~0.2 mm broad; about 100 segments; anterior segments about twice as broad as long; posterior segments about as long as broad
Prostomium: Broadly triangular; about as broad as long; eyes absent
Branchiae: From setiger 4; 8–14 pairs; digitiform; overlapping in the mid-dorsal line
Notopodia: Anterior postsetal lobe well developed, about one-quarter length of branchia; posterior postsetal lobes inconspicuous
Neuropodia: Without specialised lobes
Setae: Fine capillary setae in both rami throughout; notopodia from last branchiferous segments with one to two short forked setae, longer limb spinulose on inner margin; neuropodia without specialised setae; capillaries usually exceeding segmental width
Geographical distribution: Sweden; western Ireland; South Africa Tropical

Species name: Paradoneis lyra capensis Day, 1955
Body: Thread-like; about 10 mm long and 0.1 mm broad; approximately 80 segments; anterior segments twice as broad as long, posterior segments about as long as broad
Prostomium: Conical, longer than broad; eyes absent
Branchiae: From setiger 4; present on 10–13 segments; digitiform, each about two-thirds the segmental breadth
Notopodium: Postsetal lobe minute; not visible before setiger 8 and sometimes present only in posterior segments
Neuropodium: Without specialised lobes
Setae: Fine capillary setae present in both rami throughout; notopodia of the last few branchiferous segments and subsequent segments with two to three short forked setae, the longer limb spinulose on the inner margin; neuropodia without specialised setae, capillary setae shorter than the segmental width
Type locality: Knysna Estuary, South Africa
Distribution: South African

Species name: Prionospio krusadensis Fauvel, 1929
Body: Slender, filiform, slightly enlarged anteriorly; about 20 mm long, 0.7–0.8 mm wide; colour yellowish in alcohol
Prostomium: Long, conical; posteriorly produced as a blunt median ridge extending to setiger 2; low lateral folds present but not forming distinct wings; two clusters of 4–5 small eyes
Peristomium / Setiger 1: First setiger reduced; parapodia obsolete or poorly developed; dorsal setae present, ventral rami absent or vestigial
Branchiae: Three pairs on setigers 2–4; all pinnate; third pair often smaller than first two
Notopodia: Anterior postsetal lamellae large, oval to subtriangular; first 5–6 subequal, lamella of setiger 4 often largest; posterior lamellae progressively lower, rounded to heart-shaped, decreasing gradually but remaining conspicuous to posterior end; no dorsal membranous ridges
Neuropodia: Lamellae smaller than notopodial ones throughout; anteriorly oval, becoming rounded and very small posteriorly
Setae: Anterior notosetae and neurosetae long capillaries; From about setiger 10, one large curved golden punctate seta present in neuropodia for 3–4 segments (new character); Neuropodial hooded hooks from setigers 17–18, each with three teeth above the main fang; Notopodial hooded hooks from setigers 40–42; Inferior sabre setae absent
Genital structures: Genital pouches absent
Pygidium: With one median anal cirrus and two very small lateral cirri (new character)
Geographical distribution: Gulf of Mannar, India (Krusadai Island)

Species name: Disoma orissae Fauvel, 1932
Body: Short, anteriorly expanded; about 6 mm long, ~1 mm wide; ~25 segments; posterior end incomplete; body enlarged and flattened between setigers 4–10; discoloured in spirit
Prostomium: Elongated; anterior margin slightly notched; median region bulging; posterior crest extending to setiger 2; four minute eyes (two dorsal, two lateral); small erect tapering median tentacle; small projecting nuchal organ on each side at prostomial base
Setiger 1: Large lanceolate, subulate dorsal cirrus; ventral cirrus directed forwards; small bundle of dorsal capillary setae anterior to dorsal cirrus; fan-shaped ventral bundle of very long capillaries projecting beyond prostomium
Setiger 2: Dorsal and ventral cirri triangular, much smaller than those of setiger 1; dorsal setae absent; ventral setae in two rows: anterior row of very fine capillaries, posterior transverse row of stout short bristles with blunt curved tips (new character)
Setiger 3: Large lanceolate chopper-like dorsal cirrus with crescentic tip; triangular ventral cirrus smaller than dorsal; small ventral ligule present; dorsal capillary setae forming diverging fascicle anterior to cirrus; ventral setae including yellow acicular setae with blunt bent tips and anterior row of slender capillaries
Anterior–midbody transition: Deep triangular notch between setigers 3 and 4 on each side dividing anterior region from enlarged flattened region (new character)
Setigers 4–8(10): Dorsal and ventral cirri thick rounded lamellae; dorsal and ventral setae present; ventral setae brush-like, Aricia-type, of two kinds: stout doubly curved sickle-shaped setae with broad wing tending to split into fine spines, and capillary setae similar to dorsal ones (new character)
Midbody modifications: Dorsal setae disappearing by about setiger 11; dorsal cirri filiform from about setiger 9; ventral cirri modified from setigers 12–13
Ventral papillae: Long filiform ventral papillae appearing posterior to setiger 11; initially single, increasing posteriorly to 2–5 per segment (new character)
Posterior setae: Ventral setae of two types: stout straight bodkin-shaped setae and very slender capillaries
Geographical distribution: Off Puri, Orissa, India; depth ~4–4.5 fathoms

Species name: Ophelia anomala Day, 1961
Body: Elongate; up to 40 mm long; 26 setigers; doubtful achaetous preanal segment; constriction behind setiger 2
Branchiae: Absent throughout
Notopodia: Notosetae short; not longer than neurosetae
Neuropodia: Neurosetae similar in length to notosetae
Ventral groove: Well marked from setiger 7
Nephridiopores: From setigers 11–14
Lateral body wall: Pits absent
Dorsal structures: Crimped dorso-lateral ridges from setiger 24 to pygidium (diagnostic)
Pygidium: Two stout ventral cirri; dorsal arc of 16–18 small cirri
Geographical distribution: South Africa (Cape: False Bay);

Species name: Ophelia roscoffensis  Augener, 1910
Body: Cigar-shaped; up to 51 mm long; 32 setigers; first 8 abranchiate; next 23 branchiate; last setiger abranchiate; one doubtful achaetous preanal segment
Branchiae: Slender; from setiger 9 to setiger 31; branchial fenestrations absent
Notopodia: Notosetae long; twice length of neurosetae or more on posterior setigers
Neuropodia: Neurosetae shorter than notosetae
Nephridiopores: From setigers 12–20
Lateral body wall: Branchial fenestrations absent
Dorsal structures: Crimped dorso-lateral ridges on setigers 29–32 (diagnostic)
Pygidium: Arc of 12 small anal cirri; two stout ventral cirri
Remarks: South African material doubtful; 20–21 branchial pairs; 3–4 posterior abranchiate setigers
Geographical distribution: English Channel; doubtful record from South Africa Tropical

Species name: Ophelia capensis Kirkegaard, 1959
Body: Up to 50 mm long; 36–57 setigers; 9 (occasionally 10) anterior abranchiate setigers; 17–19 branchiferous setigers; three to four posterior abranchiate setigers; one to two achaetous preanal segments
Branchiae: Present on middle setigers; each with flattened sac-like basal projection (diagnostic)
Notopodia: Notosetae in mid-body three times as long as neurosetae
Neuropodia: Notosetae shorter than notosetae; otherwise not differentiated
Nephridiopores: On setigers 12–17
Lateral structures: Lateral swellings from setiger 26 to anus
Pygidium: Dorsal arc of 12 small papillae; two long stout ventral cirri
Geographical distribution: South Africa Tropical;

Species name: Cossura coasta Kitamori, 1960
Body: Thread-like; rounded in section; up to 15 mm long; about 107 segments; segments broader than long; intersegmental constrictions weak
Prostomium: Blunt, depressed, conical; eyes absent; appendages absent; pair of nuchal slits present
Pharynx: Eversible; lobed
Peristome: Partly fused with segment 2; apodous; achaetous
Parapodia: Parapodial lobes absent; setae arising directly from body wall
Setigers: Setiger 3 first setiger; single setal bundle; subsequent segments with two closely spaced bundles
Setae: Simple capillaries only; blades of two lengths; somewhat flattened; finely spinulose on one margin
Branchiae: Single dorsal cylindrical branchia on setiger 3; very long; about three-quarters body length
Posterior segments: Last few segments asetigerous
Pygidium: Three long filiform anal cirri; unforked in South African material
Geographical distribution: Japan; South Africa (South-west Africa, Cape, Natal)

Species name: Capitella capitata Fabricius, 1780
Body: Thread-like; 30–40 mm long; about 1.0 mm wide; dark red in life
Prostomium: Conical; pair of ventro-lateral eyes
Thorax: Segments biannulate; capillary setae in both rami from peristomial segment to setiger 6
Setiger 7: Variable; capillaries only, hooks only, or both
Sexual dimorphism: Female: Setigers 8–9 with hooks in both rami ; Male: Setigers 8–9 with enlarged dorsal genital hooks slanting inward toward genital opening; normal hooks ventrally
Abdomen: Segments smooth in section; long-shafted hooks in both rami
Hooks: Each hook with arc of three to four teeth above main fang
Geographical distribution: Arctic; North Atlantic from Greenland and Scotland to North Carolina and Senegal; Mediterranean; Black Sea; North Pacific from Bering Sea to north-west Japan; southern California; subantarctic

Species name: Notomastus fauveli Day, 1955
Body: Up to 90 mm long; about 3 mm wide; ~80 segments
Prostomium: Small; conical
Peristome: Achaetous
Thorax: First thoracic setiger with capillary setae in both notopodia and neuropodia
Abdomen – notopodia: Anterior segments with notopodia united into continuous dorsal ridge; short rows of hooks on either side of mid-dorsal line; From about 15th abdominal segment notopodia separated into well-marked papillae anterior to branching branchiae
Branchiae: Posteriorly branching; up to 20 filaments
Abdomen – neuropodia: Anterior segments with small superior branchial projection; posterior segments shorter, without projections
Setae: Hooded hooks with two transverse rows of denticles above main fang; first row with 8–10 denticles; second row with 3–4 denticles; Capillary setae with fairly narrow blades
Nephridia: Nephridial pores inconspicuous; present on first six abdominal segments
Geographical distribution: South Africa Tropical; Sri Lanka (Ceylon); India

Species name: Notomastus aberans Day, 1957
Body: About 60 mm long; ~120 segments; posterior abdominal segments often campanulate when contracted
Prostomium: Elongate conical; eyes indistinct
Peristome: Achaetous
Thorax: First thoracic setiger with notopodial capillaries only; neurosetae absent
Abdomen notopodia: Short rows of hooks on abdominal segments; minute papilla-like branchiae on outer edges, often indistinct
Branchiae: Minute papillae on outer edges of abdominal notopodia and superior edges of neuropodia
Abdomen neuropodia: Short rows of hooks; hook rows well separated ventrally
Setae: Hooded hooks with hoods twice as long as broad; at least two transverse rows of denticles above main fang; first row with 4–5 equal teeth; second row with 5–7 minute teeth
Geographical distribution: South Africa (Cape; Natal); Mozambique; Madagascar

Species name: Notomastus latericeus Sars, 1851
Body: Up to 300 mm long; >150 segments
Prostomium: Blunt; conical; biannulate; ocular specks present
Peristome: Achaetous
Thorax: Eleven thoracic setigers; early segments triannulate, later ones quinqueannulate; capillary setae in both notopodia and neuropodia from first thoracic setiger
Abdomen notopodia: Rudimentary branchiae as small swellings
Abdomen neuropodia: Long rows of hooks; rows almost meeting at mid-ventral line; superior edge with small triangular branchial projections
Branchiae: Rudimentary; represented by notopodial swellings and triangular projections on superior neuropodial edge
Lateral organs: Present between notopodia and neuropodia
Genital pores: Present in mature specimens; posterior to lateral organs; on 7–20 segments starting on second abdominal segment
Setae: Hooded hooks with short hoods less than twice as long as broad; about five denticles above main fang
Habitat: Sand; mud
Geographical distribution: Cosmopolitan; Arctic to Antarctic; intertidal to abyssal; usually below 50 m in tropical seas

Species name: Leiochrides africanus Augener, 1918
Body: About 60 mm long; ~200 segments
Prostomium: Conical; biannulate
Thorax: Not differentiated externally
Abdomen notopodia: Posterior abdominal segments with rows of notosetae broadly separated dorsally
Abdomen neuropodia: Hooks present
Branchiae: Retractile; arising between notopodia and neuropodia of posterior abdominal segments; with two to four lobes
Setae: Abdominal hooks with long hoods; two arcs of denticles above rostrum; first arc with one to two large denticles; second arc with three to four smaller denticles
Geographical distribution: Tropical western Africa from Ghana to Angola; South Africa Tropical; Natal

Species name: Mediomastus capensis Day, 1961
Body: Thread-like; about 14 mm long; ~60 segments; abdominal segments ventrally flattened and dorsally thin-walled, faecal pellets visible giving beaded appearance
Prostomium: Biannulate; conical; eyes absent
Buccal segment: Achaetous
Thorax: Segments 2–5 biannulate with capillary setae in both rami; segments 6–11 narrowed, biannulate to multiannulate, with long hooded hooks in both rami
Abdomen: First abdominal segment stouter than last thoracic; segments flattened ventrally; parapodia poorly defined
Abdomen notopodia: Short rows of hooded hooks, evenly spaced around segment
Abdomen neuropodia: Short rows of hooded hooks, evenly spaced around segment
Branchiae: Absent
Setae: Hooded hooks with two arcs of equal teeth above main fang; first arc with eight teeth; second arc with three to four teeth
Geographical distribution: South Africa (Cape, Natal); South West Africa;

Species name: Heteromastus filiformis Claparède, 1864
Body: Filiform; up to 100 mm long; ~1 mm diameter; thorax and abdomen not sharply differentiated; anterior abdominal segments long and cylindrical; posterior segments shortened, campanulate to strobiliform with projecting uncigerous lobes
Prostomium: Conical
Thorax: Biannulate; tessellated; genital pores on thoracic segments 9–12
Abdomen: Anterior segments cylindrical; middle segments shorter; posterior segments campanulate or strobiliform with short rows of hooks on projecting lobes
Branchiae: Indistinct; present as small superior projections of neuropodia from about segment 80 onwards
Setae thorax: Hooded hooks with long hoods; single arc of ~6 denticles above main fang
Setae abdomen: Hooded hooks with short hoods; 3–4 denticles above main fang
Geographical distribution: North Atlantic (Greenland to Gulf of Mexico); Mediterranean; Morocco; Persian Gulf; North Pacific (Bering Sea to Japan and southern California); South Africa (Cape, Natal); Mozambique

Species name: Dasybranchus caducus Grube, 1846
Body: Large; up to 300 mm long; ~10 mm diameter
Prostomium: Short; conical
Thorax: Segments biannulate; tessellated
Genital pores: Present in intersegmental constriction between setigers 12 and 13 in sexually mature specimens; preceding last thoracic segment
Abdomen parapodia: Low ridges bearing rows of hooks; anterior abdominal notopodial hook rows separated by narrow mid-dorsal gap
Branchiae: Retractile; arising above neuropodia from about abdominal segment 20 onwards; branching; up to 20 branches
Setae: Hooded hooks with hoods not more than twice as long as broad; three to four transverse rows of denticles above main fang; each row with ~8 equal denticles
Geographical distribution: Mediterranean; Red Sea; tropical Indian Ocean south to Madagascar; southern Africa (Natal; Mozambique)

Species name: Dasybranchus bipartitus Schmarda, 1861
Body: Large; up to 300 mm long; ~6 mm wide; >200 segments
Prostomium: Short; conical
Thorax: Segments biannulate; tessellated
Nephridia: Nephridial pores from setiger 9–10; continuing to abdominal setigers 14–15
Abdomen parapodia: Low ridges bearing rows of hooks; anterior abdominal notopodia with broad dorsal gap between right and left hook rows; anterior abdominal neuropodia with long hook rows separated by small mid-ventral gap; posterior segments with short hook rows in both rami separated by wide gaps
Branchiae: Retractile; from about abdominal segment 40 onwards; up to 13 branches per gill in large specimens
Setae: Hooded hooks with hoods three to five times as long as broad; three transverse arcs of teeth above main fang; first row with 1–4 teeth; second row with 4–8 teeth; teeth decreasing in size distally
Geographical distribution: South Africa Tropical; English Channel; probably Sweden

Species name: Scyphoproctus djiboutiensis Gravier, 1906
Body: Slender; cylindrical; 23–30 mm long; abdomen with 70+ segments
Prostomium: Bluntly conical; eyes absent
Peristome: Achaetous; following segment also achaetous
Thorax: Twelve biannulate setigers; capillary setae in both rami; neuropodial capillaries of last thoracic segment partly or completely replaced by hooks
Abdomen parapodia: No parapodial projections; no branchiae; thin-walled segments
Abdomen setal rows: Rows of hooks equal in length and evenly spaced anteriorly; notopodial rows converge dorsally posteriorly and almost fuse before anal plate
Hooks: Anterior abdominal hooks hooded and denticulate; posterior hooks enlarged, without hoods or denticles, forming stout spines; typical hook with short hood nearly as broad as long; main fang bent at right angle to shaft; crest of four rows of subequal denticles
Capillary setae: Simple; narrow-winged
Anal plate: Formed by fusion of several posterior segments with pygidium; slanting posteriorly; dorsally flattened; anus dorsal to pair of large terminal anal cirri; margin bearing 10–12 groups of spines; anterior margin with continuous palisade of ~20 fused spines; posterior groups decreasing from 4–5 spines to 1–2 near anal cirri; single row of neuropodial hooks corresponding to dorsal palisade
Geographical distribution: Tropical Indian Ocean; Gulf of Aden to Sri Lanka; Mozambique

Species name: Parheteromastus tenuis Monro, 1937
Body: Slender; up to 50 mm long; ~0.5 mm wide; about 140 segments
Prostomium: Conical; eyes absent
Peristome: Achaetous
Thorax: Slightly swollen; peristome followed by 11 setigerous segments; first four thoracic setigers with capillary setae in both notopodia and neuropodia; last seven thoracic setigers with hooded hooks in both rami
Thorax–abdomen transition: Poorly marked; distinguished mainly by hook morphology
Abdomen: Hooks present in both rami; hoods shorter than those of thoracic hooks
Parapodia: Parapodial ridges poorly developed
Branchiae: Absent
Setae: Thoracic capillaries simple; thoracic hooks with relatively long hoods; abdominal hooks with shorter hoods
Pygidium: With a single short anal cirrus
Geographical distribution: Myanmar (Burma); Mozambique

Species name: Branchiomaldane vincenti Langerhans, 1881
Body: Small; thread-like; about 10 mm long; 30–50 segments; segments biannulate
Prostomium: Ovoid-conical; two groups of ocelli; otocysts absent
Proboscis: Globular
Digestive structures: One pair of oesophageal caeca
Peristome: Achaetous; following segment also achaetous
Anterior region: 14–20 abranchiate segments; anterior annulus of each segment more prominent than posterior
Posterior region: 15–30 biannulate segments; parapodia present throughout; most segments with notopodial branchiae
Branchiae: Notopodial; three to five simple filamentous branches; arising posterior to notosetae
Notopodia: With capillary setae throughout
Neuropodia: With hooks only
Setae notosetae: Capillaries; blades flattened; tips minutely spinulose
Setae neurosetae: Hooks; three to four teeth above rostrum; hoods absent
Nephridia: Two pairs; openings on setigers 5 and 6
Reproduction: Hermaphrodite
Geographical distribution: North Atlantic from English Channel to Canary Islands; northeastern Pacific to southern California; South Africa Tropical

Species name: Arenicola loveni loveni Kinberg, 1867
Body: Very large; with long achaetous posterior region; tail region reaching up to ~800 mm
Prostomium: Trilobed; median triangular lobe broader than paired V-shaped lateral lobes
Sense organs: One pair of closed statocysts; each with single statolith
Septal pouches: Extremely large; extending to third diaphragm or beyond
Digestive structures: Oesophagus with one pair of glandular caeca
Nephridia: Five pairs; openings on segments 5–9
Circulatory system: Inner end of dorsal septal vessel shifts from subintestinal to dorsal vessel at setiger 12; preventricular dilations absent
Branchiae: Thirteen pairs; starting on setiger 7
Notopodia: With specialised notosetae
Setae notosetae: With lateral toothed crests; lamina narrow and finely spinulose
Setae neurosetae: Hooks; denticles absent or faintly indicated
Neuropodia: Ventral ridges in branchial region long; nearly meeting at mid-ventral line
Subspecies character: Nominate form lacking preventricular dilations of dorsal vessel
Habitat: Muddy sand; protected bays and estuaries; low-water neap to low-water spring
Geographical distribution: South Africa (Cape; Natal);  subspecies

Species name: Rhodine gracilior Tauber, 1879
Tube: Fragile
Body: Up to 50 mm long; ~1.0 mm wide; minimum 23 setigers; 5–10 achaetous preanal segments; colour pale with red or purple fourth setiger
Prostomium: Oval hood over mouth; smoothly arched cephalic ridge; n-shaped nuchal grooves; eyes absent
Head: About three times longer than broad; junction with setiger 1 marked only by dorsal crest
Setiger 1: About five times longer than broad
Setigers 2–5: Progressively shorter
Setigers 5–8: Subequal; about twice as long as broad
Setigers 9–10: Fused
Setigers 11–16: About three to five times longer than broad
Posterior segments: Gradually decreasing in length; achaetous preanals much broader than long
Pygidium: Short blunt cone; terminal anus; well-developed ventral valve
Collars: Smooth anterior collars on setigers 2–3; posterior collars from setiger 17 onward, including preanals
Glands: Setigers 3–4 fully glandular; setigers 5–9 anterior half glandular; posterior segments with glands restricted to area around parapodia
Notosetae: Narrow-winged capillaries; flattened sword-like setae
Neuropodia: Hooks from setiger 5 onward; arranged in paired face-to-face rows
Neuropodial hooks: Expanded head bent backward relative to shaft; cap of 15–20 denticles above rostrum; tendons rudimentary; subterminal boss present
Geographical distribution: Sweden; Nigeria; Angola; South Africa Tropical

Species name: Nicomache lumbricalis Fabricius, 1780
Body: Up to 160 mm long; cylindrical; 22–23 setigers; one very short achaetous preanal segment
Prostomium: Ill-defined; short and broad; merging into arched cephalic keel; ocelli present in juveniles
Nuchal grooves: Short; S-shaped
Pygidium: Ring and short funnel; rimmed with 15–25 equal anal cirri; anus sunken; ventral valve absent
Neuropodia anterior: First three neuropodia each with one smooth acicular spine
Neuropodia posterior: Numerous hooks; each hook with vertical series of 4–5 teeth above main fang; tendons present below
Notopodia: Winged capillary setae; fine feathered capillaries also present
Setae: Notosetae capillaries and feathered forms; neurosetae acicula anteriorly, hooks posteriorly
Geographical distribution: Arctic; North Atlantic from Greenland to English Channel; North Pacific from Bering Sea to Japan and western Canada; Bouvet Island; South Africa Tropical

Species name: Nicomache mossambica Day, 1951
Body: Up to 240 mm long; about 5 mm wide; 37 setigers; first three segments short; succeeding segments longer
Prostomium: Head bent forward; short arched cephalic keel dorsally
Nuchal grooves: Almost parallel
Pygidium: Long; cylindrical; rimmed with numerous short anal cirri; preceded by one minute achaetous preanal segment
Thorax anterior segments: First three segments ventrally glandular
Notopodia: Narrow-winged capillary setae; a few fine spinulose capillaries present
Neuropodia anterior: Setigers 1–3 with two to four straight acicular spines
Neuropodia posterior: Rows of hooks; each hook with vertical series of five teeth above main fang
Setae: Notosetae capillary and spinulose; neurosetae acicula anteriorly, hooks posteriorly
Geographical distribution: Mozambique (Delagoa Bay); single record

Species name: Maldanella fibrillata Chamberlin, 1919
Body: Up to 70 mm long; 19 setigers; three achaetous preanals; anterior segments short with glandular rims; middle segments long; posterior segments decreasing, last few sausage-shaped
Prostomium: Small; eyes absent
Cephalic plate: Oval; slanting; rim high and unnotched
Nuchal grooves: Straight; about half length of cephalic plate; anterior ends continuous with sharply bent streak curving inside rim
Pygidium: Funnel-shaped; last preanal united to pygidial funnel; about 50 subequal cirri; anus sunken; ventral valve absent
Notopodia: Narrow-winged capillary setae only; setae of two lengths
Neuropodia: Absent on setiger 1
Setae anterior: Setiger 2 with 12–20 hooks; each hook with two to three teeth above main fan
Setae posterior: Setiger 3 onward with about 30 hooks per segment; hooks with vertical series of three to four teeth above main fang
Geographical distribution: Pacific Ocean off Panama (abyssal); South Africa (Cape, abyssal)

Species name: Maldanella capensis Day, 1961
Body: Up to 45 mm long; about 2 mm wide; 19 short setigers; four very short achaetous preanals; anterior segments scarcely longer than broad; posterior segments about twice as long as broad; four preanals together shorter than last two setigers
Prostomium: Broad; anterior margin curved; numerous eye-spots present
Cephalic plate: Broadly oval; rim very low; deep lateral notches present
Nuchal grooves: Short; straight
Pygidium: Pygidial ring and funnel present; about 30 short anal cirri; anus sunken; ventral valve absent
Notopodia: Narrow-winged capillary setae and fairly broad feathered setae
Neuropodia: Absent on setiger 1
Setae anterior: Setiger 2 with two hooks; hooks with three to four teeth above main fang; setiger 3 with three to five hooks
Setae posterior: Subsequent segments with numerous hooks; hooks with acutely curved main fang surmounted by vertical series of about five teeth
Geographical distribution: South Africa (Agulhas Bank; Cape)

Species name: Axiothella quadrimaculata Augener, 1914
Body: Minute; cylindrical; about 5 mm long; 19–20 setigers; preanals absent; pygidial ring and scalloped funnel present
Prostomium: Broadly curved anteriorly; continuous posteriorly with cephalic ridge
Cephalic rim: Low; poorly defined
Nuchal grooves: Slightly curved
Pigmentation: Anterior segments barred; brown markings on head
Notopodia: Setae include hastate-bladed capillaries and a few feathered setae
Neuropodia: Hooks avicular; shaft S-shaped with a swelling
Hooks: Five teeth in a vertical series above the main fang
Pygidium: Funnel scalloped
Geographical distribution: South-west Australia; New Zealand; subantarctic islands; doubtful records from South Africa Tropical and Mozambique Island

Species name: Gravierella multiannulata Fauvel, 1919
Body: Slender; elongate; up to 80 mm long; 1–2 mm wide; about 60–70 segments; first 7 segments slightly longer than broad; segments 8–12 longer; from setiger 14 segments very short and campanulate with backwardly directed collars; achaetous preanals absent; posterior region often regenerative
Tube: Sandy; very fragile
Prostomium: Well developed; conical; with numerous ocelli
Cephalic rim: High; with lateral and posterior indentations
Nuchal grooves: Very long; parallel
Pygidium: With about 20 anal cirri; cirri increasing in length ventrally
Notopodia: Setae winged capillaries and fine feathered setae
Neuropodia: Hooks present from setigers 1–3 onward
Hooks: Setigers 1–3 with 3–5 dentate hooks; succeeding segments with more numerous hooks bearing a vertical series of 5–7 teeth above the main fang
Geographical distribution: Madagascar (Tulear); Mozambique

Species name: Johnstonia clymenoides Quatrefages, 1865
Body: Elongate; up to 200 mm long; 22 setigers; one short, poorly marked achaetous preanal
Prostomium: Broad; ocelli present
Cephalic plate: Bordered by lightly scalloped rim
Nuchal grooves: Straight; about two-thirds length of cephalic plate
Glandular structures: Glandular rings on setigers 1–7; four longitudinal glandular belts on setigers 9–15 (dorsal, ventral, and lateral)
