Posterior vascular cirri: Last 5–6 setigers with four rows of vascular cirri; usually unbranched
Pygidium: Funnel-shaped; rimmed with 20–30 anal cirri; ventral cirrus largest; ventral valve absent
Notosetae: Broadly winged capillaries; feathered capillaries
Neurosetae: Setigers 1–3 with hooks bearing one to two vestigial denticles above apex; subsequent hooks with numerous denticles in a vertical series
Geographical distribution: Atlantic from English Channel and Morocco to tropical West Africa; Mediterranean; South West Africa

Species name: Macroclymene saldanha Day, 1955
Body: About 55 mm long; ~1.3 mm wide; creamy yellow in spirit; 35–40 setigers; doubtful or absent achaetous preanal
Prostomium: Triangular; pointed; eyes absent
Cephalic plate: Rim well developed; high anteriorly; laterally and posteriorly notched
Nuchal grooves: Straight; extending over about four-fifths of cephalic plate
Segmentation: Setigers 1–3 short; setigers 4–8 longer; subsequent setigers progressively shorter; last setiger about twice as long as broad
Glandular bands: Faint on setigers 2–3; well marked on setigers 4–7; faint on setiger 8; narrow ventral glandular streak from first setiger to pygidium
Pygidium: Small; shorter than last setiger; funnel absent; sunken anus surrounded by ring of 10–20 short cirri
Notosetae: Stout broad-winged capillaries; slender spinulose capillaries; slender smooth capillaries
Neurosetae: Setigers 1–3 with straight hooks bearing three obsolescent teeth above blunt rostrum; subsequent hooks well developed with vertical series of 5–7 teeth above main fang and distinct tendons
Geographical distribution: South Africa (Cape; Langebaan Lagoon)

Species name: Euclymene oerstedi Claparède, 1863
Body: Slender; up to 100 mm long; 19 setigers; two distinct achaetous preanals followed by a circular ridge and pygidial ring with funnel
Prostomium: Small; ocelli present
Cephalic plate: Rim low; one lateral notch on each side
Nuchal grooves: About two-thirds length of cephalic plate
Segmentation: Setigers 1–7 short; remaining setigers longer; first preanal about two-thirds length of last setiger; second preanal much shorter; last preanal small and weakly marked
Glandular pattern: Broad white glandular bands on setigers 1–7 contrasting with red posterior segmental regions; broad mid-ventral glandular streak on setigers 7–14
Pygidium: Funnel present; anus sunken; small ventral valve; numerous short anal cirri with 7–10 longer alternating cirri
Notosetae: Capillary setae (not otherwise differentiated)
Neurosetae: Setigers 1–3 with one to two acicular setae bearing two to three vestigial teeth on blunt apex; subsequent segments with numerous hooks having vertical series of five teeth above main fang and well-developed tendons
Geographical distribution: North Sea; English Channel; Mediterranean; doubtful records from South Africa Tropical

Species name: Euclymene lombricoides Quatrefages, 1865
Body: Elongate; up to 150 mm long; about 9 mm broad; 19 setigers; three achaetous preanals decreasing in length; preanal region together slightly longer than last setiger
Prostomium: Broadly rounded anteriorly; ocelli indistinct
Cephalic plate: Rim posteriorly divided into about 10 lobes
Nuchal grooves: Straight; about half length of cephalic plate
Segmentation: Anterior segments slightly longer than broad; posterior segments two to four times as long as broad
Glandular pattern: Anterior glandular rings on setigers 2–8; dorsal glandular streak sometimes present on setigers 8–12
Pygidium: Ring and funnel present; funnel sunken; ventral valve absent; numerous anal cirri alternating long and short
Notosetae: Winged capillary setae; feathered capillary setae also present
Neurosetae: Setigers 1–3 with one to two smooth acicular setae; subsequent segments with numerous hooks bearing vertical series of five to six teeth above main fang and well-developed tendons
Geographical distribution: North Atlantic from Scotland and English Channel to Morocco; Mediterranean; southern Africa (South West Africa, Cape); Mozambique

Species name: Euclymene natalensis Day, 1957
Body: Elongate; up to 120 mm long; about 3.5 mm broad; 19 setigers; two achaetous preanals; first preanal almost as long as last setiger; second preanal about half its length
Prostomium: Rounded; few ocelli present
Cephalic plate: Rim high laterally; separated by a notch or step from lower posterior portion; posterior portion smooth with a median posterior notch
Nuchal grooves: Long
Segmentation: Body followed by pygidial ring and funnel
Glandular pattern: Glandular rings on setigers 2–7; median ventral glandular streak from setiger 9 onwards; dorsal glandular streak absent
Pygidium: Funnel present; about 20 subequal anal cirri plus one longer ventral cirrus; ventral valve absent
Notosetae: Numerous winged capillary setae; few fine feathered capillaries
Neurosetae: Setigers 1–3 each with a single smooth acicular spine with bent tip; subsequent segments with well-developed hooks bearing six teeth above main fang and stout tendons below
Geographical distribution: South Africa (Cape; Natal); Mozambique

Species name: Euclymene glandularis Day, 1955
Body: Brown; up to 138 mm long; about 3.5 mm broad; 19 setigers; two long achaetous preanals; first preanal twice length of second; both together about equal to length of setiger 19
Prostomium: Rounded; numerous eye-spots present
Cephalic plate: Rim posteriorly crenulated with 8–10 lobes
Nuchal grooves: Straight; about three-quarters length of cephalic plate
Segmentation: Setigers 1–7 progressively increasing in length; setiger 8 short; setiger 9 twice as long; subsequent setigers progressively shorter
Glandular pattern: Glandular rings on setigers 2–8; broad dorsal glandular streak on setigers 9–14; faint mid-ventral glandular streak from setiger 9 onwards
Pygidium: Funnel present; 25–30 subequal anal cirri; anus sunken; ventral valve absent
Notosetae: Stout winged capillaries; fine spinulose capillaries
Neurosetae: Setigers 1–3 with one to three stout smooth acicular setae with curved tips; subsequent segments with numerous hooks bearing a vertical series of 5–6 teeth above main fang and a well-marked tendon below
Geographical distribution: South Africa (Cape; Natal);

Species name: Euclymene annandalei Southern, 1921
Body: Up to 80 mm long; pale in alcohol; 21 setigers; two achaetous preanals followed by pygidial ring and funnel; anterior segments short, setigers 3–8 little longer than broad; later segments longer, decreasing in length posteriorly
Prostomium: Bluntly triangular; numerous ocelli present
Cephalic plate: Rim high anteriorly; posterior part lower and divided into about eight crenulations
Nuchal grooves: Straight; about two-thirds length of cephalic plate
Preanal segments: First preanal well developed, about two-thirds length of last setiger; second preanal much shorter and poorly developed
Glandular pattern: Faint glandular rings on setigers 1–3; broad glandular bands on setigers 4–8; mid-dorsal glandular streak from setiger 9 onwards; narrow mid-ventral glandular streak from setiger 7 to pygidium
Pygidium: Funnel present; 14 short equal anal cirri plus one longer ventral cirrus; anus sunken; ventral valve absent
Notosetae: Narrow-winged capillaries anteriorly; feathered capillaries posteriorly
Neurosetae: Setigers 1–3 with a single smooth acicular spine with bent tip; subsequent segments with numerous hooks bearing a vertical series of 5–6 teeth above the main fang and well-developed tendons below
Geographical distribution: Tropical Indian Ocean (India); not recorded from southern Africa

Species name: Praxillella praetermissa Malmgren, 1866
Body: Up to 100 mm long; 19 setigers; four long achaetous preanals; pygidial ring indistinct; short anal funnel
Prostomium: Triangular; blunt; ocelli absent
Cephalic plate: Rim low; pair of small lateral incisions; single posterior notch
Nuchal grooves: About two-thirds length of cephalic plate
Preanal segments: Four; long; achaetous
Pygidium: Short funnel with protruding anal cone; large ventral valve present; funnel encircled by 20–30 anal cirri, ventral cirrus largest
Notosetae: Not specified; typical capillaries
Neurosetae: Setigers 1–3 with two to five acicular neurosetae; rostrum blunt; three to five vestigial teeth above apex; vestigial tendon present; subsequent segments with numerous hooks bearing a vertical series of six to seven teeth above main fang and fine tendons below
Geographical distribution: Arctic; North Atlantic from Norway to Spain; Mediterranean; no confirmed southern African records

Species name: Maldane sarsi Malmgren, 1866
Body: Up to 100 mm long; enclosed in sausage-like mud tube; 19 setigers; two short indistinct achaetous preanals; pygidium present
Cephalic keel: Strongly arched and well defined in European forms; broader and less distinct in South African forms
Nuchal grooves: Short; almost straight
Cephalic rim: Low; deeply notched laterally; posterior margin smooth
Preanal segments: Two; short; indistinct; achaetous
Pygidium / anal plate: Anal plate oval; slanting; rim chitinised; laterally notched; otherwise smooth
Notosetae: Anterior segments with winged capillaries having markedly tapered blades; posterior segments with winged capillaries plus a few slender, faintly twisted spinulose forms
Neuropodial hooks: Main fang surmounted by a transverse arc of about 12 large teeth; above these a cap of numerous small denticles
Habitat: Mud; tube-dwelling
Geographical distribution: Cosmopolitan; Arctic to Antarctic; mainly deep-water records; South Africa (Cape, Natal); Mozambique

Species name: Asychis capensis Day, 1961
Body: Up to 100 mm long; enclosed in toughened mud tube; 19 setigers; one to two poorly marked achaetous preanals; pygidial plate present
Prostomium: Broadly semi-circular anteriorly; ocelli absent
Cephalic plate: Long oval; cephalic keel absent
Nuchal slits: Strongly curved
Cephalic rim: Deep; divided into three sections by deep lateral incisions; paired lateral flaps smooth; median posterior section forming deep smooth-edged pocket covering about half of cephalic plate
Head coloration: Head and cephalic plate speckled with brown when fresh
Setiger arrangement: Setigers 1–8 short; 9–13 long; 14–19 short
Glandular features: Setigers 1–5 diffusely glandular; setiger 6 with anterior glandular band; lateral glandular ridges from setiger 7 onwards
Neurosetae: Absent on setiger 1; present on subsequent setigers as a single row of hooks
Hooks: Main fang surmounted by two transverse arcs of teeth; first arc with five large teeth; second arc with about 20 fine denticles
Habitat: Mud; tube-dwelling
Geographical distribution: South Africa Tropical;

Species name: Sternaspis scutata Renier, 1807
Body: Swollen; 20–30 mm long; 20–22 segments; first seven segments forming an introvert; surface velvety due to dense fine papillae
Prostomium: Small; papillose; usually retracted into introvert
Introvert: Formed by first seven segments
Anterior spines: First three segments each with lateral rows of about 12 acicular spines
Genital structures: Pair of genital papillae on segment 7
Setae (anterior–mid body): Following eight segments with two bundles of microscopic setae embedded in body wall
Ventral shields: Posterior ventrum with striated rhomboidal shields; each shield bearing 15–17 bundles of capillary setae along outer margins
Capillary setae: Two types; fine and smooth; stouter and pilose
Branchiae: Numerous branchial filaments; often coiled into spirals
Habitat: Mud
Geographical distribution: Cosmopolitan; Arctic to Antarctic; shallow waters to very deep dredgings

Species name: Owenia fusiformis Delle Chiaje, 1844
Tube: Tough, cartilaginous; strengthened with imbricating shell fragments or sand grains
Body: Diffusely glandular; greenish-brown; up to 100 mm long; 20–30 segments
Feeding apparatus: Feeding membrane on trilobed base; membrane incised into six main divisions; terminal mouth with bilobed dorsal and ventral lips; two ocular marks at base of membrane
Thorax: Three short setigers; capillary setae present
Abdomen: First five abdominal segments much elongated; succeeding segments progressively shorter
Notopodia: Capillary setae with spinulose blades
Neuropodia: Minute hooks; long-shafted; apex with two recurved teeth
Geographical distribution: Atlantic from Greenland and Sweden to North Carolina and Gulf of Mexico; English Channel south along African coast to Angola; Mediterranean; Red Sea; Indian Ocean; northern Pacific from Bering Sea to Japan; Chile

Species name: Flabelligera affinis Sars, 1829
Body: Up to 60 mm long; ~50 segments; entirely covered by thick mucilaginous sheath supported by long pedunculate papillae
Cephalic cage: Short; formed by ~50 + 50 capillary setae of setiger 1
Prostomium: Cephalic hood triangular; median cephalic ridge on inner side with a pair of conical papillae at base; two pairs of large indistinct eyes almost fused; mouth with puckered lips
Palps: Two short, frilly palps
Branchiae: Two groups of 30+ fine branchial filaments; arising from thickened margin of cephalic hood; arranged in several irregular rows
Notopodia: From setiger 2 onward; about six annulated capillary setae per segment; supported by elongate club-shaped papillae
Neuropodia: One to two stout compound hooks per segment
Setae: Notosetae, Annulated capillaries; Neurosetae, Compound hooks with transversely striated shafts and jointed brown apices
Geographical distribution: Arctic; Atlantic from Norway and Greenland to English Channel, Canary Islands, Senegal; Falkland Islands; South Georgia; far northern Pacific from Bering Sea to north-west Japan

Species name: Pycnoderma congoense Grube, 1877
Body: About 50 mm long; ~2 mm wide; ~70 segments; not swollen anteriorly; not markedly tapered posteriorly
Integument: Surface covered with cartilaginous cuticle; long, fine, knobbed papillae scattered over body
Cephalic hood: Present; bearing numerous slender branchial filaments arranged in two groups
Palps: One pair; short; grooved
Lips: Three well developed; one dorsal; two ventro-lateral
Cephalic cage: Poorly developed; composed of notosetae and neurosetae of setiger 1 plus notosetae of setiger 2; neurosetae of setiger 2 absent; anteriorly directed setae
Notopodia: Normal body segments with slender annulated capillary setae; flagelliform tips
Neuropodia: Setae similar to notosetae but stouter
Notosetae: Slender annulated capillaries with flagelliform tips
Neurosetae: Annulated capillaries, stouter than notosetae
Geographical distribution: Tropical western Africa from Liberia to Angola

Species name: Brada villosa capensis Day, 1961
Body: Maggot-like; about 15 mm long; ~36 segments; broadly cylindrical; anterior and posterior ends truncate
Integument: Whole surface sandy, especially dorsum
Papillae: Dorsal papillae long, cylindrical; about 8× longer than broad; Parapodial papillae even longer; Ventral papillae small, cylindrical; about 3–4× longer than broad
Cephalic region / buccal apparatus; Cephalic hood poorly developed; Branchiae about 30–40 short filaments arranged in a dorsal arc, 3–4 deep; Palps one pair; short; stout; grooved; Prostomium indistinct; swollen; without eyes; Mouth ventral with two lateral lips and one ventral lip; lips not swollen
Parapodia: Setiger 1 with elongated setae but not forming a cephalic cage; ~8 notosetae and ~4 neurosetae; Later parapodia reduced and simple
Notosetae: About six long, slender capillaries per parapodium; annulated to fine tips
Neurosetae: About four to five shorter, stouter capillaries; proximal half closely annulated; distal half smooth
Nephridia: Setiger 5 with a stout nephridial papilla antero-ventral to neuropodium
Geographical distribution: South-west Africa; South Africa Tropical; subspecies probably

Species name: Pherusa monroi Day, 1957
Body: Small; seldom exceeding 20 mm long; ~60 segments; cylindrical; evenly tapering posteriorly into a distinct tail
Integument: First two segments with adherent sand grains; remainder of body naked except for papillae
Papillae: Two irregular longitudinal rows of small wart-like papillae per segment
Cephalic region / buccal apparatus: Cephalic cage well developed; formed by 33 + 33 setae of first two setigers; Cephalic hood dorsal, rolled inward on both sides; Branchiae 14–16 filaments arranged in a single continuous series on the hood; Palps one pair; stout; frilled; Lips three; short; surrounding mouth; Eyes four on cephalic ridge on inner side of hood; Dorsal entrance to introvert with a bifid process
Parapodia: Reduced; simple
Notosetae: Two to three small capillary setae per segment
Neurosetae: Segment 3 with a single long slender hook; Setiger 4 with one stout simple hook; Subsequent segments with one, occasionally two, stout simple hooks per neuropodium
Geographical distribution: Southern Arabia; South-west Africa; South Africa (Cape; Natal)

Species name: Sabellaria pectinata Fauvel, 1928
Body: Up to 8 mm long; pale in alcohol
Tube: Fragile
Operculum – paleae: Outer paleae 15–20; elongate; ~12 teeth each; teeth increasing distally from small denticles to long sharp spines; central spine not markedly longer than others; Middle paleae much smaller than outer row; asymmetrically spoon-shaped; tips produced; surface with scaly ridges forming cusps at edges except on asymmetrical overlapping flange; Inner paleae similar to middle paleae; tips longer, sharper, directed inwards; ridges forming spinules toward tip
Opercular groove: Two to three smooth spines in dorsal groove between opercular peduncles
Cirri: Median cirriform lobe present
Buccal tentacles: Very long; stiff
Geographical distribution: Tropical Indian Ocean; India (Gulf of Mannar); South Africa (Natal)

Species name: Sabellaria intoshi Fauvel, 1914
Body: Large; up to 60 mm long
Tube: Very hard; often forming gregarious masses
Operculum – paleae: Outer paleae ending in five unequal teeth; median tooth longest; usually smooth, occasionally barbed in some dorsal paleae of juveniles; Middle paleae short; broad; asymmetrically boat-shaped; laterally overlapping; Inner paleae longer and tapered; essentially similar to middle paleae
Opercular groove: Two to three smooth acicular setae present in dorsal groove between opercular peduncles
Cirri: Short median cirriform lobe ventrally between opercular lobes
Buccal region: Ridge posterior to median cirrus; one pair of slender, grooved palps anterior to mouth; Buccal cirri numerous, arranged in about 12 rows
Setae – abdomen: Abdominal uncini with two rows of seven teeth
Geographical distribution: Eastern Atlantic from the English Channel to tropical western Africa; Angola; South Africa (Natal); Mozambique

Species name: Lygdamis indicus Kinberg, 1867
Operculum: Oval; slanting
Operculum – paleae: External paleae about 25 on each side; smooth; straight; tapered to recurved tip; margins finely striate in juveniles; Inner paleae about 16 on each side; much stouter than external paleae; blunt-ended
Cirri: Median cirrus tapered
Buccal region: One pair of large, grooved palps anterior to mouth; Buccal cirri slender, arranged in about 8–10 rows on inner sides of opercular peduncles
Setae abdomen: Abdominal uncini with two rows of eight to nine teeth each
Geographical distribution: Tropical Indo–West Pacific; East Indies (Bangka Straits); South Africa (Natal)

Species name: Amphictene capensis Pallas, 1766
Body: Large; up to 90 mm long
Cephalic region / operculum: Cephalic rim with about 20 serrations; Cephalic veil medially fused to operculum but free from bases of first tentacular cirri; Two clavate papillae and one conical lobe between veil margins and base of first tentacular cirrus
Paleae: Eleven to fifteen golden paleae on each side
Tentacular cirri: Two pairs; both pairs shorter than paleae
Velum: Twenty to thirty velar cirri
Anterior segments: First three segments with notosetae only
Ventral structures: Ventrum of segment bearing second pair of tentacular cirri incised into about 12 square lappets
Branchial region: Lateral swellings dorsal to origin of second tentacular cirrus and first pair of gills
Abdomen: Thirteen abdominal segments with notosetae and uncini; followed by one achaetous prescaphal segment
Scaphe: Oval; seven to eight scaphal hooks on each side; two pairs of marginal cirri proximally and one pair distally
Anal region: Anal ligule shield-shaped; slender anal cirrus often detached
Notosetae: One row of broad, smooth-winged capillaries; one row of capillaries with basal spur and spinulose blade
Uncini: Two rows of six to eight major teeth; followed anteriorly by four crowded rows of about eight minor teeth; basal gouge large and horseshoe-shaped
Tube: Straight; composed of short lengths of sponge spicules arranged like brick rows; occasionally of small, evenly sized sand grains arranged in rows
Geographical distribution: South-west Africa; South Africa Tropical; possibly Red Sea

Species name: Melinna monoceroides Fauvel, 1936
Body: Up to 17 mm long
Prostomium: Trilobed; without eyes; without glandular ridges
Cephalic appendages: Single greatly enlarged tentacle arising from upper lip
Branchiae: Two groups of four; three branchiae united for about half their length and arranged semicircularly around the fourth; individual branchiae long; smooth; projecting well beyond prostomium
Anterior segments / setae: Segments III–V (possibly VI) with fine neuropodial acicula; Segment IV with stout notopodial hooks; Segments V and VI with fine notopodial capillaries
Dorsal structures: Segment VI with a transverse dorsal ridge forming a deep pocket with a smooth margin
Thorax: Fourteen uncigerous thoracic segments beginning at segment VII
Thoracic uncini: Single series of five to six teeth above a very small rostral point and basal prow
Abdomen: Number of abdominal segments unknown; Abdominal neuropodia without superior cirri
Geographical distribution: Morocco (Atlantic, deep water); Angola

Species name: Melinna cristata Sars, 1851
Body: Tapered; up to 50 mm long
Prostomium: With eye-spots
Buccal tentacles: Smooth; with a longitudinal groove on one side
Branchiae: Two separate groups of four; branchiae united by a web for less than half their length
Anterior segments / acicula: Segments III–VI with fine neuropodial acicula embedded in the body wall
Notopodia (anterior): Segment IV with stout notopodial hooks; Segments V and VI with notopodial capillaries
Dorsal structures: Transverse dorsal ridge on segment VI with a dentate margin
Thorax: Fourteen uncigerous thoracic segments beginning at segment VII
Thoracic uncini: Single series of three to four teeth above a small rostral point and basal prow; sometimes with an additional crest of three to five teeth
Abdomen: Thirty to fifty abdominal segments; neuropodia forming uncigerous pinnules; notopodia small and rudimentary
Anal region: Anal cirri absent
Geographical distribution: Arctic; North Atlantic (Greenland to English Channel and North Carolina); boreal North Pacific (Alaska to north-west Japan); subantarctic waters

Species name: Isolda whydahaensis Augener, 1918
Body: Small; about 5 mm long
Head: Snout-like
Prostomium: Triangular; eyes absent
Tentacles: Short; grooved; mounted on a protrusible tongue arising from roof of mouth
Cephalic / lateral structures: Pair of lateral folds embracing branchiferous region
Branchiae: Long; slender; arranged in two groups of four; basally united; inner two pairs stouter than outer two; inner pairs bearing numerous minute lamellae
Dorsal structures: Transverse dorsal ridge on segment VI; margin smooth
Anterior segments / acicula: Fine acicular neurosetae embedded in segments III–V; absent from segment VI
Notopodia (anterior): Segment IV with stout notopodial hooks; segments V and VI with notopodial capillaries
Thorax: Twelve uncigerous thoracic segments beginning at segment VII
Thoracic uncini: Single series of five to six equal teeth above a small rostral point and projecting prow
Abdomen: Numerous segments; bearing square uncigerous pinnules
Abdominal uncini: Usually with two rows of teeth
Geographical distribution: Western Africa from Morocco to Angola; not recorded from South Africa

Species name: Melinnopsides capensis Day, 1955
Body: Small; about 6 mm long; gregarious; inhabiting sandy tubes attached to corallines
Prostomium: Arched; anterior margin rounded
Eyes: Two to three pairs present
Branchiae: Three pairs; smooth; cirriform; all united basally to form a continuous row of six on segment III
Anterior segments / acicula: Fine neuropodial acicula embedded in segments III–V; absent from segment VI
Notopodia (anterior): Segments V and VI with notopodial capillaries; segment IV without notopodial hooks
Dorsal structures: No dorsal crest on segment VI
Thorax: Ten uncigerous thoracic segments beginning at segment VII
Thoracic uncini: Single vertical series of five teeth above a small rostral point and basal prow
Abdomen: About 28 segments; bearing square uncigerous pinnules
Notopodia (abdomen): Rudimentary notopodia absent
Geographical distribution: South Africa (Cape; Plettenberg Bay)

Species name: Sabellides octocirrata Sars, 1835
Body: Up to 10 mm long
Prostomium: Triangular hood over mouth; laterally pinched
Eyes: One pair
Buccal tentacles: Pennate
Branchiae: Four pairs; long; smooth; arranged obliquely on branchial ridge; minute median pair of nephridial papillae between branchial groups
Anterior segments: Segment III with four to five small notopodial capillaries; segment IV achaetous and fused to segment III; segments V–VI with notopodial capillaries
Thorax: Eleven uncigerous thoracic segments beginning at segment VII
Thoracic uncini: Single series of three to four teeth above rostral point; basal prow recurved
Abdomen: Fourteen to seventeen segments; long neuropodial cirri present above uncinigerous rows after first two segments
Abdominal uncini: Eight teeth arranged in two to three series
Pygidium: One pair of anal cirri
Geographical distribution: North Atlantic from Greenland and Sweden to Canary Islands; Mediterranean; South West Africa; South Africa Tropical; Alaska

Species name: Ampharete acutifrons Grube, 1860
Body: Up to 80 mm long
Prostomium: Triangular hood over mouth; laterally pinched
Eyes: One pair
Tentacles: Clearly pennate
Branchiae: Smooth; four in total; arranged as two anterior and two posterior on fused segments III–IV; extending well beyond prostomium
Segment III: With 10–15 large paleae; evenly tapering to fine tips
Segment IV: Without setae; notopodium achaetous or rudimentary
Segments V–VI: With small capillary setae
Thorax: Twelve uncigerous thoracic segments beginning at segment VII
Thoracic notosetae: Winged capillaries
Thoracic uncini: Two vertical series of five teeth above poorly developed rostral point and basal prow
Abdomen: Twelve segments; uncigerous pinnules bearing dorsal cirri; rudimentary notopodia absent
Pygidium: With several anal cirri, including one long pair
Geographical distribution: Arctic; North Atlantic from Greenland and Sweden to North Carolina and Morocco; Mediterranean; North Pacific from Bering Sea to north-west Japan and southern California; South Africa Tropical

Species name: Ampharete kerguelensis McIntosh, 1885
Body: Up to 18 mm long
Prostomium: Triangular hood over mouth
Eyes: One pair
Tentacles: Pennate
Branchiae: Long; smooth; extending well beyond prostomium
Segment III: With seven to eight large paleae; paleae blunt-tipped with minute filiform processes
Segment IV: With achaetous notopodium
Segments V–VI: With normal capillary setae
Thorax: Twelve uncigerous thoracic segments beginning at segment VII
Thoracic uncini: Two vertical series of six teeth above short rostral point and recurved basal prow
Abdomen: Twelve segments; no dorsal cirri on neuropodia; rudimentary notopodia absent
Pygidium: Encircled by numerous small papillae
Geographical distribution: Antarctica; South Georgia; Kerguelen; New Zealand; South-west Africa; possibly tropical western Africa

Species name: Ampharete capensis Day, 1961
Body: Tapered; up to 20 mm long
Prostomium: Pointed; arched downward over mouth
Eyes: One pair
Buccal tentacles: Beset with long papillae
Branchiae: Four pairs on branchial ridge; narrow gaps between pairs; short; not extending beyond prostomium tip
Segment III: With reduced paleae; smaller than normal capillaries of later segments
Segment IV: Achaetous; fused to segment III
Segments V–VI: Segment V with weak capillaries; segment VI with normal capillaries
Thorax: Twelve uncigerous thoracic segments beginning at segment VII
Thoracic uncini: Two vertical series of four teeth above small rostral point and recurved basal prow
Abdomen: Twelve segments; rudimentary notopodia absent
Uncigerous pinnules: Roughly triangular; minute dorsal papilla above uncini
Pygidium: With one pair of anal cirri
Geographical distribution: South Africa (Cape; Saldanha Bay); South-west Africa; endemic

Species name: Phyllocomus hiltoni Chamberlin, 1919
Body: Up to 50 mm long; dorsum speckled with brown
Prostomium: Flattened lobe over mouth; anterior margin rounded; eyes absent; glandular ridges absent
Buccal region: Numerous smooth buccal tentacles with a longitudinal groove; tentacles arising from a hood-shaped retractile membrane housed in a pocket above true mouth
Branchial region: Branchiferous ridge well developed
Branchiae: Four pairs; first (outermost) smooth; second (medial) unilamellate; third and fourth (lateral) bilamellate; first two pairs on branchial ridge; third and fourth pairs arising above segments V and VI
Segment III: Achaetous; no setae
Segments IV–VI: Notopodial capillaries present; neurosetae absent
Thorax: Twelve uncigerous thoracic segments beginning at segment VII
Notosetae: Winged capillary setae throughout thorax
Thoracic uncini: Single vertical series of five to six teeth above small rostral point; basal prow recurved
Thoracic uncigerous pinnules: With a superior papilla
Abdomen: About 50 segments; each with rudimentary notopodial lobe and uncigerous pinnule bearing a superior cirrus; anterior abdominal segments with an additional intermediate triangular projection between rudimentary notopodium and uncigerous pinnule
Pygidium: With a circular ring of short anal cirri
Geographical distribution: Southern California; India; western Indian Ocean (Natal; Mozambique)

Species name: Samythella affinis Day, 1963
Body: Up to 10 mm long
Prostomium: Flattened hood over mouth; eyes absent; glandular ridges absent
Buccal tentacles: Smooth
Branchiae: Three pairs; smooth; arranged in a continuous transverse row across segment III; no median gap; individual gills tapered and projecting far anterior to prostomium
Segment III: Paleae present but scarcely larger than normal capillaries of uncigerous segments
Segments IV–V: With small capillaries
Segment VI: With normal capillaries
Thorax: Twelve uncigerous thoracic segments beginning at segment VII
Notosetae: Winged capillary setae only; no specialised posterior notosetae
Ventral pads: Thirteen glandular ventral pads present
Thoracic uncini: Single vertical series of five teeth above rostral point; basal prow recurved
Abdomen: Eleven segments; anterior abdominal segments with small square uncigerous tori; posterior segments with longer uncigerous pinnules expanded distally
Parapodial structures: Rudimentary notopodia absent; neuropodial cirri absent
Geographical distribution: South Africa (Cape; off Port Elizabeth); single known record

Species name: Trichobranchus glacialis Malmgren, 1866
Body: Up to 40 mm long
Prostomium: With eye spots; fused to buccal segment
Tentacular lobe: Large; frilled margin overhanging mouth; numerous tentacles arising from outer surface
Buccal segment: With a pair of horizontal wing-like lateral lobes; ventral keel present
Branchiae: Six gill filaments on segments 2–4; arranged as three pairs; dorsal gap between right and left filaments decreasing posteriorly
Notosetae: Present on 15 segments starting from segment 6; capillary setae with very narrow wings and smooth tips
Neurosetae: Long-shafted on same segments as notosetae; shafts constricted below head; head bearing an arc of about 12 long denticles above the main fang
Abdominal uncini: Avicular; lateral view showing three to four denticles above main fang; face view with one to three arcs of denticles; dentition formula MF : ca 10 : 0–20
Nephridia: Present in segments 3–7
Geographical distribution: Arctic; Atlantic from North Sea to Senegal and North Carolina; Mediterranean; north-west Pacific; Magellan region; Antarctic

Species name: Terebellides stroemi Sars, 1835
Body: Up to 70 mm long; uniformly tapered
Prostomium / cephalic region: Eyes absent; tentacular lobe erect; frilled; bearing numerous short tentacles on upper surface; lower lip large; shelf-like
Branchiae: Arising from segments 2–4; forming a stout trunk bearing four lamellate lobes; lobes partially fused; outer pair larger than inner pair
Ventral features: Anterior ventral margins of segment 3 and succeeding segments prominent
Notopodia / notosetae: Notopodial capillary setae smooth-tipped; present on 18 segments; beginning on segment 3
Neuropodia / neurosetae: Neurosetae begin on setiger 6 (segment 8); first row of uncini stout; unidentate; acicular; with right-angle bend below rostrum; subsequent uncini slender with small rostrum surmounted by minute denticles
Abdominal uncini: Borne on long projecting pinnules; avicular; with one to two arcs of denticles above main fang; dentition formula MF : 0–3 : ca 10
Geographical distribution: Cosmopolitan; Arctic to subantarctic; Norway; South Africa (Cape, Natal); Madagascar

Species name: Hauchiella tribullata McIntosh, 1869
Body: Up to 46 mm long; soft; diffusely glandular; swollen; often constricted between thorax and abdomen
Prostomium / tentacular region: Tentacular lobe large; frilly; roughly trefoil-shaped; bearing numerous grooved tentacles; eyes absent
Mouth: Ventral; with two posterior lips
Thorax: Poorly defined; about 10 segments; notopodial papillae conspicuous after first three segments
Ventral surface: Mid-ventral groove present; with small rectangular ventral pads; groove and pads continued onto abdomen
Abdomen: Swollen; about 60–70 biannulate segments
Setae: Completely absent
Nephridia: Four pairs reported; opening on segments 3, 4, 5, and 7
Geographical distribution: Norway; British Isles; subantarctic; Antarctic; South Africa Tropical

Species name: Polycirrus tenuisetis Langerhans, 1880
Body: Evenly tapered; about 15 mm long
Prostomium / tentacular region: Tentacular lobe longer than broad; margin frilly; tentacles rather short
Thorax: Twelve to nineteen segments bearing notosetae; glandular swellings present on sides of nine thoracic setigers
Notopodia: Present on thoracic segments bearing notosetae
Neuropodia / uncini: Uncini commencing between setigers 7 and 10
Notosetae: With smooth wing
Uncini: With one to three large teeth above main fang followed by an arc of 10–12 slender denticles; dental formula MF: 1–3 ; 10–12
Nephridia: Three pairs of very large nephridia on setigers 1–3
Geographical distribution: Madeira Island; English Channel; South Africa Tropical

Species name: Polycirrus plumosus Wollebaek, 1912
Body: Large; up to 36 mm long; about 60 segments
Prostomium / tentacular region: Tentacular lobe large; pleated
Thorax: Seventeen segments bearing notosetae
Notopodia: Present on first 17 segments
Notosetae: Two types present; (a) capillaries with smooth, narrow wings; (b) broad “plumose” setae with blades formed by a series of transparent cones along a slender shaft
Neuropodia / uncini: Uncini commencing on setiger 18 (first abdominal segment)
Uncini: Minute; with few teeth; dental formula MF: 1 : 1–3
Ventral surface: Region behind ventral lip covered with minute glandular papillae up to setiger 15
Geographical distribution: Norway; South Africa Tropical

Species name: Lanassa capensis Day, 1955
Body: About 20 mm long; slender; pale in colour
Tentacular region: Tentacular lobe small; few tentacles present
Eyes: Few eye-spots present
Branchiae: Absent
Anterior segments: Without lateral lobes
Ventral surface: Thirteen well-marked ventral pads; followed by a glandular streak extending to setiger 20
Notopodia: Notosetae present on 27 segments starting from segment 4
Notosetae: Two forms present; long and short; each with a short winged proximal portion and a well-developed denticulate distal tip
Neuropodia / uncini: Uncini present from setiger 2 to posterior end
Uncigerous pinnules: Absent
Uncini: Avicular; short base; four to five denticles above main fang in lateral view; edge-on view with four arcs of denticles; dental formula MF: 2–3 : 4–4 : ca 6 : ca 16
Geographical distribution: South Africa Tropical; endemic

Species name: Pista unibranchia Day, 1963
Body: Small; about 10 mm long
Tentacular region: Tentacular lobe collar-shaped; eye-spots few or absent
Anterior segments: Segments 2–3 with swollen, glandular lateral lobes almost encircling anterior end; Segment 4 with small lateral lobes
Branchiae: Single median dorsal gill on segment 2; trunk naked; distal pom-pom of short filaments arranged in 6–8 whorls
Notopodia: Notosetae present on 17 segments starting from segment 4
Ventral surface: Fifteen segments with ventral pads
Neuropodia / uncini: Uncini begin on segment 5; arranged in alternating rows in posterior thorax
Abdomen: About 26 long abdominal segments with small uncigerous pinnules
Notosetae: Broad-winged capillaries; tips smooth
Uncini: Bases rounded; shafts absent even in first row; main fang stout; surmounted by four irregular arcs of closely set denticles; dental formula approximately MF: 4 : 5 : 7 : 10
Geographical distribution: South Africa, Tropical Region

Species name: Pista cristata Müller, 1776
Body: Up to 60 mm long; about 70–100 segments; 17 segments bearing notosetae
Tentacular region: Tentacular lobe short; collar-shaped; bearing many tentacles; eye-spots absent
Lips: Upper lip hood-shaped; lower lip straight, median-notched
Anterior lobes: Buccal segment with a pair of distinct rectangular lateral lobes; Segment 3 with large wing-like lateral lobes covering sides of segment 2; Segment 2 with a small but prominent pair of ventro-lateral lobes; Segment 4 with rudimentary dorso-lateral lobes
Branchiae: Two pairs; each with a long naked trunk and a shorter terminal tuft of filaments arranged in whorls
Notopodia: Seventeen segments with smooth-tipped notosetae
Ventral surface: Seventeen to twenty ventral pads
Nephridia: Nephridial papillae on segments 6 and 7
Uncini: Avicular; bases rounded; numerous denticles above main fang; dental formula MF: 5–6 : 4–5 : 12–14; Uncini of first 6–10 rows with long shafts; abdominal uncini without shafts
Abdomen: Uncini borne on well-developed uncigerous pinnules
Geographical distribution: Arctic; Atlantic from Sweden and English Channel to North Carolina, Gulf of Mexico, Senegal, Angola; Mediterranean; Magellan region; North Pacific from Japan to Bering Sea

Species name: Pista macrolobata Hessle, 1917
Body: About 25 mm long
Tentacular region: Tentacular lobe without eye-spots
Anterior lobes: Buccal segment with a pair of very large square lateral lobes extending forward as a sheath around the tentacles; Segment 2 with a small pair of ventro-lateral lobes, absent in juveniles; Segment 3 with a pair of thick lateral lobes, often reflected posteriorly; Segment 4 with rudimentary lateral lobes or none
Branchiae: Two pairs; dichotomously branched
Notopodia: Seventeen segments bearing smooth-tipped notopodial capillaries
Ventral surface: About 12 ventral pads
Nephridia: Small nephridia on segment 3; large nephridia on segments 6 and
Uncini: Avicular; denticles forming a close-set cap above main fang; dental formula MF: 4–6 : 4–9 : ~5 : ~12; uncini of first row without shafts and similar to those of subsequent segments
Abdomen: Uncini borne on square uncigerous pinnules
Geographical distribution: Western Indian Ocean (Mozambique; Madagascar); Japan; Red Sea

Species name: Pista foliigera Caullery, 1915
Body: About 50 mm long; ~120 segments
Tentacular region: Tentacular lobe with reddish-brown tentacles; numerous eye-spots present
Buccal segment: With ventro-lateral lobes; lower lip well developed
Anterior lobes: Segment 2 telescoped; with small lobes or none; Segment 3 with large wing-like lateral lobes; Segment 4 without obvious lateral lobes
Branchiae: Two pairs; dichotomously branched; terminal branches few and stout
Ventral surface: Fourteen ventral pads
Nephridia: Nephridial papillae on segments 3–8
Notopodia: Eighteen to twenty-four segments with notosetae
Notosetae: Two types; longer setae winged capillaries with smooth tips; shorter setae with finely spinulose tips, more distinct posteriorly
Uncini: First two rows large with short broad heads; fibrillar attachment lobe below main fang, disappearing in KOH; three arcs of teeth above main fang; dental formula MF: 12 : 5 : 6–8; shafts very long and broad; subsequent uncini avicular
Abdomen: Uncini borne on short ventro-lateral pinnules
Geographical distribution: South Africa (Cape; Natal); Madagascar; East Indies; tropical western Africa

Species name: Pista fasciata Grube, 1869
Body: About 58 mm long; ~131 segments
Tentacular region: Tentacles short; stout
Buccal segment: With large lateral lobes
Anterior lobes: Segment 2 with small ventro-lateral lobes or none; Segment 3 with lateral lobes about one-third size of those on buccal segment
Branchiae: Two pairs; stout; dichotomously branched; one pair often reduced or lost
Notopodia: Seventeen segments bearing notosetae
Notosetae: Winged capillaries with smooth tips
Ventral surface: Fifteen ventral pads; starting on first branchiferous segment
Uncini thorax: With slender, straight, well-marked shafts; crest with close-set cap of denticles
Uncini abdomen: Without shafts
Uncinial dentition: Approximate formula MF: 4 : 7 : ca 12
Geographical distribution: Indo-Pacific; Red Sea; Zanzibar; Bay of Bengal; Japan to Alaska and southern California; South Africa (Cape)

Species name: Loimia medusa Savigny, 1820
Body: Up to 250 mm long; ~200 segments
Tentacular lobe: Short; collar-like
Eyes: Eye-spots present
Tentacles: Long; often purple-banded
Buccal segment: With a large membranous lower lip
Anterior segments: Segments 2 and 3 fused; bearing a horizontal membranous lateral lobe and a large united ventral pad
Branchiae: Three branchiae; first often larger than the other two
Ventral surface: Well-marked ventral pads extending to setiger 15
Notopodia: Seventeen segments bearing notosetae
Notosetae: Narrow-winged capillaries with smooth tips
Uncini: Pectiniform; single vertical series of about 5–6 teeth
Uncini arrangement: Double rows back-to-back on posterior thorax; rows abruptly shortened at thorax–abdomen junction; abdominal uncini borne on square pinnules
Geographical distribution: English Channel; North Carolina (USA); West Indies; tropical Indian Ocean; Red Sea; Pacific (Japan; southern California); South Africa (Cape; Natal); Mozambique; Madagascar

Species name: Eupolymnia nebulosa Montagu, 1818
Body: Soft; skin thin; numerous white dots in life disappearing in alcohol
Tentacular lobe: With numerous ocelli
Anterior segments: Small lateral lobes on segments 2, 3 and often 4
Ventral surface: Fourteen to fifteen ventral pads extending to setiger 13; followed by a narrow glandular streak
Notopodia: Notosetae starting on segment 4; extending over 17 segments
Notosetae: Winged capillaries with smooth tips
Uncini: Present from segment 5; each with two large teeth and one to five smaller denticles above the main fang; close-set crest; formula MF: 2 : 1–5
Abdomen uncini: Borne on pinnules; pinnules abruptly shorter than thoracic ones
Nephridia: Obvious nephridial papillae on segments 3, 4 and 5; posterior and dorsal to notopodia
Geographical distribution: Atlantic from Scotland and the English Channel to tropical western Africa and Falkland Islands; Mediterranean; Red Sea; Persian Gulf; tropical Indian Ocean; Pacific (Japan); South Africa (Cape; Natal); South-west Africa; Mozambique; Madagascar

Species name: Amphitrite pauciseta Day, 1963
Body: Up to 20 mm long; ~70 segments; abdomen smoothly tapered with 40+ segments
Tube: Fragile
Tentacular lobe: With long tentacles
Eyes: Eye-spots minute or absent
Anterior segments: Obscure lateral lobes on segments 2, 3 and 4
Branchiae: Two pairs on segments 2 and 3; each gill a tuft of digitiform filaments arising from a basal stump; subdermal reddish spots at base of each gill in fresh specimens
Notopodia: Thirteen segments with notosetae starting on segment 4
Notosetae: Narrow-bladed capillaries with minutely denticulated tips
Uncini: From segment 5; arranged in double rows on posterior thorax; short bases; crest appearing as five teeth in profile but edge view showing multiple irregular arcs; approximate formula MF: ca 5 : ca 7 : ca 9 : ca 12
Ventral surface: Ten glandular ventral pads
Nephridia: Large nephridial papilla on segment 3 lateral to gill base
Abdomen uncini: Anterior segments with uncigerous tori; posterior segments with small uncigerous pinnules
Geographical distribution: South Africa (Cape); endemic

Species name: Amphitrite cirrata Müller, 1771
Body: Up to 100 mm long; ~85 segments
Tentacular lobe: Without eye-spots
Mouth: Lower lip prominent; shelf-like
Anterior segments: Small lateral lobes on segments 2–4
Branchiae: Three pairs; each gill composed of numerous simple filaments arising from a basal stump
Ventral surface: Ten to twelve ventral pads
Nephridia: Seven pairs of nephridial papillae on segments 3 and 6–11
Notopodia: Notopodial capillaries on 17 segments starting from segment 4
Notosetae: Winged capillaries with minutely denticulate tips
Uncini thorax: From segment 5; arranged in two rows from setiger 7 to 16; avicular; cap of irregularly arranged denticles above main fang; approximate formula MF: 4–5 : 5–6 : 8–10 : 10–15
Uncini abdomen: Borne on projecting pinnules
Geographical distribution: Arctic; North Atlantic from Greenland and Sweden to Azores and Senegal; Mediterranean; North Pacific from Behring Sea to Japan; western Canada to central California

Species name: Terebella pterochaeta Schmarda, 1861
Body: Slender; evenly tapered; up to 100 mm long
Head / lips: Upper and lower lips well marked
Branchiae: Two pairs; each with short, close-set branches
Notopodia: Notosetae on 28–33 segments
Ventral surface: About 16 ventral pads followed by a narrow glandular streak in a ventral groove along the abdomen
Notosetae: Two lengths; anterior notosetae with winged shafts and denticulate tips; denticulate portion increases posteriorly to form most of the blade; spur at base of denticulate blade absent
Uncini: On low tori; size decreases evenly after first three; originate from ventral ridges on abdomen; in profile with three to four teeth above main fang; in face view with three to four irregular arcs of teeth; dental formula MF: 2–4 : 5–7 : 8–10; attachment button well developed
Geographical distribution: South-west Africa; South Africa (Cape; Natal); Senegal (?); tropical Indo–west Pacific from Red Sea to Indo-China and New Caledonia

Species name: Terebella ehrenbergi Grube, 1870
Body: Elongate; notosetae extending from segment 4 to within 20–40 segments of pygidium
Branchiae: Three pairs; branched
Nephridia: One large nephridial papilla on segment 3 between bases of first and second branchiae; small nephridiopores on segments 6–12
Ventral surface: Thirteen ventral pads followed by a narrow mid-ventral glandular streak
Notosetae: Anterior notosetae with long, uniformly narrow wings and denticulate tips; posterior notosetae without wings but with enlarged denticulate tip forming a spiral blade; basal spur absent; shorter notosetae present with coarse teeth at base of blade
Uncini: With two to three arcs of denticles above main fang; dental formula MF: 2–3 : 5–7; attachment button obscure
Geographical distribution: Tropical Indo–west Pacific; Red Sea; Mozambique; Burma; Japan; New Caledonia

Species name: Terebella schmardai Day, 1934
Body: Up to 50 mm long; elongate; notosetae extending from segment 4 almost to the pygidium
Tentacular lobe: Well developed; with distinct upper and lower lips; eye-spots present
Branchiae: Three pairs; short; branched
Nephridia: Inconspicuous nephridial papillae on segments 3, 6, 7, 8, and 9
Ventral surface: Ten distinct ventral pads followed posteriorly by a narrow mid-ventral glandular streak
Notosetae: With well-marked wings and serrated blades; blades become fairly broad and strongly spiral posteriorly; basal spur absent throughout
Uncini: With approximately 12 denticles above the main fang arranged in arcs; dental formula MF: 2–3 : 8–10; attachment button poorly developed
Geographical distribution: South-west Africa; South Africa (Cape); endemic

Species name: Terebellobranchia natalensis Day, 1951
Body: Small species; less than 20 mm long
Cephalic region: Eye-spots absent; anterior segments without lateral lobes
Branchiae: Three pairs; branched; arising on segments 3, 7, and 13
Ventral surface: Thirteen ventral pads on segments 2–15; followed posteriorly by a glandular mid-ventral streak
Notosetae: Present from segment 4; total 19 or more segments bearing notosetae; each seta with a denticulate tip; in posterior segments the denticulate portion elongate and spirally twisted
Uncini: Commence on segment 5; initially in a single row, later arranged in two rows; each uncinus with three denticles above the main fang in profile view, but three to four arcs of denticles in edge-on view; attachment button absent
Geographical distribution: South Africa (Natal, Durban); endemic

Species name: Amphiglena mediterranea Leydig, 1851
Body: 6–15 mm long; slender; 35–40 segments
Branchial region: Branchial lobes each bearing seven radioles; radioles not united by a web; distal pinnules short, followed by a long naked terminal tip
Cephalic / peristomial region: Collar absent; peristomial segment forming a triangular ventral lobe fused to the base of the branchial lobes
Segmentation: Eight thoracic segments; 24–30 abdominal segments
Setiger 1: Notosetae only; winged capillaries
Notosetae (thorax): Setigers 2–8 with winged capillaries and paleae with long tips
Neurosetae (thorax): Pick-axe–shaped setae with heart-shaped blades ending in long tips; avicular uncini with striated crests
Abdominal setae: Notosetae are avicular uncini similar to those of the thorax; neurosetae are broad-bladed capillaries
Reproduction: Hermaphrodite
Geographical distribution: Mediterranean Sea; North Atlantic from the English Channel to Madeira and Morocco; Persian Gulf; recorded from South Africa (Cape); doubtful Antarctic record

Species name: Megalomma quadrioculatum Willey, 1905
Body: Slightly tapered; up to 50 mm long
Branchial crown: Each branchial lobe with multiple radioles; two or more radioles per lobe bearing large subterminal eyes
Collar: Present; dorsally notched to form two small dorsal lobes and two large lateral lobes
Palps: Short
Thoracic segments: Setigers 2–8 with notosetae; thoracic neurosetae well developed
Notosetae (thorax): Two types present on setigers 2–8; long, slender winged capillaries; paleae with short tips
Neurosetae (thorax): A row of pick-axe setae with symmetrical blades; a row of avicular uncini with fairly long shafts
Geographical distribution: Red Sea; southern Arabia; Madagascar; Sri Lanka (Ceylon); South West Africa; South Africa (Cape and Natal); Mozambique

Species name: Hypsicomus capensis Day, 1961
Body: Long, slender worm; lives in a tough, brown, translucent tube
Branchial crown: Branchial lobes borne on a long stalk; each lobe with 12 radioles united by a web for about one quarter of their length; each radiole with ~10 pairs of eye-spots located midway along; tips blunt
Collar: Divided dorsally and split ventrally; each half notched dorsally to form a small rounded dorsal lobe and a large lateral lobe slanting forward ventrally into a triangular lappet
Collar setae: Stout, smooth-winged capillaries arranged in a line
Thoracic segments: Setigers 2–8 with both noto- and neurosetae
Notosetae (thorax): Two to three smooth-winged capillaries per fascicle; numerous paleae with rounded blades ending in pointed tips
Neurosetae (thorax): A row of pick-axe setae with transparent, tapered blades; a row of avicular uncini with fairly broad tails and striated crests
Abdominal setae: Notosetae avicular uncini similar to thoracic ones; neurosetae slender-winged capillaries and paleae with blades much longer than those of the thorax
Geographical distribution: South Africa (Agulhas Bank, Cape); endemic, known only from the type locality

Species name: Hypsicomus phaeotaenia Schmarda, 1861
Body: Slender; up to 50 mm long; commonly boring in old coral
Branchial crown: Branchial lobes borne on a common stalk; each lobe with about 15–20 radioles united for roughly one third of their length; free distal portions with small, irregularly arranged lateral eye-spots and fairly long naked tips
Palps: One pair; tapering
Collar: Very low; margin smooth and straight; collar continuous with only a shallow dorsal depression and a ventral prominence
Collar setae: Very short and stout; arranged in a slanting double row; rows closely packed and difficult to distinguish; blades slightly different between rows, one with blades about twice as long as broad
Thoracic segments: Setigers 2–8 with both noto- and neurosetae
Notosetae (thorax): Two types present on setigers 2–8; winged capillaries with normal tapered blades; paleae with rounded blades lacking a distal spine
Neurosetae (thorax): A row of pick-axe setae with smooth, symmetrical blades; a row of avicular uncini with finely striated crests and very broad tails
Abdominal setae: Notosetae avicular uncini similar to those of the thorax; neurosetae of two types—very slender winged capillaries with long narrow blades, and stout paleae with oval blades bearing an abruptly arising slender tip
Geographical distribution: Western Africa (Senegal, São Tomé); Mediterranean Sea; Red Sea; tropical Indo–west Pacific from the Persian Gulf and Madagascar to western Australia, New Caledonia, and Japan

Species name: Sabella penicillus Linnaeus, 1767
Body: Up to 250 mm long; pale in colour; enclosed in a slender mud tube
Branchial crown: Branchial lobes each with about 10–40 radioles; radioles long and slender with short distal tips; gills conspicuously banded with purple
Branchial base: Without glandular cushions; annular rings present when contracted
Collar: Widely separated dorsally; reflected back dorso-laterally to form four lobes; larger lateral pair ending ventrally in thickened lappets
Thoracic segments: Thorax bearing well-developed noto- and neurosetae
Notosetae (thorax): Winged capillaries of two lengths; longer and narrower forms and shorter, broader forms present
Neurosetae (thorax): A row of pick-axe setae with broad, symmetrical blades tapering to pointed tips; a row of avicular uncini, each with a cap of 30 or more minutely denticulate ridges above the rostrum and a short tail
Tube: Slender; composed of mud
Geographical distribution: North Atlantic from Scotland to Morocco and Senegal; Mediterranean Sea; South Africa (Cape)

Species name: Sabella fusca Grube, 1870
Body: Large, stout species; overall size large; gills often distinctly banded in yellow and brown
Branchial crown: Radioles united by a web for about one-quarter of their length
Collar: Low; widely separated dorsally; attached posteriorly to setiger 2; laterally notched; ventrally produced into a pair of stout lappets
Glandular areas: A dorsal glandular area extending from the base of the branchial crown to setiger 3 or 4; often divided medially or transversely; continuous with glandular bands on the inner surface of the collar, which curve onto the ventral surface; ventral glandular area sometimes reported as separate
Thoracic segments: Thorax bearing typical noto- and neurosetae
Notosetae (thorax): Winged capillaries of the usual sabellid type
Neurosetae (thorax): A row of pick-axe setae with long, symmetrical blades; a row of avicular uncini with long, broad shafts and a crest bearing about 20 oblique rows of striations
Geographical distribution: Red Sea; Zanzibar; Andaman Islands; Sri Lanka (Ceylon); northern Australia; Mozambique

Species name: Potamilla linguicollaris Day, 1961
Body: Slender; up to 15 mm long; body with up to 12 thoracic segments and numerous abdominal segments; tube fragile
Branchial crown: Branchial lobes each with six radioles; radioles without eye-spots; tips fairly long
Palps: Slender
Collar: Widely gaping dorsally; each half notched posteriorly to form a small rounded dorso-lateral lobe and a large lateral lobe; lateral lobes slant forward beneath the gills and meet medially, giving the collar a long scoop-like appearance supporting the bases of the gills
Pygidium: With a pair of small oval lobes; no eye-spots
Collar setae: Small winged capillaries
Thoracic segments: Setigers 2–8 bearing noto- and neurosetae
Notosetae (thorax): Six winged capillaries and six spear-shaped paleae per parapodium
Neurosetae (thorax): A row of pick-axe setae with plain, symmetrical, pear-shaped blades ending in fine tips; a row of long-shafted avicular uncini with coarsely serrated crests
Abdominal setae: Abdominal uncini similar to thoracic uncini; neurosetae consist of three broad-bladed paleae; all setae symmetrical
Geographical distribution: South Africa (Cape region); endemic

Species name: Branchiomma natalensis Kinberg, 1867
Body: Stout; brownish in colour, shading to purple anteriorly
Branchial crown: Branchial lobes spiral, forming four to six whorls of radioles; radioles decrease in length distally; radiolar eye-spots present
Stylodes: Broad; extending backward as flanges along the sides of the radioles; increasing in size distally
Collar: Widely separated dorsally; notched laterally; ending ventrally in rounded lappets
Thoracic uncini: With straight tails; crest above rostrum bearing 20 or more minute denticular ridges
Type locality: Cape of Good Hope, South Africa
Geographical distribution: South West Africa; South Africa (Cape region); endemic

Species name: Branchiomma capensis McIntosh, 1885
Body: Slender; up to 50 mm long; uniformly pale except for interramal eye-spots
Branchial crown: Branchial lobes semicircular, not spiral; bearing no more than one flattened whorl of radioles
Radioles: Without marginal flanges
Stylodes: Small; strap-like; one to two times as long as the width of the radiole
Collar: Widely separated dorsally; low; without lateral notches; divided dorsally and reflected back dorso-laterally; forming small ventral lappets
Thoracic uncini: With six to eight rows of denticles above the rostrum
Geographical distribution: South Africa (Cape region); endemic

Species name: Sabellastarte longa Kinberg, 1867
Body: Large and robust; up to 150 mm long and about 15 mm wide; body shading from brown to purplish anteriorly
Branchial crown: Branchial lobes each with a central axis bearing four to six whorls of radioles; gills uniformly orange-brown or distinctly barred
Radioles: Outer whorl with double rows of eye-spots; lateral flanges present, formed by continuation of the basal web
Stylodes: Absent
Collar: Widely separated dorsally; not notched laterally; forming a pair of stout triangular ventral lappets
Thoracic notosetae: Capillaries of two lengths; shorter capillaries with broader wings than the longer ones
Thoracic uncini: With finely denticulate crests; necks relatively narrow; tails fairly long
Geographical distribution: South Africa (Cape and Natal); Mozambique; Madagascar

Species name: Euchone rosea Langerhans, 1884
Body: Up to 12 mm long; slightly tapered; 20–26 segments
Branchial crown: Branchial lobes each with five radioles; radioles united by a web for more than half their length; distal portions ending in long naked tips
Ventral filaments: About two pairs; small; rolled inwards; without pinnules
Palps: Two; long
Collar: Widely divided dorsally; well developed laterally; shallowly notched ventrally where attached to the lips
Sensory organs: One pair of otocysts and one pair of internal eyes in the collar segment
Thoracic notosetae: Winged capillaries; spear-shaped paleae
Thoracic neurosetae: Long-shafted hooks with numerous denticles above the main fang
Abdomen: 12–18 segments; posterior end with a ventral concavity and lateral flanges extending over about five to six setigers
Abdominal notosetae: Quadrangular uncini with several rows of denticles above the main fang
Abdominal neurosetae: Narrow-winged capillaries
Pygidium: With two eyes; without posterior prolongation
Geographical distribution: South-west Ireland; Madeira; Ivory Coast; South Africa (Cape)

Species name: Euchone capensis Day, 1961
Body: Up to 20 mm long; about 40 segments
Branchial crown: Branchial lobes each with nine radioles; radioles bearing pinnules with two to three elongated pinnules ventrally; all radioles united by a web for about two-thirds of their length
Collar: Divided dorsally and notched to form a pair of small dorsal lobes and a pair of large lateral lobes; lateral lobes slit ventrally and fused to the ventral lips
Sensory organs: One pair of eyes and one pair of otocysts located within the collar segment
Thorax: Eight setigers
Thoracic notosetae: Three types present on setigers 2–8; Four winged capillaries; Five paleae with broad blades and long tips; Three minute-bladed setae barely projecting from the body surface
Thoracic neurosetae: Long-shafted hooks with arcs of numerous small denticles above the main fang
Abdomen: About 32 setigers; posterior eight segments short and flanged to form a spoon-shaped concavity
Abdominal notosetae: Quadrangular uncini with five to six close-set rows of teeth above the main fang
Abdominal neurosetae: Slender capillaries
Pygidium: Conical; without eyes
Geographical distribution: South Africa (Cape); known from only two records

Species name: Chone filicaudata Southern, 1914
Body: Short and rather stout; 5–11 mm long; about 26–30 segments
Branchial crown: Each branchial lobe with 6–10 radioles plus two elongated ventral filaments; radioles united for about half their length and distally flanged
Palps and lips: Two short palps; ventral lip bifid
Collar: Well developed; small apposed dorsal lobes; lateral lobes smooth and not notched ventrally
Sensory organs: Eyes and otocysts doubtful or indistinct
Thoracic notosetae: Three types present; Winged capillaries; Paleae with tapered blades; Short, fine setae with tapered tips and no blades
Thoracic neurosetae: Long-shafted hooks; main fang surmounted by two teeth and numerous denticles; with a narrow limb (limbe étroite)
Abdominal notosetae: Quadrangular uncini with six close-set rows, each row bearing five to six teeth above the main fang and basal prow
Abdominal neurosetae: Fine-bladed capillaries
Pygidium: With a tapered terminal appendage (filiform tail)
Geographical distribution: Ireland; North Carolina (USA); South Africa (Cape and Natal)

Species name: Chone collaris Langerhans, 1880
Body: Small; about 30–40 segments
Branchial crown: Each branchial lobe with 4–8 radioles; radioles united by a web for about two-thirds of their length and distally flanged; a pair of small ventral radioles without pinnules
Palps: One pair; long and slender
Collar: Narrowly divided dorsally; straight laterally; united ventrally; margin scalloped
Sensory organs: Eyes and otocysts present inside the collar segment
Thoracic segments and setae; Setiger 1 with winged capillaries only; Setigers 2–8 with notopodial winged capillaries and paleae; neuropodia with long-shafted hooks
Thoracic neurosetae: Hooks with numerous small teeth above the main fang when viewed laterally
Abdomen: Abdominal segments numerous
Abdominal notosetae: Square uncini with three to four arcs, each arc bearing about six teeth above the large main fang
Abdominal neurosetae: Winged capillaries
Pygidium: May bear eye-spots
Geographical distribution: Madeira; Mediterranean Sea; Mozambique; possibly the Persian Gulf

Species name: Jasmineira caudata Langerhans, 1880
Body: About 5–7 mm long; slender; 25–28 segments
Branchial crown: Each branchial lobe with about 7–8 radioles; radioles free and without lateral flanges; pinnules long; a breaking plane present near the base of each radiole
Palps: One pair; long; slender
Collar: Well developed; two halves overlapping dorsally and united ventrally to the lips; margin straight and not oblique
Sensory organs: Two elongate red eyes visible in fresh specimens through the collar base; two otoliths present
Thorax: Eight setigers, Setiger 1 with winged capillaries only; Setigers 2–8 with notopodial winged capillaries and spathulate setae; neuropodia with four to five long-shafted hooks
Notosetae (thorax): Winged capillaries with blades of normal width; Spathulate setae with blades widening distally and then abruptly tapering to slender tips (palea-like)
Neurosetae (thorax): Long-shafted hooks with a prominent rostrum surmounted by about four arcs of long denticles
Abdomen: About 20 setigers; body tapered posteriorly
Abdominal setae: Capillaries with long, slender blades; Hooks Z-shaped or avicular; each with a long rostrum surmounted by closely set arcs of denticles (about 15 in total) and a long manubrium bending back abruptly to form a lightly chitinised base
Pygidium: With a long, slender caudal appendage
Geographical distribution: Warm North Atlantic from Madeira to Ireland; Mozambique

species_name: Neodexiospira foraminosa Bush in Moore & Bush, 1904
text:
Species name: Neodexiospira foraminosa Bush in Moore & Bush, 1904
Body: Very small; about 3–4 mm long
Tube: Calcareous; coiled anticlockwise when viewed from above (dextral); with five longitudinal ridges; grooves between ridges bearing transverse slits; typically attached to fronds of algae
Thorax: Three thoracic setigers; two rows of uncini on each side
Operculum: Incubatory; cylindrical with perforated calcareous walls; opercular lid with a marked rim; basal plate subcircular
Collar setae: Present; blades pilose; without basal lobes
Special setae: Setae of Apomatus absent on setiger 3
Uncini: With four to five rows of teeth; each row bearing about 20–25 teeth; basal gouge with three to five divergent prongs
Type locality: Japan
Geographical distribution: Japan; West Indies; Indian Ocean; South Africa (Cape); Mozambique

Species name: Spirobranchus giganteus Pallas, 1766
Body: Large species; up to about 120 mm long; abdomen two to three times longer than thorax; abdomen with approximately 200–300 segments
Tube: Stout; cylindrical; strongly ridged; calcareous
Branchial crown: Four to six whorls of branchial radioles; radioles usually red
Opercular stalk: With small, blunt lateral wings
Operculum: Oval; bearing two or four short, branching, antler-like processes
Collar: Usually blue; divided laterally with a fillet present at each incision
Collar setae: With a hispid boss at the base of the blade; spinulation increasing distally
Thoracic uncini: Single row of 15–18 teeth above the main fang
Type locality: West Indies
Geographical distribution: West Indies; Suez; tropical Indian Ocean; Japan; New Caledonia; Mozambique; South Africa (Natal)

Species name: Bathyvermilia challengeri Zibrowius, 1973
Body: Deep-sea serpulid; body details largely concealed within tube
Tube: Very distinctive; strongly sculptured with numerous closely spaced transverse ridges; tube robust and highly recognisable
Thoracic membranes: Rounded; extending posteriorly to the 3rd thoracic segment
Operculum: Conical; covered by a simple, slightly raised chitinous endplate; endplate with distinct rims
Opercular peduncle: Smooth; cylindrical; with a clearly visible constriction
Collar chaetae: Simple; limbate
Apomatus chaetae: Present in the thorax
Thoracic uncini: Saw-to-rasp shaped; about 12 teeth visible in lateral view; anterior fang simple and pointed
Type material examined: Christmas Island, SE Indian Ocean; depth 1225–1626 m
Geographical distribution: Mid-Pacific Ocean (Johnston Atoll); South Pacific off New South Wales, Australia; South Indian Ocean off Christmas Island; depth range approximately 380–5719 m

Species name: Filogranula stellata Southward, 1963
Body: Small deep-sea serpulid; body largely concealed within tube; seven thoracic chaetigerous segments
Tube: White; opaque; with elaborate star-like peristomes; denticulate keel present; tube surface distinctive and sculptured
Operculum: Present; with a chitinous, concave endplate
Opercular peduncle: Smooth; cylindrical; without wings; no constriction between peduncle and operculum; inserted as the second dorsal radiole on one side
Collar: Non-lobed; edge entire; collar continuous with short thoracic membranes; thoracic membranes ending at the 2nd thoracic chaetiger
Collar chaetae: Two types present; fin-and-blade chaetae and limbate chaetae
Apomatus chaetae: Present in thorax
Thoracic segments: Seven chaetigerous segments
Uncini and abdominal chaetae: Typical of genus Filogranula; detailed morphology illustrated by ten Hove & Kupriyanova (2009)
Geographical distribution: North Atlantic Ocean (320–1775 m); Mediterranean Sea (700–2485 m); Pacific Ocean (1600–1900 m); Indian Ocean including Christmas Island and Cocos (Keeling) Islands (1113–3345 m)

Species name: Polyophthalmus zhadanae Parapar et al., 2021
Body: Elongate; with 62–64 chaetigers bearing biramous parapodia; deep ventral longitudinal groove extending along entire body length, flanked by paired ventro-lateral ridges
Prostomium: Triangular; tapering anteriorly; ending in a clavate tip; prostomial eyes absent; lateral eyes absent
Nuchal organs: Large; present as conspicuous lateral depressions
Proboscis: Not protruded
Parapodia: Biramous; each with a short triangular prechaetal lobe and a small digitiform ventral cirrus
Chaetae: Simple capillary chaetae only; notochaetae generally longer than neurochaetae; chaetae of chaetigers 1–2 long, straight, directed anteriorly but not strongly curved
Branchiae: Long; cirriform; present from chaetiger 2 to the last chaetiger at the base of the anal funnel
Anal region: Anal funnel well developed; spoon-shaped; annulated; laterally slightly compressed; about twice as long as wide at base; ventral slit present, originating in the posterior third of the body; rim of anal funnel bearing slender papillae of variable length, posterior papillae shorter than anterior ones
Caudal appendages: One pair of short, slender ventral cirri at the posterior end of the ventro-lateral ridges; anal cirrus absent
Geographical distribution: Indian Ocean and western Pacific — India; Sri Lanka; Kuwait; Thailand; Vietnam; Australia
Bathymetric range: Intertidal to 79 m
