Antenna: Basal article large, flagellum short, Proepistome reduced
Chelipeds:  subequal (1.8 times CL), subcylindrical, whitish, with conical granules
Merus: elongated
Carpus: short
Propodus: elongated, dorsal and ventral margins of palm with sharp crest
Fingers: gently curved, compressed laterally, 1.1 times palm length
Telson: bluntly triangular, length 0.8 times width

Species name: Crocydocinus saravananei Padate, Lee & Cubelio, 2020
Carapace: pyriform (CW/PCL = 0.9)
Dorsal surface: pinkish covered with thick brown tomentum
Ocular peduncle: short, cornea terminal, darkly pigmented.
Antennules: folded longitudinally, basal article slender
Antenna: Basal article moderately broad, anterolateral angle rounded, large granule located at base of article, flagellum well-developed
Buccal cavern: subquadrate
Chelipeds: pinkish, subequal, 1.8 1.9 times PCL
Ischium: margins carinate
Merus: triangular in cross-section, carinate anterior margin
Dactylus: gently curved, 0.6 0.7 times propodal lengths
Fingers: palm inflated fingers slightly curved, distal tips acuminate
Telson: triangular with round distal margin, length 0.8 times width

Species name: Samadinia riversandersoni Alcock, 1895
Carapace: pyriform (CW/PCL = 0.8 0.9), convex
Dorsal surface: reddish covered with brown setae, regions well-defined by convexities, gastric region with 1 pair of short spines in transverse row, cardiac spine in the middle of hexagon formed by 1 gastric, 4 branchial and 1 intestinal spine
Orbits: incomplete, supra orbital eave not well-developed
Margin: Anterolateral margins with 1 hepatic, 1 long lateral branchial spine
Ocular peduncle: short, cornea terminal, darkly pigmented
Antennules: folded longitudinally, basal article slender
Antenna: Basal article moderately broad, anterolateral angle with short spine, flagellum well-developed
Chelipeds: subequal, reddish, smooth, covered with short tomentum, massive in males (2.1 times PCL), slender in female (1.2 times PCL)
Merus: long, triangular in cross-section, margins carinate, distal margin with 1 spine
Carpus: outer surface with 1 sharp carina
Propodus: carinate on margins; fingers (Fig. 146B) in male 0.7 times palm length, almost straight, in female subequal to palm length, curved, occlusal margins dentate
Fingers: distal tips corneous
Telson: bluntly triangular, length subequal to width

Species name: Tunepugettia corbariae Leeet al., 2019
Carapace: pyriform (CW/PCL = 0.8)
Dorsal surface: bear thick-mentum, setal tufts on lateral edges of gastric and branchial regions, smooth when denuded; regions well-defined
hepatic region: laterally directed compressed protuberance present
gastric region: with 1 median conical metagastric granule, 1 pair of depressed lateral proto gastric granules, posterior portion flanked by 3 pairs of lateral pits; cardiac region projecting posterodorsally intestinal region: depressed
Pseudorostral spines: straight, slightly dorsoventrally flattened
Ocular peduncle: short, cornea terminal, darkly pigmented
Antennules: folded longitudinally, basal article slender
Antenna: basal article moderately broad, anterolateral angle rounded, flagellum well-developed
Chelipeds: subequal (1.0 1.1 t imes PCL), thickly tomentose, smooth when denuded
Merus: triangular cross-section, all margins carinate
Carpus: inner margin carinate
Propodus: slightly inflated, margins carinate
Dactylus: dactyli curved, 0.5 0.6 times propodal lengths
Fingers: slender, gently curved, 0.8 times upper palm length, oc clusal margins with short
Telson: bluntly triangular, length 0.5 times width

Species name: Chorinachus dolichorhynchus Alcock & Anderson, 1894
Carapace: pyriform (CW/PCL = 1.0), much wider posteriorly
Dorsal surface: irregular, bearing regularly placed sharp tubercles, regions well-defined by convexities
gastric region: inflated, bear2 median spines, branchials bear 4 spines, mesial spine largest
cardiac region: distinct, 1 median spine
intestinal region: depressed bearing 1 median spine; sub-hepatic region not inflated
Pseudorostrum: long (0.5 times PCL), slender, bear serrated ridge dorsally
Orbits: absent; supraorbital eave weakly expanded
spines: supraorbital and post-ocular spines distinct
Lateral margins: spinose
Ocular peduncle: short, exposed, cornea terminal, dark pigmented
Antennules: folded longitudinally, basal article slender
Antenna: basal article long, slender, fused distally; anterolateral angle produced into spine, flagellum well-developed
Buccal cavern: subquadrate
Chelipeds: unequal slender, cylindrical,
Merus: bear row of spinules dorsally and ventrally
Carpus: spinulose dorsally
Propodus: spinulose dorsally
Fingers: short (0.5 0.6 times palm lengths), gently curved
Telson: semi-circular, length 0.4 times width.

Species name: Encephaloides armstrongi Wood-Mason & Alcock, 1891
Carapace: brownish-yellow, subtriangular or heartshaped (CW/CL = 1.1 1.4), much wider posteriorly
Dorsal surface: irregular, bearing sparsely placed sharp spinules, sub-hepatic region slightly puffed out, regions well-defined by convexities
gastric region: slightly inflated
branchial region: extremely inflated, meeting dorsally in midline
Pseudorostrum: moderately long (0.3 0.4 times PCL), beakshaped, bearing serrated ridge dorsally. Orbits absent
Ocular peduncle: well-developed, cornea terminal, dark pigment
Antennules: folded longitudinally, basal article slender
Antenna: basal article long, slender, fused distally; anterolateral angle bearing spine, flagellum well-developed
Chelipeds: bright red, unequal (left and right chelipeds 1.6 3.0 and 1.8  3.1 times PCL, respectively)
Merus: slender, cylindrical
Propodus: extremely long,
Fingers: short (0.2 0.4 times palm lengths), gently curved, occlusal margins finely dentate, tips pointed
Pereopods: bright red, slender, cylindrical, finely granular, unarmed
Telson: bluntly triangular, length 0.6 times width

Species name: Paramaja gibba Alcock, 1895
Carapace: pyriform (CW/CL = 0.9 1.0), convex, granular, regions well-defined;
Dorsal surface: light brown with reddish granules on the frontal, gastric, hepatic and cardiac regionbearing 7 large granules along median axis
hepatic spine short:, followed by shorter spine; lateral margins with 3 spines.
Postorbital spine large triangular, sparsely granular; intercalated spine large, separated from antorbital and postorbital spines by distinct gaps.
Supraorbital eave: well-developed, granular dorsally, with large antorbital spine.
Ocular peduncle: slender, movable, cornea ovate, well-pigmented
Antennules: folded longitudinally, basal article large, occupying lower half of fossa
Antenna: basal article longer than wide, lodged in orbital hiatus, sparsely tuberculate on lateral margins, with 2 distal spines, flagellum long. Proepistome well-developed, with 1 ventral directed spinous projection.
Chelipeds: subequal, slender, 0.7 times CL, sparsely setose ventrally
Merus: minutely granular
Carpus: unarmed
Propodus: slender
Fingers: straight, 0.9 times upper palm length; occlusal margins smooth, distal tips acuminate, meeting in closed position
Telson: semicircular, length 0.4 times width.

Species name: Cyrtomaia goodridgei McArdle, 1900
Carapace: transversely subcircular (CW/CL = 1.2)
Dorsal surface: light brown, minutely granular, regions well-defined
gastric region: most prominent
protogastric region: with 2 long, almost vertical spines laterally
mesogastric region: Short median spine, tuberculate ridges on gastric regions, median ridge ends at mesogastric spine, lateral ridges end at protogastric spine, with two ridges extending to supraorbital and postorbital spines
Rostrum: bifid, rostral spines 0.1  0.2 times CL, horizontal
Orbits: absent, supraocular eave weakly developed
Margin: frontal margin 0.1 0.2 times CW, Lateral margins sparsely spinose, Posterior margin gently convex
Spine: postorbital spine acuminate, almost parallel to rostral spine, supraocular spine absent
Ocular peduncle: long, with distal process, cornea well-pigmented
Antennules: folding longitudinally, basal article large, occupying lower half of fossa
Antenna: basal article cylindrical, fused to frontal margin, with 3 strong spines, articles 2 3 with 2 spinules each on external margins, flagellum well-developed
Chelipeds: ubequal in both sexes (3.1 and 2.3 times CL in male and female, respectively), male chela massive, female chela slender
Merus: margins spinose in males
Carpus: margins spinose in males
Propodus: margins spinose in males
Dactylus: dactylus with proximal spine on dorsal margin, distal tips blunt, fingers meeting in closed position
Fingers: almost straight; 0.5 and 0.6 times palm length in male and female, respectively
Pereopods: P2 P5 slender, light brown, relatively longer in males, P4  P5 glabrous, unarmed, except distal meral spine
Telson:  ounded, length 0.4 times width, distal margin notched medially.

Species name: Cyrtomaia suhmii Miers et al., 1885
Carapace: transversely subcircular (CW/CL = 1.2)
Dorsal surface: glabrous, regions well-defined; gastric region most prominent
Gastric region: protogastric region with 2 extremely long, arched, antrorse spines laterally, mesogastric with short median spine, ridges low, smooth, median ridge terminate at mesogastric spine, lateral ridges originate from median ridge terminate at protogastric spine, 2 ridges originate from protogastric spine reach supraorbital margin and postorbital spine.
Branchial region: moderately inflated, with 1 long, 3 short spines
Cardiac region: elevated, with 1 pair of diverging, submedian spines
hepatic region: slightly inflated, 1 short spine
intestinal region:  indistinct, with short median spinule
Branchial groove: shallow
Margin: frontal margin 0.1 times CW
Rostrum: bifid, rostral spines diverging
Ocular peduncle: long, with distal process, cornea well-pigmented
Antennules: folding longitudinally, basal article large, occupying lower half of fossa
Antenna: basal article cylindrical, fused to frontal margin, with 3 strong subdistal spines, articles 2 3 unarmed, flagellum well-developed
Chelipeds: slender, 3.6 times CL, minutely granular
Merus: 1.3 times propodus length, rows of antrorse spines at margin
Carpus: rows of antrorse spines at margin
Propodus: rows of antrorse spines at margin
Dactylus: with proximal spine on dorsal margin, distal tips blunt
Fingers: meeting in closed position
Telson: rounded, length 0.7 times width, with 1 mesial spinule, distal margin notched medially

Species name: Platymaia alcocki Rathbun, 1918
Carapace: transversely subcircular (CW/CL = 1.1 1.3)
Dorsal surface: reddish brown, tuberculate, spines worn out in large male, more pro nounced in small-sized female
Regions: well-defined by depression
gastric regions: strongly inflated, with 2 submedi an pairs of protogastric spines, 1 median mesogastric spine, 1 median metagastric spine
branchial regions: convex, moder ately inflated, with 8 9 moderate-sized spines
hepatic region: with 1 long antrorse spine ventral to postorbital spine
cardiac region: with 1 pair of large submedian spines; cervical groove distinct
Ocular peduncle: long, thick, cornea ventral in position, elongated
Antennules: basal article large, occupying lower half of fossa
Antenna: Basal article slender with distal and subdistal spinules, well-developed flagellum; prominent proepistome with horizontal spine
Chelipeds: Subequal, glabrous, light brown with reddish bands distally; massive in males (2.2–3.2x CL), slender and setose in females; male ischium with 9 spinules, female with 5
Ischium: Male has 9 anterior spinules, female has 5
Merus: Dorsal margin with 8 spines in 2 rows; posterior with 5 spines in 2 rows; distal margins with dorsal and ventral spinules (similar in both sexes)
Carpus: Dorsal margin with 2 spinules; female with additional spinules on anterior and posterior surfaces
Propodus: Enlarged in males (palm length 2.5x height, 10 dorsal spines); slender in females with 2 rows of 6–8 spines
Fingers: 0.4x palm length, gently curved, dentate occlusal margin with 4 large teeth, blunt tips meet when closed
Telson: Truncate triangular, 0.5x width, submedian spinules, notched distal margin.

Species name: Pleistacantha pungens Wood-Mason & Alcock, 1891
Carapace: pyriform (CW/CL = 0.8 0.9)
Dorsal surface: covered with moderate-sized conical spines with broad base regions well-defined
branchiocardiac grooves: distinct
Rostrum: bifid, rostral spines 0.3 0.4 times CL, slightly divergent, tapering distally, with 3 dorsal, 6 lateral, 3 ventral spines
Orbits: absent, supraorbital eave replaced by 1 spine; intercalated, postorbital spines distinct
Ocular peduncle: moderately long, visible dorsally, with 1 distal and 1 pair of subdistal spines,
Cornea: ventral, well-pigmented
Antennules: fold longitudinally, basal article large with 2 distolateral spines
Antenna: basal article slender, with 3 ventral spines, distal tip free, slightly overreaching anterior margin of ocular peduncle, second article short, with 2 ventral spines, flagellum well-developed
Chelipeds: Male chelipeds subequal, Female chelipeds sub equal (1.2 1.4 times CL), slender, covered with long spines, except on fingers
Merus: In male, wider distally, spinose on all margins and surfaces.
Propodus: propodus slightly compressed, tuberculate, proximal half with larger tubercles or short spines;
Dactylus: gently curved, slender, setose, distal tips corneous
Telson: rounded, length 0.7 times width, with pair of submedian spine proximally, randomly scattered spines laterally

Species name: Benthochascon hemingi Alcock & Anderson, 1899
Carapace: subhexagonal (CW/CL = 1.1)
Dorsal surface: glabrous, regions poorly defined by shallow grooves
Anterolateral teeth: 3 excluding exorbital
Orbits: incomplete, supraorbital margin minutely granular, with 2 fissures
Ocular peduncle: short, thick, cornea terminal, pigmented
Antennules: folding transversely
Antenna: basal article slender, with distolateral spine, flagellum long
Chelipeds: massive, subequal, (1.5 1.6 times CL)
Merus: massive, glabrous, pitted
Carpus: rugose, with large inner spine; palm glabrous, inner, outer surfaces of male pollex with subovate weakly calcified patch, patch absent in females
Dactylus: distal tips slender, acuminate
Pereopods: P2 P4 compressed, longer than chelipeds
Telson: truncate triangular, length 0.6 times width

Species name: Chaceon alcocki Ghosh & Manning, 1993
Carapace: subhexagonal (CW/CL = 1.10)
Dorsal surface: olive brown on anterior half, lighter brown posteriorly, glabrous, gently convex, pitted behind frontal margin and
Orbits: incomplete, supraorbital margin minutely granular, with 1 fissure; suborbital margin smooth, pterygostomial regions smooth, minutely pitted
Ocular peduncle: short, thick, cornea terminal, pigmented
Antennules: folding transversely
Antenna: basal article moderately large, flagellum long.
Epistome: wide, margins elevated, divided by 3 fissures
Chelipeds: massive, olive brown, subequal, (1.6 1.7 times CL)
Merus: massive, glabrous, pitted, dorsal margin with sharp sub-distal spine
Carpus: rugose, with large inner spine; palm minutely granular
Propodus: unarmed
Dactylus:  laterally compressed, 0.8 0.9 times propodal lengths, distal tips acuminate
Fingers: moderately slender, 1.4 1.5 times palm length, with row of pits along outer surface
Male thoracic sternum: glabrous, pitted, 0.51 times CW
Telson:  bluntly triangular, length 0.6 times width

Species name: Charybdis (Archias) hoplites Wood-Mason, 1877
Carapace: sub-hexagonal (CW/CL = 1.4 1.5)
Dorsal surface: olive brown, lighter anteriorly, smooth, regions ill-defined
Margin: Frontal margin 0.37 0.39 CW, frontal teeth 6, sharp triangular teeth
Tooth: frontal teeth 6, sharp triangular teeth, median teeth smaller than submedian teeth; lateral teeth narrow, Anterolateral teeth (including exorbital) 6
Orbits: complete, supraorbital margins with 2 sutures
Ocular peduncle: short, thick, cornea terminal, darkly pigmented
Antennular fossae: transverse
Antenna: basal article moderately large, bear ing granular transverse ridge; flagellum excluded from orbital hiatus
Chelipeds: massive, brownish, subequal (2.0 3.1 times CL), rugose
Merus: anterior margin with 3 4 large spines, 4 5 smaller spines, posterior margin with 1 distal spine; carpus with 1 inner spine, 1 dorsal spine, 2 outer spines, P5 with 1 large spine on posterior margin, distal spine present
Propodus: P2 P4 normal, propodi, P5 propodus posterior margin with 6 7 short teeth
Dactylus: P2 P4 dactyli with anterior margins setose.
Fingers: fingers moderately stout, tapering, occlusal margins dentate, distal tips slightly bent, pointed
Pereopods: P2 P5 brownish, compressed, P5 paratively much wider, flattened, ovate
Female thoracic sternum: glabrous, moderately wide
Telson: wide, bluntly triangular, fitting into invagination of somite 6

species_name: Charybdis (Archias) omanensis septentrionalis T rkay & Spiridonov, 2006
text:
Species name: Charybdis (Archias) omanensis septentrionalis T rkay & Spiridonov, 2006
Carapace: sub-hexagonal (CW/CL = 1.6)
Dorsal surface: finely granular, uniformly setose, regions well-defined, ridges including 1 pair of fine ly granular patch of frontals
Orbits: complete, supraorbital margins with 2 sutures
Ocular peduncle: short, thick, cornea terminal, darkly pigmented
Antennules: transverse, antennules
Antenna: basal article moderately large, bearing sharply granulated transverse ridge, with larger granules in the middle flagellum excluded from orbital hiatus
Epistome: wide, margins elevated
Buccal cavern: subquadrate
Chelipeds: massive, subequal (1.8 1.9 times CL), rugose
Ischium: subquadrate, with longitudinal depression, inner margin thickly setose in Mxp3
Merus: subquadrate, 0.7 times ischial length, an tero-external angle distinctly projecting laterally, inner margin thickly setos in Mxp3; merus with 2 or 3 blunt teeth on anteri or margin, posterior margin with 1 distal spine in chelipeds, P5  with 1 large spine on poste rior margin, distal spine present
Carpus:  with 1 inner spine, 1 dorsal spine, 2 smaller outer spines in chelipeds
Propodus: P2 P4 with anterior margins setose, comparatively much wider
Dactylus: P2 P4 with anterior margins setose, comparatively much wider
Pereopods:  P2 P5 compressed, P2 P4 normal, propodi, dactyli with anterior margins setose,
Telson: bluntly triangular

Species name: Charybdis (Archias) smithii Macleay, 1838
Carapace: sub-hexagonal (CW/CL = 1.4 1.5)
Dorsal surface: olive brown, lighter anteriorly, smooth, regions ill-defined, mesobranchial region slightly swollen, ridges including 1 pair of indistinct epibranchials
Margin: Frontal margin 0.37 0.39 CW
Tooth: frontal teeth 6, sharp triangular teeth, median teeth smaller than submedian teeth, lateral teeth narrow, Anterolateral teeth (including exorbital) 6, edges granular; first slightly bifid, second to fifth teeth truncated, last tooth laterally directed, slightly longer than preceding teeth
Orbits complete: supraorbital margins with 2 sutures
Ocular peduncle: short, thick, cornea terminal, darkly pigmented
Antennules: fossae transverse
Antenna: basal article moderately large, bear granular transverse ridge; flagellum excluded from orbital hiatus
Chelipeds: massive, subequal (1.9 2.6 times CL), rugose, olive brown with red margins, distal portions of fingers reddish
Ischium: subquad rate, with longitudinal depression, inner margin thickly setose in Mxp3,
Merus: subquadrate, 0.6 0.7 times ischial length in Mxp3, anterior margin with 3 large spines, 4 5 smaller spines in chelipeds
Carpus: 1 inner spine, 1 dorsal spine, 2 outer spines in chelipeds
Propodus:  flattened, ovate, posterior mar gin with 3 spinules, posterior margin setose in chelipeds
Dactylus: flattened, ovate, posterior margin setose in chelipeds
Fingers:  moderately stout, tapering, occlusal margins dentate, distal tips reddish, slightly bent, pointed in chelipeds
Telson: wide, bluntly triangular

Species name: Retropluma notopus Alcock & Anderson, 1894
Carapace: subquadrate (CW/CL = 1.2 1.3) pressed, greatest width at midlength
Dorsal surface: brownish with dark pink band on the gastric, hepatic and cardiac regions, smooth, pitted, regions poorly defined by shallow grooves
Rostrum: narrow, spatuliform, bifid
Margin: Fronto-orbital margin wide, anterolateral margins short, concave, strongly converging anteriorly, lateral margins convex; fronto-lateral lobe angular, Posterior margin gently sinuous
Ocular peduncle: moderately long, tapering, visible dorsally, cornea terminal, reduced
Antennules: fossae shallow, basal antennular article inflated distally, visible dorsally, folding transversely
Antenna: basal article slender, with distolateral spine, flagellum long, Proepistome concealed, epistome sunken
Mxp3: subpediform
Chelipeds: Unequal (1.5–1.6x CL), off-white, meri massive, granular, trigonal with 3 spinules on inner subventral surface and granules along distal and outer margins
Cheliped palm: Major palm inflated, glabrous, 1.2x height, granular dorsal margin; minor palm compressed, glabrous, 1.5x height, granular dorsal margin with a sharp spine on the inner ventral margin
Ischium: subrectangular, inner margin setose in Mxp3
Merus: suboperculiform, 0.6 t imes ischial length in Mxp3
Dactylus: occlusal margin with low teeth on proximal half in chelipeds
Fingers: almost straight, compressed, 0.9 times palm length in chelipeds
Female thoracic sternum: flat, granular, wide
Pereopods: P2 P4 brownish with red band on the dactyli
Telson: bluntly trian gular, length 1.2 times and 1.1 times width in male and female respectively.

Species name: Sphenomerides trapezioides Wood-Mason & Alcock, 1891
Carapace: hexagonal (CW/CL = 1.4)
Dorsal surface: convex, smooth, glabrous, regions ill-defined
Margin: Frontal margin moderately wide, deflexed, divided into 2 truncate rounded lobes by shallow median notch. Anterolateral margins gently rounded, 3 small teeth, posterolateral margin gently convex, distinctly converging, posterior margin gently convex
Orbits: incomplete, supraorbital margins with 1 suture, inner suborbital angle bear 1 small spine
Tooth: Anterolateral margins with 3 small teeth, first at external orbit al angle, 2 equidistant shorter teeth
Ocular peduncle: short, thick, cornea terminal, lightly pigmented
Antennules: folding transversely, Antennular fossae transverse
Antenna: basal article slender; flagellum lodged in orbital hiatus.
Ischium: ischium subrectangular, with longitudinal depression tapering anteriorly, inner margin thickly setose in Mxp3
Merus: subquadrate, 0.7 times ischial length, antero-external angle rounded, inner margin thickly setose in Mxp3
Propodus: P2 P5 sparsely covered with long setae
Dactylus: P2 P5 sparsely covered with long setae, bear paired movable spines on anterior and posterior margins
Female thoracic sternum: glabrous, moderately narrow
Pereopods:  P2 P5 normal
Telson: wide, bluntly triangular in female

Species name :Ludia maculata Muller et Troschel, 1842
Distribution: West Indian ocean, East Africa and Madagascar, North Australia, China and South Japan (Clark & Rowe, 1971), Singapore (VandenSpiegel et al., 1998), Thailand (Putchakarn & Sonchaeng, 2004), Red Sea (James & Pearse, 1969), Arabian Sea (Parameswaran et al., 2017), Persian Gulf (Mortensen, 1940; Price, 1983), and Pakistan (Haque, 1969)
Arms: five rays; R/r= 70/13 mm, large, flat, and strap-like
Disc: small and madreporite covered by paxillae
Abactinal paxillae: with eight to twenty short central spinelets and about twenty-five to thirty for more slender peripheral spinelets
Mid-arm Paxillae: located in mid arm are more irregular and smaller and have fewer spinelets than the lateral ones
Inferomarginal plates: Large inferomarginal plates with 3 to 5 short spines and numerous spinelets
Adambulacral plate: Adambulacral plate with 3 curved and flatted spines; two straight subambulacral spines and curved furrow ones
Dorsal surface of the body: a bold black mottled coloration
Ventral surface of the body: whitish
Pedicellariae : There are no large bivalve pedicellariae near the mouth.

Species name : Luidia hardwicki Gray, 1840
Distribution: West Indian ocean, East Africa and Madagascar, North Australia, China and South Japan (Clark & Rowe, 1971), Singapore (VandenSpiegel et al., 1998), Thailand (Putchakarn & Sonchaeng, 2004), Red Sea (James & Pearse, 1969), Arabian Sea (Parameswaran et al., 2017), Persian Gulf (Mortensen, 1940; Price, 1983), and Pakistan (Haque, 1969)
Arm: moderately large, flat, and straplike arms (five)
Disc:  small and madreporite covered by paxillae
Abactinal paxillae: with six to fifteen subequal, blunt-tipped, central spinelets, and with thirteen to twenty-three more slender peripheral ones
Mid-arm paxillae: more irregular and smaller, and have fewer spinelets than the peripheral ones
Inferomarginal plates: a single slender spine and numerious smaller spines encircled the inferomarginal plates
Adambulacral plates :Large slender pedicellariae on the outer part of some adambulacral plates
Pedicellariae: Large bivalve pedicellariae located near the mouth
Dorsal surface of the body: Preserved specimens pinkish in color, there are no marked color pattern on the dorsal surface body.

Species Name: Luidia integra Koehler, 1910
Distribution: Indo-Pacific, including the Philippines, Indonesia, and western Pacific Ocean
Arms: Base width 9 mm, increasing to 13 mm at 25 mm from base, tapering to a pointed tip. Median band of small, tightly packed paxillae, flanked by larger paxillae. Marginal paxillae are rounded, 1.2-1.3 mm in diameter, with 7-10 granules, sometimes forming a short spine
Disc: Flattened dorsal surface with tightly packed central paxillae and distinct boundaries. Paxillae increase in size towards the edges. Central granules range from 2-8, encircled by 10-25 small spines.
Abactinal Paxillae: Central region tight with peripheral circles of 10-25 small spines, varying by paxilla size
Mid-arm Paxillae: Median band of tightly packed paxillae with 3 rows on each side, first row rectangular, others square
Inferomarginal Plates: Each plate has 3 spines, increasing in size outward. The outermost spine is slightly flattened, curved, 3 mm long, surrounded by small spines. No pedicellariae present
Adambulacral Plates: 3 spines present, 2 external spines sharp and cylindrical, the outermost more developed. The innermost spine is shorter, flattened, and curved. A thin, long pedicellaria is above the first adambulacral spine; another larger pedicellaria is near the external spine on the oral side
Pedicellariae: One thin pedicellaria above the first adambulacral spine with flattened valves; another larger pedicellaria near the external spine
Dorsal Surface: Tight paxillae in the central disc region with well-defined boundaries, non-contiguous central granules surrounded by small spines.

Species Name: Luidia denudata Koehler, 1910
Distribution: Indian Ocean, Bay of Bengal, Andaman Sea, coastal regions of India and Sri Lanka
Arms: 10 arms, each narrow at the base, widening to 13 mm, and tapering at the tip. Arms measure up to 90 mm. Three lateral rows of paxillae on the dorsal side, with ventral marginal plates and spines
Disc: Diameter 22-23 mm. Loosely packed paxillae with cylindrical stems and tufts of fine, rough spinules, continuing onto the arms
Abactinal Paxillae: Cylindrical stems with fine spinules, forming a median band flanked by 3 longitudinal rows of spaced paxillae. Paxillae toward the median line create an irregular network, exposing soft tissue with papular orifices
Mid-arm Paxillae: Three lateral rows on each side, with cross-shaped ossicles. External row connects to ventral marginal plates by soft tissues, leaving triangular spaces
Inferomarginal Plates: T-shaped plates, slightly overlapping along the arm's axis, with small spines and two large spines on the outer edge
Adambulacral Plates: Roughly square, with 3 spines—2 external, strong and elliptical, 1 weaker and curved. A delicate pedicellaria lies above the internal spine, with another on the external face
Pedicellariae: Two types—long and delicate above the internal spine, shorter and stronger on the external face
Dorsal Surface: Loosely packed paxillae with cylindrical stems and spinules, exposing the skeleton and soft tissues.

Species name: Molpadia acuta Koehler & Vaney, 1905
Body length: Length varies between 59 mm to 100mm
Caudal region: Well-developed, tail is pigmented toward the base and whitish at the end
Tail length and Diameter: conical, diameter at the base varies between 4 and 10 mm, 15 to 80 mm in length
Skin/ Integument: rough, thick towards the anterior region and thin towards the caudal region
Body Pigmentation: strongly pigmented in red or black
Phosphatic deposits: present or absent
Calcareous ring: No info
Oral disc: bear tentacles
Number of Oral disc tentacles: The fourteen to fifteen tentacles are short and generally retracted,On each side  small lateral extension at their rounded end
Ossicles in body wall: composed of oval, red spicules, of triangular plates and spatulas. triradiate plates. Spatulas have various forms. Some end in an oval disk with some large central openings and small peripheral openings. The handle is formed of a single elongated rod, openings only at the base. Deposits anchors and rosettes of racquet shaped plates, together with oval to elongate plates 0.3 mm to 1.0 mm in length, typically with three central perforations. Tables of average diameter 0.3 mm with three perforations and spire composed of a single rod also occur
Ossicles in tail: rods, very elongated and slightly curved, The central part is a little swollen with three central openings in the middle of which rises a very short column with a pointed or rounded tip, constant presence in all the rods of the caudal region of a small central extension in the form of a tip or a crown of a series of tips.

Species name: Molpadia andamanensis Walsh, 1891
Body length: Total length varies from 25 to 140 mm, cylindrical body, diameter of the body varies between 14 and 30 mm
Caudal region: always possess a caudal extension 3 to 17 mm
Tail length and Diameter: Around 3 to 17 mm. base of tail varies between 1.5 mm and 6 mm
Skin/ Integument: rough but thin
Body Pigmentation: grey with dark spots
Phosphatic deposits: present
Calcareous ring: No info
Oral disc: diameter of 3 to 11 mm, bear tentacles. connected to the body by a very short neck
Number of Oral disc tentacles: fifteen short tentacles having at their end a pair of lateral extensions, each tentacle has three very small digits at the free end, The tentacles are yellow and between every two there is, near the base, a blue-black triangular mark
Ossicles in body wall: contains red phosphatic deposits and some fusiform calcareous ossicles more or less circular and triradiate, These calcareous ossicles have three large central openings that alternate with smaller peripheral openings
Ossicles in tail: The caudal region has fusiform calcareous ossicles whose base is more or less rounded and generally has two large opposite extensions with three large openings, while the rest of the plate has a large number of smaller openings, At the center of the spicules is a column formed of three vertical stems united by some stages that can reach a very great length, Discs of tables in tail somewhat narrowed and drawn out at the ends, with numerous 10 to 30 holes.

Species name: Molpadia brevicaudata Koehler & Vaney, 1905
Body length: Varies between 18 to 25 mm and its diameter 15mm
Caudal region: cylindrical with rounded end
Tail length and Diameter: 3 to 6 mm, Diameter 3 to 4 mm
Skin/ Integument: thin and rough, integuments of caudal region are thicker, white or greyish white
Body Pigmentation: grayish in color spotted with red
Phosphatic deposits: sometimes present
Oral disc: bears tentacles
Number of Oral disc tentacles: fifteen
Calcareous ring: inter radial pieces of calcareous ring have three anterior tips, radial pieces have two anterior tips, strong posterior extension slightly curved, bifid end
Ossicles in body wall: triradiate ossicles, red ovoid ossicles, spatulas with branched arms, and simple anchors. The triradiate ossicles appear in various forms, such as branches with few openings and circular plates featuring a fine network and large central openings. Spatulas are highly variable, characterized by short handles with large openings near the handle and smaller peripheral openings, often with lateral extensions. The anchors form a circular disk with four large openings
Ossicles in tail: fusiform triradiate spicules, elongated in opposite directions, with three central openings surrounded by uniform smaller openings, and a tall central column formed by three parallel stems connected by several transverse beams.

Species name: Molpadia concolor Koehler & Vaney, 1905
Body length: 67 mm-110mm
Caudal region:  very distinct tail, whitish; the integuments are rough, contain elongated plates
Tail length and Diameter: 16mm-20 mm in length
Skin/ Integument: thin
Body Pigmentation: Heavily spotted and marbled by an orange-red pigment on body. Tail region white in color
Phosphatic deposits: Present
Oral disc: The oral disc bears tentacles
Number and nature of Oral disc tentacles: 15 in number, on each side of tentacle, a small digitiform extension
Ossicles in body wall: Anchor-plates small, about 130 long. Tables with more or less irregular, often trifid base. They contain only red spicules and some rare triradiate rods, short and with bifurcated ends.
Ossicles in tail: only calcareous spicules in the caudal region. triradiated rods the end of this rod emitted slender and elongated extensions parallel to the plane of the plate. contain some elongated plates

Species name: Molpadia contorta Koehler & Vaney, 1905
Body length: 84-90mm
Caudal region: Conical in shape, length 9mm
Tail length and Diameter: This is conical; its width at the base is 4 to 5 millimeters and diameter reach 6 mm
Skin/ Integument: Thick and a mild rough
Body Pigmentation: Maroon brown in color
Phosphatic deposits: Phosphatic deposits absent
Oral disc:  5 mm in diameter. Bear oral disc tentacles
Oral disc tentacles: fifteen in number, are short, massive and their tip rounded, has a small extension on each side
calcareous ring: have each a very developed posterior extension and a short anterior extension. The inter radial parts have two very short anterior tips and two rounded posterior mamelons
Ossicles in body wall: Triradiate, three short and strong rods, ending in a series of points. rods, perforated rods, spatulas, anchors, tables form plates with one or two short extensions; they are pierced with a small number of large openings. anchors have two short, curved branches. The spatulas do not have the very distinct handle
Ossicles in Tail: plates having two opposite extensions, with enlarged central region that has three central openings accompanied by some peripheral openings.

Species name: Molpadia ecalcarea Koehler & Vaney, 1905
Body length: 68mm in length and 34mm in diameter. Strongly bulged body
Caudal region: Short caudal region
Tail length and Diameter: very short tail measuring only 3 mm in length and 2 to 8 mm of diameter. body have the appearance of a rubber membrane
Skin/ Integument: appearance of a rubber membrane
Body Pigmentation: The body itself has a gray coloring. The tail is purplish-violet
Phosphatic deposits: Present
Calcareous ring: Well developed, and form striations on surface. In each radius it has an anterior tip sometimes bifid and a small posterior tip. In each interradius, two small anterior tips are each extended by a slightly projecting ridge.
Oral disc: bear tentacles
Number of Oral disc tentacles: 15 tentacles in number
Ossicles in body wall: lack calcareous ossicles, but only phosphatic deposits
Ossicles in tail: calcareous ossicles absent in caudal region

Species name: Molpadia elongata Koehler & Vaney,1905
Body length: The total length reaches 49 mm, the body itself measures 28mm in length, maximum width about 8 mm
Caudal region: distinct, elongated caudal region. Thick and rough integument present
Tail length and Diameter: 26 mm, width is 25 mm
Skin/ Integument: thin and rough due to the presence of numerous calcareous ossicles, Thick and rough Caudal Integuments present
Body Pigmentation: grayish
Phosphatic deposits: No info
Calcareous ring: No info
Oral disc: The oral disc is 3 mm in diameter, it is carried by a neck of 4 mm length
Number of Oral disc tentacles:  No info
Ossicles in body wall: perforated rod with three distinct central openings and rods extending from each. Rods (Perforated, arched, curved)
Ossicles in tail: anchor, perforated rods, Tables.

Species name: Molpadia granulata Ludwig, 1893
Body length: total length varies from 57 mm to 75 mm
Caudal region: No info
Tail length and Diameter: tail is between 20 and 28 mm
Skin/ Integument: very thin, rough and fine grained appearance that the skin
Body Pigmentation: yellow color or yellow-gray to brown-yellow color. blackish-brown in the anterior and posterior regions of the trunk
Phosphatic deposits: No info
Calcareous ring: No info
Oral disc: bear tentacles
Number of Oral disc tentacles: 15 tentacles in number
Ossicles in body wall: triradiated, perforated rods with 3 openings at the center, long rods, wide, perforated plate
Ossicles in tail: Curved rods preseng. The anus is made up of five groups of small, flexible, surrounded by cylindrical anal papillae.

Species name: Molpadia musculus Risso, 1826
Body length: 100- 200 mm, sausage shaped
Caudal region: well defined tail
Tail length and Diameter: No info
Skin/ Integument: rough and thick
Body Pigmentation: grayish-white to dark purple
Phosphatic deposits: Phosphatic deposits present
Calcareous ring: Calcareous ring with posterior bifurcate projections on radial plates
Oral disc: bear tentacles
Number of Oral disc tentacles: 15 in number. Digitate tentacles with small pro-longations
Ossicles in body wall: fusiform bodies rod-like, usually with narrow, rounded, unperforated, and undivided ends, occurring all over the body, sometimes flattened and
widened. im bhe: tall fusiform rods, tables with three or more perforations and a solid spire. rosette and racquet-shape plates and anchors present. Fusiform rods sometimes present.
Ossicles in tail: fusiform rods 500 to 1300 micron long always present in the tail 500 to 1300 micron long
Distribution: Cosmopolitan occurring in 35 to 5205 m, but not known above the Arctic Circle (Pawson et al. 2001, 2009)
Habitat.: Buried in soft sediments

Species name: Molpadia paupera Koehler & Vaney, 1905
Body length: 75 mm. and a diameter of 32 mm. The body usually swollen.
Caudal region: very short, the tail is pink and rough and rounded at end
Tail length and Diameter: 6 mm in length, 2 mm of width
Skin/ Integument: soft and have the consistency of rubber.  Integument has two layers. The external has a grayish color. The internal is violet black and its surface is more or less grainy. This latter layer alone contains red spicules and the integument of the body strictly speaking contains no calcareous ossicles
Body Pigmentation: grayish in color
Phosphatic deposits: No info
Calcareous ring: No info
Oral disc: Bear tentacles
Number of Oral disc tentacles: Tentacles are 15 in number
Calcareous ring: The calcareous ring exists, but it is thin and is very difficult to see because of the state of contraction of the tissues where it is embedded, Ends of the narrow plates not expanded and perforated.
Ossicles in body wall: No calcareous ossicles. Only contain Fusiform bodies transformed into very flat rods or narrow plates, with an expanded middle portion.
Ends of the flat rods
Ossicles in tail: Has calcareous ossicles in the form of flattened rods, whose central part is flattened with more or less sinuous borders. Perforated rods by two to four openings in central region.

Species name: Molpadia polymorpha Koehler & Vaney, 1905
Body length: 50 mm
Caudal region: distinct, thicker
Tail length and Diameter: 15 mm in, buccal disk is 5 mm diameter, the base of tail 2 to 3 mm
Skin/ Integument: tough integument
Body Pigmentation: white with red patches
Phosphatic deposits: No info
Calcareous ring: Well developed with longitudinal striations, interradial parts of calcareous ring have some very small tips directed forward two posterior mamelons, projecting radial parts are extended posteriorly in strong tip whose end is bifid
Oral disc: Bear tentacles
Number of Oral disc tentacles: Tentacles are 15 in number
Ossicles in body wall: oval red spicules triradiate plates anchors with two three or four branches and spatulas plates or tables more or less rounded three central openings with base of column formed of three stems ending in a crown of spines some peripheral openings nearly same size as the central openings, anchors have different forms, Some two short arms, have three slightly curved arms located at equal distances from each other, others have four arms arranged more or less exactly in pairs, spatulas oval or quadrangular plate with rounded rim, One of its sides is extended by flat and rectangular handle with large openings, but it has toward the rounded terminal border very large number of peripheral openings, The handle has likewise very elongated openings over its entire length
Ossicles in tail: enlarged plates in their center that are continued by two diametrically opposed extensions, At center are three openings arranged at base of small column formed of contiguous stems and that ends in series of tips, spatulas and fusiform plates present.

Species name: Molpadia undulata Koehler & Vaney, 1905
Body length: 20-35mm
Caudal region: distinct, whitish in color
Tail length and Diameter: 8-17 mm in length
Skin/ Integument: No info
Body Pigmentation: body is pigmented, while the caudal region is whitish
Phosphatic deposits: Present
Calcareous ring: No info
Oral disc: bear tentacles
Number of Oral disc tentacles: 15 in number
Ossicles in body wall: contain ossicles
Ossicles in tail: only rods are seen, mostly perforated with some large openings and some rounded lateral expansions from the sinuous border.

Species name: Hexanchus griseus Bonnaterre, 1788
Body Shape: Body rather stout; size very large, to at least 4.8 m
Snout: Snout wide,
Mouth part: a big mouth and a ventrally arched symphyseal tooth on both jaws, and six rows of large, serrated comb-shaped teeth on each side of lower jaw
Teeth: Ten teeth on each side of the upper jaw with hooked cusps, not counting the smallest and molariform ones
Gills: Six large gill slits not inserted on pectoral fins
Eyes: Eyes small, pupil dark with white rim, prominent tapetum lucidum giving a fluorescent greenish colouration in life
Dorsal fin: Single dorsal fin originating ahead of anal fin insertion
Caudal Peduncle: Caudal peduncle short and stout, distance from dorsal fin insertion to upper caudal origin about equal or slightly greater than length of, dorsal fin base
Geographical Distribution: Widespread in temperate and tropical seas, from the Western and Eastern Atlantic to the Indian Ocean, Western and Central Pacific, and Eastern Pacific, ranging broadly from Iceland and Japan to Australia, Hawaii, and down to Chile and Argentina.

Species name: Heptranchias perlo Bonnaterre, 1788
Body Shape: Small, slender shark, head very narrow
Snout: snout very narrow
Gills: Head with 7 gill slits
Mouth part: teeth of upper and lower jaws unlike at sides of mouth
Teeth: uppers smaller, narrower, with a main cusp and a few small cusplets, lowers larger, compressed and comblike, with a long main cusp and several cusplets, their inner edges with a few short cusplets but no serrations
Eyes: very large
Dorsal fin: A single dorsal fin, separated from origin of caudal fin by over twice its base length
Caudal Peduncle: short lower caudal fin lobe in adults
Colour: grey-brown above, pale below, the young with dark tips on dorsal fin and terminal lobe of caudal fin, lost in adults
Geographical Distribution: Found in temperate to tropical waters across the Atlantic, Indian Ocean, Western Pacific, and Southeast Pacific, mostly in deep waters (100-1875m). Juveniles may be nearshore. It avoids the Northeast Pacific

Species name: Chiloscyllium arabicum Gubanov, 1980
Diagnostic Features: Body and tail moderately slender
Snout: fairly thick and rounded anteriorly
Trunk: lateral ridge present on each side of trunk
Dorsal fin: large and angular, somewhat larger than pelvic fins, dorsals with projecting free rear tips,
Caudal fin: origin of caudal fin somewhat behind free rear tip of first dorsal, caudal fin length
from origin to free rear tip, somewhat less than hypural caudal lobe, from lower caudal origin to free rear tip.
Colour: No colour pattern, colour light brown.
Geographical distribution: confined to the "Gulf" between Iran and the Arabian Peninsula.

Species name:  Neotrygon indica Pavan-Kumaretal.,2018
Body: Disc is kite-like, wider than long, naked with few dorsal denticles
Snout: short and gently rounded
Mouth: two papillae are present inside mouth
Tail: as long as disc with upper and lower cutaneous folds
Spin: pair of sharp spin on the upper surface of middle part of tail
Colour: Pale brown; bright blue-centered ocelli; scattered dark speckles and black spots; conspicuous occipital mark; white underside; tail with black-and-white bands behind sting
Geographical distribution: India and Sri Lanka; sandy areas adjacent to reefs

Species name: Taeniura meyeni Müller & Henle, 1841
Body: Disc almost rounded
Mouth: Buccal cavity with 4–5 papillae; about 40 tooth rows per jaw
Fins: Dorsal and caudal fins absent
Tail: Stout tail with large dorsal spine and conspicuous ventral cutaneous fold
Dorsal surface: Dorsal disc surface rough with widely distributed granulations
Colour: Disc grey, mottled with black spots and irregular blotches; ventral tail fold black
Geographical distribution: Indo-West Pacific: Red Sea and East Africa to Marquesas; north to southern Japan and Ogasawara; south to Queensland. Sandy clays bordering coral reefs

Species name: Sebastapistes cyanostigma Bleeker, 1856
Body: Dorsal fin: 12 spines, 9 soft rays; anal fin: 3 spines, 5–6 soft rays; pectoral fin: 15–16 rays; lateral-line scale series: 42–45 scales, body depth 2.7–2.8 in SL
Scale: ctenoid
Spines: Two suborbital ridges ending in blunt spine; lacrimal spines five, three extending ventrally over upper lip
Colour: body pink to reddish with small white spots and yellow blotches; fins yellowish
Geographical distribution: Indo-West Pacific: Red Sea to East Africa, east to Line Islands and Samoa; south to Queensland and Timor Sea; north to Ryukyu and Ogasawara Islands; solitary or small groups among Pocillopora branches on surge-exposed shallow reefs

Species name:  Pseudanthias ignitus Randall & Lubbock, 1981
Body: Dorsal fin 10 spines, 16–17 soft rays; anal fin 3 spines, 7 soft rays; pectoral fin 19–20 rays; lateral-line scales 53–58; gill rakers 11–12 upper limb + 22–25 lower limb; body depth 2.5–3.0 in SL
Caudal fin: lunate, lobes filamentous
Pelvic fin:  elongate filament in males
Colour: Body orange; lavender-edged band to opercle; dorsal red with yellow base; caudal yellowish with pinkish margins
Geographical distribution: Indian Ocean: Maldives, Andaman Sea, northwestern Sumatra; lagoonal reefs and upper edges of shallow reef slopes

Species name: Zoramia virdiventer Greenfield, Langston & Randall, 2005
Body: First dorsal 6 spines; second dorsal 1 spine, 9 rays; anal 2 spines, 9 rays; pectoral 14 rays; lateral-line scales 24; gill rakers 6–7 + 24–27; body depth 2.5–3.3 in SL; second dorsal spine 19.0–21.5% SL; anal spine 13.0–16.0% SL
Colour: Body semi-transparent with silvery abdomen and operculum; head and anterior body with scattered blue spots; faint snout band occasional; distinct black spot at mid caudal-fin base; caudal-fin tips often black
Geographical distribution: Indo-Pacific: Indonesia to Samoa, Fiji, Marshall Islands; north to Japan, south to Australia; sheltered shallow reefs to 15m

Species name:  Lutjanus rivulatus Cuvier, 1828
Body: Dorsal fin 10 spines, 15 soft rays; anal fin 3 spines, 8 soft rays; pectoral fin 17 rays; pelvic fin 1 spine, 5 soft rays; lateral-line scales 47–49, Body deep; dorsal head profile steeply sloped.
Teeth: Vomerine tooth patch crescentic
Anal fin: Anal fin posterior profile pointed
Mouth: Preopercular notch moderately developed
Colour: Body reddish-brown with one or two bluish spots per scale; head with fine wavy blue lines; lips whitish; fins yellow with dusky markings; caudal fin grayish with yellow margin
Geographical distribution: Indo-Pacific: Red Sea to East Africa, India to Japan and Australia, reaching Tahiti; inshore reef areas

Species name: Monotaxis heterodon Bleeker, 1854
Body: Dorsal fin 10 spines, 10 soft rays; anal fin 3 spines, 9 soft rays; pectoral fin 13–14 rays; lateral-line scales 44–47; transverse scales 5/12.5, body depth 2.2 in SL
Scales: Small scales present on inner surface of pectoral-fin axil
Mouth: Jaw with 5–7 large molariform teeth on sides
Eyes: Eyes large, 2.7–3.8 in head length
Colour: Adults silvery grey with dark scale margins; black pectoral-axil blotch; 3–4 narrow white upper-body bars; caudal lobes with orange bands; fins yellowish to reddish
Geographical distribution: Indo–West Pacific: Seychelles to New Caledonia; shallow coral reefs, solitary or small groups; first record from Lakshadweep

Species name: Parapercis millepunctata Gunther, 1860
Body: Dorsal fin 4 spines, 20–21 soft rays; anal fin 1 spine, 17–18 soft rays; pectoral fin 17 rays; gill rakers 14–17; lateral-line scales 55–60
Scales:  predorsal scales 9–11
Mouth: Six canines at front of lower jaw
Spines: Last dorsal-fin spine joined to first soft ray at spine-tip level
Colour: Back with dark and light brown spots; lower half white with two spot rows—upper rounded, lower elongate; upper-row spots ocellated in males, small dark spot in females; caudal-fin center with white streak
Geographical distribution: Indo-Pacific: Maldives and Sri Lanka to Pitcairn; north to Ryukyu and Ogasawara; south to southern Great Barrier Reef and New Caledonia; sand–rubble bottoms near shallow reefs

Species name:  Helcogramma striata Hansen, 1986
Body: First dorsal fin 3 spines; second dorsal fin 11–15 spines plus 9–12 soft rays; anal fin 1 spine, 17–22 soft rays; pectoral fin 15–17 rays; pelvic fin 1 spine, 2 soft rays; lateral-line pores 14–20, continuous; lateral-line scales 38–39
Scales: Head scaled on nape; belly naked
Mouth: Mandibular pores arranged as 3 front + 2 middle + 3 rear
Dorsal fin: One free pterygiophore between second and third dorsal fins
Eyes: Eyes with yellow ring
Colour: Upper two-thirds red with three white or bluish-white stripes; 6–7 spots between lowest two stripes
Geographical distribution: Indo–West Pacific: Sri Lanka to Andaman Sea, Line Islands, Fiji, Western Australia and Queensland; north to Taiwan, Japan, and Ogasawara

Species name: Ecsenius yaeyamaensis Aoyagi, 1954
Body: Dorsal fin 11–12 spines, 13–15 soft rays; anal fin 2 spines, 14–17 soft rays; pelvic fin 1 spine, 3 soft rays, body depth at anal-fin origin 5.3–5.7 in SL
Spines: Lateral-line tubes extending to below 10th–11th dorsal-fin spine
Mouth: Nasal cirri present on posterior rim of anterior nostril
Colour: Body light brown with pale cheek; interrupted dark post-orbital stripe; lower cheek margin black; pectoral-fin base with Y-shaped mark plus occasional white spots and blotches
Geographical distribution: Indo–West Pacific: Sri Lanka to Vanuatu; north to southern Japan; south to Australia and New Caledonia; sheltered coastal reefs in shallow water, solitary or small groups

Species name: Thalassoma amblycephalum Bleeker, 1856
Body: Dorsal fin 8 spines, 13 soft rays; anal fin 3 spines, 11 soft rays; pectoral fin 15 rays; lateral-line scales 26–27
Mouth: Jaws with one anterior pair of canines
Caudal fin: Caudal fin truncate to slightly emarginate, becoming lunate in large males attains to 15cm
Colour: Male reddish with vertical green lines, yellow nape zone, green head with paired pink lines, yellow pectorals with large blue spot. Female pale green dorsally with broad dark mid-lateral stripe and white lower half. Occurs in aggregations on shallow reefs, lagoon edges, and seaward areas
Geographical distribution: Indo-Pacific; first record from Lakshadweep, previously known from Andaman Islands

Species name: Scolopsis xenochroa Günther, 1872
Body: Dorsal fin 10 spines, 9 soft rays; anal fin 3 spines, 7 soft rays; pectoral fin 17 rays; pelvic fin 1 spine, 5 soft rays; lateral-line scales 44; gill rakers 9; body moderately deep; body depth 3.21 in SL; head large, 2.92 in SL; snout short, 3.58 in HL
Scales: with ctenoid scales
Spines: Small antrorse spine below eye
Mouth: Maxillary smooth along external edge
Colour: Upper body greyish brown, lower body silvery white; pearly streak from eye to dorsal-fin base; oblique brown-edged pearly blue bar above pectoral base; elongate white blotch below lateral line posteriorly with yellowish tinge above; snout dusky; opercle with black blotch
Geographical distribution: Maldives, Sri Lanka to northeastern Australia, New Guinea, and Solomon Islands

Species name: Eubleekeria splendens Cuvier, 1829
Body: Dorsal 8–9 spines, 16 rays; anal 3 spines, 14–15 rays; pectoral 13–14; pelvic 1,5; caudal 15–16; LL 45–57; gill rakers 9; body compressed, deep; convex dorsal profile with notch; snout blunt, short; body depth 40.85–55.36% SL; head 31.34–34.62% SL; snout 22.22–31.58% HL; eye 33.33–44.44% HL
Fins: Dorsal spines II–VI with jet-black membranes; other dorsal and anal membranes faint yellow; pelvic with axillary scale; caudal tips dusky, moderately forked; pectoral long
Scales: Ctenoid scales; lateral line prominent, convex, extending past soft dorsal and anal bases, ending before caudal base
Spines: Preopercular margin finely serrated
Mouth: Small subocular gape; jaws with minute villiform teeth; mandibles slightly concave.
Colour: Silvery body with bright abdomen; back grey-silvery with faint wavy streaks; snout tip dotted black; pectoral axil black; dorsal membranes II–VI jet black; other fins faint yellow; caudal tips dusky
Geographical distribution: Indian coast: Veraval, Mangalore, Calicut, Cochin, Mandapam, Porto Novo, Madras, Visakhapatnam, Kakinada

Species name: Nuchequula mannusella Chakrabarty & Sparks, 2007
Body: Dorsal 8 spines, 16–17 rays; anal 3 spines, 14 rays; pectoral 13–15 with rudimentary rays; pelvic 1,5; caudal 15; LL 52–64; body oval, compressed; dorsal and abdominal profiles equally convex; mouth protractile, downward; lower jaw margin concave; body depth 43.75–50.00% SL; head 29.85–33.33% SL; snout 26.32–35.71% HL; eye 30.00–36.84% HL
Fins: Pelvic with axillary scale; reach two-thirds to anal origin; caudal deeply forked; spinous dorsal golden mid-height; pectoral axil dotted black
Scales: Ctenoid; lateral line anteriorly concave, extending to caudal base
Spines: Two small cephalic spines opposite anterior eye border; preopercular margin finely serrated
Mouth: Protractile tube; small teeth in single row each jaw
Colour: Silvery belly with golden patch; dorsal body with dark wavy lines; nape brown blotch; snout tip dotted black; pectoral axil dotted; spinous dorsal golden
Geographical distribution: Mangalore, Cochin, Palk Bay, Gulf of Mannar, Kakinada, Godavari estuary, Vembanad Lake, Rameswaram

Species name: Nuchequula nuchalis Temminck & Schlegel, 1845
Body: Dorsal 8 spines, 15–16 rays; anal 2 spines, 14 rays; pectoral 12–14 with rudimentary rays; pelvic 1,5; caudal 15; LL 49–57; body oval, compressed, slightly elongate; dorsal and ventral profiles equally convex; snout pointed; mouth tube-forming, downward; lower jaw strongly concave; body depth 36.21–42.59% SL; head 27.59–31.03% SL; snout 22.22–30.00% HL; eye 27.78–37.50% HL
Fins: Pelvic with axillary scale; reach less than halfway to anal origin; caudal deeply forked; dorsal membranes II–VII black
Scales: Ctenoid; lateral line anteriorly concave, then slightly convex, extending to caudal base
Spines: Two small cephalic spines opposite anterior eye border; preopercular margin finely serrated
Mouth: Small protractile tube; villiform teeth numerous in single row each jaw
Colour: Silvery abdomen; back with black irregular bands; brown nape blotch; snout tip dotted black; ventral half with fine black dots; inner pectoral dark; gill-opening region dotted
Geographical distribution: Cochin, Quilon, Madras, Kakinada, Calcutta, Sundarbans, Chalk Lake

Species name: Leiognathus equulus Forsskål, 1775
Body: Dorsal 8 spines, 16–17 rays; anal 3 spines, 13–14 rays; pectoral 15–17; pelvic 1,5; caudal 15; LL 54–64; body oblong, deep, compressed; dorsal profile strongly convex, humped; snout blunt; mouth thick-lipped, downturned when protracted; gape below eye; lower jaw strongly concave; body depth 53.45–60.00% SL; head 31.40–35.94% SL; snout 28.57–35.71% HL; eye 31.25–37.93% HL
Fins: Pelvic with prominent axillary scale and strong spine; ventrals short; caudal not deeply forked with rounded lobes; anal membranes yellowish; caudal margins pale yellow, dusky
Scales: Ctenoid; lateral line conspicuous, anteriorly concave, then slightly convex, extending to caudal base
Spines: Two small cephalic spines opposite anterior eye border; preopercular lower margin concave, serrated
Mouth: Thick lips; villiform teeth numerous in each jaw
Colour: Silvery body; grayish back; fine vertical bands to mid-height; snout dotted black; pectoral axil faintly dusky; caudal margins pale yellow, dusky
Geographical distribution: Bombay, Mangalore, Calicut, Cochin, Quilon, Cape Comorin, Mandapam, Rameswaram, Kilakarai, Pamban, Madras, Porto Novo, Visakhapatnam, Kakinada; Godavari estuary; Chilka Lake

Species name: Karalla dussumieri Valenciennes, 1835
Body: Dorsal 8 spines, 16 rays; anal 3 spines, 14 rays; pectoral 14–15; pelvic 1,5; caudal 15; LL 51–60; body oblong, moderately compressed; dorsal and ventral profiles equally convex; slight concavity behind occiput; snout blunt; mouth small, downward when protracted; gape below eye; mandibles slightly concave; body depth 43.21–49.49% SL; head 29.82–34.21% SL; snout 23.53–34.48% HL; eye 30.77–40.91% HL
Fins: Pelvic with strong spine and large axillary scale; ventrals short of anal origin; caudal forked with rounded lobes; pectoral base dark
Scales: Ctenoid scales; lateral line anteriorly concave, then slightly convex, extending past soft dorsal and anal bases, ending short of caudal base
Spines: Two small cephalic spines opposite anterior eye border; preopercular margin finely serrated
Mouth: Small protractile tube; villiform teeth numerous in each jaw
Colour: Abdomen silvery; back brownish; sides with narrow wavy vertical lines; elongate yellow belly spot below pectoral; pectoral base dark
Geographical distribution: Cochin, Quilon, Tuticorin, Pamban, Mandapam, Kakinada, Visakhapatnam; dominant in southern Tamil Nadu, Gulf of Mannar

Species name: Karalla daura Cuvier, 1829
Body: Dorsal 8 spines, 16 rays; anal 3 spines, 14 rays; pectoral 14–16; pelvic 1,5; caudal 15; LL 64–69; body elongate, compressed; dorsal and ventral profiles equally convex; occipital concavity with rise to spinous dorsal; snout blunt; mouth small, thick-lipped, downward when protracted; gape at lower third of eye; lower jaw slightly concave; body depth 37.21–47.52% SL; head 26.79–30.77% SL; snout 25.00–31.25% HL; eye 30.77–39.13% HL
Fins: Pelvic with strong spine and large axillary scale; ventrals short of anal origin; caudal forked; inner pectoral base gray; anal golden distally; black line along base of soft dorsal
Scales: Ctenoid scales; lateral line anterior concavity, then slightly convex, extending to caudal base
Spines: Two cephalic spines; outer spine larger; preopercular lower margin finely serrate
Mouth: Small protractile tube; villiform teeth numerous in both jaws
Colour: Silvery abdomen; gray back; ventral half with black dots; snout tip black; deep black blotch on upper spinous dorsal (spines II–VI region); broad yellow band over lateral line to caudal base
Geographical distribution: Goa, Cochin, Quilon, Palk Bay, Gulf of Mannar, Chilka Lake, Kakinada, Porto Novo

Species name: Photopectoralis bindus Valenciennes, 1835
Body: Dorsal 8 spines, 16 rays; anal 3 spines, 14 rays; pectoral 11–13; pelvic 1,5; caudal 14–15; LL ending below mid soft dorsal; body deep, oval, strongly compressed; ventral profile more convex than dorsal; abdomen strongly convex before anal; slight occipital concavity; mouth protracted forward to slightly downward; gape above lower eye border; mandible slightly concave; body depth 48.65–57.14% SL; head 26.92–30.99% SL; snout 18.18–26.67% HL; eye 35.00–45.00% HL
Fins: Ventral with long axillary scale; ventrals short of halfway to anal origin; caudal deeply forked with pointed lobes; spinous dorsal black mid-height with bright orange blotch between spines II–V (yellow in preservative); caudal margins dusky
Scales: Ctenoid; lateral line straight anteriorly, then slightly convex, ending below mid soft dorsal, posterior portion obsolete
Spines: Two small cephalic spines opposite anterior eye border; preopercular lower margin finely serrate
Mouth: Small, protractile; villiform teeth numerous in both jaws
Colour: Silvery body; abdomen brighter; dark zigzag vermiculate markings from nape to soft dorsal; males with translucent flank patch; females silvery; snout tip and ventral half with grey dots; pectoral axil dotted; faint yellow on basal spinous anal membrane; caudal dusky
Geographical distribution: Veraval, Mangalore, Calicut, Cochin, Palk Bay, Gulf of Mannar, Madras, Kakinada, Visakhapatnam, West Bengal; major silverbelly fishery component in Gujarat and Tamil Nadu

Species name: Photopectoralis aureus Abe & Haneda, 1972
Body: Dorsal 8 spines, 16 rays; anal 3 spines, 14 rays; pectoral 12; pelvic 1,5; caudal 15; LL indistinct posteriorly; body elongate, slender, moderately compressed; dorsal and ventral profiles evenly curved; snout sharp, pointed; mouth downward when protracted; mandibular slightly concave; body depth 21.43–24.59% SL; head 29.51–30.36% SL; snout 27.78–29.41% HL; eye 27.78–29.41% HL
Fins: Caudal deeply forked; ventrals reaching halfway to anal origin; black spot at base of each dorsal and anal ray; anal membrane yellow between spines II–III; anterior anal margin yellow
Scales: Lateral line conspicuous anteriorly, obscure posteriorly; counts not traceable beyond initial portion
Spines: Cephalic region without paired external spines (not described); standard preopercular serration absent or minimal (not stated)
Mouth: Narrow band of small teeth in each jaw; mouth protractile, downward pointing
Colour: Silvery body; back and sides with irregular brown spots and vermiculations; ventral half with fine black dots; snout and gill-opening edge dotted; underside of pectoral with minute dark dots; caudal dark along margins; bright yellow on anterior anal margin
Geographical distribution: Stray coastal occurrences only

Species name: Equulites absconditus Chakrabarty & Sparks, 2010
Body: Dorsal 8 spines, 16 rays; anal 3 spines, 14 rays; pectoral 11–12; pelvic 1,5; caudal 15; LL 49–57 (posteriorly indistinct); body oblong, compressed, elongate; dorsal and ventral profiles equally convex; slight occipital concavity; snout pointed; mouth tube-forming downward; lips narrow, thick; gape at lower third of eye; mandible slightly concave; body depth 31.71–40.00% SL; head 26.67–29.17% SL; snout 21.43–31.25% HL; eye 31.25–38.46% HL
Fins: Pelvic with axillary scale, short of anal origin; caudal deeply forked; dorsal and anal bases with no color blotches except flank translucency in males; male midflank with expansive equilateral translucent patch
Scales: Ctenoid; lateral line with anterior concavity, then less convex; posterior portion untraceable from mid to end of dorsal region
Spines: Paired cephalic spines above anterior third of orbit; preopercular lower margin straight, finely serrated
Mouth: Small downward tube; numerous small teeth on both jaws
Colour: Silvery belly; brownish back with sparse zigzag or vermiculate lines; ventral half with fine black dots; snout tip dotted black; inner pectoral base dotted; lower gill-opening edge dotted
Geographical distribution: Cochin, Quilon, Palk Bay, Gulf of Mannar, Madras, Kakinada

Species name: Equulites leuciscus Günther, 1860
Body: Dorsal 8 spines, 16 rays; anal 3 spines, 14 rays; pectoral 13–14; pelvic 1,5; caudal 15; LL 61–64; body compressed, elongate; dorsal profile slightly more convex; slight cranial concavity; snout pointed; mouth small, downward when protracted; gape opposite mid–lower third of eye; mandible slightly concave; body depth 36.07–41.86% SL; head 26.25–28.85% SL; snout 28.57–33.33% HL; eye 29.17–37.50% HL
Fins: Second dorsal spine elongated, filiform, flexible; second dorsal spine reaching dorsal rays 2–4 when flexed; third dorsal spine half length of second; anal origin below eighth dorsal spine; ventrals reaching two-thirds to anal origin; caudal forked; dorsal membranes soft yellow; posterior caudal yellowish
Scales: Ctenoid scales; lateral line extending beyond soft dorsal and anal bases to caudal base
Spines: Two supraorbital spines above eye; preopercular serration not emphasized (finely serrate as typical)
Mouth: Narrow downward tube; villiform teeth numerous in both jaws
Colour: Silvery body; back and sides with irregular semicircular gray-brown vermiculation; yellow spots below lateral line on larger specimens; pectoral axil black dotted; dorsal membrane yellow mid-height; soft dorsal margin yellow
Geographical distribution: Cochin, Quilon, Palk Bay, Gulf of Mannar, Madras

Species name: Aurigequula fasciata Lacepède, 1803
Body: Dorsal 8 spines, 16 rays; anal 3 spines, 14 rays; pectoral 14–16; pelvic 1,5; caudal 15; LL 62; body compressed, ovate, deep; strongly arched back; horizontal mouth; downward tube when protruded; gape opposite/below eye; mandible slightly concave; body depth 54.95–56.59% SL; head 31.01–32.43% SL; snout 33.33–35.00% HL; eye 35.00–36.11% HL
Fins: Second dorsal spine filiform, reaching origin of dorsal ray 8 when flexed; second anal spine elongate; ventral fin with prominent axillary scale; ventral not reaching anal origin; caudal deeply forked; anal fin with faint yellow; caudal dusky
Scales: Lateral line slightly concave anteriorly, then convex, extending short of caudal base
Spines: Pair of supraorbital spines above anterior orbit; preopercular margin finely serrated
Mouth: Narrow gape; villiform teeth in both jaws
Colour: Silvery abdomen and back; upper half with 10–15 indistinct gray-brown vertical bands; large oval yellow blotches between lateral line and midbody; pectoral base dotted black; marginal yellow on spinous anal
Geographical distribution: Cochin, Quilon, Gulf of Mannar, Palk Bay

Species name: Aurigequula longispina Valenciennes, 1835
Body: Dorsal 8 spines, 16 rays; anal 3 spines, 14 rays; pectoral 17; pelvic 1,5; caudal 15; LL 61; body oval, compressed, deep; strongly arched dorsal profile; gentle cranial concavity; snout blunt; body depth 56.98% SL; head 30.23% SL; snout 30.77% HL; eye 34.62% HL
Fins: Second dorsal and second anal spines greatly elongated; second dorsal spine reaching dorsal ray 6; ventral spine reaching dorsal ray 5; caudal lobes dusky; soft anal and soft dorsal margins yellow; pectoral 22.09% SL
Scales: Lateral line strongly convex, extending past soft dorsal and anal bases, ending short of caudal base
Spines: Pair of supraorbital spines above anterior orbit; preopercular margin distinctly finely serrated
Mouth: Small downward-pointing gape; cleft above lower eye edge; villiform teeth in both jaws; mandibles slightly concave
Colour: Silvery abdomen; back with faint, elongated grey-brown streaks; variable yellow flank blotches below lateral line; pectoral base dotted black; snout tip grey; caudal margins dusky
Geographical distribution: Palk Bay, Kakinada, Cochin (first record)

Species name: Secutor insidiator Bloch, 1787
Body: Dorsal 8 spines, 16 rays; anal 3 spines, 14 rays; pectoral 13–15; pelvic 1,5; caudal 15; body oval, deep, elongate, compressed; dorsal profile less convex, occipital concavity strong; snout pointed; body depth 41.67–50.72% SL; head 26.23–28.57% SL; snout 20.00–28.57% HL; eye 29.41–40.00% HL
Fins: Caudal deeply forked; ventrals with axillary scales, reaching halfway to anal origin; dorsal membranes II–VI black apically; caudal yellowish with dusky margins; pectoral 19.44–23.08% SL
Scales: Lateral line slightly concave anteriorly, weakly convex posteriorly, extending near caudal base
Spines: Single spine above eye; preopercular margin finely serrated (implied from genus)
Mouth: Small, oblique; tubular when protruded upward; lips broad, thin; villiform teeth; mandible nearly vertical when closed, slightly concave inferiorly
Colour: Silvery; back with ~10 black vertical band patches; abdomen with black spots; black curved stripe from eye to lower jaw angle; pectoral base dotted black; dorsal membranes II–VI black on upper third; caudal yellowish with dusky edges
Geographical distribution: Mangalore, Cochin, Quilon, Mandapam, Madras, Visakhapatnam, Kakinada

Species name: Secutor ruconius Hamilton-Buchanan, 1822
Body: Dorsal 8 spines, 16 rays; anal 3 spines, 14 rays; pectoral 12–14; pelvic 1,5; caudal 15; body oval, strongly compressed, deep; ventral profile strongly convex; cranial profile concave; body depth 56.41–62.75% SL; head 26.42–30.77% SL; snout 18.18–28.57% HL; eye 30.00–42.86% HL
Fins: Caudal deeply incised, pointed lobes; ventrals with axillary scales, not reaching halfway to anal origin; dorsal membranes II–V black in upper third; pectoral 20.93–25.00% SL
Scales: Lateral line convex anteriorly, weakening mid–soft dorsal, less convex posteriorly
Spines: Single supraorbital spine; preopercular margin finely serrated
Mouth: Small, oblique; tubular upward when protruded; lips broad, thin; lower lip smaller; villiform teeth; mandible slightly concave, nearly perpendicular to mouth slit
Colour: Silvery; ~10 black/gray vertical bands to slightly below lateral line; curved black stripe from eye to lower jaw angle; abdomen dotted black; pectoral axil black; dorsal membranes II–V black apically
Geographical distribution: Goa, Cochin, Quilon, Gulf of Mannar, Palk Bay, Chilka Lake, Porto Novo, Godavari estuary; abundant at Visakhapatnam, Kakinada

Species name: Gazza minuta Bloch, 1797
Body: Dorsal 8 spines, 15–16 rays; anal 3 spines, 13–14 rays; pectoral 13–14; pelvic 1,5; caudal 15; LL 57–59; body oval, compressed, moderately deep; dorsal/ventral profiles equally convex; snout pointed; body depth 38.71–45.05% SL; head 30.30–34.07% SL; snout 23.81–29.17% HL; eye 33.33–40% HL
Fins: Caudal deeply forked; ventrals with axillary scales, not reaching anal origin; spinous dorsal membrane black-edged; anal fin front yellowish; pectoral 15.79–19.48% SL
Scales: Lateral line convex, parallel to dorsal profile, becoming obsolete near end of soft dorsal
Spines: Two supraorbital spines; preopercular margin finely serrated
Mouth: Large; horizontal tube when protruded; upper jaw with sharp teeth plus large curved lateral canines; lower jaw with curved pointed teeth, enlarged anteriorly, paired symphysial canines with receiving notch; mandible angled ~45°
Colour: Silvery; greyish back; upper body with irregular grey marks, wavy lines or blotches; ~7 grey blotches along lateral line; snout margin dotted black; pectoral base dotted black; ventral half with fine black dots; anal front yellowish; caudal edges dusky; dorsal base black line
Geographical distribution: Cochin, Cape Comorin, Quilon, Tuticorin, Pamban, Mandapam, Madras, Porto Novo, Visakhapatnam, Kakinada; abundant at Tuticorin, Pamban, Mandapam

Species name: Gazza achlamys Jordan & Starks, 1917
Body: Dorsal 8 spines, 16 rays; anal 3 spines, 14 rays; pectoral 13; pelvic 1,5; caudal 15; LL 59–61; body oval, compressed, deep; slight cranial concavity; snout pointed; body depth 46.59–49.37% SL; head 31.82–34.18% SL; snout 24.00–28.57% HL; eye 35.71–39.29% HL
Fins: Caudal deeply forked; ventral with axillary scales, not reaching anal origin; spinous dorsal membrane black distally; soft dorsal edge grey; pectoral 18.18–19.77% SL
Scales: Lateral line convex, parallel to dorsal profile, extending to caudal base
Spines: Two supraorbital spines; preopercular margin finely serrated
Mouth: Large; horizontal tube when protruded; oblique gape opposite mid-eye; villiform teeth with paired symphysial canines upper/lower jaws; lower jaw teeth enlarging anteriorly; mandible angled 50–60°
Colour: Silvery; greyish back with irregular dark marks/circles; snout tip grey-dotted; pectoral base dotted black; gill-opening edge dark; ventral half with minute black dots; caudal posterior margin dusky
Geographical distribution: Great Nicobar Island, southern India; stray occurrences off Cochin
